column1: e7c9f16fa12e6ba02c25f4f881791448d3e6ae860f982c12c8f9a95ac20a0bf5;posted_link;r/science;https://www.uni-goettingen.de/en/3240.html?id=6192;['m1gyyi'];['mvea'];[1615325677.0];['Breaking the warp barrier for faster-than-light travel: Astrophysicist discovers new theoretical hyper-fast soliton solutions
column2: as reported in the journal Classical and Quantum Gravity. This reignites debate about the possibility of faster-than-light travel based on conventional physics.'];[nan];2022-08-04;Georg-August-Universität Göttingen;Press release: Breaking the warp barrier for faster-than-light travel;"Press release: Breaking the warp barrier for faster-than-light travel

column1: Astrophysicist at Göttingen University discovers new theoretical hyper-fast soliton solutions
If travel to distant stars within an individual’s lifetime is going to be possible
column2: a means of faster-than-light propulsion will have to be found. To date
column3: even recent research about superluminal (faster-than-light) transport based on Einstein’s theory of general relativity would require vast amounts of hypothetical particles and states of matter that have “exotic” physical properties such as negative energy density. This type of matter either cannot currently be found or cannot be manufactured in viable quantities. In contrast
column4: new research carried out at the University of Göttingen gets around this problem by constructing a new class of hyper-fast ‘solitons’ using sources with only positive energies that can enable travel at any speed. This reignites debate about the possibility of faster-than-light travel based on conventional physics. The research is published in the journal Classical and Quantum Gravity.

column1: The author of the paper
column2: Dr Erik Lentz
column3: analysed existing research and discovered gaps in previous ‘warp drive’ studies. Lentz noticed that there existed yet-to-be explored configurations of space-time curvature organized into ‘solitons’ that have the potential to solve the puzzle while being physically viable. A soliton – in this context also informally referred to as a 'warp bubble’ – is a compact wave that maintains its shape and moves at constant velocity. Lentz derived the Einstein equations for unexplored soliton configurations (where the space-time metric’s shift vector components obey a hyperbolic relation)
column4: finding that the altered space-time geometries could be formed in a way that worked even with conventional energy sources. In essence
column5: the new method uses the very structure of space and time arranged in a soliton to provide a solution to faster-than-light travel
column6: which – unlike other research – would only need sources with positive energy densities. No “exotic” negative energy densities needed.

column1: If sufficient energy could be generated
column2: the equations used in this research would allow space travel to Proxima Centauri
column3: our nearest star
column4: and back to Earth in years instead of decades or millennia. That means an individual could travel there and back within their lifetime. In comparison
column5: the current rocket technology would take more than 50
column6: 000 years for a one-way journey. In addition
column7: the solitons (warp bubbles) were configured to contain a region with minimal tidal forces such that the passing of time inside the soliton matches the time outside: an ideal environment for a spacecraft. This means there would not be the complications of the so-called “twin paradox” whereby one twin travelling near the speed of light would age much more slowly than the other twin who stayed on Earth: in fact
column8: according to the recent equations both twins would be the same age when reunited.

column1: “This work has moved the problem of faster-than-light travel one step away from theoretical research in fundamental physics and closer to engineering. The next step is to figure out how to bring down the astronomical amount of energy needed to within the range of today's technologies
column2: such as a large modern nuclear fission power plant. Then we can talk about building the first prototypes
column3: says Lentz.

column1: Currently
column2: the amount of energy required for this new type of space propulsion drive is still immense. Lentz explains
column3: “The energy required for this drive travelling at light speed encompassing a spacecraft of 100 meters in radius is on the order of hundreds of times of the mass of the planet Jupiter. The energy savings would need to be drastic
column4: of approximately 30 orders of magnitude to be in range of modern nuclear fission reactors.” He goes on to say: “Fortunately
column5: several energy-saving mechanisms have been proposed in earlier research that can potentially lower the energy required by nearly 60 orders of magnitude.” Lentz is currently in the early-stages of determining if these methods can be modified
column6: or if new mechanisms are needed to bring the energy required down to what is currently possible.";4213;['gqeddex'

column1: 02dcb8cb079fe6bf93b3855762205be5be8f5b48d9f3cd25ad5c30a4c369799b;posted_link;r/Futurology;http://venturebeat.com/2015/12/08/google-says-its-quantum-computer-is-more-than-100-million-times-faster-than-a-regular-computer-chip/;['3w0irg'];['unknownfunctionfx'];[1449625445.0];['Google says its quantum computer is more than 100 million times faster than a regular computer chip | VentureBeat | Business | by Jordan Novet'];[nan];2015-12-08;Jordan Novet;Google says its quantum computer is more than 100 million times faster than a regular computer chip;"Google appears to be more confident about the technical capabilities of its D-Wave 2X quantum computer
column2: which it operates alongside NASA at the U.S. space agency’s Ames Research Center in Mountain View
column3: California.

column1: D-Wave’s machines are the closest thing we have today to quantum computing
column2: which works with quantum bits
column3: or qubits — each of which can be zero or one or both — instead of more conventional bits. The superposition of these qubits enable machines to make great numbers of computations simultaneously
column4: making a quantum computer highly desirable for certain types of processes.

column1: In two tests
column2: the Google Quantum Artificial Intelligence Lab today announced that it has found the D-Wave machine to be considerably faster than simulated annealing — a simulation of quantum computation on a classical computer chip.

column1: Google director of engineering Hartmut Neven went over the results of the tests in a blog post today:
We found that for problem instances involving nearly 1
column2: 000 binary variables
column3: quantum annealing significantly outperforms its classical counterpart
column4: simulated annealing. It is more than 108 times faster than simulated annealing running on a single core. We also compared the quantum hardware to another algorithm called Quantum Monte Carlo. This is a method designed to emulate the behavior of quantum systems
column5: but it runs on conventional processors. While the scaling with size between these two methods is comparable
column6: they are again separated by a large factor sometimes as high as 108.

column1: Google has also published a paper on the findings.
If nothing else
column2: this is a positive signal for venture-backed D-Wave
column3: which has also sold quantum computers to Lockheed Martin and Los Alamos National Laboratory. At an event at NASA Ames today where reporters looked at the D-Wave machine
column4: chief executive Vern Brownell sounded awfully pleased at the discovery. Without question
column5: the number 100
column7: 000 is impressive. It’s certainly the kind of thing the startup can show when it attempts to woo IT buyers and show why its technology might well succeed in disrupting legacy chipmakers such as Intel.

column1: But Google continues to work with NASA on quantum computing
column2: and meanwhile Google also has its own quantum computing hardware lab. And in that initiative
column3: Google is still in the early days.

column1: “I would say building a quantum computer is really
column2: really hard
column3: so first of all
column4: we’re just trying to get it to work and not worry about cost or size or whatever
column5: ” said John Martinis
column6: the person leading up Google’s hardware program and a professor of physics at the University of California

column1: Commercial applications of this technology might not happen overnight
column2: but it’s possible that eventually they could lead to speed-ups for things like image recognition
column3: which is in place inside of many Google services. But the tool could also come in handy for a traditional thing like cleaning up dirty data. Outside of Google
column4: quantum speed-ups could translate into improvements for planning and scheduling and air traffic management
column5: said David Bell
column6: director of the Universities Space Research Association’s Research Institute for Advanced Computer Science
column7: which also works on the D-Wave machine at NASA Ames.";3227;['cxsj14d'

column1: fe1b04f530fe136dcd9b1eeae8d90729f270660a59b448eccdf22fb650efdd2e;posted_link;r/science;http://phys.org/news/2015-10-zeno-effect-verifiedatoms-wont.html;['3pw7xy'];['drewiepoodle'];[1445599886.0];"[""One of the oddest predictions of quantum theory
column2: that a system can't change while you're watching it
column3: has been confirmed in an experiment by physicists. Their work opens the door to a fundamentally new method to control and manipulate the quantum states of atoms and could lead to new kinds of sensors""]";[nan];2015-10-23;Bill Steele;'Zeno effect' verified—atoms won't move while you watch;"Zeno effect' verified—atoms won't move while you watch

column1: One of the oddest predictions of quantum theory – that a system can't change while you're watching it – has been confirmed in an experiment by Cornell physicists. Their work opens the door to a fundamentally new method to control and manipulate the quantum states of atoms and could lead to new kinds of sensors.
The experiments were performed in the Utracold Lab of Mukund Vengalattore
column2: assistant professor of physics
column3: who has established Cornell's first program to study the physics of materials cooled to temperatures as low as .000000001 degree above absolute zero. The work is described in the Oct. 2 issue of the journal Physical Review Letters

column1: Graduate students Yogesh Patil and Srivatsan K. Chakram created and cooled a gas of about a billion Rubidium atoms inside a vacuum chamber and suspended the mass between laser beams. In that state the atoms arrange in an orderly lattice just as they would in a crystalline solid.
column2: But at such low temperatures
column3: the atoms can ""tunnel"" from place to place in the lattice. The famous Heisenberg uncertainty principle says that the position and velocity of a particle interact. Temperature is a measure of a particle's motion. Under extreme cold velocity is almost zero
column4: so there is a lot of flexibility in position; when you observe them
column5: atoms are as likely to be in one place in the lattice as another.

column1: The researchers demonstrated that they were able to suppress quantum tunneling merely by observing the atoms. This so-called ""Quantum Zeno effect""
column2: named for a Greek philosopher
column3: derives from a proposal in 1977 by E. C. George Sudarshan and Baidyanath Misra at the University of Texas
column4: Austin
column6: who pointed out that the weird nature of quantum measurements allows
column8: for a quantum system to be ""frozen"" by repeated measurements.

column1: Previous experiments have demonstrated the Zeno Effect with the ""spins"" of subatomic particles. ""This is the first observation of the Quantum Zeno effect by real space measurement of atomic motion
column2: Vengalattore said. ""Also
column3: due to the high degree of control we've been able to demonstrate in our experiments
column4: we can gradually 'tune' the manner in which we observe these atoms. Using this tuning
column5: we've also been able to demonstrate an effect called 'emergent classicality' in this quantum system."" Quantum effects fade
column6: and atoms begin to behave as expected under classical physics.

column1: The researchers observed the atoms under a microscope by illuminating them with a separate imaging laser. A light microscope can't see individual atoms
column2: but the imaging laser causes them to fluoresce
column3: and the microscope captured the flashes of light. When the imaging laser was off
column4: or turned on only dimly
column5: the atoms tunneled freely. But as the imaging beam was made brighter and measurements made more frequently
column6: the tunneling reduced dramatically.

column1: This gives us an unprecedented tool to control a quantum system
column2: perhaps even atom by atom
column3: said Patil
column4: lead author of the paper. Atoms in this state are extremely sensitive to outside forces
column5: l he noted
column6: so this work could lead to the development of new kinds of sensors.

column1: The experiments were made possible by the group's invention of a novel imaging technique that made it possible to observe ultracold atoms while leaving them in the same quantum state. ""It took a lot of dedication from these students and it has been amazing to see these experiments be so successful
column2: Vengalattore said. ""We now have the unique ability to control quantum dynamics purely by observation.""

column1: The popular press has drawn a parallel of this work with the ""weeping angels"" depicted in the Dr. Who television series – alien creatures who look like statues and can't move as long as you're looking at them. There may be some sense to that. In the quantum world
column2: the folk wisdom really is true: ""A watched pot never boils.""";3887;['cwa196w'

column1: 95e8e700a8fe4128692b8d92ecacd583e7007015a7fd566c309b847098d652ca;posted_link;r/science;http://www.zmescience.com/research/ibm-quantum-computer-28022012/;['q9k5f'];['mareacaspica'];[1330426747.0];['IBM announces breakthrough in quantum computing
column2: promising scalability '];[nan];2012-02-28;Mihai Andrei;IBM makes significant breakthrough towards scalable quantum computers;"During the past months we’ve been reporting several breakthroughs in the field of quantum computing
column3: and now IBM seems ready to truly pave the way for quantum computers. Researchers announced they are now able to develop a superconducting qubit made from microfabricated silicon that maintains coherence long enough for practical computation. Whoa! That probably sounds like a lot to swallow
column4: so let’s break it down.

column1: Bits and Qubits
Information is measured in ‘bits’
column2: and a bit may have two positions (described typically as 0 or 1). Quantum computers however don’t use these bits
column3: and instead they use quantum bits
column4: or ‘qubits’. But while a bit must be a 0 or a 1
column5: a qubit can be both 0
column7: or a superposition of both. This difference might seem small and subtle
column9: it is absolutely humongous: a mere hundred qubits can store more classical ‘bit’ information than there are atoms in the Universe.

column1: Needless to say a computer running on qubits would be game changing
column2: in pretty much the same way microprocessors were in their days. But what makes quantum computing extremely difficult is a problem called ‘decoherence‘. In the quantum world
column3: things don’t happen as they do in the ‘real world’; when a qubit will move from the 0 state to the 1 state or to a superposition
column4: it will decohere to state 0 due to interference from other parts of the computer. Generally speaking
column5: decoherence is the loss order of the phase angles between the components. So in order for quantum computers to be practical and scalable
column6: the system would have to remain coherent for a long enough time to allow error-correction techniques to function properly.

column2: coherence times were about 1 nanosecond
column3: ” said IBM scientist Matthias Steffen. “Last year
column4: coherence times were achieved for as long as 1 to 4 microseconds. With these new techniques
column5: we’ve achieved coherence times of 10 to 100 microseconds. We need to improve that by a factor of 10 to 100 before we’re at the threshold we want to be. But considering that in the past ten years we’ve increased coherence times by a factor of 10

column1: Two different approaches
column2: one breakthrough

column1: IBM announced they took two different approaches
column2: both of which played a significant part in the breakthrough they revealed. The first one was to build a 3-D qubit made from superconducting
column3: microfabricated silicon. The main advantage here is that the equipment and know-how necessary to create this technology already exists
column4: nothing new has to be invented
column5: thanks to developments made by Yale researchers (for which Steffen expressed a deep admiration). Using this approach
column6: they managed to maintain coherence for 95 microseconds – “But you could round that to 100 for the piece if you want

column1: The second idea involved a traditional 2-D qubit
column2: which IBM’s scientists used to build a “Controlled NOT gate” or CNOT gate
column3: which is a building block of quantum computing. A CNOT gate connects two qubits in such a way that the second qubit will change state if the first qubit changes its state to 1. The CNOT gate was able to produce a coherence of 10 microseconds
column4: which is long enough to show a 95% accuracy rate – a notable improvement from the 81% accuracy rate
column5: the highest achieved until now. Of course
column6: the technology is still years away from being actually on the shelves
column7: but the developments are very impressive.

column1: From quantum to reality
Given the rapid progress that is being made in the field of quantum computing
column2: one can only feel that a quantum computer is looking more and more like a real possibility. As error correction protocols become more accurate and coherence times grow longer
column3: we are moving more and more towards accurate quantum computing – but you shouldn’t expect a quantum smartphone just yet.

column1: “There’s a growing sense that a quantum computer can’t be a laptop or desktop
column2: ” said Steffen. “Quantum computers may well just being housed in a large building somewhere. It’s not going to be something that’s very portable. In terms of application
column3: I don’t think that’s a huge detriment because they’ll be able to solve problems so much faster than traditional computers.”

column1: The next steps are simple
column2: in principle
column3: but extremely hard to do in practice. The accuracy rate has to be at at least 99.99%
column4: up to the point where it achieves what is called a ‘logical qubit’ – one that
column5: for practical purposes
column6: doesn’t suffer decoherence. From that point
column7: the only thing left to do is develop the quantum computer architecture
column8: and this will prove troublesome too – but the reward is definitely worth it.

column1: “We are very excited about how the quantum computing field has progressed over the past ten years
column2: ” he told me. “Our team has grown significantly over past 3 years
column3: and I look forward to seeing that team continue to grow and take quantum computing to the next level.”";4848;['c3vtkf4'

column1: aecbf075ee140d43c79ae518e6688437bc0d6a77943694db030c2c59de817ad7;posted_link;r/science;https://newatlas.com/telecommunications/quantum-entanglement-atoms-distance-record/;['vu7s81'];['jdse2222'];[1657276864.0];['Record-setting quantum entanglement connects two atoms across 20 miles'];[nan];2022-07-08;Michael Irving;Record-setting quantum entanglement connects two atoms across 20 miles;"Record-setting quantum entanglement connects two atoms across 20 miles

Researchers in Germany have demonstrated quantum entanglement of two atoms separated by 33 km (20.5 miles) of fiber optics. This is a record distance for this kind of communication and marks a breakthrough towards a fast and secure quantum internet.
Quantum entanglement is the uncanny phenomenon where two particles can become so inextricably linked that examining one can tell you about the state of the other. Stranger still
column2: changing something about one particle will instantly alter its partner
column3: no matter how far apart they are. That leads to the unsettling implication that information is being “teleported” faster than the speed of light
column4: an idea that was too much for even Einstein
column5: who famously described it as “spooky action at a distance.”

column1: Despite its apparent impossibility
column2: quantum entanglement has been consistently demonstrated in experiments for decades
column3: with scientists taking advantage of its bizarre nature to quickly transmit data over long distances. And in the new study
column4: researchers from Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich (LMU) and Saarland University have now broken a distance record for quantum entanglement between two atoms over fiber optics.

column1: In their experiments
column2: the team entangled two rubidium atoms kept in optical traps in two different buildings on the LMU campus. They were separated by 700 m (2
column3: 297 ft) of fiber optics
column4: which was extended out to 33 km with extra spools of cable. Each atom was excited with a laser pulse
column5: which causes it to emit a photon that’s quantum entangled with the atom.

column1: The photons are then sent down the fiber optic cables to meet at a receiving station in the middle. There
column2: the photons undergo a joint measurement
column3: which entangles them – and because they’re each already entangled with their own atom
column4: the two atoms become entangled with each other as well.

column1: While photons have been entangled over great distances before
column2: this study marks a new distance record for entangling two atoms
column3: which could function as “quantum memory” nodes
column4: over fiber optics. The key is that the mediating photons were converted into a longer wavelength so that they travel further through the fibers – their natural wavelength of 780 nanometers (nm) means they’d normally be lost after a few kilometers
column5: so before their journey started the team ran them through a device to convert them to a wavelength of 1
column6: 517 nm. This is close to the 1
column7: 550-nm wavelength commonly used for telecoms in fiber optics

column1: The team says this is an important step on the way to realizing a practical quantum internet. Such communications networks would be much faster and more secure than those in use today and
column2: importantly
column3: this study shows that they can operate using existing fiber optic infrastructure. This could be paired with technologies like satellites
column4: which have previously demonstrated the ability to beam entangled photons over thousands of kilometers.";2982;['ifc334g'
column5: 'ifcbn7j'
column6: 'ifcd77y'

column1: fe3a81093124b4ef278b549b73c19c1445612870b1b41e85983cd8d9d6c4e6f1;posted_link;r/programming;https://www.techradar.com/in/news/ibm-says-it-will-have-thousands-of-quantum-computers-for-sale-by-2025;['uqrlu7'];['IsDaouda_Games'];[1652692050.0];['IBM says it will have thousands of quantum computers for sale by 2025'];[nan];2022-05-11;Sead Fadilpaši?;IBM says it will have thousands of quantum computers for sale by 2025;"IBM CEO Arvind Krishna has said the company will have thousands of quantum computers (opens in new tab) up for sale within the next three years.
Speaking to Reuters ahead of its Think conference
column2: Krishna said that the devices that should go up for sale in 2025 will have more than 4
column3: 000 qubits of computing power. To put things in perspective
column4: today’s machines have some 127 qubits.

column1: Further explaining what such a device would be capable of doing
column2: Krishna said it would be able to optimize routing truck fleets
column3: or improve financial risk modeling. To tackle these challenges with traditional computer hardware
column4: he says
column5: would require a machine “the size of this planet”.

column1: Treading carefully
Krishna also touched on the topic of over-hyping the company’s Watson AI which
column2: as it turns out
column3: delivered results in healthcare and other industries
column4: a bit slower than what was expected.

column1: Building quantum computers is a more difficult task that developing Artificial Intelligence (AI)
column2: he added. ""We might have hyped some things
column3: Krishna said. ""This time
column4: we try to tread the line carefully.""

column1: In late January 2022
column2: IBM published a research paper
column3: arguing just how difficult it was to build quantum computing devices. The paper proposes a method for increasing the applications available for quantum power.

column2: but the limited capabilities of today’s quantum processors permit only small
column3: and often approximate
column4: simulations
column5: IBM said in the paper.

column1: The solution
column2: the company says
column3: is to combine classical and quantum computing power
column4: a process called ""entanglement forging"". If successful
column5: the system can double the size of the available quantum computations.

column1: Quantum is a nascent technology
column2: albeit one with great potential. In layman’s terms
column3: quantum computing moves beyond binary processing (where everything is either a one or zero) and can allow for states in between those two poles

column1: 03757a5a3fa20fadf5a935d1415cf4f413258347a8d62d7fc3a9467ac48786a0;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.sciencealert.com/aliens-could-be-using-quantum-communications-to-talk-across-interstellar-space;['vumwlv'];['Flimsy-Union1524'];[1657320011.0];['Aliens Could Be Using Quantum Communications to Talk Across Interstellar Space'];[nan];2022-07-07;David Nield;Aliens Could Be Using Quantum Communications to Talk Across Interstellar Space;"While we haven't found any evidence of alien life yet
column2: that doesn't mean it's not out there
column3: beyond our reach. Now
column4: a team of researchers has put together a mathematical model showing aliens could potentially be communicating across space – via quantum physics.

column1: Efforts are well underway to make quantum communications a reality here on Earth. The idea is that quantum mechanics provide certain properties that would make information transfer inherently faster and more secure than regular systems… if we can get it to work.
One of the major hurdles to overcome before quantum networks can be established is that they're very fragile and susceptible to interference. According to this latest study
column2: such networks could fly across space without breaking up.

column1: Quantum states you generally think of as very delicate
column2: and if there's any kind of external interaction
column3: you kind of destroy that state
column4: lead author of the research
column5: theoretical physicist Arjun Berera from the University of Edinburgh in the UK
column6: told Science News.

column1: Berera and his colleague Jaime Calderón-Figueroa
column2: a fellow theoretical physicist at the University of Edinburgh
column3: ran calculations on the movement of X-rays across the emptiness of space to check for potential decoherence (the breaking up of the quantum state).

column1: If photons – particles of light – were used as the quantum particles
column2: the researchers determined
column3: they could be beamed across hundreds of thousands of light-years at least
column4: a greater stretch of distance than the entire Milky Way galaxy.

column1: That's partly because the average density of matter in space is much less than it is on Earth
column2: and this 'cleaner' environment means less chance of interference. Even gravitational pulls wouldn't be enough to knock a quantum communication network off course.

column1: It is plausible that quantum communication mediated by photons could be established across interstellar distances
column2: in particular for photons in the X-ray region below the electron mass
column3: write the researchers in their published paper.

column1: That alien life forms might be using quantum networks to speak to each other or to try and get in touch with us is
column2: of course
column3: pure speculation – but at the same time it gives astronomers another potential sign of life they can monitor for.

column1: The ""considerable information transfer"" possible with a quantum signal would make it attractive to any extraterrestrial intelligence out there in the cosmos
column2: the researchers say
column3: though it may require a fully functioning quantum computer in order to decode it.

column1: And even quantum communication isn't magic: Information still can't travel faster than the speed of light
column2: so transmissions may take several years to reach their destinations.

column1: Based on these findings
column2: we can now add quantum communication as well as classical communication to the possible ways aliens might be chatting with each other – or perhaps might be trying to make themselves known to us.

column1: In principle
column2: it should be possible to detect a quantum signal coming from an astrophysical body or even an intelligent signal from an extraterrestrial civilization
column3: write the researchers.";3103;['ifemei4'

column1: 59b4ae6bcd3d51039b4433e1529d7028fbccf1e8b5521346127a7456b73d2709;posted_link;r/science;https://www.nbcnews.com/news/all/quantum-interaction-10-000-times-faster-light-flna1c8889471;['1bavah'];['Boris740'];[1364651748.0];['Quantum interaction: 10
column2: 000 times faster than light'];[nan];2023-02-17;Jesse Emspak;Quantum interaction: 10
column3: 000 times faster than light;"How fast do quantum interactions happen? Faster than light
column5: 000 times faster.

column1: That's what a team of physicists led by Juan Yin at the University of Science and Technology of China in Shanghai found in an experiment involving entangled photons
column2: or photons that remain intimately connected
column3: even when separated by vast distances.They wanted to see what would happen if you tried assigning a speed to what Einstein called ""spooky action at a distance.""

column1: They didn't find anything unexpected
column2: but that wasn't the point: in physics
column3: sometimes it's good to be sure. The group published their work on the ArXiv.org
column4: a preprint server for physics papers.

column1: All tangled up
Quantum physicists have long known that after two particles — photons
column2: for example — interact
column3: they sometimes become ""entangled."" This kind of experiment has been repeated many times
column4: and involves taking two entangled photons and sending them to different places. Perhaps photon A goes to Los Angeles and photon B goes to Boston.

column1: When photon A is observed
column2: it has a certain polarization
column3: perhaps ""up."" The other photon in Boston is always in the opposite polarization
column4: ""down."" No matter what measurement is made of photon A
column5: photon B will always be opposite. It is impossible to tell what the polarization will be before you measure it
column6: but the entangled photons always seem to ""know"" the right state to be in

column1: As Chad Orzel
column2: assistant professor of physics at Union College
column3: explained
column4: ""It's as though you sent two cards to two different addresses. One might be the jack of diamonds and the other the ace of hearts. When you get the card at one address you know which one went to the other. Quantum mechanics is weird because until you open the envelope
column5: saying which card it is doesn't have any meaning; it could be either one.""

column1: Speed of quantum interaction

This is what Albert Einstein called ""spooky action at a distance."" And the correlation between the photons' states seems to happen instantaneously. But what does ""instantaneous"" really mean? That's part of what the Chinese team wanted to look at.
So the researchers entangled two photons and sent them to two different stations about 10 miles (16 kilometers) apart. In their ArXiv paper
column2: the scientists said that previous experiments had ""locality loopholes
column3: which is another way of saying that it's possible to explain the link between photons with something other than the ""action at a distance.""

column1: The group measured the state of one photon and timed how long the entangled state took to show up in the other. They found that the slowest possible speed for quantum interactions is 10
column2: 000 times the speed of light — assuming your experiment is moving relatively slowly
column3: at least relative to light beams.

column1: Whereas the result may sound like a way to send faster-than-light messages
column2: it isn't
column3: really
column4: because you can't know the state of the entangled photon pair before it's measured; so there's no way to control it and make the photon at the other end take on certain states and use it like a Morse code telegraph. [10 Implications of Faster-Than-Light Travel]

column1: This type of experiment has been done before
column2: notably by a European team
column3: in 2008. So why do it again? Many physics experiments are performed to check more closely the values of constants used in equations
column4: for instance
column5: which enable more precise measurements in other areas.

column1: Orzel said that even if it turned out that there was some small amount of time it takes for the state of a photon to change (meaning it's not instantaneous)
column2: it isn't clear that lag would mean much for quantum physics generally. That's because there are several interpretations for why quantum phenomena happen the way they do
column3: and all explain the experimental results equally well. Physicists aren't even certain that there's an experiment one could do to tell the difference.

column1: He added that it is extremely unlikely that anyone will ever get an ""exact"" value for the speed of such quantum interactions
column2: and
column3: in fact
column4: modern physics prohibits that kind of finding in principle. But it is useful to see what the limits are — to clarify what we mean when we say ""instantaneous.""

column1: There's a certain strain of physics that people that will say it has to be instantaneous – in fact
column2: if it is faster than light it mustbe instantaneous
column3: Orzel said. ""So if you can put a limit on it that is kind of cool.""";4433;['c9577bm'
column5: 'c957asb'

column1: 91fedf335be37f1bacc5d0e395f1169bb3d3180d61748375aae332bada4960ec;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.technologyreview.com/s/604242/googles-new-chip-is-a-stepping-stone-to-quantum-computing-supremacy/;['66urr6'];['Dislated'];[1492845683.0];['Google says it is on track to definitively prove it has a quantum computer in a few months’ time'];[nan];2017-04-21;Tom Simonite;Google’s New Chip Is a Stepping Stone to Quantum Computing Supremacy;"John Martinis has given himself just a few months to reach a milestone in the history of computing.
He’s leader of the Google research group working on building astonishingly powerful computer chips that manipulate data using the quirks of quantum physics. By the end of this year
column2: Martinis says
column3: his team will build a device that achieves “quantum supremacy
column4: ” meaning it can perform a particular calculation that’s beyond the reach of any conventional computer. Proof will come from a kind of drag race between Google’s chip and one of the world’s largest supercomputers.

column1: “We think we’re ready to do this experiment. It’s something we can do now
column2: ” says Martinis.

column1: One reason for his confidence is that Google’s roughly 25-strong group has made a new quantum chip that tests out key design features needed to make a device for that head-to-head contest.
Quantum chips represent digital bits of data using qubits
column2: devices that can shortcut through some tough calculations by exploiting the counterintuitive physics of quantum mechanics. Researchers have so far demonstrated quantum computing with only small groups of qubits
column3: though. Google has released results from a chip that has nine qubits arranged in a line
column4: but Martinis says he’ll need a grid of 49 qubits for his quantum supremacy experiment.

column1: Google’s latest chip has only six qubits
column2: but they are arranged in a two-by-three configuration that Martinis says shows the company’s technology still works when qubits are nestled side by side
column3: as they will be in larger devices.

column1: The six-qubit chip is also a test of a manufacturing method in which the qubits and the conventional wiring that controls them are made on separate chips later “bump bonded” together. That approach
column2: a major focus of Google’s team since it was established just over two years ago
column3: is intended to eliminate the extra control lines needed in a larger chip
column4: which can interfere with how qubits function.

column1: “That process is all working
column2: ” says Martinis. “Now we’re ready to kind of move fast.” Designs for devices with 30 to 50 qubits are already in progress
column3: he says. He briefly flashed up images of the six-qubit chip at the recent IEEE TechIgnite conference in Burlingame
column4: California
column5: but his group has yet to formally disclose technical details.

column1: Martinis joined Google in late 2014 from the University of California
column2: Santa Barbara
column3: where he remains a professor today (see “Google Launches Effort to Build Its Own Quantum Computer”). His team is one of several industrial research groups recently formed or expanded thanks to growing signs that the technology behind quantum computing is becoming more tractable. The race to develop quantum processors includes Intel
column4: Microsoft
column5: IBM
column6: and even startups (see “10 Breakthrough Technologies 2017: Practical Quantum Computers”).

column1: Simon Gustavsson
column2: a principal investigator in a quantum computing research group at MIT
column3: says that Google is one of the leaders. “It’s pretty comparable between Google and IBM
column4: ” he says.

column1: Pulling off its quantum supremacy experiment this year would underline the search company’s competitiveness
column2: although quantum processors would need to be much larger than 50 qubits to be capable of useful work.

column1: “It’ll be an academic milestone
column2: ” says Chris Monroe
column3: a professor at the University of Maryland and cofounder of the quantum computing startup IonQ. “Afterward you still have to figure out how to make it more scalable and programmable.”

column1: Martinis agrees that much will remain to be done
column2: but he argues that the experiment could become a benchmark for anyone claiming to have a working quantum computer.

column1: He also says the target has helped managers at Google
column2: and the company’s cofounder Sergey Brin
column3: appreciate that the technology is becoming real. “They all get it and are very excited about it
column4: ” says Martinis. “We’re trying to get support within Google
column5: and this experiment has been very good to get other engineers talking to us.”

column1: Computing
How Rust went from a side project to the world’s most-loved programming language
For decades

column1: 901967680a3b4787b39a6beb15dea997d6f637d168f631e60f680399085b267b;posted_link;r/technology;http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2012/04/26/3489504.htm;['stjso'];['davidreiss666'];[1335448632.0];['Researchers claim quantum breakthrough:  Researchers say they have designed a tiny crystal that acts like a quantum computer so powerful it would take a computer the size of the known universe to match it.'];[nan];2012-04-26;ABC;Researchers claim quantum breakthrough;"Giant leap Researchers say they have designed a tiny crystal that acts like a quantum computer so powerful it would take a computer the size of the known universe to match it.
Details of the crystal
column2: which is made up of just 300 atoms
column3: are published today in the journal Nature.

column1: Quantum computing is a kind of information science that is based on the notion that if one performs computations in a fundamentally different way than the way your classical desktop computer works
column2: says study co-author University of Sydney's Dr Michael Biercuk.

column1: There's a huge potential to solve a variety of problems that are very
column2: very hard or near impossible for standard computer.""

column1: The crystal simulator uses a property of quantum mechanics called superposition
column2: where a quantum particle appears to be in two distinct states at the same time. This means the particle
column3: known as a qubit
column4: can be used to solve two equations simultaneously.

column1: As the number of qubits increase
column2: the number or states increases exponentially. For example
column3: 2 qubits can simultaneously be in 4 states
column4: 3 qubits in 8 states: 2 to the power of n states for n qubits.

column1: Outstrips classical computers
According to Biercuk
column2: the computing power of the 300-atom crystal simulator far outstrips the capacity of today's classical computer.

column1: It turns out that that computer would need to be the size of the known universe - which is clearly something that's not possible to achieve
column2: he says.

column1: Experts believe quantum computing is moving to a stage where it is so far out in front and performing such complex tasks it will be difficult to check if it is working accurately.
They're not easily checked by a classical computer which opens a whole variety of problems
column2: says Biercuk.

column1: And he adds that there is still plenty of work to be done before quantum computers start appearing on desks in homes and offices.
The central element is something like a millimetre in diameter
column2: 300 atoms that are suspended in space
column3: says Biercuk.

column1: But of course everything depends on a huge amount of technical infrastructure around it. There are vacuum chambers and pumps and lasers
column2: and all of that takes up something like a room.""";2162;['c4guxrs'

column1: 195b83a2f954744904be0f5234ab1e311c8a9d35b057e0a2a744f04904702e6f;posted_link;r/technews;https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/12/un-computable-quantum-maze-computed-by-quantum-maze-computer/;['k8vzf3'];['CostelloSS'];[1607396379.0];['Quantum device performs 2.6 billion years of computation in 4 minutes'];[nan];2020-12-07;Chris Lee;Quantum device performs 2.6 billion years of computation in 4 minutes;"I am a great believer in solving problems with lasers. Are you suffering from a severely polarized society and a fast-growing population living below the poverty line? Well
column2: I have the laser to solve all your problems.

column1: OK
column2: maybe not. But when it comes to quantum computing
column3: I believe that lasers are the future. I suspect that the current architectures are akin to the Colossus or the ENIAC: they are breakthroughs in their own right
column4: but they are not the future. My admittedly biased opinion is that the future is optical. A new paper provides my opinion some support
column5: demonstrating solutions to a mind-boggling 1030 problem space using a quantum optical system. Unfortunately
column6: the support is a little more limited than I'd like
column7: as it is a rather limited breakthrough.

column1: Photons flipping coins

The researchers have demonstrated something called a Gaussian boson sampling system. This is essentially a device designed to solve a single type of problem. It's based on devices called ""beam splitters
column2: so let's start with a closer look at how those work.

column1: If you shine light on a mirror that is 50 percent reflective
column2: called a beam splitter
column3: then half the light will be transmitted and half reflected. If the light intensity is low enough that only a single photon is present
column4: it is either reflected or transmitted with the same randomness as a fair coin toss. This is the idea behind a beam splitter
column5: which can take an incoming stream of photons from a laser beam and divide it into two beams traveling in different directions.

column1: A beam splitter at 45 degrees can be thought of as a four-port device (see picture). In that picture
column2: you can see that if two identical photons are incident on the same beam splitter from two different ports
column3: then the result is not entirely random. They will both exit the same port
column4: though which port they exit is random.

column1: These two simple ideas
column2: along with the idea of entanglement
column3: result in a specific type of universal quantum computer
column4: called a linear optical quantum computer. It's basically a big network of beam splitters. Photons solve a problem by the way they spread through the network
column5: which is determined based on where they exit.

column1: Entanglement comes in the form of the path taken by the photons. Until and unless we measure that path
column2: we cannot know its details
column3: so we have to consider that all photons take all possible paths. Under these circumstances
column4: if two photons arrive at a beam splitter at the same time via different ports
column5: then their paths will become linked (entangled). Build a big-enough network of beam splitters and this can happen many times
column6: creating sprawling entangled states.

column1: Flipping entangled photonic coins
The number of output states scales very quickly with the number of inputs and beam splitters. In the current demonstration
column2: the researchers used 50 inputs and—the exact type of device is not described—a chip with the equivalent of 300 beam splitters. The total number of possible output states is about 1030
column3: which is about 14 orders of magnitude greater than the next biggest demonstration of quantum computing.

column1: Photons are sent into the network (one at each input) and exit in a state that is randomly chosen from all possible states. In less than four minutes
column2: the researchers had obtained results that they estimate would take a fast classical computer about 2.5 billion years to calculate.

column1: This was followed by careful tests to check that the behavior was indeed quantum. Now
column2: of course
column3: computing the exact output for a full input is impossible. But it is possible to calculate what would happen given specific input states and compare the output states with the results of those calculation. It is also possible to calculate the output of the network if the light is not in a quantum state or if the photons are not identical. In the first case
column4: the measurement results match the predictions
column5: and in the second two cases
column6: the measurement results don’t match the predictions. This provides strong evidence for the result being due to quantum effects.

column1: Flipping useless
In many respects
column2: this is a fantastic result. I don’t think anyone can very easily argue that the researchers have not demonstrated a quantum speed-up. It is also an incredible engineering achievement. One laser provides 25 equal-intensity beams
column3: each carefully aligned to two crystals that each generate single photons. These are then carefully aligned to optical fibers
column4: the outputs of which have to be carefully coupled to the chip that houses the beam splitters. The outputs need to be carefully aligned to photodetectors. The whole setup
column5: which probably occupies an area of about 1.5m x 2.5m
column6: has to be carefully stabilized to high precision (about 10nm). No doubt there are several super-proud PhD students who did all of that painstaking work.

column1: On the other hand
column2: the work is no different to other quantum-advantage experiments: take a problem that is mostly useless but happens to map exactly to the architecture of your computer. Naturally
column3: the computer can solve it. But the point of a computer—and this is why the researchers do not refer to the device as a computer—is to solve many different useful problems. And for these cases
column4: we have not yet seen undisputed evidence of the promised quantum advantage. I have no doubt that it will come
column5: though.

column1: Light is enlightening
Even though this work is not as overwhelmingly positive as it first seems
column2: I still think optical quantum computers are the way to go.

column1: At the moment
column2: practical quantum computers come in only two flavors. The licorice-flavored variety consists of a string of ions (an atom with an electron removed) that are all lined up like a string of pearls. The ions are far enough apart that they can be separately addressed
column3: which means that information (in the form of quantum bits
column4: called qubits) can be stored and read from individual atoms. Computation operations can be performed using microwaves and by using the motion of the ions. Here
column5: each bit is highly reliable
column6: but performing complex computation is a rather difficult and stately dance of microwave pulses and laser pulses.

column1: The lemon sherbet of quantum computers are the liquid-helium-cooled superconducting rings. Each ring represents a qubit
column2: which are addressed and coupled to each other via wires. The advantage of this approach is that the hardware is relatively easy to scale—it’s basically the same skill as making printed circuit boards. But the quantum behavior of each qubit is much easier to disrupt
column3: so your board is unlikely to work. You compensate for the reliability problem by repeating the computation many times and looking for the most common answer.

column1: Neither option is particularly attractive in any context other than quantum computing as a service.
Size and temperature
Unlike both of these options
column2: an optical quantum computer could be a (large) chip-scale device that is powered by an array of laser diodes
column3: with readout done by a series of single-photon detectors. None of these require ultralow temperatures or vacuum (if photon-counting detectors are required
column4: liquid nitrogen would be required). Optical quantum computing will require temperature stability and
column5: as this paper demonstrates
column6: a rather complicated feedback system to ensure that the lasers are working exactly as required. However
column7: all of that could be contained in one large rack-mounted box. And that is
column9: the critical advantage of optical systems.

column1: This does not mean that light will win
column2: though. After all
column3: germanium is a better semiconductor than silicon
column4: but silicon still rules the roost.";7569;['gf0z9ds'
column5: 'gf0zsg9'
column6: 'gf109rm'

column1: 6e8abe0d7c2dd8a173f20417dd695b202df68e1164f4519c6ee8a343485dc82a;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.sciencealert.com/scientists-achieve-sustained-high-fidelity-quantum-teleportation-over-44-km;['kojtvm'];['izumi3682'];[1609537527.0];['Quantum Teleportation Was Just Achieved With 90% Accuracy Over a 44km Distance'];[nan];2020-12-31;David Nield;Quantum Teleportation Was Just Achieved With 90% Accuracy Over a 44km Distance;"Scientists are edging closer to making a super-secure
column2: super-fast quantum internet possible: they've now been able to 'teleport' high-fidelity quantum information over a total distance of 44 kilometres (27 miles).

column1: Both data fidelity and transfer distance are crucial when it comes to building a real
column2: working quantum internet
column3: and making progress in either of these areas is cause for celebration for those building our next-generation communications network.

column1: In this case the team achieved a greater than 90 percent fidelity (data accuracy) level with its quantum information
column2: as well as sending it across extensive fibre optic networks similar to those that form the backbone of our existing internet.

column1: We're thrilled by these results
column2: says physicist Panagiotis Spentzouris
column3: from the Fermilab particle physics and accelerator laboratory based at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech).

column1: This is a key achievement on the way to building a technology that will redefine how we conduct global communication.""
Quantum internet technology uses qubits; unmeasured particles that remain suspended in a mix of possible states like spinning dice yet to settle.

Qubits that are introduced to one another have their identities 'entangled' in ways that become obvious once they're finally measured. Imagine these entangled qubits as a pair of dice - while each can land on any number
column2: they are both guaranteed to add to seven no matter how far apart they are. Data in one location instantly reflects data in another.

column1: By clever arrangement of entangling three qubits
column2: it's possible to force the state of one particle to adopt the 'dice roll' of another via their mutually entangled partner. In quantum land
column3: this is as good as turning one particle into another
column4: teleporting its identity across a distance in a blink.

column1: The unstable
column2: delicate nature of quantum information makes it tricky to beam entangled photons over long distances without interference
column3: however. Longer optical fibres simply mean more opportunity for noise to interfere with the entangled states.

column1: In total
column2: the lengths of fibre used to channel each cubit added to 44 kilometres
column3: setting a new limit to how far we can send entangled qubits and still successfully use them to teleport quantum information.

column1: It's never before been demonstrated to work over such a long distance with such accuracy
column2: and it brings a city-sized quantum network closer to reality – even though there are still years of work ahead to make that possible.

column1: With this demonstration we're beginning to lay the foundation for the construction of a Chicago-area metropolitan quantum network
column2: says Spentzouris.

column1: Quantum entanglement and data teleportation is a complex science
column2: and not even the experts fully understand how it might ultimately be used in a quantum network. Each proof of concept like this that we get puts us a little closer to making such a network happen though.

column1: As well as promising huge boosts in speed and computational power
column2: a quantum internet would be ultra-secure – any hacking attempt would be as good as destroying the lock being picked. For now at least
column3: scientists think quantum internet networks will act as specialist extensions to the classical internet
column4: rather than a complete replacement.

column1: Researchers are tackling quantum internet problems from all different angles
column2: which is why you'll see a variety of distances mentioned in studies – they're not all measuring the same technology
column3: using the same equipment
column4: to test the same standards.

column1: What makes this study special is the accuracy and the distance of the quantum entanglement teleportation
column2: as well as the 'off the shelf' equipment used – it should theoretically be relatively easy to scale up this technology using the hardware we're already got in place.

column1: We are very proud to have achieved this milestone on sustainable
column2: high-performing and scalable quantum teleportation systems
column3: says physicist Maria Spiropulu
column4: from Caltech.

column1: The results will be further improved with system upgrades we are expecting to complete by the second quarter of 2021.""";4072;['ghrlgi7'

column1: aa06fc7c6e7cf20045c33d58c4806fa3fa37ded6cd7661c5b1ddc0e37edd108c;posted_link;r/gadgets;https://www.zdnet.com/article/google-weve-made-quantum-supremacy-breakthrough-with-54-qubit-sycamore-chip/;['dlz540'];['PrabidhiInfo'];[1571836449.0];"[""Google: We've made 'quantum supremacy' breakthrough with 54-qubit Sycamore chip""]";[nan];2019-10-23;Liam Tung;Google: We've made 'quantum supremacy' breakthrough with 54-qubit Sycamore chip;"Google researchers today published their latest work on quantum computing in Nature
column2: showing off how its new Sycamore processor can run a test computation in 200 seconds that would take the world's biggest supercomputers 10
column3: 000 years to complete.

column1: News of the paper leaked via a Nasa website last month
column2: detailing that Google had achieved so-called 'quantum supremacy'
column3: which happens when a quantum computer can solve problems that would take a classical computer too long to be considered practical.

column1: IBM this week challenged Google's claim that it had achieved quantum supremacy
column2: because the ad giant's researchers failed to account for ""plentiful disk storage"" and other assets on a classical computer. Rather than 10
column3: 000 years
column4: IBM researchers claim Google's challenge would take a classical computer just two and half days.

column1: Because the original meaning of the term ""quantum supremacy
column2: as proposed by John Preskill in 2012
column3: was to describe the point where quantum computers can do things that classical computers can't
column4: this threshold has not been met
column5: IBM researchers wrote.

column1: Google's experiment is an excellent demonstration of the progress in superconducting-based quantum computing
column2: showing state-of-the-art gate fidelities on a 53-qubit device
column3: but it should not be viewed as proof that quantum computers are 'supreme' over classical computers
column4: the IBMers said.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: Google CEO Sundar Pichai has heralded Google's work as a ""big breakthrough in quantum computing known as quantum supremacy"".

column1: The allure of quantum computing is that a qubit can be both a 0 and 1 simultaneously thanks to the quantum property called superposition.
So
column2: instead of just a 1 and 0 in classical computers
column3: the 1 and 0 can on a quantum computer be in four possible states at any time. A quantum computer with 54 qubits can have 2^54 computational states and since it can scale exponentially
column4: it holds the possibility for computers to one day solve much more complex challenges.

column1: It's comprised of a two-dimensional grid where each qubit is connected to four other qubits. As a consequence
column2: the chip has enough connectivity that the qubit states quickly interact throughout the entire processor
column3: making the overall state impossible to emulate efficiently with a classical computer
column4: the Google researchers explain.

column1: The quantum supremacy experiment was enabled by its improved two-bit gates
column2: which are the foundation of quantum circuits and serve the same function as logic gates in classical computers. Google showed it could achieve record performance even when operating many gates simultaneously.

column1: We achieved this performance using a new type of control knob that is able to turn off interactions between neighboring qubits. This greatly reduces the errors in such a multi-connected qubit system. We made further performance gains by optimizing the chip design to lower crosstalk
column2: and by developing new control calibrations that avoid qubit defects.""

column1: As noted in a Nature report on the research
column2: Google's supremacy demonstration was carried out by ""sampling solutions"" on a circuit implemented on Sycamore. The results were then compared with simulations performed on classical supercomputers
column3: including the huge Summit supercomputer at Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee.

column1: Google says in the future it will make its ""supremacy-class"" processors available to collaborators
column2: academic researchers and companies that want to develop algorithms and applications for today's quantum processors.

column1: The group is also racing to build a fault-tolerant quantum computer that they believe can be used to design new materials
column2: such as lightweight batteries for cars and airplanes
column3: better fertilizers and more effective medicines.

column1: Achieving the necessary computational capabilities will still require years of hard engineering and scientific work. But we see a path clearly now
column2: and we're eager to move ahead
column3: the researchers noted.";3925;['f4va7h3'

column1: 9aa9b7b6262e5b005032ded6f66456e7f78cc7d76edda40114d37ef27bc1cb12;posted_link;r/worldnews;http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/quantum-spookiness-passes-toughest-test-yet/;['3iso3v'];['madam1'];[1440810154.0];['The most rigorous test of quantum theory ever carried out has confirmed that the ‘spooky action at a distance’ that the German physicist famously hated — in which manipulating one object instantaneously seems to affect another
column2: far away one — is an inherent part of the quantum world.'];[nan];2015-08-28;"Zeeya Merali; Nature magazine";Quantum 'spookiness' passes toughest test yet;"It’s a bad day both for Albert Einstein and for hackers. The most rigorous test of quantum theory ever carried out has confirmed that the ‘spooky action at a distance’ that the German physicist famously hated — in which manipulating one object instantaneously seems to affect another
column3: far away one — is an inherent part of the quantum world.

column1: The experiment
column2: performed in the Netherlands
column3: could be the final nail in the coffin for models of the atomic world that are more intuitive than standard quantum mechanics
column4: say some physicists. It could also enable quantum engineers to develop a new suite of ultrasecure cryptographic devices.

column1: “From a fundamental point of view
column2: this is truly history-making
column3: ” says Nicolas Gisin
column4: a quantum physicist at the University of Geneva in Switzerland.

column1: Einstein’s annoyance
In quantum mechanics
column2: objects can be in multiple states simultaneously: for example
column3: an atom can be in two places
column4: or spin in opposite directions
column5: at once. Measuring an object forces it to snap into a well-defined state. Furthermore
column6: the properties of different objects can become ‘entangled’
column7: meaning that their states are linked: when a property of one such object is measured
column8: the properties of all its entangled twins become set

column1: This idea galled Einstein because it seemed that this ghostly influence would be transmitted instantaneously between even vastly separated but entangled particles — implying that it could contravene the universal rule that nothing can travel faster than the speed of light. He proposed that quantum particles do have set properties before they are measured
column2: called hidden variables. And even though those variable cannot be access
column3: he suggested that they pre-program entangled particles to behave in correlated ways.

column1: In the 1960s
column2: Irish physicist John Bell proposed a test that could discriminate between Einstein’s hidden variables and the spooky interpretation of quantum mechanics. He calculated that hidden variables can explain correlations only up to some maximum limit. If that level is exceeded
column3: then Einstein’s model must be wrong.

column1: The first Bell test was carried out in 1981
column2: by Alain Aspect’s team at the Institute of Optics in Palaiseau
column3: France. Many more have been performed since
column4: always coming down on the side of spookiness — but each of those experiments has had loopholes that meant that physicists have never been able to fully close the door on Einstein’s view. Experiments that use entangled photons are prone to the ‘detection loophole’: not all photons produced in the experiment are detected
column5: and sometimes as many as 80% are lost. Experimenters therefore have to assume that the properties of the photons they capture are representative of the entire set.

column1: To get around the detection loophole
column2: physicists often use particles that are easier to keep track of than photons
column3: such as atoms. But it is tough to separate distant atoms apart without destroying their entanglement. This opens the ‘communication loophole’: if the entangled atoms are too close together
column4: then
column5: in principle
column6: measurements made on one could affect the other without violating the speed-of-light limit.

column1: Entanglement swapping
In the latest paper
column2: which was submitted to the arXiv preprint repository on August 24 and has not yet been peer reviewed
column3: a team led by Ronald Hanson of Delft University of Technology reports the first Bell experiment that closes both the detection and the communication loopholes. The team used a cunning technique called entanglement swapping to combine the benefits of using both light and matter. The researchers started with two unentangled electrons sitting in diamond crystals held in different labs on the Delft campus
column4: 1.3 kilometers apart. Each electron was individually entangled with a photon
column5: and both of those photons were then zipped to a third location. There
column6: the two photons were entangled with each other — and this caused both their partner electrons to become entangled

column1: This did not work every time. In total
column2: the team managed to generate 245 entangled pairs of electrons over the course of nine days. The team's measurements exceeded Bell’s bound
column3: once again supporting the standard quantum view. Moreover
column4: the experiment closed both loopholes at once: because the electrons were easy to monitor
column5: the detection loophole was not an issue
column6: and they were separated far enough apart to close the communication loophole

column1: “It is a truly ingenious and beautiful experiment
column2: ” says Anton Zeilinger
column3: a physicist at the Vienna Centre for Quantum Science and Technology.

column1: “I wouldn’t be surprised if in the next few years we see one of the authors of this paper
column2: along with some of the older experiments
column3: Aspect’s and others
column4: named on a Nobel prize
column5: ” says Matthew Leifer
column6: a quantum physicist at the Perimeter Institute in Waterloo for Theoretical Physics

column1: A loophole-free Bell test also has crucial implications for quantum cryptography
column2: says Leifer. Companies already sell systems that use quantum mechanics to block eavesdroppers. The systems produce entangled pairs of photons
column3: sending one photon in each pair to the first user and the other photon to the second user. The two users then turn these photons into a cryptographic key that only they know. Because observing a quantum system disrupts its properties
column4: if someone tries to eavesdrop on this process it will produce a noticeable effect
column5: setting off an alarm.

column1: The final chink
But loopholes
column2: and the detection loophole in particular
column3: leave the door open to sophisticated eavesdroppers. Through this loophole
column4: malicious companies could sell devices that fool users into thinking that they are getting quantum-entangled particles
column5: while they are instead being given keys that the company can use to spy on them. In 1991
column6: quantum physicist Artur Ekert observed that integrating a Bell test into the cryptographic system also would ensure that the system uses a genuine quantum process. For this to be valid
column8: the Bell test must be free of any loopholes that a hacker could exploit. The Delft experiment “is the final proof that quantum cryptography can be unconditionally secure”

column1: In practice
column2: however
column3: the entanglement-swapping idea will be hard to implement. The team took more than week to generate a few hundred entangled electron pairs
column4: whereas generating a quantum key would require thousands of bits to be processed per minute
column5: points out Gisin
column6: who is a co-founder of the quantum cryptographic company ID Quantique in Geneva.

column1: Zeilinger also notes that there remains one last
column2: somewhat philosophical loophole
column3: first identified by Bell himself: the possibility that hidden variables could somehow manipulate the experimenters’ choices of what properties to measure
column4: tricking them into thinking quantum theory is correct.

column1: Leifer is less troubled by this ‘freedom-of-choice loophole’
column2: however. “It could be that there is some kind of superdeterminism
column3: so that the choice of measurement settings was determined at the Big Bang
column4: ” he says. “We can never prove that is not the case
column5: so I think it’s fair to say that most physicists don’t worry too much about this.”";7164;['cujf3aw'
