column1: 29297764d823210c31d28168deeb30a91e4d4978b10bf8b9a0675ddbc2b596b7;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/958880;['yavq6p'];['flemay222'];[1666465287.0];['Strange new phase of matter created in quantum computer acts like it has two time dimensions'];[nan];2022-07-20;;Strange new phase of matter created in quantum computer acts like it has two time dimensions;"By shining a laser pulse sequence inspired by the Fibonacci numbers at atoms inside a quantum computer
column2: physicists have created a remarkable
column3: never-before-seen phase of matter. The phase has the benefits of two time dimensions despite there still being only one singular flow of time
column4: the physicists report July 20 in Nature.

column1: This mind-bending property offers a sought-after benefit: Information stored in the phase is far more protected against errors than with alternative setups currently used in quantum computers. As a result
column2: the information can exist without getting garbled for much longer
column3: an important milestone for making quantum computing viable
column4: says study lead author Philipp Dumitrescu.

column1: The approach’s use of an “extra” time dimension “is a completely different way of thinking about phases of matter
column2: ” says Dumitrescu
column3: who worked on the project as a research fellow at the Flatiron Institute’s Center for Computational Quantum Physics in New York City. “I’ve been working on these theory ideas for over five years
column4: and seeing them come actually to be realized in experiments is exciting.”

column1: Dumitrescu spearheaded the study’s theoretical component with Andrew Potter of the University of British Columbia in Vancouver
column2: Romain Vasseur of the University of Massachusetts
column3: Amherst
column4: and Ajesh Kumar of the University of Texas at Austin. The experiments were carried out on a quantum computer at Quantinuum in Broomfield
column5: Colorado
column6: by a team led by Brian Neyenhuis.

column1: The workhorses of the team’s quantum computer are 10 atomic ions of an element called ytterbium. Each ion is individually held and controlled by electric fields produced by an ion trap
column2: and can be manipulated or measured using laser pulses.

column1: Each of those atomic ions serves as what scientists dub a quantum bit
column2: or ‘qubit.’ Whereas traditional computers quantify information in bits (each representing a 0 or a 1)
column3: the qubits used by quantum computers leverage the strangeness of quantum mechanics to store even more information. Just as Schrödinger’s cat is both dead and alive in its box
column4: a qubit can be a 0
column5: a 1 or a mashup — or ‘superposition’ — of both. That extra information density and the way qubits interact with one another promise to allow quantum computers to tackle computational problems far beyond the reach of conventional computers.

column1: There’s a big problem
column2: though: Just as peeking in Schrödinger’s box seals the cat’s fate
column3: so does interacting with a qubit. And that interaction doesn’t even have to be deliberate. “Even if you keep all the atoms under tight control
column4: they can lose their quantumness by talking to their environment
column5: heating up or interacting with things in ways you didn’t plan
column6: ” Dumitrescu says. “In practice
column7: experimental devices have many sources of error that can degrade coherence after just a few laser pulses.”

column1: The challenge
column2: therefore
column3: is to make qubits more robust. To do that
column4: physicists can use ‘symmetries
column5: ’ essentially properties that hold up to change. (A snowflake
column6: for instance
column7: has rotational symmetry because it looks the same when rotated by 60 degrees.) One method is adding time symmetry by blasting the atoms with rhythmic laser pulses. This approach helps
column8: but Dumitrescu and his collaborators wondered if they could go further. So instead of just one time symmetry
column9: they aimed to add two by using ordered but non-repeating laser pulses.

column1: The best way to understand their approach is by considering something else ordered yet non-repeating: ‘quasicrystals.’ A typical crystal has a regular
column2: repeating structure
column3: like the hexagons in a honeycomb. A quasicrystal still has order
column4: but its patterns never repeat. (Penrose tiling is one example of this.) Even more mind-boggling is that quasicrystals are crystals from higher dimensions projected
column5: or squished down
column6: into lower dimensions. Those higher dimensions can even be beyond physical space’s three dimensions: A 2-D Penrose tiling
column8: is a projected slice of a 5-D lattice.

column1: For the qubits
column2: Dumitrescu
column3: Vasseur and Potter proposed in 2018 the creation of a quasicrystal in time rather than space. Whereas a periodic laser pulse would alternate (A
column4: B
column5: A
column6: B
column10: the researchers created a quasi-periodic laser-pulse regimen based on the Fibonacci sequence. In such a sequence
column11: each part of the sequence is the sum of the two previous parts (A
column20: it’s a 2D pattern squashed into a single dimension. That dimensional flattening theoretically results in two time symmetries instead of just one: The system essentially gets a bonus symmetry from a nonexistent extra time dimension.

column1: Actual quantum computers are incredibly complex experimental systems
column2: though
column3: so whether the benefits promised by the theory would endure in real-world qubits remained unproven.

column1: Using Quantinuum’s quantum computer
column2: the experientialists put the theory to the test. They pulsed laser light at the computer’s qubits both periodically and using the sequence based on the Fibonacci numbers. The focus was on the qubits at either end of the 10-atom lineup; that’s where the researchers expected to see the new phase of matter experiencing two time symmetries at once. In the periodic test
column3: the edge qubits stayed quantum for around 1.5 seconds — already an impressive length given that the qubits were interacting strongly with one another. With the quasi-periodic pattern
column4: the qubits stayed quantum for the entire length of the experiment
column5: about 5.5 seconds. That’s because the extra time symmetry provided more protection
column6: Dumitrescu says.

column1: “With this quasi-periodic sequence
column2: there’s a complicated evolution that cancels out all the errors that live on the edge
column3: ” he says. “Because of that
column4: the edge stays quantum-mechanically coherent much
column5: much longer than you’d expect.”

column1: Though the findings demonstrate that the new phase of matter can act as long-term quantum information storage
column2: the researchers still need to functionally integrate the phase with the computational side of quantum computing. “We have this direct
column3: tantalizing application
column4: but we need to find a way to hook it into the calculations
column5: ” Dumitrescu says. “That’s an open problem we’re working on.”";6273;['itdcmtn'
column6: 'itdqptx'

column1: dde2299e9e6a60a19468fbe2d0e775933b508048fad36c3725344325ac46ca92;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.sciencealert.com/physicists-used-a-quantum-computer-to-show-their-time-crystal-design-is-the-real-deal;['r6x48q'];['MichaelTen'];[1638414334.0];['Physicists Confirm The Existence of Time Crystals in Epic Quantum Computer Simulation'];[nan];2021-12-01;Mike McRae;Physicists Confirm The Existence of Time Crystals in Epic Quantum Computer Simulation;"Are you in the market for a loophole in the laws that forbid perpetual motion? Knowing you've got yourself an authentic time crystal takes more than a keen eye for high-quality gems.
In a new study
column2: an international team of researchers used Google's Sycamore quantum computing hardware to double-check their theoretical vision of a time crystal
column3: confirming it ticks all of the right boxes for an emerging form of technology we're still getting our head around.

column1: Similar to conventional crystals made of endlessly repeating units of atoms
column2: a time crystal is an infinitely repeating change in a system
column3: one that remarkably doesn't require energy to enter or leave.

column1: Though such a thing comes close to breaking certain laws of thermodynamics
column2: the fact that the system's entropy doesn't increase means it should sit on the right side of physics.

column1: In reality
column2: such a crystal might look like an oscillation of some sort that doesn't synchronize with the rest of the system's rhythms. A laser tapping out a steady beat on your time crystal
column3: for example
column4: might make its particles' spins flip only on every other tap.

column1: But the sheer complexity of a huge number of interacting quantum objects all swinging to their own rhythm leaves some wiggle room for explanations that aren't necessarily dependent on the same rules that underpin time crystal physics.
So while unlikely
column2: we can't rule out that a system that initially looks like a time crystal might in reality warm up over the eons and eventually fall into disarray.

column1: You could just sit and watch your crystal hum away until the eventual heat death of the Universe
column2: of course. Or you could let a quantum computer carry out the job for you.

column1: The big picture is that we are taking the devices that are meant to be the quantum computers of the future and thinking of them as complex quantum systems in their own right
column2: says Stanford University physicist Matteo Ippoliti.

column1: Instead of computation
column2: we're putting the computer to work as a new experimental platform to realize and detect new phases of matter.""

column1: The starting place for this particular time crystal was a surprisingly unintentional one
column2: emerging from work conducted by Stanford theoretical physicist Vedika Khemani on non-equilibrium physics.

column1: We're intimately familiar with the consequences of this kind of physics in everyday life. Leave your hot cup of coffee out on the bench for half an hour
column2: and you'll discover how quickly its heat energy dissipates as it sits out of equilibrium with its environment.

column1: Khemani and her colleagues were more interested in the imbalance of energy on the far less intuitive level of quantum physics.
It was only when a reviewer of Khemani's research drew her attention to similarities between her own work and time crystals that she turned her focus to this exciting new field of physics.
Time-crystals are a striking example of a new type of non-equilibrium quantum phase of matter
column2: says Khemani.

column1: While much of our understanding of condensed matter physics is based on equilibrium systems
column2: these new quantum devices are providing us a fascinating window into new non-equilibrium regimes in many-body physics.""

column1: Modelling their time crystal on Google's quantum technology allowed the team to look for signs of infinite repetition within just a few hundred kicks of a laser pulse. They could also run the simulation backwards and scale its size.
It essentially told us how to correct for its own errors
column2: so that the fingerprint of ideal time-crystalline behavior could be ascertained from finite time observations
column3: says Roderich Moessner
column4: a theoretical physicist from the Max Planck Institute for Physics of Complex Systems in Germany.

column1: Having ways to model actual time crystals with confidence that they represent a truly unique phase of matter could be invaluable for probing the insane complexities of non-equilibrium quantum physics.
Time crystals promise to be a window into the novel ways that a wide range of complex systems operate
column2: providing insights not just into quantum spaces
column3: but systems as complex as our own brains.

column1: One day a lot of scientists across a range of fields will be in the market for a time crystal. Now there's less of a chance they'll be ripped off.";4212;['hmw9uq4'

column1: 1998b1f0c32c239632a281c3d27669f7849b0007e68f89f04147b97a36a65935;posted_link;r/science;https://www.zdnet.com/article/samsung-develops-method-for-self-emissive-qled/;['e2v5mz'];['the_phet'];[1574929387.0];['Samsung says its new method for making self-emissive quantum dot diodes (QLED) extended their lifetime to a million hours and the efficiency improved by 21.4% in a paper published today in Nature.'];[nan];2019-11-28;Cho Mu-Hyun;Samsung develops method for self-emissive QLED;"Samsung Electronics has developed a new method to extend the lifetime and efficiency of quantum dot light-emitting diodes (QLEDs) that may lead to their commercialisation
column2: which has been published in the science journal Nature .

column1: A team led by Dr. Eunjoo Jang
column2: a Samsung fellow
column3: and Dr. Yu-Ho Won
column4: a principal researcher at Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology
column5: improved the structure of the quantum dot made out of environmentally-friendly indium phosphide.

column1: Their proposed structure prevents oxidation of the core and builds a symmetrical and thick shell around it to prevent energy leaks. The ligand on the shell surface has also been made shorter to allow it to absorb electric current faster.
Quantum efficiency improves by 21.4% and the lifetime of the diodes increased to a million hours
column2: the South Korean tech giant said.

column1: The company added that it has over 170 patents on element structure in QLEDs and will continue to develop new technology to lead in advanced displays.
A Samsung spokesman declined to comment on when the company will commercialise self-emissive QLED technology.
STILL A DISTANT FUTURE
Despite Samsung's announcement
column2: the commercialisation of displays that uses quantum dot (QD) as the light source is still far away
column3: and may never be realised at all as there are mountain of challenges ahead.

column1: Research into using QD has focused on avoiding cadmium
column2: which is the best material to use as a light source thanks to its malleability and integrity
column3: but is harmful to humans.

column1: Materials such as indium phosphide have so far failed to match the performance of cadmium when used as the direct light source in actual practice.
Samsung's current flagship TVs are called QLED
column2: which does use QD that are cadmium-free. But they do not use QD as the light sources absorbs electricity directly. Rather
column3: QD is used as a film on Liquid Crystal Display that emits luminance by absorbing the light from the backlight.

column1: The production of the first iteration of this will begin in 2021
column2: but will be QD-enabled OLED
column3: which uses organic material as the light source and QD material as a film. It will be more similar to Samsung's own AMOLED used for mobile phones and LG's OLED TVs.

column1: If Samsung's eventual goal is to launch a self-emissive QLED display
column2: at minimum
column3: the industry will have to wait until 2025 to see if it is indeed viable.

column1: The aggressive investment plan is Samsung Display's attempt to diversify its portfolio amid slowing smartphone growth and the rise of China
column2: with the company set to begin production of 65-inch QD displays in 2021.";2557;['f8xqptn'

column1: 8ea4ba8801656b269bdf90c2078fe047e24bdf4227e9b4b14e1adc429d473f98;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.space.com/quantum-time-flipped-photon-first-time;['zloibj'];['Tao_Dragon'];[1671017138.0];"[""'Quantum time flip' makes light move simultaneously forward and backward in time""]";[nan];2022-12-13;Ben Turner;'Quantum time flip' makes light move simultaneously forward and backward in time;"For the first time
column2: physicists have made light appear to move simultaneously forward and backward in time. The new technique could help scientists improve quantum computing and understand quantum gravity.

column1: By splitting a photon
column2: or packet of light
column3: using a special optical crystal
column4: two independent teams of physicists have achieved what they describe as a ""quantum time flip
column5: in which a photon exists in both forward and backward time states.

column1: The effect results from the convergence of two strange principles of quantum mechanics (opens in new tab)
column2: the counterintuitive rules that govern the behavior of the very small. The first principle
column3: quantum superposition
column4: enables minuscule particles to exist in many different states
column5: or different versions of themselves
column6: at once
column7: until they are observed. The second — charge
column8: parity and time-reversal (CPT) symmetry — states that any system containing particles will obey the same physical laws even if the particles' charges
column9: spatial coordinates and movements through time are flipped as if through a mirror.

column1: By combining these two principles
column2: the physicists produced a photon that appeared to simultaneously travel along and against the arrow of time. They published the results of their twin experiments Oct. 31 (opens in new tab) and Nov. 2 (opens in new tab) on the preprint server arXiv
column3: meaning the findings have yet to be peer-reviewed.

column1: The concept of the arrow of time is giving a word to the apparent unidirectionality of time that we observe in the macroscopic world we inhabit
column2: Teodor Strömberg (opens in new tab)
column3: a physicist at the University of Vienna who was first author on one of the papers
column4: told Live Science. ""This is actually in tension with many of the fundamental laws of physics
column5: which by and large are time symmetric
column6: and which therefore do not have a preferred time direction.""

column1: The second law of thermodynamics (opens in new tab) states that the entropy of a system
column2: a rough analogue of its disorder
column3: must increase. Known as the ""arrow of time
column4: entropy is one of the few quantities in physics that sets time to go in a particular direction.

column1: This tendency for disorder to grow in the universe explains why it's easier to mix ingredients than to separate them. It's also through this growing disorder that entropy is wedded so intimately to our sense of time. A famous scene in Kurt Vonnegut's novel ""Slaughterhouse-Five"" demonstrates how differently entropy makes one direction of time look to the other by playing World War II in reverse: Bullets are sucked from wounded men; fires are shrunk
column2: gathered into bombs
column3: stacked in neat rows
column4: and separated into composite minerals; and the reversed arrow of time undoes the disorder and devastation of war.

column1: However
column2: as entropy is primarily a statistical concept
column3: it doesn’t apply to single subatomic particles. In fact
column4: in every particle interaction scientists have observed so far — including the up to 1 billion interactions per second that take place inside the world's largest atom smasher
column5: the Large Hadron Collider — CPT symmetry is upheld. So particles seeming to move forward in time are indistinguishable from those in a mirrored system of antiparticles moving backward in time. (Antimatter was created with matter during the Big Bang and doesn't actually move backward in time; it just behaves as if it is following an opposite arrow of time to normal matter.)

column1: The other factor at play in the new experiments is superposition. The most famous demonstration of quantum superposition is Schrödinger's cat
column2: a thought experiment in which a cat is placed inside a sealed box with a vial of poison whose release is triggered by the radioactive decay of an alpha particle. Radioactive decay is a quantum mechanical process that occurs at random
column3: so it is initially impossible to know what happened to the cat
column4: which is in a superposition of states
column5: simultaneously dead and alive
column6: until the box is opened and the outcome observed.

column1: This superposition of states enables a particle to exist in both forward and backward time states at the same time
column2: but witnessing this feat experimentally is tricky. To achieve it
column3: both teams devised similar experiments to split a photon along a superposition of two separate paths through a crystal. The superposed photon moved on one path through the crystal as normal
column4: but another path was configured to change the photon's polarization
column5: or where it points in space
column6: to move as if it were traveling backward in time.

column1: After recombining the superposed photons by sending them through another crystal
column2: the team measured the photon polarization across a number of repeated experiments. They found a quantum interference pattern
column3: a pattern of light and dark stripes that could exist only if the photon had been split and was moving in both time directions.

column1: The superposition of processes we realized is more akin to an object spinning clockwise and counter-clockwise at the same time
column2: Strömberg said. The researchers created their time-flipped photon out of intellectual curiosity
column3: but follow-up experiments showed that time flips can be paired with reversible logic gates to enable simultaneous computation in either direction
column4: thus opening the way for quantum processors with greatly enhanced processing power.

column1: Theoretical possibilities also sprout from the work. A future theory of quantum gravity
column2: which would unite general relativity and quantum mechanics
column3: should include particles of mixed time orientations like the one in this experiment
column4: and could enable the researchers to peer into some of the universe's most mysterious phenomena.

column1: A nice way to put it is to say that our experiment is a simulation of exotic scenarios where a photon might evolve forward and backward in time
column2: Giulio Chiribella
column3: a physicist at the University of Oxford who was the lead author of the other paper
column4: told Live Science. ""What we do is an analogue to some experiments that simulate exotic physics
column5: such as the physics of black holes or time travel.""";5991;['j06cr0l'
column6: 'j06keaa'

column1: 06399c5b4ab1a5472f8b503f64dcdd4c780bf8a06c73629571dafe49243a694d;posted_link;r/science;http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/05/150527103110.htm;['37wfte'];['drewiepoodle'];[1433029019.0];['The bizarre nature of reality as laid out by quantum theory has survived another test
column2: with scientists performing a famous experiment and proving that reality does not exist until it is measured.'];[nan];2023-02-20;;Experiment confirms quantum theory weirdness;"The bizarre nature of reality as laid out by quantum theory has survived another test
column3: with scientists performing a famous experiment and proving that reality does not exist until it is measured.

column1: Physicists at The Australian National University (ANU) have conducted John Wheeler's delayed-choice thought experiment
column2: which involves a moving object that is given the choice to act like a particle or a wave. Wheeler's experiment then asks -- at which point does the object decide?

column1: Common sense says the object is either wave-like or particle-like
column2: independent of how we measure it. But quantum physics predicts that whether you observe wave like behavior (interference) or particle behavior (no interference) depends only on how it is actually measured at the end of its journey. This is exactly what the ANU team found.

column1: It proves that measurement is everything. At the quantum level
column2: reality does not exist if you are not looking at it
column3: said Associate Professor Andrew Truscott from the ANU Research School of Physics and Engineering.

column1: Despite the apparent weirdness
column2: the results confirm the validity of quantum theory
column3: which governs the world of the very small
column4: and has enabled the development of many technologies such as LEDs
column5: lasers and computer chips.

column1: The ANU team not only succeeded in building the experiment
column2: which seemed nearly impossible when it was proposed in 1978
column3: but reversed Wheeler's original concept of light beams being bounced by mirrors
column4: and instead used atoms scattered by laser light.

column1: Quantum physics predictions about interference seem odd enough when applied to light
column2: which seems more like a wave
column3: but to have done the experiment with atoms
column4: which are complicated things that have mass and interact with electric fields and so on
column5: adds to the weirdness
column6: said PhD student Roman Khakimov.

column1: Professor Truscott's team first trapped a collection of helium atoms in a suspended state known as a Bose-Einstein condensate
column2: and then ejected them until there was only a single atom left.

column1: The single atom was then dropped through a pair of counter-propagating laser beams
column2: which formed a grating pattern that acted as crossroads in the same way a solid grating would scatter light.

column1: A second light grating to recombine the paths was randomly added
column2: which led to constructive or destructive interference as if the atom had travelled both paths. When the second light grating was not added
column3: no interference was observed as if the atom chose only one path.

column1: However
column2: the random number determining whether the grating was added was only generated after the atom had passed through the crossroads.

column1: If one chooses to believe that the atom really did take a particular path or paths then one has to accept that a future measurement is affecting the atom's past
column2: said Truscott.

column1: The atoms did not travel from A to B. It was only when they were measured at the end of the journey that their wave-like or particle-like behavior was brought into existence
column2: he said.";2969;['crqd8la'
column3: 'crqelzj'

column1: 605ce34a40a6581b6c88c335e82be5e7224586812afd8e6ee7ce0baafc1b526e;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.livescience.com/google-invents-time-crystal;['po6e2o'];['izumi3682'];[1631637436.0];"[""Otherworldly 'time crystal' made inside Google quantum computer could change physics forever. The crystal is able to forever cycle between states without losing energy.""]";[nan];2021-09-14;Ben Turner;Otherworldly 'time crystal' made inside Google quantum computer could change physics forever;"Researchers working in partnership with Google may have just used the tech giant's quantum computer to create a completely new phase of matter — a time crystal.
With the ability to forever cycle between two states without ever losing energy
column2: time crystals dodge one of the most important laws of physics — the second law of thermodynamics
column3: which states that the disorder
column4: or entropy
column5: of an isolated system must always increase. These bizarre time crystals remain stable
column6: resisting any dissolution into randomness
column7: despite existing in a constant state of flux.

column1: According to a research article posted July 28 to the preprint database arXiv
column2: scientists were able to create the time crystal for roughly 100 seconds using qubits (quantum computing's version of the traditional computer bit) inside the core of Google's Sycamore quantum processor.

column1: The existence of this weird new matter phase
column2: and the entirely new realm of physical behaviors it reveals
column3: is incredibly exciting to physicists
column4: especially as time crystals were only first predicted to exist just nine years ago.

column1: This was a big surprise
column2: Curt von Keyserlingk
column3: a physicist at the University of Birmingham in the U.K. who was not involved in the study
column4: told Live Science. ""If you asked someone 30
column5: 20 or maybe even 10 years ago
column6: they would not have expected this.""

column1: Time crystals are fascinating objects to physicists because they essentially sidestep the second law of thermodynamics
column2: one of the most ironclad laws in physics. It states that entropy (a rough analog for the amount of disorder in a system) always increases. If you want to make something more ordered
column3: you need to put more energy into it.

column1: This tendency for disorder to grow explains a lot of things
column2: such as why it's easier to stir ingredients into a mixture than it is to separate them out again
column3: or why headphone cords get so tangled in pants' pockets. It also sets the arrow of time
column4: with the past universe always more ordered than the present; watching a video in reverse
column5: for instance
column6: is likely to look strange to you primarily because you're witnessing the counterintuitive reversal of this entropic flow.(opens in new tab)

column1: Time crystals don't follow this rule. Instead of slowly approaching thermal equilibrium — ""thermalizing"" so that their energy or temperature is equally distributed throughout their surroundings
column2: they get stuck between two energy states above that equilibrium state
column3: cycling back and forth between them indefinitely.

column1: To explain how deeply unusual this behavior is
column2: von Keyserlingk said to picture a sealed box filled with coins before being shaken a million times. As the coins ricochet from
column3: and bounce around
column4: each other
column5: they ""become more and more chaotic
column6: exploring all of the sorts of configurations that they can explore"" until the shaking stops
column7: and the box is opened to reveal the coins in a random configuration
column8: with roughly half of the coins facing up and half facing down. We can expect to see this random
column10: half-down endpoint regardless of the way we first arranged the coins in the box.

column1: Inside the ""box"" of Google's Sycamore
column2: we can view the quantum processor's qubits much like we would our coins. In the same way that the coins can be either heads or tails
column3: qubits can be either a 1 or a 0 — the two possible positions in a two-state system — or a weird mix of the probabilities of both states called a superposition. What's weird about time crystals
column4: von Keyserlingk says
column5: is that no amount of shaking
column6: or zapping from one state to another
column7: can move the time crystal's qubits into the lowest energy state
column8: which is a random configuration; they can only flip it from its starting state to its second state

column1: It just sort of flip-flops
column2: von Keyserlingk said. ""It doesn't end up looking random
column3: it just gets jammed stuck. It's like it remembers what it looked like initially
column4: and it repeats that pattern over time.""

column1: In this sense
column2: a time crystal is like a pendulum that never stops swinging.

column1: Even if you totally physically isolate a pendulum from the universe
column2: so there's no friction and no air resistance
column3: it will eventually stop. And that's because of the second law of thermodynamics
column4: Achilleas Lazarides
column5: a physicist at the University of Loughborough in the U.K. who was among the scientists to first discover the theoretical possibility of the new phase in 2015
column6: told Live Science. ""Energy starts out concentrated in the pendulum's center of mass
column7: but there's all of these internal degrees of freedom — like the ways the atoms can vibrate inside the rod — that it will eventually be transferred into.""

column1: In fact
column2: there's no way for a large-scale object to behave like a time crystal without sounding absurd
column3: because the only rules that enable time crystals to exist are the spooky and surreal rules that govern the world of the very small — quantum mechanics.

column1: In the quantum world
column2: objects behave both like point particles and little waves at the same time
column3: with the magnitude of these waves in any given region of space representing the probability of finding a particle at that location. But randomness (such as random defects in a crystal's structure or a programmed randomness in the interaction strengths between qubits) can cause a particle's probability wave to cancel itself out everywhere apart from one very small region. Rooted in place
column4: unable to move
column5: change states or thermalize with its surroundings
column6: the particle becomes localized.

column1: The researchers used this localization process as the foundation of their experiment. Using 20 strips of superconducting aluminum for their qubits
column2: the scientists programmed each one into one of two possible states. Then
column3: by blasting a microwave beam over the strips
column4: they were able to drive their qubits to flip states; the researchers repeated the experiment for tens of thousands of runs and stopped at different points to record the states their qubits were in. What they found was that their collection of qubits was flipping back and forth between only two configurations
column5: and the qubits weren't absorbing heat from the microwave beam either — they had made a time crystal.

column1: They also saw a key clue that their time crystal was a phase of matter. For something to be considered a phase
column2: it usually has to be very stable in the face of fluctuations. Solids will not melt if the temperatures around them vary slightly; neither will slight fluctuations cause liquids to evaporate or freeze suddenly. In the same way
column3: if the microwave beam used to flip the qubits between states was adjusted to be close to but slightly off from the exact 180 degrees needed for a perfect flip
column4: the qubits still nonetheless flipped to the other state.

column1: It's not the case that if you're not exactly at the 180 degrees you will scramble them
column2: Lazarides said. ""It [the time crystal] magically will always tip a bit in
column3: even if you're making slight mistakes.""

column1: Another hallmark of moving from one phase to another is the breaking of physical symmetries
column2: the idea that the laws of physics are the same for an object at any point in time or space. As a liquid
column3: the molecules in water follow the same physical laws at every point in space and in every direction
column4: but cool water down enough so that it transforms into ice and its molecules will pick regular points along a crystal structure — or lattice — to arrange themselves across. Suddenly
column5: the water molecules have preferred points in space to occupy
column6: and they leave the other points empty — the spatial symmetry of the water has been spontaneously broken.

column1: In much the same way that ice becomes a crystal in space by breaking with spatial symmetry
column2: time crystals become crystals in time by breaking with time symmetry. At first
column3: before their transformation into the time crystal phase
column4: the row of qubits will experience a continuous symmetry between all moments in time. But the periodic cycle of the microwave beam chops the constant conditions experienced by the qubits down into discrete packets (making the symmetry imposed by the beam a discrete time-translation symmetry). Then
column5: by flipping back and forth at twice the period of the wavelength of the beam
column6: the qubits break with the discrete time-translation symmetry imposed by the laser. They are the first objects we know of that are able to do this.

column1: All of this weirdness makes time crystals rich in new physics
column2: and the control that Sycamore provides researchers beyond other experimental setups could make it an ideal platform for further investigation. That's not to say it cannot be improved
column3: however. Like all quantum systems
column4: Google's quantum computer needs to be perfectly isolated from its environment to prevent its qubits from undergoing a process called decoherence
column5: which eventually breaks down the quantum localization effects
column6: destroying the time crystal. The researchers are working on ways to better isolate their processor and mitigate the impact of decoherence
column7: but it's unlikely they will eliminate the effect for good.

column1: Despite this
column2: Google's experiment is likely to remain the best way to study time crystals for the foreseeable future. Though numerous other projects have succeeded in making what convincingly appear to be time crystals in other ways — with diamonds
column3: helium-3 superfluids
column4: quasiparticles called magnons and with Bose-Einstein condensates — for the most part the crystals produced in these setups dissipate too quickly for detailed study.

column1: The theoretical newness of the crystals is in some ways a double-edged sword
column2: as physicists currently struggle to find clear applications for them
column3: although von Keyserlingk has suggested that they could be used as highly accurate sensors. Other proposals include using the crystals for better memory storage or for developing quantum computers with even faster processing power.

column1: But in another sense
column2: the greatest application of time crystals may already be here: They allow scientists to probe the boundaries of quantum mechanics.

column1: It allows you to not just study what shows up in nature
column2: but to actually design it and look at what quantum mechanics lets you do and doesn't let you do
column3: Lazarides said. ""If you don't find something in nature then it doesn't mean it can't exist — we just created one of those things.""";10233;['hcufooi'
column4: 'hcuumfm'

column1: 3b7cd20193006db9bbc577ed5875bb525338879b42c76c5c12b244387a5810dd;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://thenextweb.com/science/2018/10/18/ibm-just-proved-quantum-computers-can-do-things-impossible-for-classical-ones/;['9ph39y'];['Odant'];[1539929023.0];['IBM just proved quantum computers can do things impossible for classical ones'];[nan];2018-10-18;Tristan Greene;IBM just proved quantum computers can do things impossible for classical ones ;"A team of researchers from IBM
column2: the University of Waterloo
column3: and the Technical University of Munich (TUM) today published the results of an experiment proving a quantum computer can do things a classical one cannot. This may be a watershed moment in the history of computer science.

column1: The term for a clear case in which a quantum computer can perform computations or run algorithms that no classical computer
column2: now or in the conceivable future
column3: could is “quantum advantage.” Until now
column4: it’s never been achieved.

column1: Sure
column2: there are algorithms that
column3: theoretically couldn’t be run on a classical system. But none of those theories have been proven. Now quantum advantage is no longer up for debate.

column1: One of the authors on the paper
column2: TUM’s Robert Konig
column3: told Phys.org “Our result shows that quantum information processing really does provide benefits—without having to rely on unproven complexity-theoretic conjectures.”

column1: The team set out
column2: specifically
column3: to prove that quantum computers can do something (anything
column4: really) regular computers can’t. To do this
column5: they simply built a quantum circuit that solves a complex algebraic formula through the exploitation of a quantum physics loophole allowing things to be in two places at once. No biggie.

column1: This particular formula
column2: according to the researchers
column3: cannot be solved using classical computer circuits. You can read the whole paper here if you want to know more about how the team demonstrated actual quantum advantage.

column1: As for what this accomplishment means? Well
column2: there’s nothing tangible to point out. The algorithm that the researchers ran wasn’t an algebraic mystery whose solution will result in any immediate impact – at least as best as we can tell. It was
column3: almost certainly
column4: developed simply to prove it could be done.

column1: But that’s the point. By showing that the people claiming quantum advantage was a fantasy were wrong
column2: and that the research is heading in the right direction
column3: we’re closer than ever to realizing the potential of quantum computing.

column1: The field of quantum computing may be decades from producing something that changes “everything” in the way that media hype and marketing teams would have us all believe. But proof of quantum advantage is the guarantee that this research is going to pay off some day.";2270;['e81riql'

column1: 23d1b95ff5161dbca8f3c204f2106f97b83776ed28c3b2cb0f2af33544c80308;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://techcrunch.com/2022/11/09/ibm-unveils-its-433-qubit-osprey-quantum-computer/;['yr5y16'];['nick7566'];[1668056786.0];['IBM unveils its 433 qubit Osprey quantum computer'];[nan];2022-11-09;Frederic Lardinois;IBM unveils its 433 qubit Osprey quantum computer;"IBM wants to scale up its quantum computers to over 4
column2: 000 qubits by 2025 — but we’re not quite there yet. For now
column3: we have to make do with significantly smaller systems and today
column4: IBM announced the launch of its Osprey quantum processor
column5: which features 433 qubits
column6: up from the 127 qubits of its 2021 Eagle processor. And with that
column7: the slow but steady march toward a quantum processor with real-world applications continues.

column1: “The new 433 qubit ‘Osprey’ processor brings us a step closer to the point where quantum computers will be used to tackle previously unsolvable problems
column2: ” said Darío Gil
column3: senior vice president
column4: IBM and director of Research. “We are continuously scaling up and advancing our quantum technology across hardware
column5: software and classical integration to meet the biggest challenges of our time
column6: in conjunction with our partners and clients worldwide. This work will prove foundational for the coming era of quantum-centric supercomputing.”

column1: IBM’s quantum roadmap includes two additional stages — the 1
column2: 121-qubit Condor and 1
column3: 386-qubit Flamingo processors in 2023 and 2024 — before it plans to hit the 4
column4: 000-qubit stage with its Kookaburra processor in 2025. So far
column5: the company has generally been able to make this roadmap work
column6: but the number of qubits in a quantum processor is obviously only one part of a very large and complex puzzle
column7: with longer coherence times and reduced noise being just as important.

column1: Ideally
column2: that’s something developers who want to work with these machines wouldn’t have to worry about
column3: so increasingly
column4: the tools they use are abstracting the hardware away for them. With the new version of its Qiskit Runtime
column5: for example
column6: developers can now trade speed for reduced error count.

column1: The company also today detailed its Quantum System Two — basically IBM’s quantum mainframe — which will be able to house multiple quantum processors and integrate them into a single system with high-speed communication links. The idea here is to launch this system by the end of 2023.";2010;['ivs5dbs'

column1: e2f143a30e6988bcdfc8859ddf43e5e186b9ba4e019134be8a3be968f49baf88;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.geekwire.com/2018/trump-signs-legislation-back-quantum-computing-research-1-2-billion/;['a95b94'];['awesomedan24'];[1545661053.0];['US passes National Quantum Initiative Act
column2: providing 1.2 billion in funding for quantum computing research'];[nan];2018-12-22;Alan Boyle;Trump signs legislation to boost quantum computing research with $1.2 billion;"President Donald Trump on Friday signed legislation ramping up quantum computing research and development.

column1: The National Quantum Initiative Act (H.R. 6227) authorizes $1.2 billion over five years for federal activities aimed at boosting investment in quantum information science
column2: or QIS
column3: and supporting a quantum-smart workforce.

column1: The law also establishes a National Quantum Coordination Office
column2: calls for the development of a five-year strategic plan and establishes an advisory committee to advise the White House on issues relating to quantum computing.

column1: “This next great technological revolution has far-reaching implications for job creation
column2: economic growth and national security
column3: ” Michael Kratsios
column4: deputy assistant to the president for technology policy
column5: said in a White House statement. “We look forward to building upon efforts to support the quantum-smart workforce of the future and engage with government
column6: academic and private-sector leaders to advance QIS.”

column1: Today’s White House signing came after the bill was approved by unanimous consent in the Senate and by a vote of 348-11 vote in the House.

Quantum computing make use of weird subatomic phenomena to provide capabilities that are beyond the scope of classical computers. Classical computing technologies make use of electronic bits that represent either “on” or “off
column2: ” one or zero. In contrast
column3: quantum computers manipulate “qubits” that can represent ones and zeroes simultaneously.

column1: The quantum approach is particularly well-suited to certain types of tasks
column2: including the prime factorization of large numbers. That’s important
column3: because modern-day encryption techniques are based on prime factorization. A sufficiently powerful quantum computer could conceivably crack the code that currently protects secure communications and financial transactions.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: a report from the National Academies of Science said there is an urgent need to develop “post-quantum” encryption protocols in order to protect commerce and national security.

column1: QIS research could also produce new types of quantum processors
column2: sensors
column3: navigation tools and security systems. The challenges could bring about “new approaches to understanding materials
column4: chemistry and even gravity through quantum information theory
column5: ” according to a White House strategy paper issued in September.

column1: Researchers in the U.S. and allied countries have made lots of headway in quantum computing over the past couple of decades. For example
column2: Canada’s D-Wave Systems recently reported that its 2
column3: 048-qubit quantum computer could be used to simulate exotic phenomena associated with superconductivity. D-Wave
column4: which counts Amazon billionaire Jeff Bezos among its investors
column5: has been working for years with Google
column6: NASA
column7: Lockheed Martin and other customers on the frontiers of quantum computing.

column1: Microsoft has its own initiative in the field: At last year’s GeekWire Summit
column2: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella listed quantum computing
column3: along with artificial intelligence and mixed reality
column4: as a core technology that will shape his company’s future.

column1: China and the European Union are investing billions of dollars in quantum computing
column2: and the newly approved National Quantum Initiative is meant to keep America in the forefront of the technological race.";3272;['ecex33w'

column1: 117685caa073514fe73c350dabff4803f174fc7a2824050dfa35006b5dbc738a;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://thenextweb.com/news/your-brain-might-be-quantum-computer-hallucinates-math;['sttmr0'];['Devils_doohickey'];[1645010707.0];['Your brain might be a quantum computer that hallucinates math'];[nan];2022-02-16;Tristan Greene;Your brain might be a quantum computer that hallucinates math;"There's a code for arithmetic hidden inside your head
Quick: what’s 4 + 5? Nine right? Slightly less quick: what’s five plus four? Still nine
column2: right?

column1: Okay
column2: let’s wait a few seconds. Bear with me. Feel free to have a quick stretch.

column1: Now
column2: without looking
column3: what was the answer to the first question?

column1: It’s still nine
column2: isn’t it?

column1: You’ve just performed a series of advanced brain functions. You did math based on prompts designed to appeal to entirely different parts of your brain and you displayed the ability to recall previous information when queried later. Great job!
This might seem like old hat to most of us
column2: but it’s actually quite an amazing feat of brain power.

column1: And
column2: based on some recent research by a pair of teams from the University of Bonn and the University of Tübingen
column3: these simple processes could indicate that you’re a quantum computer.

column1: Let’s do the math
Your brain probably isn’t wired for numbers. It’s great at math
column2: but numbers are a relatively new concept for humans.

column1: Numbers showed up in human history approximately 6
column2: 000 years ago with the Mesopotamians
column3: but our species has been around for about 300
column4: 000 years.

column1: Prehistoric humans still had things to count. They didn’t randomly forget how many children they had just because there wasn’t a bespoke language for numerals yet.
Instead
column2: they found other methods for expressing quantities or tracking objects such as holding up their fingers or using representative models.

column1: If you had to keep track of dozens of cave-mates
column2: for example
column3: you might carry a pebble to represent each one. As people trickled in from a hard day of hunting
column4: gathering
column5: and whatnot
column6: you could shift the pebbles from one container to another as an accounting method.

column1: It might seem sub-optimal
column2: but the human brain really doesn’t care whether you use numbers
column3: words
column4: or concepts when it comes to math.

column1: Let’s do the research
The aforementioned research teams recently published a fascinating paper titled “Neuronal codes for arithmetic rule processing in the human brain.”
As the title intimates
column2: the researchers identified an abstract code for processing addition and subtraction inside the human brain. This is significant because we really don’t know how the brain handles math.

column1: You can’t just slap some electrodes on someone’s scalp or stick them in a CAT scan machine to suss out the nature of human calculation.
Math happens at the individual neuron level inside the human brain. EKG readings and CAT scans can only provide a general picture of all the noise our neurons produce.
And
column2: as there are some 86 billion neurons making noise inside our heads
column3: those kinds of readings aren’t what you’d call an “exact science.”

column1: The Bonn and Tübingen teams got around this problem by conducting their research on volunteers who already had subcranial electrode implants for the treatment of epilepsy.
Nine volunteers met the study’s criteria and
column2: because of the nature of their implants
column3: they were able to provide what might be the world’s first glimpse into how the brain actually handles math.

column1: Per the research paper:
We found abstract and notation-independent codes for addition and subtraction in neuronal populations.
Decoders applied to time-resolved recordings demonstrate a static code in hippocampus based on persistently rule-selective neurons
column2: in contrast to a dynamic code in parahippocampal cortex originating from neurons carrying rapidly changing rule information.

column1: An image of single neuron activity
Single neurons across multiple brain sectors responding to different encoded rules for math.
Basically
column2: the researchers saw that different parts of the brain light up when we do addition than when we do subtraction. They also discovered that different parts of the brain approach these tasks with different timing.

column1: It’s a bit complex
column2: but the gist of it is that one part of our brain tries to figure out the problem while another works on a solution.

column1: As the researchers put it:
Neuron recordings in human and nonhuman primates
column2: as well as computational modeling
column3: suggest different cognitive functions for these two codes for working memory: although a dynamic code seems to suffice for short maintenance of more implicit information in memory
column4: the intense mental manipulation of the attended working memory contents may require a static code.

column1: Following this logic
column2: parahippocampal cortex may represent a short-term memory of the arithmetic rule
column3: whereas downstream hippocampus may “do the math” and process numbers according to the arithmetic rule at hand.

column1: Let’s take inventory

So far we’ve learned that every math process requires both a hard-coded memory solution (a static rule) and a novel one (a dynamic rule). And each of those is transient based on what kind of arithmetic we’re performing.
Keeping in mind that there are 86 billion neurons in the human brain
column2: and that something as basic as simple arithmetic appears to be hidden across all or most of them
column3: it’s obvious there’s something more complex than simple pebble-counting going on.

column1: Per the paper:
Mental calculation is a classic working memory task
column2: and although working memory has traditionally been attributed to the prefrontal cortex
column3: more recent data suggest that the MTL may also be important in working memory tasks and that it is part of a brain-wide network subserving working memory.

column1: Either our brains are working extra-hard to do simple binary mathematics or they’re quantum computing systems doing what they do best: hallucinating answers.
The art of math
Think about an apple. No
column2: not that one. Think about a green apple. How many calculations did it take for you to arrive at a specific apple density and relative size? Did you have to adjust the input variables in order to produce an apple that wasn’t red?

column1: I’m going to go out on a limb and say you didn’t. You just thought about some apples and they happened inside your head. You hallucinated those apples.
Artificial intelligence systems designed to produce original content based on learned styles go through the exact same process.

These AI systems aren’t using advanced math features to psychologically exploit the human propensity for art or imagery. They’re just following some simple rules and swirling data around until they spit out something their creators will reward them for.
That’s kind of how your brain does math. At least according to this new research
column2: anyway. It uses rules to surface the answer that makes the most sense. There’s a part that tries to get the “correct” solution based on things that never change (one plus one always equals two) and another part that tries to guess based on intuition when the answer isn’t something we have memorized.

column1: And that’s why two humans of relative intelligence and education can perceive the same scene differently when it comes to processing math. Can you guess how many candies are in the jar below?
a jar full of colored candies
There’s not enough information for you to deduce the correct answer but that doesn’t stop your brain from trying to do math.
What does it all mean?
That remains to be seen. The simple fact that scientists were able to observe individual neurons participating in the math process inside human brains is astounding.
But it could take years of further research to understand the ramifications of these findings. First and foremost
column2: we have to ask: is the human brain a quantum computer?

column1: It makes sense
column2: and this research might give us our first actual glimpses at a quantum function inside the human brain. But
column3: as far as we can tell
column4: they were only able to record and process hundreds of neurons at a time. That’s obviously a very tiny drop from a giant bucket of data.

column1: To help with that
column2: the researchers created an artificial intelligence system to interpret the data in a more robust manner. The hope is that continued research will lead to a greater understanding of math processes in the brain.

column1: Per the paper’s conclusion:
More fine-grained analyses
column2: ideally combined with perturbation approaches
column3: will help to decipher the individual roles of brain areas and neuronal codes in mental arithmetic.

column1: Yet
column2: there could be potential implications on a much grander scale. The researchers don’t mention the ramifications for technology in their biology experiment or directly discuss its results in quantum computing terms.

column1: But
column2: if this research is accurate
column3: Occam’s Razor tells us that the human brain is probably a quantum computer. Either that
column4: or it’s poorly-designed.

column1: Just like our prehistoric ancestors would have carved notches on the handles of their tools to keep track of objects
column2: a binary brain should be able to handle counting objects through localized abstraction mechanisms.

column1: Why go through all the trouble of hallucinating an answer across myriad neuronal complexes when individual neurons could just pretend to be ones and zeros like a binary computer?
The answer may lie in the quantum nature of the universe. When you perform a simple math function
column2: such as adding two plus two
column3: your brain may hallucinate all of the possible answers at once while simultaneously working to both remember the answer (you’ve definitely added those numbers before) and to process the data (1+1+1+1).

column1: If the human brain were binary
column2: you’d probably have to wait for it to go through each permutation individually instead of hallucinating them all at once.

column1: The result is that you’re probably answering the question in your head before you can actively recognize that you’re thinking about it because both functions occur simultaneously. That’s called quantum time travel.
Quick: what’s 4 + 5? Nine right? Slightly less quick: what’s five plus four? Still nine
column2: right?

column1: Okay
column2: let’s wait a few seconds. Bear with me. Feel free to have a quick stretch.

column1: Now
column2: without looking
column3: what was the answer to the first question?

column1: It’s still nine
column2: isn’t it?

column1: You’ve just performed a series of advanced brain functions. You did math based on prompts designed to appeal to entirely different parts of your brain and you displayed the ability to recall previous information when queried later. Great job!
This might seem like old hat to most of us
column2: but it’s actually quite an amazing feat of brain power.

column1: And
column2: based on some recent research by a pair of teams from the University of Bonn and the University of Tübingen
column3: these simple processes could indicate that you’re a quantum computer.

column1: Let’s do the math
Your brain probably isn’t wired for numbers. It’s great at math
column2: but numbers are a relatively new concept for humans.

column1: Numbers showed up in human history approximately 6
column2: 000 years ago with the Mesopotamians
column3: but our species has been around for about 300
column4: 000 years.

column1: Prehistoric humans still had things to count. They didn’t randomly forget how many children they had just because there wasn’t a bespoke language for numerals yet.
Instead
column2: they found other methods for expressing quantities or tracking objects such as holding up their fingers or using representative models.

column1: If you had to keep track of dozens of cave-mates
column2: for example
column3: you might carry a pebble to represent each one. As people trickled in from a hard day of hunting
column4: gathering
column5: and whatnot
column6: you could shift the pebbles from one container to another as an accounting method.

column1: It might seem sub-optimal
column2: but the human brain really doesn’t care whether you use numbers
column3: words
column4: or concepts when it comes to math.

column1: Let’s do the research
The aforementioned research teams recently published a fascinating paper titled “Neuronal codes for arithmetic rule processing in the human brain.”
As the title intimates
column2: the researchers identified an abstract code for processing addition and subtraction inside the human brain. This is significant because we really don’t know how the brain handles math.

column1: You can’t just slap some electrodes on someone’s scalp or stick them in a CAT scan machine to suss out the nature of human calculation.
Math happens at the individual neuron level inside the human brain. EKG readings and CAT scans can only provide a general picture of all the noise our neurons produce.
And
column2: as there are some 86 billion neurons making noise inside our heads
column3: those kinds of readings aren’t what you’d call an “exact science.”

column1: The Bonn and Tübingen teams got around this problem by conducting their research on volunteers who already had subcranial electrode implants for the treatment of epilepsy.
Nine volunteers met the study’s criteria and
column2: because of the nature of their implants
column3: they were able to provide what might be the world’s first glimpse into how the brain actually handles math.

column1: Per the research paper:
We found abstract and notation-independent codes for addition and subtraction in neuronal populations.
Decoders applied to time-resolved recordings demonstrate a static code in hippocampus based on persistently rule-selective neurons
column2: in contrast to a dynamic code in parahippocampal cortex originating from neurons carrying rapidly changing rule information.

column1: An image of single neuron activity
Single neurons across multiple brain sectors responding to different encoded rules for math.
Basically
column2: the researchers saw that different parts of the brain light up when we do addition than when we do subtraction. They also discovered that different parts of the brain approach these tasks with different timing.

column1: It’s a bit complex
column2: but the gist of it is that one part of our brain tries to figure out the problem while another works on a solution.

column1: As the researchers put it:
Neuron recordings in human and nonhuman primates
column2: as well as computational modeling
column3: suggest different cognitive functions for these two codes for working memory: although a dynamic code seems to suffice for short maintenance of more implicit information in memory
column4: the intense mental manipulation of the attended working memory contents may require a static code.

column1: Following this logic
column2: parahippocampal cortex may represent a short-term memory of the arithmetic rule
column3: whereas downstream hippocampus may “do the math” and process numbers according to the arithmetic rule at hand.

column1: Let’s take inventory

So far we’ve learned that every math process requires both a hard-coded memory solution (a static rule) and a novel one (a dynamic rule). And each of those is transient based on what kind of arithmetic we’re performing.
Keeping in mind that there are 86 billion neurons in the human brain
column2: and that something as basic as simple arithmetic appears to be hidden across all or most of them
column3: it’s obvious there’s something more complex than simple pebble-counting going on.

Mental calculation is a classic working memory task
column2: and although working memory has traditionally been attributed to the prefrontal cortex
column3: more recent data suggest that the MTL may also be important in working memory tasks and that it is part of a brain-wide network subserving working memory.

column1: f0e9921caa2f1a19dbcfb6fb57e5fd0d65ac37610d394524b7cced8ca750dbeb;posted_link;r/science;https://news.st-andrews.ac.uk/archive/ancient-namibian-stone-holds-key-to-future-quantum-computers/;['u5ahcj'];['MistWeaver80'];[1650153124.0];['Ancient Namibian stone holds key to future quantum computers. Scientists used a naturally mined cuprous oxide (Cu2O) gemstone from Namibia to produce Rydberg polaritons that switch continually from light to matter and back again.'];[nan];2022-04-15;University;Ancient Namibian stone holds key to future quantum computers | University of St Andrews news;"Ancient Namibian stone holds key to future quantum computers
A special form of light made using an ancient Namibian gemstone could be the key to new light-based quantum computers
column2: which could solve long-held scientific mysteries
column3: according to new research led by the University of St Andrews.

column1: The research
column2: conducted in collaboration with scientists at Harvard University in the US
column3: Macquarie University in Australia and Aarhus University in Denmark and published in Nature Materials
column4: used a naturally mined cuprous oxide (Cu2O) gemstone from Namibia to produce Rydberg polaritons
column5: the largest hybrid particles of light and matter ever created.

column1: Rydberg polaritons switch continually from light to matter and back again. In Rydberg polaritons
column2: light and matter are like two sides of a coin
column3: and the matter side is what makes polaritons interact with each other.

column1: This interaction is crucial because this is what allows the creation of quantum simulators
column2: a special type of quantum computer
column3: where information is stored in quantum bits. These quantum bits
column4: unlike the binary bits in classical computers that can only be 0 or 1
column5: can take any value between 0 and 1. They can therefore store much more information and perform several processes simultaneously.

column1: This capability could allow quantum simulators to solve important mysteries of physics
column2: chemistry and biology
column3: for example
column4: how to make high-temperature superconductors for highspeed trains
column5: how cheaper fertilisers could be made potentially solving global hunger
column6: or how proteins fold making it easier to produce more effective drugs.

column1: Project lead Dr Hamid Ohadi
column2: of the School of Physics and Astronomy at the University of St Andrews
column3: said: “Making a quantum simulator with light is the holy grail of science. We have taken a huge leap towards this by creating Rydberg polaritons
column4: the key ingredient of it.”

column1: To create Rydberg polaritons
column2: the researchers trapped light between two highly reflective mirrors. A cuprous oxide crystal from a stone mined in Namibia was then thinned and polished to a 30-micrometer thick slab (thinner than a strand of human hair) and sandwiched between the two mirrors to make Rydberg polaritons 100 times larger than ever demonstrated before.

column1: One of the leading authors Dr Sai Kiran Rajendran
column2: of the School of Physics and Astronomy at the University of St Andrews
column3: said: “Purchasing the stone on eBay was easy. The challenge was to make Rydberg polaritons that exist in an extremely narrow colour range.”

column1: The team is currently further refining these methods in order to explore the possibility of making quantum circuits
column2: which are the next ingredient for quantum simulators.";2661;['i50qj68'

column1: 04d0b5f99f47b05b52e2bc1a76cb676dac025415f29e096a0ab31d3eb279d1d0;posted_link;r/science;https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2019-06/ynu-rti062519.php;['c6j2vp'];['Wagamaga'];[1561721485.0];['Researchers teleport information within a diamond. Researchers from the Yokohama National University have teleported quantum information securely within the confines of a diamond.'];[nan];2019-06-28;;Researchers teleport information within a diamond;"Researchers from the Yokohama National University have teleported quantum information securely within the confines of a diamond. The study has big implications for quantum information technology - the future of how sensitive information is shared and stored.
The researchers published their results on June 28
column2: 2019 in Communications Physics.

column1: Quantum teleportation permits the transfer of quantum information into an otherwise inaccessible space
column2: said Hideo Kosaka
column3: a professor of engineering at Yokohama National University and an author on the study. ""It also permits the transfer of information into a quantum memory without revealing or destroying the stored quantum information.""

column1: The inaccessible space
column2: in this case
column3: consisted of carbon atoms in diamond. Made of linked
column4: yet individually contained
column5: carbon atoms
column6: a diamond holds the perfect ingredients for quantum teleportation.

column1: A carbon atom holds six protons and six neutrons in its nucleus
column2: surrounded by six spinning electrons. As the atoms bond into a diamond
column3: they form a notoriously strong lattice. Diamonds can have complex defects
column4: though
column5: when a nitrogen atom exists in one of two adjacent vacancies where carbon atoms should be. This defect is called a nitrogen-vacancy center.

column1: Surrounded by carbon atoms
column2: the nucleus structure of the nitrogen atom creates what Kosaka calls a nanomagnet.

column1: To manipulate an electron and a carbon isotope in the vacancy
column2: Kosaka and the team attached a wire about a quarter the width of a human hair to the surface of a diamond. They applied a microwave and a radio wave to the wire to build an oscillating magnetic field around the diamond. They shaped the microwave to create the optimal
column3: controlled conditions for the transfer of quantum information within the diamond.

column1: Kosaka then used the nitrogen nanomagnet to anchor an electron. Using the microwave and radio waves
column2: Kosaka forced the electron spin to entangle with a carbon nuclear spin - the angular momentum of the electron and the nucleus of a carbon atom. The electron spin breaks down under a magnetic field created by the nanomagnet
column3: allowing it to become susceptible to entanglement. Once the two pieces are entangled
column4: meaning their physical characteristics are so intertwined they cannot be described individually
column5: a photon which holds quantum information is applied and the electron absorbs the photon. The absorption allows the polarization state of the photon to be transferred into the carbon
column6: which is mediated by the entangled electron
column7: demonstrating a teleportation of information at the quantum level.

column1: The success of the photon storage in the other node establishes the entanglement between two adjacent nodes
column2: Kosaka said. Called quantum repeaters
column3: the process can take individual chunks of information from node to node
column4: across the quantum field.

column1: Our ultimate goal is to realize scalable quantum repeaters for long-haul quantum communications and distributed quantum computers for large-scale quantum computation and metrology
column2: Kosaka said.";3020;['es8zlwb'

column1: ef43f8883015ee218167361e633f8079b5cd9ee16f0d0f3b43a69d364c82cf5f;posted_link;r/science;http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/30/science/scientists-report-finding-reliable-way-to-teleport-data.html?_r=1;['26u06z'];['liberationforce'];[1401408707.0];['Scientists achieve reliable quantum teleportation for first time'];[nan];2014-05-29;John Markoff;Scientists Report Finding Reliable Way to Teleport Data;"Scientists in the Netherlands have moved a step closer to overriding one of Albert Einstein’s most famous objections to the implications of quantum mechanics
column2: which he described as “spooky action at a distance.”

column1: In a paper published on Thursday in the journal Science
column2: physicists at the Kavli Institute of Nanoscience at the Delft University of Technology reported that they were able to reliably teleport information between two quantum bits separated by three meters
column3: or about 10 feet.

column1: Quantum teleportation is not the “Star Trek”-style movement of people or things; rather
column2: it involves transferring so-called quantum information — in this case what is known as the spin state of an electron — from one place to another without moving the physical matter to which the information is attached.

column1: Classical bits
column2: the basic units of information in computing
column3: can have only one of two values — either 0 or 1. But quantum bits
column4: or qubits
column5: can simultaneously describe many values. They hold out both the possibility of a new generation of faster computing systems and the ability to create completely secure communication networks.

column1: Moreover
column2: the scientists are now closer to definitively proving Einstein wrong in his early disbelief in the notion of entanglement
column3: in which particles separated by light-years can still appear to remain connected
column4: with the state of one particle instantaneously affecting the state of another.

column1: They report that they have achieved perfectly accurate teleportation of quantum information over short distances. They are now seeking to repeat their experiment over the distance of more than a kilometer. If they are able to repeatedly show that entanglement works at this distance
column2: it will be a definitive demonstration of the entanglement phenomenon and quantum mechanical theory.

column1: Succeeding at greater distances will offer an affirmative solution to a thought experiment known as Bell’s theorem
column2: proposed in 1964 by the Irish physicist John Stewart Bell as a method for determining whether particles connected via quantum entanglement communicate information faster than the speed of light.

column1: “There is a big race going on between five or six groups to prove Einstein wrong
column2: ” said Ronald Hanson
column3: a physicist who leads the group at Delft. “There is one very big fish.”

column1: In the past
column2: scientists have made halting gains in teleporting quantum information
column3: a feat that is achieved by forcing physically separated quantum bits into an entangled state.

column1: But reliability of quantum teleportation has been elusive. For example
column3: University of Maryland physicists demonstrated the transfer of quantum information
column4: but only one of every 100 million attempts succeeded
column5: meaning that transferring a single bit of quantum information required roughly 10 minutes.

column1: In contrast
column2: the scientists at Delft have achieved the ability “deterministically
column3: ” meaning they can now teleport the quantum state of two entangled electrons accurately 100 percent of the time.

column1: They did so by producing qubits using electrons trapped in diamonds at extremely low temperatures. According to Dr. Hanson
column2: the diamonds effectively create “miniprisons” in which the electrons were held. The researchers were able to establish a spin
column3: or value
column4: for electrons
column5: and then read the value reliably.

column1: In addition to the possibility of an impregnable quantum Internet
column2: the research holds out the possibility of networks of quantum computers.

column1: To date
column2: practical quantum computers
column3: which could solve certain classes of problems far more quickly than even the most powerful computers now in use
column4: remain a distant goal. A functional quantum computer would need to entangle a large number of qubits and maintain that entangled state for relatively long periods
column5: something that has so far not been achieved.

column1: A distributed quantum network might also offer new forms of privacy
column2: Dr. Hanson suggested. Such a network would make it possible for a remote user to perform a quantum calculation on a server
column3: while at the same time making it impossible for the operator of the server to determine the nature of the calculation.";4108;['chugknm'
