column1: 0dd45a56bdab6a6e4e45f49580dce6a1132ca5112ec93e557ecb479247e8b11e;posted_link;r/science;https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/trapping-the-tiniest-sound/;['cyg5vi'];['mvea'];[1567374951.0];['Researchers have gained control of the elusive “particle” of sound
column2: the phonon
column3: the smallest units of the vibrational energy that makes up sound waves. Using phonons
column4: instead of photons
column5: to store information in quantum computers may have advantages in achieving unprecedented processing power.'];[nan];2019-08-30;Leila Sloman;Trapping the Tiniest Sound;"Researchers have gained control of the elusive “particle” of sound
column6: the phonon. Although phonons—the smallest units of the vibrational energy that makes up sound waves—are not matter
column7: they can be considered particles the way photons are particles of light. Photons commonly store information in prototype quantum computers
column8: which aim to harness quantum effects to achieve unprecedented processing power. Using sound instead may have advantages
column9: although it would require manipulating phonons on very fine scales.

column1: Until recently
column2: scientists lacked this ability; just detecting an individual phonon destroyed it. Early methods involved converting phonons to electricity in quantum circuits called superconducting qubits. These circuits accept energy in specific amounts; if a phonon’s energy matches
column3: the circuit can absorb it—destroying the phonon but giving an energy reading of its presence.

column1: In a new study
column2: scientists at JILA (a collaboration between the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the University of Colorado Boulder) tuned the energy units of their superconducting qubit so phonons would not be destroyed. Instead the phonons sped up the current in the circuit
column3: thanks to a special material that created an electric field in response to vibrations. Experimenters could then detect how much change in current each phonon caused.

column1: “There’s been a lot of recent and impressive successes using superconducting qubits to control the quantum states of light. And we were curious—what can you do with sound that you can’t with light?” says Lucas Sletten of U.C. Boulder
column2: lead author of the study published in June in Physical Review X. One difference is speed: sound travels much slower than light. Sletten and his colleagues took advantage of this to coordinate circuit-phonon interactions that sped up the current. They trapped phonons of particular wavelengths (called modes) between two acoustic “mirrors
column3: ” which reflect sound
column4: and the relatively long time sound takes to make a round trip allowed the precise coordination. The mirrors were a hair’s width apart—similar control of light would require mirrors separated by about 12 meters.

column1: Sound’s “slowness” also let the experimenters identify phonons of more than one mode. Typically
column2: Sletten says
column3: quantum computers increase their capacity through additional superconducting qubits. But having just one qubit process information with multiple modes could achieve the same result.

column1: “This is definitely a milestone
column2: ” says Yiwen Chu
column3: a physicist at ETH Zurich
column4: who was not involved in the study. Analogous experiments with light were a first step toward much of today’s work on quantum computers
column5: she notes.

column1: Similar applications for sound are far off
column2: however: among other things
column3: scientists must find a way to keep phonons alive much longer than they currently can—about 600 nanoseconds. Eventually
column4: though
column5: the research could open new paths forward in quantum computing.";2943;['eyrw9lq'
column6: 'eys3fbe'

column1: 04e35243dba48f516aab2258ae8b4a0c138ffa820cb2b865adc59266909109a1;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://futurism.com/the-byte/oxford-physicist-unloads-quantum-computing;['x5d6j2'];['61-127-217-469-817'];[1662263453.0];"[""Oxford physicist unloads on quantum computing industry
column2: says it's basically a scam.""]";[nan];2022-09-03;Victor Tangermann;Oxford Physicist Unloads on Quantum Computing Industry
column3: Says It's Basically a Hype Bubble;"""In essence
column4: the quantum computing industry has yet to demonstrate any practical utility...""

column1: Seriously Though
Oxford quantum physicist Nikita Gourianov tore into the quantum computing industry this week
column2: comparing the ""fanfare"" around the tech to a financial bubble in a searing commentary piece for the Financial Times.

column1: In other words
column2: he wrote
column3: it's far more hype than substance.

column1: It's a scathing
column2: but also perhaps insightful
column3: analysis of a burgeoning field that
column4: at the very least
column5: still has a lot to prove.

column1: Cashing In
Despite billions of dollars being poured into quantum computing
column2: Gourianov argues
column3: the industry has yet to develop a single product that's actually capable of solving practical problems.

column1: That means these firms are collecting orders of magnitude more in financing than they're able to earn in actual revenue — a growing bubble that could eventually burst.
The little revenue they generate mostly comes from consulting missions aimed at teaching other companies about 'how quantum computers will help their business
column2: '"" Gourianov wrote for the FT
column3: ""as opposed to genuinely harnessing any advantages that quantum computers have over classical computers.""

column1: Contemporary quantum computers are also ""so error-prone that any information one tries to process with them will almost instantly degenerate into noise
column2: he wrote
column3: which scientists have been trying to overcome for years.

column1: Gourianov also took aim at other assumptions about the field
column2: arguing that fears over quantum computers being able to crack even the securest of cryptographic schemes are overblown.

column1: Notably
column2: the piece comes just weeks after a group of researchers found that a conventional computer was indeed able to rival Google's Sycamore quantum computer
column3: undermining the tech giant's 2019 claims of having achieved ""quantum supremacy.""

column1: Pure Hype
Despite the industry's less-than-stellar results
column2: investors are still funneling untold sums into quantum computing ventures.

column1: In essence
column2: the quantum computing industry has yet to demonstrate any practical utility
column3: despite the fanfare
column4: Gourianov wrote. ""Why is then so much money flowing in? Well
column5: it is mainly due to the fanfare.""

column1: The money
column2: he argues
column3: is coming from investors who typically don't have ""any understanding of quantum physics
column4: while ""taking senior positions in companies and focusing solely on generating fanfare.""

column1: In short
column2: Gourianov believes it's only a matter of time until the ""bubble will pop"" and the ""funding will dry up"" — at which point
column3: it's already too late.";2515;['in0ivb4'

column1: e5e5913e209aa268744c836418e9d7fe9d771edb641ba253ae2ec8e7e00f80b7;posted_link;r/science;http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2012-10/uov-qcr100212.php;['10vejc'];['wafedo'];[1349268767.0];"[""Quantum causal relations: A causes B causes A.  In quantum mechanics it's possible for an event to be both
column2: the cause and an effect of another one.""]";[nan];2012-10-02;;Quantum causal relations: A causes B causes A;"One of the most deeply rooted concepts in science and in our everyday life is causality; the idea that events in the present are caused by events in the past and
column3: in turn
column4: act as causes for what happens in the future. If an event A is a cause of an effect B
column5: then B cannot be a cause of A. Now theoretical physicists from the University of Vienna and the Université Libre de Bruxelles have shown that in quantum mechanics it is possible to conceive situations in which a single event can be both
column6: a cause and an effect of another one. The findings will be published this week in ""Nature Communications"".

column1: Although it is still not known if such situations can be actually found in nature
column2: the sheer possibility that they could exist may have far-reaching implications for the foundations of quantum mechanics
column3: quantum gravity and quantum computing.

column1: Causal relations: who influences whom
In everyday life and in classical physics
column2: events are ordered in time: a cause can only influence an effect in its future not in its past. As a simple example
column3: imagine a person
column4: Alice
column5: walking into a room and finding there a piece of paper. After reading what is written on the paper Alice erases the message and leaves her own message on the piece of paper. Another person
column6: Bob
column7: walks into the same room at some other time and does the same: he reads
column8: erases and re-writes some message on the paper. If Bob enters the room after Alice
column9: he will be able to read what she wrote; however Alice will not have a chance to know Bob's message. In this case
column10: Alice's writing is the ""cause"" and what Bob reads the ""effect"". Each time the two repeat the procedure
column11: only one will be able to read what the other wrote. Even if they don't have watches and don't know who enters the room first
column12: they can deduce it by what they write and read on the paper. For example
column13: Alice might write ""Alice was here today""
column14: such that if Bob reads the message
column15: he will know that he came to the room after her.

column1: Quantum violation of causal order
As long as only the laws of classical physics are allowed
column2: the order of events is fixed: either Bob or Alice is first to enter the room and leave a message for the other person. When quantum mechanics enters into play
column3: however
column4: the picture may change drastically. According to quantum mechanics
column5: objects can lose their well-defined classical properties
column6: such as e.g. a particle that can be at two different locations at the same time. In quantum physics this is called a ""superposition"". Now an international team of physicists led by Caslav Brukner from the University of Vienna have shown that even the causal order of events could be in such a superposition. If - in our example - Alice and Bob have a quantum system instead of an ordinary piece of paper to write their messages on
column7: they can end up in a situation where each of them can read a part of the message written by the other. Effectively
column8: one has a superposition of two situations: ""Alice enters the room first and leaves a message before Bob"" and ""Bob enters the room first and leaves a message before Alice"".

column1: Such a superposition
column2: however
column3: has not been considered in the standard formulation of quantum mechanics since the theory always assumes a definite causal order between events""
column4: says Ognyan Oreshkov from the Université Libre de Bruxelles (formerly University of Vienna). ""But if we believe that quantum mechanics governs all phenomena
column5: it is natural to expect that the order of events could also be indefinite
column6: similarly to the location of a particle or its velocity""
column7: adds Fabio Costa from the University of Vienna.

column1: The work provides an important step towards understanding that definite causal order might not be a mandatory property of nature. ""The real challenge is finding out where in nature we should look for superpositions of causal orders""
column2: explains Caslav Brukner from the Quantum Optics
column3: Quantum Nanophysics
column4: Quantum Information group of the University of Vienna.";3950;['c6h0u2s'
column5: 'c6h17lt'
column6: 'c6h18zp'

column1: aaaaf2d45e8707f0312b069aef2fdad270d8ff400062152fa25e2bba9d6b1c8e;posted_link;r/science;http://www.livescience.com/17264-quantum-entanglement-macroscopic-diamonds.html;['mwole'];['skreendreamz1'];[1322778246.0];['Two diamonds linked by strange quantum entanglement.'];[nan];2011-12-01;Clara Moskowitz;Two Diamonds Linked by Strange Quantum Entanglement;"Scientists have linked two diamonds in a mysterious process called entanglement that is normally only seen on the quantum scale.

Entanglement is so weird that Einstein dubbed it ""spooky action at a distance."" It's a strange effect where one object gets connected to another so that even if they are separated by large distances
column2: an action performed on one will affect the other. Entanglement usually occurs with subatomic particles
column3: and was predicted by the theory of quantum mechanics
column4: which governs the realm of the very small.

column1: But now physicists have succeeded in entangling two macroscopic diamonds
column2: demonstrating that quantum mechanical effects are not limited to the microscopic scale.

column1: I think it's an important step into a new regime of thinking about quantum phenomena
column2: physicist Ian Walmsley of England's University of Oxford said.""That is
column3: in this regime of the bigger world
column4: room temperatures
column5: ambient conditions. Although the phenomenon was expected to exist
column6: actually being able to observe it in such a system we think is quite exciting."" [Twisted Physics: 7 Mind-Blowing Findings]

column1: Another study recently used quantum entanglement to teleport bits of light from one place to another. And other researchers have succeeded in entangling macroscopic objects before
column2: but they have generally been under special circumstances
column3: prepared in special ways
column4: and cooled to cryogenic temperatures. In the new achievement
column5: the diamonds were large and not prepared in any special way
column6: the researchers said.

column1: It's big enough you can see it
column2: Walmsley told LiveScience of the diamonds.""They're sitting on the table
column3: out in plain view. The laboratory isn't particularly cold or particularly hot
column4: it's just your everyday room.""

column1: Walmsley
column2: along with a team of physicists led by Oxford graduate student Ka Chung Lee
column3: accomplished this feat by entangling the vibration of two diamond crystals. To do so
column4: the researchers set up an apparatus to send a laser pulse at both diamonds simultaneously. Sometimes
column5: the laser light changed color
column6: to a lower frequency
column7: after hitting the diamonds. That told the scientists it had lost a bit of energy.

column1: Because energy must be conserved in closed systems (where there's no input of outside energy)
column2: the researchers knew that the ""lost"" energy had been used in some way. In fact
column3: the energy had been converted into vibrational motion for one of the diamonds (albeit motion that is too small to observe visually). However
column4: the scientists had no way of knowing which diamond was vibrating.

column1: Then
column2: the researchers sent a second pulse of laser light through the now-vibrating system. This time
column3: if the light emerged with a color of higher frequency
column4: it meant it had gained the energy back by absorbing it from the diamond
column5: stopping its vibration.

column1: The scientists had set up two separate detectors to measure the laser light — one for each diamond.
If the two diamonds weren't entangled
column2: the researchers would expect each detector to register a changed laser beam about 50 percent of the time. It's similar to tossing a coin
column3: where random chance would lead to heads about half the time and tails the other half the time on average.

column1: Instead
column2: because the two diamonds were linked
column3: they found that one detector measured the change every time
column4: and the other detector never fired. The two diamonds
column5: it seemed
column6: were so connected they reacted as a single entity

column1: Recent advances in quantum control techniques have allowed entanglement to be observed for physical systems with increasing complexity and separation distance
column2: University of Michigan physicist Luming Duan
column3: who was not involved in the study
column4: wrote in an accompanying essay in the same issue of Science.""Lee et al. take an important step in this direction by demonstrating entanglement between oscillation patterns of atoms—phonon modes—of two diamond samples of millimeter size at room temperature
column5: separated by a macroscopic distance of about 15 cm.""

column1: In addition to furthering scientists' understanding of entanglement
column2: the research could help develop faster computers called photonic processors
column3: relying on quantum effects
column4: said Oxford physicist Michael Sprague
column5: another team member on the project.

column1: The long-term goal is that if you can harness the power of quantum phenomena
column2: you can potentially do things more efficiently than is currently possible
column3: Sprague said.";4384;['c34g4xj'

column1: 90b2e04127e573538a9ed494b35a8632aa8b90bb676c66425dfe3c1f1ac289b5;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.zdnet.com/article/researchers-created-an-un-hackable-quantum-network-over-hundreds-of-kilometers-using-optical-fiber/;['ny3g3u'];['izumi3682'];[1623492458.0];"[""Researchers create an 'un-hackable' quantum network over hundreds of kilometers using optical fiber - Toshiba's research team has broken a new record for optical fiber-based quantum communications
column2: thanks to a new technology called dual band stabilization.""]";[nan];2021-06-10;Daphne Leprince-Ringuet;Researchers create an 'un-hackable' quantum network over hundreds of kilometers using optical fiber;"Researchers from Toshiba have successfully sent quantum information over 600-kilometer-long optical fibers
column3: creating a new distance record and paving the way for large-scale quantum networks that could be used to exchange information securely between cities and even countries.

column1: Working from the company's R&D lab in Cambridge in the UK
column2: the scientists demonstrated that they could transmit quantum bits (or qubits) over hundreds of kilometers of optical fiber without scrambling the fragile quantum data encoded in the particles
column3: thanks to a new technology that stabilizes the environmental fluctuations occurring in the fiber.

column1: This could go a long way in helping to create a next-generation quantum internet that scientists hope will one day span global distances.
The quantum internet
column2: which will take the shape of a global network of quantum devices connected by long-distance quantum communication links
column3: is expected to enable use-cases that are impossible with today's web applications. They range from generating virtually un-hackable communications
column4: to creating clusters of inter-connected quantum devices that together could surpass the compute power of classical devices.

column1: But in order to communicate
column2: quantum devices need to send and receive qubits – tiny particles that exist in a special
column3: but extremely fragile
column4: quantum state. Finding the best way to transmit qubits without having them fall from their quantum state has got scientists around the world scratching their heads for many years.

column1: One approach consists of shooting qubits down optical fibers that connect quantum devices. The method has been successful but is limited in scale: small changes in the environment
column2: such as temperature fluctuations
column3: cause the fibers to expand and contract
column4: and risk messing with the qubits.

column1: This is why experiments with optical fiber
column2: until now
column3: have typically been limited to a range of hundreds of kilometers; in other words
column4: nowhere near enough to create the large-scale
column5: global quantum internet dreamed up by scientists.

column1: To tackle the instable conditions inside optical fibers
column2: Toshiba's researchers developed a new technique called ""dual band stabilization"". The method sends two signals down the optical fiber at different wavelengths. The first wavelength is used to cancel out rapidly varying fluctuations
column3: while the second wavelength
column4: which is at the same wavelength as the qubits
column5: is used for finer adjustments of the phase.

column1: Put simply
column2: the two wavelengths combine to cancel environmental fluctuations inside the fiber in real time
column3: which according to Toshiba's researchers
column4: enabled qubits to travel safely over 600 kilometers.

column1: Already
column2: the company's team has used the technology to trial one of the most well-known applications of quantum networks: quantum-based encryption.

column1: Known as Quantum Key Distribution (QKD)
column2: the protocol leverages quantum networks to create security keys that are impossible to hack
column3: meaning that users can securely exchange confidential information
column4: like bank statements or health records
column5: over an untrusted communication channel such as the internet.

column1: During a communication
column2: QKD works by having one of the two parties encrypt a piece of data by encoding the cryptography key onto qubits and sending those qubits over to the other person thanks to a quantum network. Because of the laws of quantum mechanics
column3: however
column4: it is impossible for a spy to intercept the qubits without leaving a sign of eavesdropping that can be seen by the users – who
column5: in turn
column6: can take steps to protect the information.

column1: Unlike classical cryptography
column2: therefore
column3: QKD does not rely on the mathematical complexity of solving security keys
column4: but rather leverages the laws of physics. This means that even the most powerful computers would be unable to hack the qubits-based keys. It is easy to see why the idea is gathering the attention of players from all parts
column5: ranging from financial institutions to intelligence agencies.

column1: Toshiba's new technique to reduce fluctuations in optical fibers enabled the researchers to carry out QKD over a much larger distance than previously possible. ""This is a very exciting result
column2: said Mirko Pittaluga
column3: research scientist at Toshiba Europe. ""With the new techniques we have developed
column4: further extensions of the communication distance for QKD are still possible and our solutions can also be applied to other quantum communications protocols and applications.""

column1: When it comes to carrying out QKD using optical fiber
column2: Toshiba's 600-kilometer mark is a record-breaker
column3: which the company predicts will enable secure links to be created between cities like London
column4: Paris
column5: Brussels
column6: Amsterdam and Dublin.

column1: Other research groups
column2: however
column3: have focused on different methods to transmit qubits
column4: which have enabled QKD to happen over even larger distances. Chinese scientists
column5: for example
column6: are using a mix of satellite-based transmissions communicating with optical fibers on the ground
column7: and recently succeeded in carrying out QKD over a total distance of 4

column1: Every approach has its pros and cons: using satellite technologies is more costly and could be harder to scale up. But one thing is certain: research groups in the UK
column2: China and the US are experimenting at pace to make quantum networks become a reality.

column1: Toshiba's research was partially funded by the EU
column2: which is showing a keen interest in developing quantum communications. Meanwhile
column3: China's latest five-year plan also allocates a special place for quantum networks; and the US recently published a blueprint laying out a step-by-step guide leading to the establishment of a global quantum internet.";5616;['h1i7tsd'

column1: 6cf1a48706f28308760b04053772040ba97f659d4952fad22dc478cc019ee4af;posted_link;r/science;http://arstechnica.com/science/2012/08/open-air-quantum-teleportation-performed-across-a-97km-lake/;['xxz59'];['lazyink'];[1344527069.0];['Open-air quantum teleportation has been performed across a 97km lake. It only works at night
column2: but the technique sets a new distance record.'];[nan];2012-08-09;Matthew Francis;Open-air quantum teleportation performed across a 97km lake;"Sending signals through fiber optic cable is reliable and fast
column3: but because of internal absorption and other effects
column4: they will lose photons—which is a problem when the number of photons being sent is small. This is of particular concern in quantum networks
column5: which typically involve a small number of entangled photons. Direct transmission through free space (vacuum or air) experiences less photon loss
column6: but it's very difficult to align a distant receiver perfectly with the transmitter so that photons arrive at their destination.

column1: A group in China has made significant progress toward solving that problem
column2: via a high accuracy pointing and tracking system. Using this method
column3: Juan Yin and colleagues performed quantum teleportation (copying of a quantum state) using multiple entangled photons through open air between two stations 97 kilometers apart across a lake. Additionally
column4: they demonstrated entanglement between two receivers separated by 101.8km
column5: transmitted by a station on an island roughly halfway between them.

column1: Though the authors do not make this clear in the paper
column2: their method is currently limited to nighttime communication. Nevertheless
column3: their results achieved larger distances for multi-photon teleportation and three-point entanglement than before
column4: and the tracking system used may even enable ground-to-satellite quantum communication—at least if it happens at night.

column1: Quantum communication requires transmitting an arbitrary quantum state between two points
column2: similar to how ordinary communication sends bits (voice or other data) across distances. However
column3: a quantum state is a small amount of information
column4: typically carried by a single photon
column5: so many methods used in ordinary communication are out of the question (including broadcasting).

column1: In fiber optic quantum networks
column2: photon loss is large over significant distances
column3: requiring the use of quantum repeaters. Point-to-point free-space transmission—either open-air or through the vacuum of space—is better
column4: though larger distances allow the beam of photons to disperse. Atmospheric turbulence also contributes to photon loss in the air
column5: with the losses increasing the farther the signal must travel.

column1: One of the biggest challenges in point-to-point communication
column2: however
column3: is target acquisition by the transmitter and/or receiver. If the ground shifts slightly due to settling or tectonic activity
column4: or atmospheric turbulence makes the receiver appear to move
column5: the laser transmitting the signal can miss its target entirely. With few photons to spare in quantum communication
column6: real-time tracking and acquisition is necessary. The researchers solved this problem using beacon lasers
column7: bright beams that carry no information
column8: but can be used to aim both transmitter and receiver

column1: As usual in quantum entanglement experiments
column2: the group created entangled photons by stimulating a crystal with ultraviolet light. This produces a pair of photons with the same wavelength
column3: but opposite (and unknown) polarization values. These entangled photons were subsequently sent to detectors
column4: where their polarization quantum states were measured and compared. In the first experiment
column5: one photon was sent 97km across Qinghai Lake (using a telescope to focus the beam)
column6: while the second was analyzed locally. Using these photons
column7: the researchers copied the quantum state from the laboratory to the far station
column8: achieving quantum teleportation over a much larger distance than previously obtained.

column1: However
column2: quantum communication sometimes also requires coordination between two distant receivers
column3: so the researchers set up the transmitter on an island in the lake. The receivers were 51.2 and 52.2 km from the photon source respectively
column4: on opposite shores of Qinghai lake
column5: forming a triangle with the transmitter. The distance between the receivers—101.8km—was far enough to create a 3 microsecond delay between measurements of the photon polarization.

column1: Given this setup
column2: there was no possible way for the two receiving stations to communicate. Yet the photons they registered were correlated
column3: indicating entanglement was maintained.

column1: These experiments provide not only a proof of principle for free-space quantum communication
column2: but also a means to test the foundations of quantum theory over larger distances than before. With very large detector separation
column3: quantum entanglement experiments can help differentiate between standard and alternative interpretations of the quantum theory.

column1: Though the long-distance aspect is promising
column2: the fact that they set up on the shores of a lake (where no intervening obstacles exist) and that the experiment could only be performed successfully at night indicate its limitations. Author Yuao Chen told Ars via e-mail that they are working on solving the problem for daytime communication
column3: but since the signal consists of single photons
column4: it's not clear how this will work—the number of received photons fluctuated with the position of the Moon
column5: so noise appeared to be a significant problem for them. Point-to-point communication will need to solve that problem as well before satellite-to-ground quantum networks are practical.";5146;['c5qjyq6'
column6: 'c5qnz3d'

column1: fec93fbbb4ba66468152150231edd532fbde851a49940ce90ecaa692f460f34d;posted_link;r/science;http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn22336-quantum-measurements-leave-schrodingers-cat-alive.html;['10yemu'];['Aurolyn'];[1349383039.0];"[""Schrödinger's Cat is Alive! Scientists measure a system's quantum state without collapsing its superposition""]";[nan];2012-10-03;"Author Fullname; Lisa Grossman";Quantum measurements leave Schrödinger's cat alive;"Schrödinger’s cat
column2: the enduring icon of quantum mechanics
column3: has been defied. By making constant but weak measurements of a quantum system
column4: physicists have managed to probe a delicate quantum state without destroying it – the equivalent of taking a peek at Schrodinger’s metaphorical cat without killing it. The result should make it easier to handle systems such as quantum computers that exploit the exotic properties of the quantum world.

column1: Quantum objects have the bizarre but useful property of being able to exist in multiple states at once
column2: a phenomenon called superposition. Physicist Erwin Schrödinger illustrated the strange implications of superposition by imagining a cat in a box whose fate depends on a radioactive atom. Because the atom’s decay is governed by quantum mechanics – and so only takes a definite value when it is measured – the cat is
column3: somehow
column4: both dead and alive until the box is opened.

column1: Superposition could
column2: in theory
column3: let quantum computers run calculations in parallel by holding information in quantum bits. Unlike ordinary bits
column4: these qubits don’t take a value of 1 or 0
column5: but instead exist as a mixture of the two
column6: only settling on a definite value of 1 or 0 when measured.

column1: But this ability to destroy superpositions simply by peeking at them makes systems that depend on this property fragile. That has been a stumbling block for would-be quantum computer scientists
column2: who need quantum states to keep it together long enough to do calculations.

column1: Gentle measurement
Researchers had suggested it should be possible
column2: in principle
column3: to make measurements that are “gentle” enough not to destroy the superposition. The idea was to measure something less direct than whether the bit is a 1 or a 0 – the equivalent of looking at Schrödinger’s cat through blurry glasses. This wouldn’t allow you to gain a “strong” piece of information – whether the cat was alive or dead – but you might be able to detect other properties.

column1: Now
column2: R. Vijay of the University of California
column3: Berkeley
column4: and colleagues have managed to create a working equivalent of those blurry glasses. “We only partially open the box
column5: ” says Vijay.

column1: The team started with a tiny superconducting circuit commonly used as a qubit in quantum computers
column2: and put it in a superposition by cycling its state between 0 and 1 so that it repeatedly hit all the possible mixtures of states.

column1: Next
column2: the team measured the frequency of this oscillation. This is inherently a weaker measurement than determining whether the bit took on the value of 1 or 0 at any point
column3: so the thought was that it might be possible to do this without forcing the qubit to choose between a 1 or a 0. However
column4: it also introduced a complication.

column1: Quantum pacemaker
Even though the measurement was gentle enough not to destroy the quantum superposition
column2: the measurement did randomly change the oscillation rate. This couldn’t be predicted
column3: but the team was able to make the measurement very quickly
column4: allowing the researchers to inject an equal but opposite change into the system that returned the qubit’s frequency to the value it would have had if it had not been measured at all.

column1: This feedback is similar to what happens in a pacemaker: if the system drifts too far from the desired state
column2: whether that’s a steady heartbeat or a superposition of ones and zeros
column3: you can nudge it back towards where it should be.

column1: Vijay’s team was not the first to come up with this idea of using feedback to probe a quantum system
column2: but the limiting factor in the past had been that measurements weak enough to preserve the system gave signals too small to detect and correct
column3: while bigger measurements introduced noise into the system that was too big to control.

column1: Error correction

Vijay and colleagues used a new kind of amplifier that let them turn up the signal without contaminating it. They found that their qubit stayed in its oscillating state for the entire run of the experiment. That was only about a hundredth of a second – but
column2: crucially
column3: it meant that the qubit had survived the measuring process.

column1: “This demonstration shows we are almost there
column2: in terms of being able to implement quantum error controls
column3: ” Vijay says. Such controls could be used to prolong the superpositions of qubits in quantum computing
column4: he says
column5: by automatically nudging qubits that were about to collapse.

column1: The result is not perfect
column2: points out Howard Wiseman of Griffith University in Brisbane
column3: Australia
column4: in an article accompanying the team’s paper. “But compared with the no-feedback result of complete unpredictability within several microseconds
column5: the observed stabilization of the qubit’s cycling is a big step forward in the feedback control of an individual qubit.”";4682;['c6hpq6v'

column1: b1ccad944a7f32a07834d7b41ed7590ed6ce09067b5c2838c7073851423bc53a;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2022-10-brains-quantum.html;['y8ufdr'];['izumi3682'];[1666261389.0];['New research suggests our brains use quantum computation'];[nan];2022-10-19;Trinity College Dublin;New research suggests our brains use quantum computation;"New research suggests our brains use quantum computation

Scientists from Trinity College Dublin believe our brains could use quantum computation. Their discovery comes after they adapted an idea developed to prove the existence of quantum gravity to explore the human brain and its workings.
The brain functions measured were also correlated to short-term memory performance and conscious awareness
column2: suggesting quantum processes are also part of cognitive and conscious brain functions.

column1: If the team's results can be confirmed—likely requiring advanced multidisciplinary approaches—they would enhance our general understanding of how the brain works and potentially how it can be maintained or even healed. They may also help find innovative technologies and build even more advanced quantum computers.
Dr. Christian Kerskens
column2: lead physicist at the Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience (TCIN)
column3: is the co-author of the research article that has just been published in the Journal of Physics Communications. He said
column4: ""We adapted an idea
column5: developed for experiments to prove the existence of quantum gravity
column6: whereby you take known quantum systems
column7: which interact with an unknown system. If the known systems entangle
column8: then the unknown must be a quantum system
column9: too. It circumvents the difficulties to find measuring devices for something we know nothing about.

column1: For our experiments we used proton spins of 'brain water' as the known system. 'Brain water' builds up naturally as fluid in our brains and the proton spins can be measured using MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). Then
column2: by using a specific MRI design to seek entangled spins
column3: we found MRI signals that resemble heartbeat evoked potentials
column4: a form of EEG signals. EEGs measure electrical brain currents
column5: which some people may recognize from personal experience or simply from watching hospital dramas on TV.""

column1: Electrophysiological potentials like the heartbeat evoked potentials are normally not detectable with MRI and the scientists believe they could only observe them because the nuclear proton spins in the brain were entangled.
Dr. Kerskens added
column2: ""If entanglement is the only possible explanation here then that would mean that brain processes must have interacted with the nuclear spins
column3: mediating the entanglement between the nuclear spins. As a result
column4: we can deduce that those brain functions must be quantum.

column1: Because these brain functions were also correlated to short-term memory performance and conscious awareness
column2: it is likely that those quantum processes are an important part of our cognitive and conscious brain functions.

column1: Quantum brain processes could explain why we can still outperform supercomputers when it comes to unforeseen circumstances
column2: decision making
column3: or learning something new. Our experiments
column4: performed only 50 meters away from the lecture theater where Schrödinger presented his famous thoughts about life
column5: may shed light on the mysteries of biology
column6: and on consciousness which scientifically is even harder to grasp.""";3015;['iszyxzm'

column1: 62077eaa137927fb40efd79dc9a4cf05f576c2302224d6c0dfa4abaf9454f495;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.chinadailyhk.com/article/271882;['us6tek'];['ICSSH'];[1652856496.0];"[""China launches 'unhackable'
column2: quantum-secured smartphone""]";[nan];2022-05-17;Xinhua;China launches 'unhackable'
column3: quantum-secured smartphone;"BEIJING - A Chinese telecom service provider rolled off a smartphone using quantum tech that can ensure the user chat on the device is almost ""unhackable.""

column1: Launched by China Telecom
column2: Tianyi No 1 2022 is a smartphone mounted with a quantum-secured encryption module and purpose-built SIM card that can encrypt and decipher voice calls on the phone using the quantum key distribution
column3: Science Daily reported Tuesday.

column1: Chinese scientists
column2: some of whom were part of the founding team of QuantumCTeck
column3: tested the quantum key distribution with the world's first quantum satellite Micius launched in August 2016

column1: The telecom giant and the startup QuantumCTeck set up a joint venture in 2021 to develop quantum-based communication and bring the ingenious know-how to market.
Chinese scientists
column2: some of whom were part of the founding team of QuantumCTeck
column3: tested the quantum key distribution with the world's first quantum satellite Micius launched in August 2016.

column1: Unlike traditional cryptography
column2: the technology uses single photons in quantum superposition states by which the key is embedded to guarantee unconditional security between distant parties.

column1: Quantum superposition is a fundamental principle of quantum mechanics
column2: stating that
column3: much like waves in classical physics
column4: any two or more quantum states can be added together.

column1: The communication is
column2: therefore
column3: ""unhackable"" as any attempt to intercept the key would be known immediately both to the sender and the intended recipient.

column1: When a user initiates a quantum-secured chat
column2: a secret key will be generated at random to verify his or her identity
column3: said Zhang Rutong
column4: an engineer with QuantumCTeck. ""After verification
column5: the quantum network will generate a new real-time key to encrypt voice data.""

column1: The key is randomly generated
column2: hard to crack and discarded immediately after calling
column3: Zhang added.

column1: The service is available when both senders and recipients use the quantum-based phone.";1934;['i91on7i'

column1: a950a8970ee56a73929725650036db031ca30585e56c600c84b28bf96f82ff81;posted_link;r/technews;https://phys.org/news/2022-04-ancient-namibian-stone-key-future.html#amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&aoh=16503410537393&csi=0&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fphys.org%2Fnews%2F2022-04-ancient-namibian-stone-key-future.html;['u6w5xr'];['MichaelTen'];[1650341091.0];['Ancient Namibian stone could hold key to future quantum computers'];[nan];2022-04-15;University;Ancient Namibian stone could hold key to future quantum computers;"Ancient Namibian stone could hold key to future quantum computers
A special form of light made using an ancient Namibian gemstone could be the key to new light-based quantum computers
column2: which could solve long-held scientific mysteries
column3: according to new research led by the University of St Andrews.

column1: The research
column2: conducted in collaboration with scientists at Harvard University in the US
column3: Macquarie University in Australia and Aarhus University in Denmark and published in Nature Materials
column4: used a naturally mined cuprous oxide (Cu2O) gemstone from Namibia to produce Rydberg polaritons
column5: the largest hybrid particles of light and matter ever created.

column1: Rydberg polaritons switch continually from light to matter and back again. In Rydberg polaritons
column2: light and matter are like two sides of a coin
column3: and the matter side is what makes polaritons interact with each other.

column1: This interaction is crucial because this is what allows the creation of quantum simulators
column2: a special type of quantum computer
column3: where information is stored in quantum bits. These quantum bits
column4: unlike the binary bits in classical computers that can only be 0 or 1
column5: can take any value between 0 and 1. They can therefore store much more information and perform several processes simultaneously.

column1: This capability could allow quantum simulators to solve important mysteries of physics
column2: chemistry and biology
column3: for example
column4: how to make high-temperature superconductors for highspeed trains
column5: how cheaper fertilizers could be made potentially solving global hunger
column6: or how proteins fold making it easier to produce more effective drugs.

column1: Project lead Dr. Hamid Ohadi
column2: of the School of Physics and Astronomy at the University of St Andrews
column3: says that ""making a quantum simulator with light is the holy grail of science. We have taken a huge leap towards this by creating Rydberg polaritons
column4: the key ingredient of it.""

column1: To create Rydberg polaritons
column2: the researchers trapped light between two highly reflective mirrors. A cuprous oxide crystal from a stone mined in Namibia was then thinned and polished to a 30-micrometer thick slab (thinner than a strand of human hair) and sandwiched between the two mirrors to make Rydberg polaritons 100 times larger than ever demonstrated before.

column1: One of the leading authors Dr. Sai Kiran Rajendran
column2: of the School of Physics and Astronomy at the University of St Andrews
column3: says that ""purchasing the stone on eBay was easy. The challenge was to make Rydberg polaritons that exist in an extremely narrow color range.""

column1: The team is currently further refining these methods in order to explore the possibility of making quantum circuits
column2: which are the next ingredient for quantum simulators.";2675;['i5ax7xn'

column1: 88770fb2890ab53c9458f6dcdb117605543d8574f331dbbd442bb23a8b60977b;posted_link;r/science;https://physics.aps.org/articles/v15/29;['t1l724'];['MistWeaver80'];[1645841448.0];['Euler’s 243-Year-Old mathematical puzzle that is known to have no classical solution has been found to be soluble if the objects being arrayed in a square grid show quantum behavior. It involves finding a way to arrange objects in a grid so that their properties don’t repeat in any row or column.'];[nan];2022-02-25;Philip Ball;A Quantum Solution to an 18th-Century Puzzle;"A Quantum Solution to an 18th-Century Puzzle
A sudoku-style mathematical puzzle that is known to have no classical solution has been found to be soluble if the objects being arrayed in a square grid show quantum behavior [1]. The problem
column2: posed by Swiss mathematician Leonard Euler in 1779
column3: involves finding a way to arrange objects in a grid so that their properties don’t repeat in any row or column. The quantum solution might be useful for problems in quantum information processing
column4: such as creating algorithms for correcting errors in quantum computing.

column1: Euler imagined a group of 36 army officers
column2: six from each of six regiments
column3: with each officer having one of six different ranks. Can they be arranged in a square formation such that no regiment or rank is repeated in any row or column?

column1: Solutions can be found for all squares (
column3: and so on
column4: assuming the appropriate number of officers) except for and Euler’s case of . In 1900
column5: the impossibility of a solution was proven by the French mathematician Gaston Tarry. But Suhail Rather of the Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IITM)
column6: Adam Burchardt of Jagiellonian University in Poland
column7: and their colleagues wondered if the problem could be solved if the objects were quantum mechanical instead of classical. Then the objects could be placed in combinations (superpositions) of the various possible states: a single officer could be
column9: partially a colonel from the red regiment and partially a lieutenant from the blue regiment.

column1: This quantum version requires an adjusted definition of when two such states can be considered “different.” Quantum superpositions can be represented as vectors in the space of possible states of the components
column2: and the team assumed that two superpositions are mutually exclusive if their vectors are perpendicular (orthogonal) to one another.

column1: The researchers used a computer algorithm to search for such quantum solutions of Euler’s “36 officers” problem. They started from a classical configuration that had only a few repetitions in the rows and columns and tried to improve it by adding in superposition. They found that a full quantum solution to the problem exists for a particular set of superposition states.
A superposition between two quantum objects often implies that they are entangled: their properties are interdependent and correlated. If
column2: say
column3: one quantum officer is found (on inspection) to be a colonel
column4: the other with which it is entangled might have to be a lieutenant. The quantum solution requires a complicated set of entanglements between officers
column5: reminiscent of the entanglements created between quantum bits (qubits) in quantum computing.

column1: The researchers realized that their solution is closely related to a problem in quantum information processing involving “absolutely maximally entangled” (AME) states
column2: in which the correlation between any pair of entangled qubits in the group is as strong as it can possibly be. Such states are relevant to quantum error correction
column3: where errors in a quantum computation must be identified and corrected without actually reading out the states of the qubits. AME states are also important in quantum teleportation
column4: where the quantum state of one particle in an entangled pair is recreated in the other particle.

column1: Qubits have two possible readout states
column2: 0 and 1
column3: but quantum objects can
column4: in principle
column5: also have three (qutrits) or more states. Theorists have derived mathematical expressions for AME states for different-sized groups of quantum objects
column6: but an AME state for four six-state objects (so-called quhex objects
column7: like quantum dice) has proven curiously elusive. Rather and colleagues found that their quantum solution to the Euler problem shows how to entangle four quantum dice to also produce this so-called AME(4
column8: 6) solution. The lack of an AME(4
column9: 6) state had been puzzling to theorists
column10: but the solution required an approach that had not been previously considered. The result shows a new design principle for creating states with entangled particles
column11: an essential element of error-correcting codes
column12: says team member Arul Lakshminarayan of the IITM.

column1: Finding the AME(4
column2: 6) state solves “a problem that has been investigated by several researchers within the last few years
column3: ” says quantum information theorist Barbara Kraus of the University of Innsbruck in Austria. Quantum technologist Hoi-Kwong Lo of the University of Toronto says the work is potentially significant. “The argument looks plausible to me
column4: and if the result is correct
column5: I think it is very important
column6: with implications for quantum error correction.” But he admits that it’s not easy to understand intuitively why the six-state case turns out to be so special
column7: both for Euler’s problem and for the AME states.";4747;['hyguxo3'

column1: 1ffa4c02919bc8849f4df1fe7d2369a0bc2c2bc7c15049fe8aef672884223c63;posted_link;r/science;http://qz.com/121143/toshiba-has-invented-a-quantum-cryptography-network-that-even-the-nsa-cant-hack/;['1luenb'];['nastratin'];[1378460037.0];['Toshiba has invented a quantum cryptography network that even the NSA can’t hack'];[nan];2013-09-04;Bernhard Warner;Toshiba has invented a quantum cryptography network that even the NSA can’t hack;"If you’ve got communications that absolutely cannot be intercepted—whether you’re a NSA whistleblower
column2: the president of Mexico
column3: or Coca-Cola—quantum cryptography is the way to go.

column1: It harnesses the bizarro-world properties of quantum physics to ensure that information sent from point A to point B isn’t intercepted. The laws of physics dictate that nobody—not even the NSA—can measure a quantum system without disrupting it.
The problem
column2: as Edward Snowden could probably tell you
column3: is that quantum cryptography is still in its infancy. It only works over relatively short distances
column4: and the required gear—including lasers and a dedicated fiber optic network—is prohibitively expensive
column5: limiting its use to a handful of research labs
column6: corporations and governments.

column1: A new research paper from scientists at Toshiba brings quantum cryptography a baby-step closer to the masses. The paper
column2: published today in Nature
column3: explains how to expand a point-to-point quantum network with only two users into a “quantum access network” with up to 64 users.

column1: “This kind of communication cannot be defeated by future advances in computing power
column2: nor new mathematical algorithms
column3: nor fancy new engineering
column4: ” said co-author Andrew Shields
column5: head of the Quantum Information Group of Toshiba Research Europe. “As long as the laws of physics hold true
column6: it will ensure that your communications are fully secured.”

column1: A quantum network uses specially polarized photons to encode an encryption key—a very long series of numbers and letters that can unlock a digital file. The photons are then sent down a fiber optic cable until they reach their destination
column2: a photon detector
column3: which counts them
column4: and delivers the key to the intended recipient. If the photons are interfered with
column5: the individual packets of information are forever altered and the recipient can see the telltale signs of tampering.

column1: The Toshiba team focused its efforts on improving the photon detector
column2: and created a system that counts up to 1 billion photons per second
column3: which makes it feasible to add more people to the network. “Our breakthrough is we’ve developed an architecture that is point-to-multipoint. This greatly increase the number of potential users in the network
column4: and reduces costs
column5: ” Shields said.

column1: Current quantum cryptography systems from companies like ID Quantique start at around $50
column3: and only connect two parties at a time. “If up to 64 people can share a single photon detector than you can spread out those costs
column4: ” Shields said.

column1: The next step toward mainstreaming quantum crypto is increasing the distance that photons can travel before they degrade—currently the record is 200 km (124 miles) using a dedicated fiber optic cable. But researchers are working on ways to transmit quantum bits on so-called “noisy” fiber that carries other information
column2: which means that the day may not be far away when your Gmail may have a quantum key.

column1: Until then
column2: it’s probably safer to assume that Big Brother is listening.";2969;['cc2v7im'

column1: 41fe5477fb1215e2fe84fc6052c9b38fea7b9fe4b9c55595eadf5d47f91222df;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/ai-designs-quantum-physics-experiments-beyond-what-any-human-has-conceived/;['oc9n1n'];['Gari_305'];[1625230940.0];['AI Designs Quantum Physics Experiments Beyond What Any Human Has Conceived - Originally built to speed up calculations
column2: a machine-learning system is now making shocking progress at the frontiers of experimental quantum physics'];[nan];2021-07-02;Anil Ananthaswamy;AI Designs Quantum Physics Experiments beyond What Any Human Has Conceived;"Quantum physicist Mario Krenn remembers sitting in a café in Vienna in early 2016
column3: poring over computer printouts
column4: trying to make sense of what MELVIN had found. MELVIN was a machine-learning algorithm Krenn had built
column5: a kind of artificial intelligence. Its job was to mix and match the building blocks of standard quantum experiments and find solutions to new problems. And it did find many interesting ones. But there was one that made no sense. “The first thing I thought was
column6: ‘My program has a bug because the solution cannot exist

column1: MELVIN had seemingly solved the problem of creating highly complex entangled states involving multiple photons (entangled states being those that once made Albert Einstein invoke the specter of “spooky action at a distance”). Krenn
column2: Anton Zeilinger of the University of Vienna and their colleagues had not explicitly provided MELVIN the rules needed to generate such complex states
column3: yet it had found a way. Eventually Krenn realized that the algorithm had rediscovered a type of experimental arrangement that had been devised in the early 1990s. But those experiments had been much simpler. MELVIN had cracked a far more complex puzzle. “When we understood what was going on
column4: we were immediately able to generalize [the solution]
column5: ” says Krenn
column6: who is now at the University of Toronto.

column1: Since then
column2: other teams have started performing the experiments identified by MELVIN
column3: allowing them to test the conceptual underpinnings of quantum mechanics in new ways. Meanwhile Krenn
column4: working with colleagues in Toronto
column5: has refined their machine-learning algorithms. Their latest effort
column6: an AI called THESEUS
column7: has upped the ante: it is orders of magnitude faster than MELVIN
column8: and humans can readily parse its output. While it would take Krenn and his colleagues days or even weeks to understand MELVIN’s meanderings
column9: they can almost immediately figure out what THESEUS is saying. “It is amazing work
column10: ” says theoretical quantum physicist Renato Renner of the Institute for Theoretical Physics at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich
column11: who reviewed a 2020 study about THESEUS but was not directly involved in these efforts.

column1: Krenn stumbled on this entire research program somewhat by accident when he and his colleagues were trying to figure out how to experimentally create quantum states of photons entangled in a very particular manner. When two photons interact
column2: they become entangled
column3: and both can be mathematically described only using a single shared quantum state. If you measure the state of one photon
column4: the measurement instantly fixes the state of the other even if the two are kilometers apart (hence Einstein’s derisive comments on entanglement being “spooky”).

column1: In 1989 three physicists—Daniel Greenberger
column2: the late Michael Horne and Zeilinger—described an entangled state that came to be known as GHZ (after their initials). It involved four photons
column3: each of which could be in a quantum superposition of
column4: say
column5: two states
column6: 0 and 1 (a quantum state called a qubit). In their paper
column7: the GHZ state involved entangling four qubits such that the entire system was in a two-dimensional quantum superposition of states 0000 and 1111. If you measured one of the photons and found it in state 0
column9: and the other photons would also be in state 0. The same went for state 1. In the late 1990s Zeilinger and his colleagues experimentally observed GHZ states using three qubits for the first time.

column1: Krenn and his colleagues were aiming for GHZ states of higher dimensions. They wanted to work with three photons
column2: where each photon had a dimensionality of three
column3: meaning it could be in a superposition of three states: 0
column4: 1 and 2. This quantum state is called a qutrit. The entanglement the team was after was a three-dimensional GHZ state that was a superposition of states 000
column5: 111 and 222. Such states are important ingredients for secure quantum communications and faster quantum computing. In late 2013 the researchers spent weeks designing experiments on blackboards and doing the calculations to see if their setups could generate the required quantum states. But each time they failed. “I thought
column6: ‘This is absolutely insane. Why can’t we come up with a setup?’” Krenn says.

column1: To speed up the process
column2: Krenn first wrote a computer program that took an experimental setup and calculated the output. Then he upgraded the program to allow it to incorporate in its calculations the same building blocks that experimenters use to create and manipulate photons on an optical bench: lasers
column3: nonlinear crystals
column4: beam splitters
column5: phase shifters
column6: holograms
column7: and the like. The program searched through a large space of configurations by randomly mixing and matching the building blocks
column8: performed the calculations and spat out the result. MELVIN was born. “Within a few hours the program found a solution that we scientists—three experimentalists and one theorist—could not come up with for months
column9: ” Krenn says. “That was a crazy day. I could not believe that it happened.” Then he gave MELVIN more smarts. Anytime it found a setup that did something useful
column10: MELVIN added that setup to its toolbox. “The algorithm remembers that and tries to reuse it for more complex solutions

column1: It was this more evolved MELVIN that left Krenn scratching his head in a Viennese café. He had set it running with an experimental toolbox that contained two crystals
column2: each capable of generating a pair of photons entangled in three dimensions. Krenn’s naive expectation was that MELVIN would find configurations that combined these pairs of photons to create entangled states of at most nine dimensions. But “it actually found one solution
column3: an extremely rare case
column4: that has much higher entanglement than the rest of the states
column5: ” Krenn says.

column1: Eventually he figured out that MELVIN had used a technique that multiple teams had developed nearly three decades ago. In 1991 Xin Yu Zou
column2: Li Jun Wang and Leonard Mandel
column3: all then at the University of Rochester
column4: designed one method. And in 1994 Zeilinger
column5: then at the University of Innsbruck in Austria
column6: and his colleagues came up with another. Conceptually these experiments attempted something similar
column7: but the configuration that Zeilinger and his colleagues devised is simpler to understand. It starts with one crystal that generates a pair of photons (A and B). The paths of these photons go right through another crystal
column8: which can also generate two photons (C and D). The paths of photon A from the first crystal and of photon C from the second overlap exactly and lead to the same detector. If that detector clicks
column9: it is impossible to tell whether the photon originated from the first or the second crystal. The same goes for photons B and D.

column1: A phase shifter is a device that effectively increases the path a photon travels as some fraction of its wavelength. If you were to introduce a phase shifter in one of the paths between the crystals and kept changing the amount of phase shift
column2: you could cause constructive and destructive interference at the detectors. For example
column3: each of the crystals could be generating
column4: say
column6: 000 pairs of photons per second. With constructive interference
column8: 000 pairs of photons per second. And with destructive interference
column9: they would detect none: the system as a whole would not create any photons even though individual crystals would be generating 1
column10: 000 pairs a second. “That is actually quite crazy

column1: MELVIN’s funky solution involved such overlapping paths. What had flummoxed Krenn was that the algorithm had only two crystals in its toolbox. And instead of using those crystals at the beginning of the experimental setup
column2: it had wedged them inside an interferometer (a device that splits the path of
column3: say
column4: a photon into two and then recombines them). After much effort
column5: he realized that the setup MELVIN had found was equivalent to one involving more than two crystals
column6: each generating pairs of photons
column7: such that their paths to the detectors overlapped. The configuration could be used to generate high-dimensional entangled states.

column1: Quantum physicist Nora Tischler
column2: who was a Ph.D. student working with Zeilinger on an unrelated topic when MELVIN was being put through its paces
column3: was paying attention to these developments. “It was kind of clear from the beginning [that such an] experiment wouldn’t exist if it hadn’t been discovered by an algorithm
column4: ” she says.

column1: Besides generating complex entangled states
column2: the setup using more than two crystals with overlapping paths can be employed to perform a generalized form of Zeilinger’s 1994 quantum interference experiments with two crystals. Aephraim Steinberg
column3: an experimentalist who is a Toronto colleague of Krenn’s but has not worked on these projects
column4: is impressed by what the AI found. “This is a generalization that (to my knowledge) no human dreamed up in the intervening decades and might never have done
column5: ” he says. “It’s a gorgeous first example of the kind of new explorations these thinking machines can take us on.”

column1: In one such generalized configuration with four crystals
column2: each generating a pair of photons
column3: and overlapping paths leading to four detectors
column4: quantum interference can create situations where either all four detectors click (constructive interference) or none of them do so (destructive interference). Until recently
column5: carrying out such an experiment had remained a distant dream. Then
column6: in a March preprint paper
column7: a team led by Lan-Tian Feng of the University of Science and Technology of China
column9: reported that they had fabricated the entire setup on a single photonic chip and performed the experiment. The researchers collected data for more than 16 hours: a feat made possible because of the photonic chip’s incredible optical stability
column10: something that would have been impossible to achieve in a larger-scale tabletop experiment. For starters
column11: the setup would require a square meter’s worth of optical elements precisely aligned on an optical bench
column13: “a single optical element jittering or drifting by a thousandth of the diameter of a human hair during those 16 hours could be enough to wash out the effect

column1: During their early attempts to simplify and generalize what MELVIN had found
column2: Krenn and his colleagues realized that the solution resembled abstract mathematical forms called graphs
column3: which contain vertices and edges and are used to depict pairwise relations between objects. For these quantum experiments
column4: every path a photon takes is represented by a vertex. And a crystal
column5: for example
column6: is represented by an edge connecting two vertices. MELVIN first produced such a graph and then performed a mathematical operation on it. The operation
column8: involves generating an equivalent graph in which each vertex is connected to only one edge. This process makes calculating the final quantum state much easier
column9: although it is still hard for humans to understand.

column1: That changed with MELVIN’s successor THESEUS
column2: which generates much simpler graphs by winnowing the first complex graph representing a solution that it finds down to the bare minimum number of edges and vertices (such that any further deletion destroys the setup’s ability to generate the desired quantum states). Such graphs are simpler than MELVIN’s perfect matching graphs
column3: so it is even easier to make sense of any AI-generated solution. Renner is particularly impressed by THESEUS’s human-interpretable outputs. “The solution is designed in such a way that the number of connections in the graph is minimized
column4: ” he says. “And that’s naturally a solution we can better understand than if you had a very complex graph.”

column1: Eric Cavalcanti of Griffith University in Australia is both impressed by the work and circumspect about it. “These machine-learning techniques represent an interesting development. For a human scientist looking at the data and interpreting it
column2: some of the solutions may look like ‘creative’ new solutions. But at this stage
column3: these algorithms are still far from a level where it could be said that they are having truly new ideas or coming up with new concepts
column4: ” he says. “On the other hand
column5: I do think that one day they will get there. So these are baby steps—but we have to start somewhere.” Steinberg agrees. “For now they are just amazing tools
column6: ” he says. “And like all the best tools
column7: they’re already enabling us to do some things we probably wouldn’t have done without them.”";12546;['h3suy51'

column1: 3cba1b966b04bb45a0c163044a414adcf5ab2c9cbb30d316a22190b52f8ba620;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.techradar.com/news/us-blacklists-chinese-quantum-computing-firms-over-security-fears;['r1z3ld'];['sillinessalso'];[1637854349.0];['US blacklists Chinese quantum computing firms over security fears'];[nan];2021-11-25;Mayank Sharma;US blacklists Chinese quantum computing firms over security fears;"The US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Industry and Security has added 27 companies to its list of entities prohibited from doing business with the US
column2: including several Chinese firms that dabble with quantum computing (opens in new tab).

column1: The Financial Times (opens in new tab) reports that the companies were banned on grounds they threaten national security.
Eight of the Chinese groups have been specifically targeted to prevent them from accessing sensitive quantum technologies (opens in new tab)
column2: with the Department accusing the companies of helping develop the Chinese military’s quantum computing programme.

column1: Military use
According to reports
column2: Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo said the eight Chinese firms are working to advance Beijing’s “efforts that support military applications
column3: such as counter-stealth and counter-submarine applications
column4: and the ability to break encryption (opens in new tab) or develop unbreakable encryption.”

column1: FT notes that the addition of the 27 companies to the ban list is the latest move by the Biden administration to prevent Beijing from getting its hands on bleeding edge technology that could have military applications.
“This is a sensible move and an important reminder of the scope and scale of China’s efforts to achieve technological breakthroughs that erode US national security
column2: ” Martijn Rasser
column3: a former US official told FT.

column1: In addition to the targeted Chinese groups
column2: Washington has placed 13 Pakistani companies on the “entity list” for activities related to nuclear and ballistic missile programs
column3: as well as firms from Japan
column4: and Singapore.";1599;['hm1xxq2'
