column1: 8ebd01e59b98b1bf0448b2f1f5c4eb38e86a5e733ed711cf48a46649b46ef932;posted_link;r/science;https://www.the-scientist.com/news-opinion/new-study-fuels-debate-about-source-of-birds-magnetic-sense-68917;['o851fy'];['MistWeaver80'];[1624687284.0];['A protein found in robins’ eyes has all the hallmarks of a magnetoreceptor & could help birds navigate using the Earth’s magnetic fields. The research revealed that the protein fulfills several predictions of one of the leading quantum-based theories for how avian magnetoreception might work.'];[nan];2021-06-24;Catherine Offord;New Study Fuels Debate About Source of Birds’ Magnetic Sense;"A protein found in robins’ eyes has all the hallmarks of a magnetoreceptor and could help birds navigate using the Earth’s magnetic fields
column2: according to a study published today (June 23) in Nature. The research
column3: an intensive in vitro analysis of robin cryptochrome 4 (Cry4)
column4: revealed that the protein is magnetically sensitive and fulfills several predictions of one of the leading quantum-based theories for how avian magnetoreception might work.

column1: The authors of the study argue that their findings support Cry4 as the likely receptor for birds’ still largely mysterious magnetic sense. But some other researchers who spoke to The Scientist say that while the results are extremely useful for understanding cryptochromes
column2: a family of proteins often studied in circadian rhythms
column3: the paper omits some scientific context for its findings and doesn’t necessarily support Cry4 as the elusive magnetoreceptor.

column1: “It’s a very important step to show that this cryptochrome 4 actually can perceive light and then become magnetically sensitive
column2: ” says Rachel Muheim
column3: a zoologist and magnetoreception researcher at Lund University in Sweden who was not involved in this work. She says that in her view Cry4 has already emerged in the wider literature as the most likely candidate in avian navigation
column4: but “there are a number of experiments that can’t be explained” by the mechanism the new study focuses on and that aren’t addressed in the paper
column5: she adds. “There’s a lot of unanswered questions.”

column1: Many animals use the Earth’s magnetic fields to help them navigate
column2: but scientists have long debated the biological mechanisms underpinning this sixth sense
column3: with repeated accusations of irreproducible findings and sometimes heated debates between different research groups.

column1: The cryptochrome theory of magnetoreception is based on quantum mechanics. Cryptochromes are light-sensitive flavoproteins found in the retinas of birds and several other groups of animals
column2: and they’re known to form a pair of radicals—molecules with unpaired electrons—when exposed to light. These electrons have correlated spins
column3: and theoretical and in vitro work indicate that their states can be influenced by magnetic fields
column4: leading to the hypothesis that cryptochrome proteins could provide the basis for animal magnetoreception.

column1: At least four cryptochromes (Cry1a
column2: Cry1b
column3: Cry2
column4: and Cry4) have been found in birds’ eyes to date. While some groups have focused their attention on Cry1a
column5: University of Oxford chemist Peter Hore
column6: a coauthor on the new study
column7: tells The Scientist that he and his colleagues at Oxford and at the University of Oldenburg in Germany view Cry4 as the more likely candidate. Unlike some of the other avian cryptochromes
column9: Cry4 binds to a particular molecule needed to help it absorb light and undergo the sort of photochemistry necessary to sense magnetic fields.

column1: In our view
column2: the evidence is overwhelmingly pointing to Cry4 being the hottest candidate.—Henrik Mouritsen
column3: University of Oldenburg

column1: “Also
column2: the other cryptochromes in birds show a 24-hour rhythm in their expression
column3: consistent with their involvement in circadian regulation
column4: whereas the Cry4 doesn’t—but it does show a seasonal variation
column5: which the others don’t
column6: ” he adds. “That could be consistent with the need to migrate in spring and autumn.”

column1: To explore the idea further
column2: the team isolated Cry4 from European robins (Erithacus rubecula) that migrate at night when skies are dim
column3: though not completely dark
column4: and studied the protein in vitro using various techniques
column5: including computer simulations and several types of spectroscopy that can measure how magnetic fields affect protein photochemistry. The researchers also created mutant versions of the protein to figure out the role of individual amino acids in Cry4’s sensitivity to magnetic fields.

column1: They showed that Cry4 generates radical pairs in a light-dependent reaction by having electrons hop along a string of tryptophan amino acids
column2: and that these pairs are highly sensitive to magnetic fields. What’s more
column3: compared to robin Cry4
column4: the same cryptochrome isolated from chickens and pigeons—two nonmigratory birds—were a lot less sensitive to magnetic fields
column5: suggesting that robin Cry4 might be particularly specialized for magnetoreception
column6: the authors write in their paper.

column1: David Keays of Ludwig Maximilians University in Munich who was not involved in the work says that the findings do seem to support Cry4’s role in magnetoreception
column2: and adds that the study is consistent with his own group’s research on the protein’s sensing of magnetic fields. He notes that the magnetic fields used in the study were stronger than those generated by the Earth. “The authors see a clear magnetic effect when applying 10-30mT fields to CRY4 in test tubes
column3: ” he adds in an email. “[W]hether the same applies to Earth strength fields (50uT) in a migrating bird is an open question.”

column1: Alex Jones
column2: a specialist in photochemistry and magnetic field effects at the UK’s National Physical Laboratory who was not involved in the study
column3: says that the data and the authors’ interpretation of the results as they relate to the protein’s behavior are “very solid.” Regarding the strength of the magnetic fields used
column4: he adds that “the radical pair mechanism predicts effects at both weaker and stronger fields
column5: and starting from exposure to stronger fields makes sense from an experimental point of view.”

column1: Debate about existing behavioral data
Margaret Ahmad
column2: a photobiologist at Sorbonne Université in Paris who helped discover cryptochromes in the early 1990s while working on Arabidopsis plants and was not involved in the current work
column3: says that while the researchers “did a tremendous job” of providing valuable data on Cry4
column4: she finds their conclusions about avian navigation unsupported and contrary to existing data from experiments in animal behavior.

column1: “It’s not scientifically admissible to relate [this Cry4 mechanism] to magnetosensing in view of the behavioral evidence that contradicts any role” for it in avian magnetoreception
column2: says Ahmad
column3: who has previously debated with Hore’s group in the literature about the functions of other cryptochrome proteins in plants.

column1: One of the points of contention is the fact that the particular radical pair mechanism described in the new paper is known not to work under green light. Yet Muheim and others have reported from behavioral experiments that robins and other birds are in fact capable of orienting just fine under green light
column2: although there is an ongoing discussion in the field about whether these findings could partly be due to the light conditions birds were exposed to before being tested.

column1: Hore says that it’s unclear how Cry4 fits into this literature at the moment. “I’m not sure what to make of that
column2: ” he says. “Maybe the photochemistry is more complicated than we think—it could certainly be different in vivo.”

column1: Ahmad also points to research by veteran magnetoreception researchers Roswitha Wiltschko and Wolfgang Wiltschko
column2: who carried out orientation experiments using flickering lights and changing magnetic fields. The pair concluded that robins’ magnetosensor worked even in complete darkness. This typically isn’t the sort of condition that robins would navigate under
column3: but the findings led the researchers to propose that it’s a different
column4: light-independent radical pair reaction in cryptochrome that’s important for magnetoreception.

column1: My personal sense is that we’re a little beyond just looking at one end of this
column2: at just the physical chemistry
column3: or just the birds.—Thorsten Ritz
column4: University of California
column5: Irvine

column1: These points weren’t discussed in the paper
column2: Ahmad notes. “Why would you ignore this [data in your paper]? You have to fit your model into the existing behavioral data
column3: ” she says. “If I wasn’t in the field at all
column4: I would get the idea that ‘Ah! The bird magnetoreceptor
column5: we’ve got it!’”

column1: The Wiltschkos
column2: who are based at Goethe University Frankfurt and have collaborated with Ahmad and Hore on various occasions
column3: have argued that Cry4’s position in the eye—associated with oil droplets that block the types of light needed to activate the protein—also make Cry4 an unlikely candidate. In an email sent to The Scientist
column4: Roswitha Wiltschko highlights many of the same points as Ahmad
column5: and notes that she favors Cry1a
column6: “which is found in [photoreceptors that] contain clear oil droplet that let all wavelengths pass
column7: ” as the likely magnetoreceptor in birds.

column1: She also adds that “the avian magnetic compass is not at all restricted to migratory birds. [In] particular homing pigeons and chickens have been demonstrated to use a magnetic compass; hence we would not expect them to be poorer equipped.”
The University of Oldenburg’s Henrik Mouritsen
column2: a coauthor on the new study
column3: says that his group has tried to replicate a number of different studies of magnetoreception by the Wiltschkos and other groups without success. “If we cannot replicate certain claims
column4: we cannot really refer to those things as facts
column5: because we cannot see that—and we have also published that we cannot see that.”

column1: He agrees that the team’s current study doesn’t provide conclusive proof that Cry4 is the magnetoreceptor in robins
column2: but adds that in combination with the rest of the literature (excluding papers his group has concluded are irreproducible)
column3: “in our view
column4: the evidence is overwhelmingly pointing to Cry4 being the hottest candidate.”

column1: He emphasizes that the protein’s behavior in vitro matches up very well with theoretical predictions about magnetoreception. “I would say that it is astounding if what we measure in this molecule is just a coincidence
column2: ” he adds. “[I] think that the claim that what we have measured is unlikely to have anything to do with magnetic sensing in birds is . . . unwarranted.”

column1: A better link between in vitro and in vivo
Thorsten Ritz
column2: a physicist at the University of California
column3: Irvine
column4: who helped develop the original cryptochrome radical pair model of avian magnetoreception more than 20 years ago and was one of the reviewers on the new paper
column5: which was submitted in mid-2019
column6: tells The Scientist that while detailed descriptions of the proteins that are potentially involved are extremely important
column7: “my personal sense is that we’re a little beyond just looking at one end of this
column9: or just the birds—that’s how we started 50 years ago in this field.” Researchers should be working on developing new experimental systems that allow them to study everything from sensing a magnetic field through to some kind of phenotypic effect

column1: Hore says that although it’s challenging to do in vivo experiments with purported magnetoreceptors
column2: it might be possible to inhibit Cry4 function in birds’ eyes and study the importance of the protein’s magnetosensitivity in vivo. He adds that the team is now working with mutant cryptochrome proteins to understand what makes robin Cry4 particularly sensitive to magnetic fields compared to chicken or pigeon cryptochrome.

column1: They’re also interested in the role of a tyrosine amino acid that sits at the end of the tryptophan chain. “I think that could be quite important for the mechanism of sensing and signaling
column2: ” says Hore. “I’d like to find a way to make the in vitro experiments mimic the situation in vivo more closely to see if we can get evidence for the involvement of that tyrosine.”";11375;['h332hab'

column1: 95d91646c8913e57cb2f706ccb3fab13ae55d0082016db15c9441b32c5ac9182;posted_link;r/worldnews;https://www.dw.com/en/ibm-unveils-first-quantum-computer-in-germany/a-57909494;['o0tz8a'];['DoremusJessup'];[1623808332.0];"[""IBM unveils first quantum computer in Germany: It is Germany's first quantum computer
column2: and it is capable of bending the laws of physics and computing in order to work. IBM hopes to have a quantum computer that is 37 times faster in two years""]";[nan];2021-06-15;;IBM unveils first quantum computer in Germany – DW – 06/15/2021;"IBM unveiled one of Europe's most powerful quantum computers on Tuesday
column3: during an event at its German headquarters.

column1: IBM said the Q System One was ""Europe's most powerful quantum computer in the industrial context.""
The quantum computer is to be housed in Ehningen
column2: which is about 20 kilometers (12 miles) southwest of Stuttgart. It will be operated by Germany's Fraunhofer research institute. It is the company's first quantum computer in use outside of the US.

column1: 'Miracle of technology'
Regular modern computers process functions in a binary fashion
column2: carrying out tasks that use fragments of data that are only ever a 1 or 0. Quantum computers use subatomic particles to perform calculations at far greater speeds than existing supercomputers
column3: and data can be both a 1 and 0 at the same time. The data fragments on a quantum computer
column4: known as qubits (short for ""quantum bits"")
column5: significantly boost its computing power.

column1: The machine is housed in a 9-foot (2.7 meter) tall glass cube to shield the qubits from noise and other physical disturbances
column2: to which they can be sensitive.

column1: Companies hope to harness the power of quantum computers to potentially develop new materials
column2: medications or artificial intelligence (AI).

column1: The computer has been running since February
column2: but its launch event was postponed as a result of the pandemic.

column1: German Chancellor Angela Merkel
column2: who holds a PhD in quantum chemistry from her time as a scientist in former East Germany
column3: called the computer a ""miracle of technology.”

column1: Speaking via video
column2: Merkel said it could play ""a key role in our efforts for technological and digital sovereignty
column3: and of course for economic growth.""

column1: Looking to the future
The German government announced last month that it planned to invest some €2 billion ($2.4 billion) in quantum technology research by 2025.

The Fraunhofer institute said it would work with German companies and other research organizations to use the quantum computer to deepen its understanding of quantum computing and experiment with practical uses.
The project
column2: funded by German taxpayers
column3: will cost about €40 million over the next four years.

column1: The European Commission wants the European Union to develop its first quantum computer before the end of the decade.
Martin Jetter
column2: IBM’s chairman for Europe
column3: the Middle East and Africa
column4: said IBM is working towards making a stable quantum computer capable of handling more than 1

column1: 29aacf90c0bb542751556541980cb921498d68d374feef5848a2daeb0a80421c;posted_link;r/philosophy;http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/cross-check/2014/08/21/quantum-gravity-expert-says-philosophical-superficiality-has-harmed-physics/;['2e9qe8'];['PerryStroika'];[1408708507.0];['Quantum Gravity Expert Says “Philosophical Superficiality” Has Harmed Physics'];[nan];2014-08-21;John Horgan;The Philosophy of Guessing Has Harmed Physics
column2: Expert Says;"As readers of this blog know
column3: late last spring I spoke at a cool conference in England called How the Light Gets In
column4: where I hung out with all kinds of professional reality-ponderers. I've already posted Q&As with two fellow speakers I shared housing with: biologist Rupert Sheldrake
column5: who urges scientists to take telepathy more seriously; and physicist George Ellis
column6: who deplores the philosophical philistinism of some fellow physicists. Below is my Q&A with another housemate
column7: physicist Carlo Rovelli of Aix-Marseille University and the Intitut Universitaire de France. I interviewed Rovelli by phone in the early 1990s when I was writing a story for Scientific American about loop quantum gravity
column8: a quantum-mechanical version of gravity proposed by Rovelli
column9: Lee Smolin and Abhay Ashtekar. (General relativity
column11: is notoriously difficult to reconcile with quantum mechanics.) I was thrilled to meet Rovelli face to face
column12: especially since he turned out to be
column14: a good as well as smart guy. Rovelli is the author of a leading textbook on quantum gravity and a biography about the ancient Greek philosopher Anaximander (discussed below). For more on Rovelli's views on physics and philosophy
column15: see this 2012 conversation with him on Edge.org.

column1: Horgan: Why did you become a physicist?
Rovelli: I was young in the sixties and seventies
column2: and shared the dream of my generation: changing the world and make it more just and gentle. We lost. I did not know what to do next. I found physics
column3: where
column4: instead
column5: revolutions succeed. I got in love with it. It has been a passion that hasn't ended.

column1: Horgan: Has physics lived up to your expectations?

Rovelli: It has been much better than I expected. Infinite fun and enthusiasm. Investigating the secrets of the world. Thinking things that nobody else has thought before. Great adventures in thinking. Great companions of travel. Fantastic.
Horgan: What is loop quantum gravity?
Rovelli: It is
column2: in my humble opinion
column3: the best tentative theory of quantum gravity we have at present. We do not know if it is right. But we know there is a problem
column4: and this is the best possible solution found so far for this problem.

column1: Horgan: Is it still a viable contender as a unified theory?

Rovelli: ""Unified theory"" generally means a theory that unifies all forces and all fields: a ""theory of everything."" Loop quantum gravity doesn't have anything to do with this. [Horgan note: LQG doesn't include electromagnetism or the nuclear forces.] I think that for the moment we know nothing about a ""unified theory"" and the attempts to write it are by far premature and ill conceived. So
column2: LQG is not a contender as a unified theory. Much more humbly
column3: it is just a tentative solution for a simpler problem: describing the quantum aspects of gravity. Which is to say the quantum aspects of spacetime. This is hard enough. But it is a problem that we have chances to solve
column4: because we have the ingredients.

column1: Horgan: Do multiverse theories and quantum gravity theories deserve to be taken seriously if they cannot be falsified?
Rovelli: No.
Horgan: Do you ever think it's time for physicists to abandon the quest for a unified theory?
Rovelli: The ""quest for a unified theory"" is a misconception. Physicists never really searched for it. They stumbled upon string theory
column2: which to some appeared as a possible unification of everything
column3: and
column4: for lack of imagination
column5: put too much energy into strings. When the enthusiasm for strings begun to fade
column6: many felt lost. Now that supersymmetry is not showing up where string theorists expected it

column1: Horgan: Can physics—or science in general—ever completely solve the mystery of the universe?
Rovelli: What is the ""mystery of the universe""? There isn't a ""mystery of the universe."" There is an ocean of things we do not know. Many of them we'll figure out
column2: if we continue to be somewhat rational and do not kill one another first (which is well possible.) There will always be plenty of things that we will not understand
column3: I think
column4: but what do I know? In any case
column5: we are very very very far from any complete comprehension of everything we would like to know.

column1: Horgan: Can science attain absolute truth?

Rovelli: I have no idea what ""absolute truth"" means. I think that science is the attitude of those who find funny the people saying they know something is absolute truth. Science is the awareness that our knowledge is constantly uncertain. What I know is that there are plenty of things that science does not understand yet. And science is the best tool found so far for reaching reasonably reliable knowledge.
Horgan: What's your opinion of the recent philosophy-bashing by Stephen Hawking
column2: Lawrence Krauss and Neil deGrasse Tyson?

column1: Rovelli: Seriously: I think they are stupid in this. I have admiration for them in other things
column2: but here they have gone really wrong. Look: Einstein
column3: Heisenberg
column4: Newton
column5: Bohr.... and many many others of the greatest scientists of all times
column6: much greater than the names you mention
column10: and could have never done the great science they did without the input they got from philosophy
column11: as they claimed repeatedly. You see: the scientists that talk philosophy down are simply superficial: they have a philosophy (usually some ill-digested mixture of Popper and Kuhn) and think that this is the ""true"" philosophy
column12: and do not realize that this has limitations.

column1: Here is an example: theoretical physics has not done great in the last decades. Why? Well
column2: one of the reasons
column3: I think
column4: is that it got trapped in a wrong philosophy: the idea that you can make progress by guessing new theory and disregarding the qualitative content of previous theories. This is the physics of the ""why not?"" Why not studying this theory
column5: or the other? Why not another dimension
column6: another field
column7: another universe? Science has never advanced in this manner in the past. Science does not advance by guessing. It advances by new data or by a deep investigation of the content and the apparent contradictions of previous empirically successful theories. Quite remarkably
column8: the best piece of physics done by the three people you mention is Hawking's black-hole radiation
column9: which is exactly this. But most of current theoretical physics is not of this sort. Why? Largely because of the philosophical superficiality of the current bunch of scientists.

column1: Horgan: You have written about the Greek thinker Anaximander. Who was he
column2: and why do you find him interesting?

column1: Rovelli: He is the guy who understood that the Earth is a stone that floats in the middle of the Sky without falling down. He understood that the Sky is not just above out head: it is also under our feet. It surrounds us in every direction. He is the only one in the history of our planet who understood this
column2: and convinced everybody else that this is the case. In fact
column3: he has done much more than this
column4: but this is his greatest achievement. I find him immensely interesting because he represents one of the main steps in the development of scientific thinking. He is a giant.

column1: Horgan: Do you agree with philosopher Thomas Nagel that science needs a new paradigm to account for the emergence of life and consciousness in the cosmos?
Rovelli: No. When we do not understand something
column2: people are tempted to think that ""some new paradigm"" is needed
column3: or a ""great mystery"" is there. Then we understand it
column4: and all fog dissolves.

column1: Horgan: Do you believe in God?
Rovelli: No. But perhaps I should qualify the answer
column2: because like this it is bit too rude and simplistic. I do not understand what ""to believe in God"" means. The people that ""believe in God"" seem like Martians to me. I do not understand them. I suppose this means that I ""do not believe in God"". If the question is whether I think that there is a person who has created Heavens and Earth
column3: and responds to our prayers
column4: then definitely my answer is no
column5: with much certainty.

column1: If the question is whether I believe that ""God"" is a powerful something in the people
column2: which causes a lot of disasters but also a lot of good
column3: then of course I believe it. In fact
column4: I am extremely curious about religion. I think that we should study what is religion much more than what is done. There is a sort of taboo in this
column5: a sort of respect towards people who ""believe in God""
column6: which makes it difficult to understand better.

column1: I think that viewing the ""belief in God"" just as a bunch of silly superstitions is wrong. The ""belief in God"" is one form of human religious attitude
column2: and human religious attitude is something very general and universal about our functioning. Something which is important for man
column3: and we have not yet understood.

column1: Horgan: Are science and religion compatible?
Rovelli: Of course yes: you can be great in solving Maxwell's equations and pray to God in the evening. But there is an unavoidable clash between science and certain religions
column2: especially some forms of Christianity and Islam
column3: those that pretend to be repositories of ""absolute Truths."" The problem is not that scientists think they know everything. It is the opposite: scientists know that there are things we simply do not know
column4: and naturally question those who pretend to know. Many religious people are disturbed by this
column5: and have difficulty in coping with it. The religious person says
column6: ""I know that God has created light saying
column7: 'Fiat Lux.'"" The scientist does not believe the story. The religious people feel threatened. And here the clash develops. But not all religions are like that. Many forms of Buddhism
column9: have no difficulty with the continual critical attitude of science. Monotheistic religions
column10: and in particular Islam and Christianity

column1: I have an idea about the source of the conflict: there is beautiful research by anthropologists in Australia which shows that religious beliefs are often considered a-temporal but in reality change continuously and adapt to new conditions
column2: new knowledge and so on. This was discovered by comparing religious beliefs held by native Australians studied by anthropologists in the thirties and
column3: much later
column4: in the seventies. So
column5: in a natural situation
column6: religious beliefs adapt to the change in man's culture and knowledge. The problem with Islam and Christianity is that many centuries ago somebody had the idea of writing down beliefs. So now some religious people are stuck with the culture and knowledge of centuries ago. They are fish trapped in a pond of old water.

column1: Horgan: Have you ever accepted money from a military organization?
Rovelli: No. In my country military service was compulsory when I was a young man. I refused to join the army and was briefly detained for this.
Horgan: Do you think physicists—and scientists in general--have a moral responsibility to oppose militarism?
Rovelli: I think that we have a moral responsibility to oppose war as human beings
column2: not as physicists or scientists. I think that the problem is that everybody ""opposes the war"" in words
column3: but then many people are ready to make exceptions to serve their interests
column4: defend their power and economical superiority. And these people hide this behind ""feel good"" words like ""help people"" or ""fight terrorism"". I found this morally disgusting. I wish people were less religious and more moral .

column1: Horgan: In 2002 I bet physicist Michio Kaku $1
column2: 000 that by 2020 ""no one will have won a Nobel Prize for work on superstring theory
column3: membrane theory
column4: or some other unified theory describing all the forces of nature.” Who do you think is going to win? [Horgan note: Lee Smolin was originally going to bet against me but backed out at the last minute
column5: the big chicken.]

column1: Rovelli: You. No doubt.
Postscript from Horgan: In the comments section
column2: you can see that Carlo Rovelli posts responses to some early comments on his remarks. I'm copying his responses here for easier access.

column1: A few answers from carlo rovelli:
- to “lakefield”: I actually loved these questions: finally general questions allowing ideas to be expressed
column2: instead of the common boring technicalities.

column1: - to “pupplesan”: I think what you do in your post about the “hard problem of consciousness is not characterising it
column2: but rather anticipating a possible answer. Which might be right. Or not.

column1: - to “Strangelove”: Yes
column2: Archimedes and Eudoxus are also giants. Establishing ranking is not of much interest
column3: I think. I had the misfortune that my US publisher chose the title “The First Scientist” for my book on Anaximander
column4: raising a silly priority debate. I meant bringing attention to Anaximander’s wonderful achievements
column5: not to open an empty discussions about who is greatest or the first! More on the substance of your post
column6: I agree that the key is being testable
column7: which is the main thing you say. But I think that the picture of science as “random guesses” then tested is not a good picture. The “guesses” that have a good chance of being later confirmed are those that have ground. Your example about the spherical Earth is very good: there had been a long sequence of observations
column8: arguments and rational thinking (An example in Aristotle’s ‘On the Heavens’ is the round shade of the Earth on the Moon during lunar eclipses) that provided very strong plausibility to the idea. I think that a problem of today’s theoretical physics is the difficulty of appreciating the difference between a “random guess” and a “well motivated guess”.

column1: - to “ZoranOstric”. You ask about a way to overcome this separation. I think a good starting point could be simply physicists stoping talking philosophy down. For centuries scientists were cultured people
column2: who knew the main philosophical ideas of the past
column3: knew well the history of science
column4: and were very curious about the philosophers of their own times. Yes
column5: I do think that knowing what people in analytical philosophy do now would be useful. There are many thinker in analytical philosophy nowadays that I have found very interesting for a physics (Butterfield
column6: Price
column18: Sauders… just to name a few at random). An example: people talking about “other worlds existing” could usefully read John Austin and David Lewis
column19: at least to avoid using “exist” so superficially…

column1: - to ""cshbar""
column2: who asks: 'how [my] favored theory can be falsified?' Good question. Thanks. Answers in several steps:(i) In principle
column3: Loop Quantum Gravity gives specific quantitative predictions
column4: for instance regarding the possible values of the area of any surface
column5: or cross section. Any measurement of a cross section that does not enter the set of the values predicted by theory falsifies the theory. (ii) These predictions are pretty general
column6: and the situation is very different from string theory
column7: which has zillions of vacua each with a different set of predictions
column9: where it is not even very clear what a 'prediction' is going to be.(iii) In practice
column10: it is difficult to test predictions
column11: because the Planck length is small.(iv) But the claim of LQG is simple
column12: and low key: it is not a theory we try to sell as the final theory of everything that everybody should buy; we present it is a tentative theory whose physical viability we ourselves we are far from sure about
column13: until some empirical support comes in.(v) As for myself
column14: predictions and testing the theory is what I am consider interesting and what I am working on. This is why I am trying to use the theory to compute the probability of black holes tunnelling into white holes
column15: with the hope to see signals of this process in cosmic rays
column17: the short answer is: LQG is developed with the idea that what cannot be tested empirically is not good science.";15756;['cjxfedi'

column1: 0bd49370ee2c42be2cd8441bac2013ba14781aee228ddf96894bcd9a41ee6a88;posted_link;r/Futurology;http://www.tomshardware.com/news/google-72-qubit-quantum-computer
column2: 36617.html;['82925f'];['johnmountain'];[1520281825.0];['Google Unveils 72-Qubit Quantum Computer With Low Error Rates'];[nan];2018-03-05;Lucian Armasu;Google Unveils 72-Qubit Quantum Computer With Low Error Rates;"Google announced a 72-qubit universal quantum computer that promises the same low error rates the company saw in its first 9-qubit quantum computer. Google believes that this quantum computer
column3: called Bristlecone
column4: will be able to bring us to an age of quantum supremacy.

column1: Ready For Quantum Supremacy

Google has teased before that it would build a 49-qubit quantum computer to achieve “quantum supremacy.” This achievement would show that quantum computers can perform some well-defined science problems faster than the fastest supercomputers in the world can.
In a recent announcement
column2: Google said:

column1: If a quantum processor can be operated with low enough error
column2: it would be able to outperform a classical supercomputer on a well-defined computer science problem
column3: an achievement known as quantum supremacy. These random circuits must be large in both number of qubits as well as computational length (depth). Although no one has achieved this goal yet
column4: we calculate quantum supremacy can be comfortably demonstrated with 49 qubits
column5: a circuit depth exceeding 40
column6: and a two-qubit error below 0.5%. We believe the experimental demonstration of a quantum processor outperforming a supercomputer would be a watershed moment for our field
column7: and remains one of our key objectives.

column1: Not long after Google started talking about its 49-qubit quantum computer
column2: IBM showed that for some specific quantum applications
column3: 56 qubits or more may be needed to prove quantum supremacy. It seems Google wanted to remove all doubt
column4: so now it’s experimenting with a 72-qubit quantum computer.

column1: Don’t let the numbers fool you
column2: though. Right now
column3: the most powerful supercomputers can simulate only 46 qubits and for every new qubit that needs to be simulated
column4: the memory requirements typically double (although some system-wide efficiency can be gained with new innovations).

column1: Therefore
column2: in order for us to simulate a 72-qubit quantum computer
column3: we’d need millions of times more RAM (2^(72-46)). We probably won’t be able to use that much RAM in a supercomputer anytime soon
column4: so if Bristlecone will be able to run any algorithm faster than our most powerful supercomputers
column5: then the quantum supremacy era will have arrived.

column1: High Number Of Qubits Is Not Enough

A high number of qubits is not the only thing that’s needed to achieve quantum supremacy. You also need qubits with low error rates so they don’t mess-up the calculations. A useful quantum computer is a function of both number of qubits and error rate.
According to Google
column2: a minimum error rate for quantum computers needs to be in the range of less than 1%
column3: coupled with close to 100 qubits. Google seems to have achieved this so far with 72-qubit Bristlecone and its 1% error rate for readout
column4: 0.1% for single-qubit gates
column5: and 0.6% for two-qubit gates.

column1: Quantum computers will begin to become highly useful in solving real-world problems when we can achieve error rates of 0.1-1% coupled with hundreds of thousand to millions of qubits.
According to Google
column2: an ideal quantum computer would have at least hundreds of millions of qubits and an error rate lower than 0.01%. That may take several decades to achieve
column3: even if we assume a “Moore’s Law” of some kind for quantum computers (which so far seems to exist
column4: seeing the progress of both Google and IBM in the past few years
column5: as well as D-Wave).

column1: That said
column2: we may start seeing some ""useful"" applications of quantum computers well before that. For instance
column3: breaking most existing cryptography may be possible when the quantum computers have only a few thousand qubits. If the current rate of progress for quantum computers holds
column4: we may be able to reach that in about a decade.

column1: Google is “cautiously optimistic” that the Bristlecone quantum computer will not only achieve quantum supremacy
column2: but could also be used as a testbed for researching qubit scalability and error rates
column3: as well as applications such as simulation
column4: optimization
column5: and machine learning.";3936;['dv8al0f'
column6: 'dv8li93'

column1: 9b2f68aa0a4f075ec52bff19436a0f5b5041f73aa00c60a1020010bf60359fdf;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.sciencealert.com/physicists-have-teleported-information-between-particles-of-matter-for-the-first-time;['hgu2j0'];['izumi3682'];[1593266694.0];['Physicists Just Quantum Teleported Information Between Particles of Matter'];[nan];2020-06-26;Mike McRae;Physicists Just Quantum Teleported Information Between Particles of Matter;"By making use of the 'spooky' laws behind quantum entanglement
column2: physicists think have found a way to make information leap between a pair of electrons separated by distance.

column1: Teleporting fundamental states between photons – massless particles of light – is quickly becoming old news
column2: a trick we are still learning to exploit in computing and encrypted communications technology.

column1: But what the latest research has achieved is quantum teleportation between particles of matter – electrons –something that could help connect quantum computing with the more traditional electronic kind.
We provide evidence for 'entanglement swapping
column2: ' in which we create entanglement between two electrons even though the particles never interact
column3: and 'quantum gate teleportation
column4: ' a potentially useful technique for quantum computing using teleportation
column5: says physicist John Nichol from the University of Rochester in New York.

column1: Our work shows that this can be done even without photons.""
Entanglement is physics jargon for what seems like a pretty straightforward concept.
If you buy a pair of shoes from a shop and leave one behind
column2: you'll automatically know which foot it belongs to the moment you get home. The shoes are – in a manner of speaking – entangled.

column1: If the shopkeeper randomly pulls out its matching partner when you return
column2: you'll think they either remembered your sale
column3: made a lucky guess
column4: or were perhaps a little 'spooky' in their prediction.

column1: The real weirdness arises when we imagine your lonely shoe as being both left and right at the same time
column2: at least until you look at it. At that very moment
column3: the shoe's partner back at the shop also snaps into shape
column4: as if your sneaky peek teleported across that distance.

column1: It's a kind of serendipitous exchange that Einstein felt was a little too spooky for comfort. Nearly a century after physicists raised the possibility
column2: we now know teleportation between entangled particles is how the Universe works on a fundamental level.

column1: While it's not exactly a Star Trek-type teleportation that could beam whole objects across space
column2: the mathematics describing this information jump are mighty useful in carrying out special kinds of calculations in computing.

column1: Typical computer logic is made up of a binary language of bits
column2: labelled either 1s and 0s. Quantum computing is built with qubits that can occupy both states at once – providing far greater possibilities that classical technology can't touch.

column1: The problem is the Universe is like a big jumble of shoes
column2: all threatening to turn your delicate game of 'guess which foot' into a nightmare gamble the moment any qubit interacts with its environment.

column1: Manipulating photons to transmit their entangled states is made easier thanks to the fact they can be quickly separated at light speed over huge distances through a vacuum or down an optical fibre.
But separating entangled masses – such as pairs of electrons – is more of a challenge
column2: given their clunky interactions as they bounce along are almost certain to ruin their mathematically pure quantum state.

column1: It's a challenge well worth the effort
column2: though.

column1: Individual electrons are promising qubits because they interact very easily with each other
column2: and individual electron qubits in semiconductors are also scalable
column3: says Nichol.

column1: Reliably creating long-distance interactions between electrons is essential for quantum computing.""
To achieve it
column2: the team of physicists and engineers took advantage of some strange fine print in the laws that govern the ways the fundamental particles making up atoms and molecules hold their place.

column1: Any two electrons that share the same quantum spin state can't occupy the same spot in space. But there is a bit of a loophole that says nearby electrons can swap their spins
column2: almost as if your feet could swap shoes if you bring them close enough.

column1: The researchers had previously shown that this exchange can be manipulated without needing to move the electrons at all
column2: presenting a potential method for teleportation.

column1: This latest advance helps bring the process closer to technological reality
column2: overcoming hurdles that would connect quantum weirdness with existing computing technology.

column1: We provide evidence for 'entanglement swapping
column2: ' in which we create entanglement between two electrons even though the particles never interact
column3: and 'quantum gate teleportation
column4: ' a potentially useful technique for quantum computing using teleportation
column5: says Nichol.

column1: Our work shows that this can be done even without photons.""
Of course
column2: we're still some way off replacing photons with electrons for this kind of quantum information transfer. The researchers haven't gone as far as measuring the states of electrons themselves
column3: meaning there could still be all kinds of interference to iron out.

column1: But having strong evidence of the possibility of teleportation between electrons is an encouraging sign of the possibilities open to future engineers.";4907;['fw65a7e'
column2: 'fw67xv9'
column4: 'fw68gf1'

column1: 65d178ab1755fe72794383d2a04084c8a9dffa268212d16832a8c08120c6920d;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.sciencealert.com/physicists-say-aliens-may-be-using-black-holes-as-quantum-computers;['1124pmv'];['Gari_305'];[1676379281.0];['Physicists Say Aliens May Be Using Black Holes as Quantum Computers : ScienceAlert'];[nan];2023-02-14;Universe Today;Physicists Say Aliens May Be Using Black Holes as Quantum Computers;"If life is common in our Universe
column2: and we have every reason to suspect it is
column3: why do we not see evidence of it everywhere? This is the essence of the Fermi Paradox
column4: a question that has plagued astronomers and cosmologists almost since the birth of modern astronomy.

column1: It is also the reasoning behind the Hart-Tipler Conjecture
column2: one of the many (many!) proposed resolutions
column3: which asserts that if advanced life had emerged in our galaxy sometime in the past
column4: we would see signs of their activity everywhere we looked. Possible indications include self-replicating probes
column5: megastructures
column6: and other Type III-like activity.

column1: On the other hand
column2: several proposed resolutions challenge the notion that advanced life would operate on such massive scales. Others suggest that advanced extraterrestrial civilizations would be engaged in activities and locales that would make them less noticeable.

column1: This makes sense from a computing standpoint and offers an explanation for the apparent lack of activity we see when we look at the cosmos.
The research was conducted by Gia Dvali
column2: a theoretical physicist with the Max Planck Institute for Physics and the physics chair at Ludwig-Maximilians-University in Munich
column3: and Zaza Osmanov
column4: a professor of physics at the Free University of Tbilisi
column5: and a researcher with the Kharadze Georgian National Astrophysical Observatory and the SETI Institute.

column1: The paper that describes their findings recently appeared online and is being reviewed for publication in the International Journal of Astrobiology.

The first SETI survey (Project Ozma) was conducted in 1960 and was led by famed astrophysicist Dr. Frank Drake (who proposed the Drake Equation). This survey relied on the Green Bank Observatory's 26-meter (85-foot) radio telescope to listen for radio transmissions from the nearby star systems of Tau Ceti and Epsilon Eridani.
Since then
column2: the vast majority of SETI projects have been geared towards the search for radio technosignatures
column3: owing to the ability of radio waves to propagate through interstellar space. As Dvali and Osmanov explained to Universe Today via email:

column1: Currently
column2: we are mainly looking for radio messages
column3: and there have been several attempts to study the sky for finding the so-called Dyson sphere candidates – megastructures built around stars. On the other hand
column4: the problem of SETI is so complex that one should test all possible channels.

column1: A whole ""spectrum"" of technosignatures might be much wider: for instance
column2: the infrared or optical emission from megastructures also built around pulsars
column3: white dwarfs
column4: and black holes. A completely new ""direction"" must be the search for an anomalous spectral variability of these technosignatures
column5: which might distinguish them from normal astrophysical objects.""

column1: For many researchers
column2: this limited focus is one of the main reasons SETI has failed to find any evidence of technosignatures. In recent years
column3: astronomers and astrophysicists have recommended extending the search by looking for other technosignatures and methods – such as Messaging Extraterrestrial Intelligence (METI).

column1: These include directed energy (lasers)
column2: neutrino emissions
column3: quantum communications
column4: and gravitational waves
column5: many of which are spelled out in the NASA Technosignature Report (released in 2018) and at the TechnoClimes 2020 workshop.

column1: For their study
column2: Dvali and Osmanov suggest looking for something altogether different: evidence of large-scale quantum computing. The benefits of quantum computing are well-documented
column3: which include the ability to process information exponentially faster than digital computing and being immune to decryption.

column1: Given the rate at which quantum computing is advancing today
column2: it is entirely logical to assume that an advanced civilization could adapt this technology to a much grander scale. Said Dvali and Osmanov:

column1: No matter how advanced is a civilization or how different is their particle composition and chemistry from ours
column2: we are unified by laws of quantum physics and gravity. These laws tell us that the most efficient storers of quantum information are black holes.

column1: Although our recent studies show that theoretically
column2: there may exist devices created by non-gravitational interactions that also saturate the capacity of information storage (so-called ""saturons"")
column3: the black holes are the clear champions. Correspondingly
column4: any sufficiently advanced ETI is expected to use them for information storage and processing.""

column1: This idea builds on the work of Nobel-prize winner Roger Penrose
column2: who famously proposed that limitless energy could be extracted from a black hole by tapping into the ergosphere. This space lies just outside the event horizon
column3: where infalling matter forms a disk that is accelerated to near the speed of light and emits tremendous amounts of radiation.

column1: Several researchers have suggested that this may be the ultimate power source for advanced ETIs
column2: either by feeding matter onto an SMBH (and harnessing the resulting radiation) or simply harnessing the energy they already put out.

column1: Two possibilities for this latter scenario involve harnessing the angular momentum of their accretions disks (the ""Penrose Process"") or capturing the heat and energy generated by their hypervelocity jets (perhaps in the form of a Dyson Sphere).
In their later paper
column2: Dvali and Osamov suggest that black holes could be the ultimate source of computation. This is based on the notions that: a) a civilization's advancement is directly correlated to its level of computational performance
column3: and b) that there exist certain universal markers of computational advancement which can be used as potential technosignatures

column1: for SETI.
Using the principles of quantum mechanics
column2: Dvali and Osomanov explained how black holes would be the most efficient capacitors for quantum information. These black holes would likely be artificial in nature and micro-sized rather than large and naturally occurring (for the sake of computing efficiency).

column1: As a result
column2: they argue
column3: these black holes would be more energetic than naturally-occurring ones:

column1: By analyzing the simple scaling properties of information retrieval time
column2: we showed that the optimization of the information volume and processing time suggests that it is maximally beneficial for ETI to invest energy in the creation of many microscopic black holes as opposed to a few large ones.

column1: First
column2: the micro-black holes radiate with much higher intensity and in the higher energy spectrum of Hawking radiation. Secondly
column3: such black holes must be manufactured by means of high-energy particle collisions in accelerators. This manufacturing necessarily provides an accompanying high-energy radiation signature.""

column1: Hawking radiation
column2: named in honor of the late and great Stephen Hawking
column3: is theorized to be released just outside the event horizon of a black hole due to relativistic quantum effects. The emission of this radiation reduces the mass and rotational energy of black holes
column4: theoretically resulting in their eventual evaporation.

column1: The resulting Hawking radiation
column2: said Dvali and Osomanov
column3: would be ""democratic"" in nature
column4: meaning that it would produce many different species of subatomic particles that are detectable by modern instruments:

column1: The great thing about Hawking radiation is that it is universal in all the existing particle species. Thereby
column2: ETI quantum computers must radiate ""ordinary"" particles such as neutrinos and photons. Neutrinos
column3: in particular
column4: are excellent messengers due to their extraordinary penetration ability
column5: which avoids the possibility of screening.

column1: This
column2: in particular
column3: offers novel fingerprints of ETI in the form of a flux of very high energy neutrinos coming both from Hawking radiation of information storing micro black holes as well as from the collision 'factories' that manufacture them. The Hawking component of radiation is expected to be a superposition of black body spectra of very high energies.

column1: In the paper
column2: we have shown that the IceCube observatory can potentially observe such technosignatures. However
column3: this is just one potential example of a very exciting new direction for SETI.""

column1: In many respects
column2: this theory echoes the logic of the Barrow Scale
column3: proposed by astrophysicist and mathematician John D. Barrow in 1998. A revision of the Kardashev Scale
column4: the Barrow Scale suggests that civilizations should be characterized not by their physical mastery of outer space (i.e.
column5: planet
column6: solar system
column8: etc.) but of inner space – i.e.

column1: This Scale is central to the Transcension Hypothesis
column2: a proposed resolution to Fermi's Paradox that suggests that ETIs would have ""transcended"" beyond anything we would recognize.

column1: Herein lies another exciting aspect of this theory
column2: which is how it offers another possible resolution to the Fermi Paradox. As they explained:

column1: Up until now
column2: we have completely overlooked a natural direction for SETI in form of high energy neutrinos and other particles produced by the Hawking radiation of artificial black holes. Thereby
column3: various experimental searches for such high energy particles can potentially shed an extremely important light on the presence of advanced ETI within the observable part of the Universe.""

column1: In short
column2: it could be that we see a ""Great Silence"" when we look into the cosmos because we've been looking for the wrong technosignatures.

column1: After all
column2: if extraterrestrial life has had a jump on humanity (which seems reasonable given the age of the Universe)
column3: it stands to reason they would have outgrown radio communications and digital computing a long time ago. Another advantage to this theory is that it need not apply to all ETIs to explain why we haven't heard from any civilizations to date.

column1: Given the exponential rate at which computing progresses (using humanity as a template)
column2: advanced civilizations might have a short window in which they broadcast in radio wavelengths. This is a key part of the Drake Equation: the L parameter
column3: which refers to the length of time civilizations have to release detectable signals into space.

column1: In the meantime
column2: this study offers another potential technosignature for SETI surveys to look for in the coming years. The Paradox persists
column3: but we need only find one indication of advanced life to resolve it.";10252;['j8hvwor'
column4: 'j8iacxl'
column5: 'j8id6hv'
column6: 'j8ig1dd'

column1: f03e79be4c968095d5f1e3b63bc4c9dc2df54259df93de0a4963728af4193288;posted_link;r/science;https://www.stevens.edu/news/quantum-future-which-starship-destroys-other;['cu871h'];['The_Necromancer10'];[1566530527.0];"[""Physicists have shown that time itself can exist in a state of superposition. The work is among the first to reveal the quantum properties of time
column2: whereby the flow of time doesn't observe a straight arrow forward
column3: but one where cause and effect can co-exist both in forward and backward direction.""]";[nan];2019-08-22;;In a Quantum Future
column4: Which Starship Destroys The Other?;"Quantum physicists blur the lines of cause and effect
column5: illustrating how a sequence of events can flip and co-exist at the same time

column1: Quantum mechanics boasts all sorts of strange features
column2: one being quantum superposition – the peculiar circumstance in which particles seem to be in two or more places or states at once. Now
column3: an international group of physicists led by Stevens Institute of Technology
column4: University of Vienna and University of Queensland flip that description on its head
column5: showing that particles are not the only objects that can exist in a state of superposition – so can time itself.

column1: “The sequence of events can become quantum mechanical
column2: ” said co-author Igor Pikovski
column3: a physicist at the Center for Quantum Science and Engineering at Stevens Institute of Technology. “ We looked at quantum temporal order where there is no distinction between one event causing the other or vice versa. So at the same time
column4: A can cause B and B can cause A
column5: in a quantum loop that blurs the lines of cause and effect.”

column1: The work
column2: reported in the August 22 issue of Nature Communications
column3: is among the first to reveal the quantum properties of time
column4: whereby the flow of time doesn’t observe a straight arrow forward
column5: but one where cause and effect can co-exist both in the forward and backward direction. In the upcoming era of quantum computers
column6: the work holds particular promise: quantum computers that exploit the quantum order of performing operations might beat devices that operate using only fixed sequences.

column1: Pikovski and colleagues merged two seemingly conflicting theories – quantum mechanics and general relativity – to conduct a Gedanken experiment
column2: a way of using the imagination to investigate the nature of things. The team
column3: consisting of Pikovski
column4: Magdalena Zych
column5: Fabio Costa and Caslav Brukner
column6: started by asking the question
column7: “what would a clock measure if it was influenced by a massive object in a quantum superposition state
column8: i.e. both near and far at the same time?”

column1: According to general relativity
column2: the presence of a massive object slows down the flow of time
column3: such that a clock placed close to a massive object will run slower compared to an identical one that is farther away.

column1: Based on that observation
column2: the Gedanken experiment goes like this: imagine a pair of starships training for a mission. They are asked to fire at each other at a specified time and dodge the fire at another time
column3: whereby each ship knows the exact time when to fire and when to dodge. If either ship fires too early
column4: one will destroy the other
column5: establishing an unmistakable time order between the firing events. That is
column6: starship A fires before starship B
column7: and starship A survives and starship B is destroyed.

column1: However
column2: if a powerful agent could place a sufficiently massive object
column3: say a planet
column4: closer to one starship it would slow down its flow of time. As a result
column5: the starship would be in line of fire of the attack and be destroyed.

column1: Quantum mechanics complicates the matter. When placing the planet in a state of superposition near one starship or the other
column2: both can be destroyed or survive at the same time. The sequence of events exists in a state of superposition
column3: such that each starship simultaneously destroys the other as two separate events
column4: llustrating for the first time how this quantum scenario can occur and how it can be verified.

column1: “Moving planets around is hard
column2: ” said Pikovski. “But imagining it helped us examine a quantum aspect of time that was previously unknown.”

column1: c7c3ba82a7b0f2f913cac7ec1f9a7a4ac50b6af0e462f4e31990aed2c694c775;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.inverse.com/article/36317-quantum-internet-erbium-crystal;['6zmbnt'];['mvea'];[1505215408.0];['Crystal treated with erbium
column2: an element already found in fluorescent lights and old TVs
column3: allowed researchers to store quantum information successfully for 1.3 seconds
column4: which is 10
column5: 000 times longer than what has been accomplished before
column6: putting the quantum internet within reach - Nature Physics.'];[nan];2017-09-11;Alasdair Wilkins;This Glowing Crystal Has the Quantum Internet Within Reach;"And the key element is already found in fluorescent lights and old TVs.

column1: The quantum computer has the potential to revolutionize the 21st century
column2: solving problems so massively complex they would baffle today’s computers. But a single quantum computer is still no match for the more than billion classical computers currently in use. Quantum computers need a quantum internet
column3: and researchers may just have found the perfect — and practical — material to built that network.

column1: A team at the Australian National University details this big challenge facing dreamers who want to create a quantum internet in a paper published Monday in Nature Physics.
How can one store quantum information in a way that can be transmitted across the planet? Being able to keep quantum bits
column2: or qubits
column3: entangled over tens of thousands of miles is a huge challenge
column4: considering it’s only recently that researchers were able to move beyond a few meters.

column1: But it is more an engineering problem than a theoretical one
column2: and their work suggests a crystal treated with the element erbium just might be the answer. These crystals allowed the researchers to store quantum information successfully for 1.3 seconds.

column1: That may not sound like much
column2: but it’s actually a whopping 10
column3: 000 times longer than what has been accomplished before. And when you consider information traveling at the speed of light needs far less than a second to travel around the world
column4: 1.3 seconds is already long enough to start thinking about a global quantum internet.

column1: Erbium is a common enough element found in fluorescent lights
column2: older-model televisions
column3: and lasers. It’s already used in existing fiber optic networks because it naturally operates at the right wavelength to greatly boost communication signals.

column1: It turns out the same principle can work for a quantum communications network. Using erbium-treated crystals means there would be no need to build an entirely new network
column2: as the researchers say quantum information transmitted by using such crystals would be compatible with the planet’s existing telecommunications system.

column1: Any other material than erbium would operate at a different wavelength
column2: meaning a quantum internet would need to convert qubits from wavelength to another and then back again as part of any transmission
column3: which makes an already fiendishly complicated challenge a nearly impossible one. ";2365;['dmwgwbb'
column4: 'dmwji66'

column1: 279bd7d9482f5c5cb0b48da7f10a0acbfb0ca1ca6b39d7bed849fa9e1ca3f764;posted_link;r/space;https://www.news.com.au/technology/science/big-bang-theory-under-threat-from-quantum-graphity-breakthrough/news-story/405634e8db86f3561e8bae8967f75eb1;['yjhhu'];['DueyDerp'];[1345493912.0];['Big Bang theory under threat from quantum graphity breakthrough. Researchers from University of Melbourne and RMIT believe they may be on the brink of rewriting the history of the universe.'];[nan];2012-08-20;AAP;Big Bang theory under threat from quantum graphity breakthrough;"AUSTRALIAN researchers believe they may be on the brink of rewriting the history of the universe.
A paper being published in a US physics journal suggests it may be possible to view ""cracks"" in the universe that would support the theory of ""quantum graphity""
column2: considered to be the holy grail of physics.

column1: The team of researchers from the University of Melbourne and RMIT say that instead of thinking of the start of the universe as being a big bang
column2: we should imagine it as a cooling of water into ice.

column1: Think of the early universe as being like a liquid
column2: Melbourne University theoretical physics researcher James Quach said.

column1: Then as the universe cools
column2: it `crystalises'.

column1: The reason we use the water analogy is water is without form.
In the beginning there wasn't even space
column2: space did not exist because there was no form.""

column1: Their research rests on a school of thought that has emerged recently to suggest space is made of indivisible building blocks
column2: like atoms
column3: that can be thought of as similar to pixels that make up images on a computer screen.

column1: Mr Quach says the standing model for the origins of the universe
column2: the big bang
column3: needs to be rewritten.

column1: He hopes experimentalists will be able to find evidence to support the theory put forward by the Melbourne team of researchers
column2: that would replace it.

column1: The biggest problem with the big bang model is the bang itself
column2: Mr Quach says.

column1: At the bang
column2: physics breaks down.

column1: The model cannot make any predictions at what occurs at the big bang. You can't use any of the mathematics (or) any of the theories.""
Mr Quach and his fellow researchers theorise that if quantum graphity ""cracks"" do exist
column2: they will bend or reflect light
column3: which
column4: if observed through a telescope would support their predictions.

column1: If they prove my predictions that's really good evidence for the condensed matter model of quantum graphity in which case you can throw out all the other attempts.""";1930;['c5w5q04'
column3: 'c5w7md0'
column6: 'c5wadxt'

column1: 0e2c511268f9d5f0e1d3449da52a048a8fdc7b62e2dde7f005e91eba5787d508;posted_link;r/tech;https://phys.org/news/2021-02-quantum-tunneling-graphene-advances-age.html;['ld51by'];['JackFisherBooks'];[1612523504.0];['Quantum tunneling in graphene advances the age of terahertz wireless communications'];[nan];2021-02-03;"Moscow Institute; Technology";Quantum tunneling in graphene advances the age of terahertz wireless communications;"Quantum tunneling in graphene advances the age of terahertz wireless communications
Scientists from MIPT (Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology)
column2: Moscow Pedagogical State University and the University of Manchester have created a highly sensitive terahertz detector based on the effect of quantum-mechanical tunneling in graphene. The sensitivity of the device is already superior to commercially available analogs based on semiconductors and superconductors
column3: which opens up prospects for applications of the graphene detector in wireless communications
column4: security systems
column5: radio astronomy
column6: and medical diagnostics. The research results are published in Nature Communications.

column1: Information transfer in wireless networks is based on transformation of a high-frequency continuous electromagnetic wave into a discrete sequence of bits. This technique is known as signal modulation. To transfer the bits faster
column2: one has to increase the modulation frequency. However
column3: this requires synchronous increase in carrier frequency. A common FM-radio transmits at frequencies of a hundred megahertz
column4: a Wi-Fi receiver uses signals of roughly five gigahertz frequency
column5: while the 5G mobile networks can transmit up to 20 gigahertz signals. This is far from the limit
column6: and further increase in carrier frequency admits a proportional increase in data transfer rates. Unfortunately
column7: picking up signals with hundred gigahertz frequencies and higher is an increasingly challenging problem.

column1: A typical receiver used in wireless communications consists of a transistor-based amplifier of weak signals and a demodulator that rectifies the sequence of bits from the modulated signal. This scheme originated in the age of radio and television
column2: and becomes inefficient at frequencies of hundreds of gigahertz desirable for mobile systems. The fact is that most of the existing transistors aren't fast enough to recharge at such a high frequency.

column1: An evolutionary way to solve this problem is just to increase the maximum operation frequency of a transistor. Most specialists in the area of nanoelectronics work hard in this direction. A revolutionary way to solve the problem was theoretically proposed in the beginning of 1990's by physicists Michael Dyakonov and Michael Shur
column2: and realized
column3: among others
column4: by the group of authors in 2018. It implies abandoning active amplification by transistor
column5: and abandoning a separate demodulator. What's left in the circuit is a single transistor
column6: but its role is now different. It transforms a modulated signal into bit sequence or voice signal by itself
column7: due to non-linear relation between its current and voltage drop.

column1: In the present work
column2: the authors have proved that the detection of a terahertz signal is very efficient in the so-called tunneling field-effect transistor. To understand its work
column3: one can just recall the principle of an electromechanical relay
column4: where the passage of current through control contacts leads to a mechanical connection between two conductors and
column5: hence
column6: to the emergence of current. In a tunneling transistor
column7: applying voltage to the control contact (termed as ''gate'') leads to alignment of the energy levels of the source and channel. This also leads to the flow of current. A distinctive feature of a tunneling transistor is its very strong sensitivity to control voltage. Even a small ""detuning"" of energy levels is enough to interrupt the subtle process of quantum mechanical tunneling. Similarly
column8: a small voltage at the control gate is able to ""connect"" the levels and initiate the tunneling current.

column1: The idea of strong reaction of a tunneling transistor to low voltages is known for about fifteen years
column2: says Dr. Dmitry Svintsov
column3: one of the authors of the study
column4: head of the laboratory for optoelectronics of two-dimensional materials at the MIPT center for photonics and 2-D materials. ""But it's been known only in the community of low-power electronics. No one realized before us that the same property of a tunneling transistor can be applied in the technology of terahertz detectors. Georgy Alymov (co-author of the study) and I were lucky to work in both areas. We realized then: if the transistor is opened and closed at a low power of the control signal
column5: then it should also be good in picking up weak signals from the ambient surrounding. ""

column1: The created device is based on bilayer graphene
column2: a unique material in which the position of energy levels (more strictly
column3: the band structure) can be controlled using an electric voltage. This allowed the authors to switch between classical transport and quantum tunneling transport within a single device
column4: with just a change in the polarities of the voltage at the control contacts. This possibility is of extreme importance for an accurate comparison of the detecting ability of a classical and quantum tunneling transistor.

column1: The experiment showed that the sensitivity of the device in the tunneling mode is few orders of magnitude higher than that in the classical transport mode. The minimum signal distinguishable by the detector against the noisy background already competes with that of commercially available superconducting and semiconductor bolometers. However
column2: this is not the limit—the sensitivity of the detector can be further increased in 'cleaner' devices with a low concentration of residual impurities. The developed detection theory
column3: tested by the experiment
column4: shows that the sensitivity of the optimal detector can be a hundred times higher.

column1: The current characteristics give rise to great hopes for the creation of fast and sensitive detectors for wireless communications
column2: says the author of the work
column3: Dr. Denis Bandurin. And this area is not limited to graphene and is not limited to tunnel transistors. We expect that
column4: with the same success
column5: a remarkable detector can be created
column6: for example
column7: based on an electrically controlled phase transition. Graphene turned out to be just a good launching pad here
column9: behind which is a whole world of exciting new research.""

column1: The results presented in this paper are an example of a successful collaboration between several research groups. The authors note that it is this format of work that allows them to obtain world-class scientific results. For example
column2: earlier
column3: the same team of scientists demonstrated how waves in the electron sea of graphene can contribute to the development of terahertz technology. ""In an era of rapidly evolving technology
column4: it is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve competitive results
column5: comments Dr. Georgy Fedorov
column6: deputy head of the nanocarbon materials laboratory
column8: ""Only by combining the efforts and expertise of several groups can we successfully realize the most difficult tasks and achieve the most ambitious goals
column9: which we will continue to do.""";6774;['gm3zmda'

column1: 0b2c7fbc152b3e9d3a52714b4970912f238562d485080f628032be3c76266761;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.sciencealert.com/new-study-proves-that-global-quantum-communication-is-going-to-be-possible;['a963g1'];['Valcaralho'];[1545667125.0];['Study Confirms: Global Quantum Internet Really Is Possible'];[nan];2018-12-21;David Nield;Study Confirms: Global Quantum Internet Really Is Possible;"Quantum internet promises ultra-secure
column2: next-generation communications
column3: but is it actually feasible on a global scale?

column1: Absolutely
column2: according to a new experiment carried out between satellites in orbit and a station on the ground.

column1: The team of scientists was able to exchange several carefully managed photons in pulses of infrared light
column2: carried between Russian GLONASS satellites and the Space Geodesy Centre on the ground run by the Italian Space Agency.

column1: Getting these signals to pass through some 20
column2: 000 kilometres (12
column3: 427 miles) of air and space without any interference or data loss is no easy task – but the signs are promising that such a global network could indeed be functional.

column1: Space quantum communications (QC) represent a promising way to guarantee unconditional security for satellite-to-ground and inter-satellite optical links
column2: by using quantum information protocols as quantum key distribution (QKD)
column3: says one of the researchers
column4: Giuseppe Vallone from the University of Padova in Italy.

column1: The quantum key distribution or QKD method Vallone mentions refers to data encrypted using the power of quantum mechanics: thanks to the delicate nature of the technology
column2: any interference is quickly detected
column3: making QKD communications impossible to intercept.

column1: In fact
column2: hacking into a quantum mechanics message would cause it to self-destruct.

column1: So far so good in theory
column2: but keeping these secure channels open across long distances has proved tricky.

column1: The key to the successful data exchange here was the use of passive retro-reflectors mounted on the satellites to keep the long-distance light signals intact
column2: breaking the previous record distance for this type of quantum communication by an extra 15
column3: 000 kilometres (9
column4: 321 miles).

column1: While satellites placed higher in orbit
column2: like the GLONASS ones
column3: are more difficult to communicate reliably with
column4: they pass within sight of ground stations more regularly
column5: potentially enabling an unhackable quantum network that can span the globe.

column1: We're only just getting started with this type of technology – not least because scientists are still trying to figure out if it can actually work – and for the moment it's not clear exactly what a quantum internet would be used for or how it might be operated.
One idea is that it might become a specialised
column2: very secure extension to the normal internet
column3: used by a small selection of apps and devices.

column1: What we do now know is that quantum communications are possible between the ground and high orbit satellites
column2: extending the potential reach of the new technology.

column1: That's important as the satellite networks we rely on continue to get developed and upgraded.
Satellite-based technologies enable a wide range of civil
column2: scientific and military applications like communications
column3: navigation and timing
column4: remote sensing
column5: meteorology
column6: reconnaissance

column1: The core of these systems is to safely transmit information and data from orbiting satellites to ground stations on Earth. Protection of these channels from a malicious adversary is therefore crucial for both military and civilian operations.""";3140;['ececaha'
