column1: 4af6c1fcd8ea04e11b61d9dd9949aee2f906c9839a9df57651fe4ee255d77f75;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/quantum-teleportation-breakthrough-third-dimension-a9075476.html;['cu4f6x'];['QuantumThinkology'];[1566511328.0];"[""Scientists have made a major breakthrough in quantum teleportation
column2: successfully transferring something far more complex than ever before. Discovery opens up new 'dimension' in transmitting information""]";[nan];2019-08-22;Andrew Griffin;Scientists announce major breakthrough in 'quantum teleportation';"Scientists have made a major breakthrough in quantum teleportation
column3: successfully transferring something far more complex than ever before.

column1: Quantum teleportation is a still mysterious phenomena that can see information flung across space.

The effect is not the same as the teleportation often seen in science fiction – where matter is moved through space – but instead is the transfer information about the quantum state of a particle. It could have huge and unimagined effects on the way we organise and transmit information
column2: including the possibility of a vastly more complicated quantum internet.

column1: Until now
column2: scientists have only been able to teleport quantum bits
column3: or qubits. Those are the simplest possible piece of quantum information
column4: where a particle can be in two states at once.

column1: But a qutrit – which scientists have now successfully teleported – adds a whole extra dimension. If a qubit is polarised in two ways at once
column2: a qutrit is polarised in three directions – a vastly more complicated unit
column3: and a far greater challenge for the scientists involved.

column1: It means
column2: in effect
column3: that scientists have more detailed information that can be teleported. A qubit could be 0 or 1; a qutrit can be 0
column4: 1 or 2.

column1: Sending a qutrit rather than a qubit means a vast increase in complexity
column2: because of the nature of the process.

column1: But it also means that the effect could be far more useful. The extra information that can be transferred could power technologies such as a possible quantum internet
column2: allowing for instant and very secure communication.

column1: “The higher the dimensions of your quantum system
column2: the more secure you can ensure your communication is and the more information you can encode
column3: ” Ciarán Lee
column4: from University College London
column5: told New Scientist. “But going from a qubit to a qutrit is especially difficult — the tricks you use for qubits have to do with a nice symmetry that qutrits don’t have.”

column1: The researchers report in their new paper
column2: published in Physical Review Letters
column3: that the demonstrations of their technique had a 75 per cent fidelity. That may appear low
column4: but is far better than similar techniques that do not use quantum entanglement and is likely to improve in time.";2183;['exrekh2'

column1: 0deea3506c00dd4a4d67a8411123c2d0e7053620ef64df1a5cf01e3d6272b5d0;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2020-08-scientists-quantum-states-longer.html;['i9k0nh'];['izumi3682'];[1597403432.0];['Scientists discover way to make quantum states last 10
column2: 000 times longer'];[nan];2020-08-13;Louise Lerner;Scientists discover way to make quantum states last 10
column3: 000 times longer;"Scientists discover way to make quantum states last 10
column4: 000 times longer

column1: If we can harness it
column2: quantum technology promises fantastic new possibilities. But first
column3: scientists need to coax quantum systems to stay yoked for longer than a few millionths of a second.

column1: A team of scientists at the University of Chicago's Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering announced the discovery of a simple modification that allows quantum systems to stay operational—or ""coherent""—10
column2: 000 times longer than before. Though the scientists tested their technique on a particular class of quantum systems called solid-state qubits
column3: they think it should be applicable to many other kinds of quantum systems and could thus revolutionize quantum communication
column4: computing and sensing.

column1: This breakthrough lays the groundwork for exciting new avenues of research in quantum science
column2: said study lead author David Awschalom
column3: the Liew Family Professor in Molecular Engineering
column4: senior scientist at Argonne National Laboratory and director of the Chicago Quantum Exchange. ""The broad applicability of this discovery
column5: coupled with a remarkably simple implementation
column6: allows this robust coherence to impact many aspects of quantum engineering. It enables new research opportunities previously thought impractical.""

column1: Down at the level of atoms
column2: the world operates according to the rules of quantum mechanics—very different from what we see around us in our daily lives. These different rules could translate into technology like virtually unhackable networks or extremely powerful computers; the U.S. Department of Energy released a blueprint for the future quantum internet in an event at UChicago on July 23. But fundamental engineering challenges remain: Quantum states need an extremely quiet
column3: stable space to operate
column4: as they are easily disturbed by background noise coming from vibrations
column5: temperature changes or stray electromagnetic fields.

column1: Thus
column2: scientists try to find ways to keep the system coherent as long as possible. One common approach is physically isolating the system from the noisy surroundings
column3: but this can be unwieldy and complex. Another technique involves making all of the materials as pure as possible
column4: which can be costly. The scientists at UChicago took a different tack.

column1: With this approach
column2: we don't try to eliminate noise in the surroundings; instead
column3: we ""trick"" the system into thinking it doesn't experience the noise
column4: said postdoctoral researcher Kevin Miao
column5: the first author of the paper.

column1: In tandem with the usual electromagnetic pulses used to control quantum systems
column2: the team applied an additional continuous alternating magnetic field. By precisely tuning this field
column3: the scientists could rapidly rotate the electron spins and allow the system to ""tune out"" the rest of the noise.

column1: To get a sense of the principle
column2: it's like sitting on a merry-go-round with people yelling all around you
column3: Miao explained. ""When the ride is still
column4: you can hear them perfectly
column5: but if you're rapidly spinning
column6: the noise blurs into a background.""

column1: This small change allowed the system to stay coherent up to 22 milliseconds
column2: four orders of magnitude higher than without the modification—and far longer than any previously reported electron spin system. (For comparison
column3: a blink of an eye takes about 350 milliseconds). The system is able to almost completely tune out some forms of temperature fluctuations
column4: physical vibrations
column5: and electromagnetic noise
column6: all of which usually destroy quantum coherence.

column1: The simple fix could unlock discoveries in virtually every area of quantum technology
column2: the scientists said.

column1: This approach creates a pathway to scalability
column2: said Awschalom. ""It should make storing quantum information in electron spin practical. Extended storage times will enable more complex operations in quantum computers and allow quantum information transmitted from spin-based devices to travel longer distances in networks.""

column1: Though their tests were run in a solid-state quantum system using silicon carbide
column2: the scientists believe the technique should have similar effects in other types of quantum systems
column3: such as superconducting quantum bits and molecular quantum systems. This level of versatility is unusual for such an engineering breakthrough.

column1: There are a lot of candidates for quantum technology that were pushed aside because they couldn't maintain quantum coherence for long periods of time
column2: Miao said. ""Those could be re-evaluated now that we have this way to massively improve coherence.

column1: The best part is
column2: it's incredibly easy to do
column3: he added. ""The science behind it is intricate
column4: but the logistics of adding an alternating magnetic field are very straightforward.""";4681;['g1fllmq'

column1: c6fa1f05a17773064ca90289cfc5153caa0e4780b78cea5593e2548b3ff70026;posted_link;r/technology;https://singularityhub.com/2022/06/07/a-photonic-quantum-device-took-microseconds-to-do-a-task-a-conventional-computer-would-spend-9000-years-on/;['v8tkxn'];['Vailhem'];[1654816232.0];['Quantum Chip Takes Microseconds to Do a Task a Supercomputer Would Spend 9
column2: 000 Years On'];[nan];2022-06-07;Shelly Fan;Quantum Chip Takes Microseconds to Do a Task a Supercomputer Would Spend 9
column3: 000 Years On;"Are quantum computers overhyped?

column1: A new study in Nature says no. A cleverly-designed quantum device developed by Xanadu
column2: a company based in Toronto
column3: Canada
column4: obliterated conventional computers on a benchmark task that would otherwise take over 9
column5: 000 years.

column1: For the quantum chip Borealis
column2: answers came within 36 microseconds.

column1: Xanadu’s accomplishment is the latest to demonstrate the power of quantum computing over conventional computers—a seemingly simple idea dubbed quantum advantage.
Theoretically
column2: the concept makes sense. Unlike conventional computers
column3: which calculate in sequence using binary bits—0 or 1—quantum devices tap into the weirdness of the quantum world
column4: where 0 and 1 can both exist at the same time with differing probabilities. The data is processed in qubits
column5: a noncommittal unit that simultaneously performs multiple calculations thanks to its unique physics.

column1: Translation? A quantum computer is like a hyper-efficient multitasker
column2: whereas conventional computers are far more linear. When given the same problem
column3: a quantum computer should be able to trounce any supercomputer in any problem in terms of speed and efficiency. The idea
column4: dubbed “quantum supremacy
column5: ” has been the driving force to push for a new generation of computers completely alien to anything previously made.

column1: The problem? Proving quantum supremacy is extremely difficult. As quantum devices increasingly leave the lab to solve more real-world problems
column2: scientists are embracing an intermediate benchmark: quantum advantage
column3: which is the idea that a quantum computer can beat a conventional one at just one task—any task.

column1: Back in 2019
column2: Google broke the internet showcasing the first example of a quantum computer
column3: Sycamore
column4: solving a computational problem in just 200 seconds with 54 qubits—compared to a conventional supercomputer’s estimate of 10
column5: 000 years. A Chinese team soon followed with a second fascinating showcase of quantum computational advantage
column6: with the machine spitting out answers that would take a supercomputer over two billion years.

column1: Yet a crucial question remains: are any of these quantum devices even close to being ready for practical use?
A Drastic Redesign
It’s easy to forget that computers rely on physics. Our current system
column2: for example
column3: taps into electrons and cleverly-designed chips to perform their functions. Quantum computers are similar
column4: but they rely on alternative particle physics. Initial generations of quantum machines looked like delicate
column5: shimmering chandeliers. While absolutely gorgeous
column6: compared to a compact smartphone chip
column7: they’re also completely impractical. The hardware often requires tightly-controlled climates—for example
column8: near absolute zero temperature—to reduce interference and boost the computer’s efficacy.

column1: The core concept of quantum computing is the same: qubits processing data in superposition
column2: a quantum physics quirk that allows them to encode 0s
column3: 1s
column4: or both at the same time. The hardware that supports the idea vastly differs.

column1: Google’s Sycamore
column2: for example
column3: uses superconducting metal loops—a setup popular with other tech giants including IBM
column4: which introduced Eagle
column5: a powerful 127-qubit quantum chip in 2021 that’s about the size of a quarter. Other iterations from companies such as Honeywell and IonQ took a different approach
column6: tapping into ions—atoms with one or more electrons removed—as their main source for quantum computing.

column1: Another idea relies on photons
column2: or particles of light. It’s already been proven useful: the Chinese demonstration of quantum advantage
column3: for example
column4: used a photonic device. But the idea’s also been shunned as a mere stepping stone towards quantum computing rather than a practical solution
column5: largely because of difficulties in engineering and setup.

column1: A Photonic Revolution
Xanadu’s team proved naysayers wrong. The new chip
column2: Borealis
column3: is marginally similar to the one in the Chinese study in that it uses photons—rather than superconducting materials or ions—for computation.

column1: But it has a huge advantage: it’s programmable. “Previous experiments typically relied on static networks
column2: in which each component is fixed once fabricated
column3: ” explained Dr. Daniel Jost Brod at the Federal Fluminense University at Rio de Janeiro in Brazil
column4: who was not involved in the study. The earlier quantum advantage demonstration in the Chinese study used a static chip. With Borealis
column5: however
column6: the optical elements “can all be readily programmed
column7: ” making it less of a single-use device and more of an actual computer potentially capable of solving multiple problems. (The quantum playground is available on the cloud for anyone to experiment and explore once you sign up.)

column1: The chip’s flexibility comes from an ingenious design update
column2: an “innovative scheme [that] offers impressive control and potential for scaling
column3: ” said Brod.

column1: The team zeroed in on a problem called Gaussian boson sampling
column2: a benchmark for evaluating quantum computing prowess. The test
column3: while extraordinarily difficult computationally
column4: doesn’t have much impact on real-world problems. However
column5: like chess or Go for measuring AI performance
column6: it acts as an unbiased judge to examine quantum computing performance. It’s a “gold standard” of sorts: “Gaussian boson sampling is a scheme designed to demonstrate the advantages of quantum devices over classical computers

column1: The setup is like a carnival funhouse mirror tent in a horror movie. Special states of light (and photons)—amusingly called “squeezed states”—are tunneled onto the chip embedded with a network of beam splitters. Each beam splitter acts like a semi-reflective mirror: depending on how the light hits
column2: it splits into multiple daughters
column3: with some reflecting back and others passing through. At the end of the contraption is an array of photon detectors. The more beam splitters
column4: the more difficult it is to calculate how any individual photon will end up at any given detector.

column1: As another visualization: picture a bean machine
column2: a peg-studded board encased in glass. To play
column3: you drop a puck into the pegs at the top. As the puck falls
column4: it randomly hits different pegs
column5: eventually landing in a numbered slot.

column1: Gaussian boson sampling replaces the pucks with photons
column2: with the goal of detecting which photon lands in which detector slot. Due to quantum properties
column3: the possible resulting distributions grow exponentially
column4: rapidly outpacing any supercomputer powers. It’s an excellent benchmark
column5: explained Brod
column6: largely because we understand the underlying physics
column7: and the setup suggests that even a few hundred photons can challenge supercomputers.

column1: Taking up the challenge
column2: the new study reimagined a photonic quantum device with an admirable 216 qubits. Contradicting classic designs
column3: the device calculated photons in bins of arrival time rather than the previous standard of direction. The trick was to introduce loops of optical fibers to delay photons so they can interfere at specific spots important for quantum computation.

column1: These tweaks led to a vastly slimmed-down device. The usual large network of beam splitters—normally needed for photon communications—can be reduced to just three to accommodate all the necessary delays for photons to interact and compute the task. The loop designs
column2: along with other components
column3: are also “readily programmable” in that a beam splitter can be fine-tuned in real time—like editing computer code
column4: but at the hardware level.

column1: The team also aced a standard sanity check
column2: certifying that the output data was correct.

column1: For now
column2: studies that reliably show quantum supremacy remain rare. Conventional computers have a half century head start. As algorithms keep evolving on conventional computers—especially those that tap into powerful AI-focused chips or neuromorphic computing designs—they may even readily outperform quantum devices
column3: leaving them struggling to catch up.

column1: But that’s the fun of the chase. “Quantum advantage is not a well-defined threshold
column2: based on a single figure of merit. And as experiments develop
column3: so too will techniques to simulate them —we can expect record-setting quantum devices and classical algorithms in the near future to take turns in challenging each other for the top spot
column4: ” said Brod.

column1: “It might not be the end of the story
column2: ” he continued. But the new study “is a leap forward for quantum physics in this race.”";8308;['ibsl79x'

column1: 67f791878bd165e3943cf9c59e5af0548d1214f319f2d923e140a7edbe651450;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.zdnet.com/article/a-quantum-computer-just-solved-a-decades-old-problem-three-million-times-faster-than-a-classical-computer/?ftag=TRE3e6936e&bhid=29741352980441994768287064264648&mid=13278497&cid=2369785666;['ls1ifr'];['Docusnap_Official'];[1614240356.0];['A quantum computer just solved a decades-old problem three million times faster than a classical computer'];[nan];2021-02-23;Daphne Leprince-Ringuet;A quantum computer just solved a decades-old problem three million times faster than a classical computer;"Scientists from quantum computing company D-Wave have demonstrated that
column2: using a method called quantum annealing
column3: they could simulate some materials up to three million times faster than it would take with corresponding classical methods.

column1: Together with researchers from Google
column2: the scientists set out to measure the speed of simulation in one of D-Wave's quantum annealing processors
column3: and found that performance increased with both simulation size and problem difficulty
column4: to reach a million-fold speedup over what could be achieved with a classical CPU.

column1: The calculation that D-Wave and Google's teams tackled is a real-world problem; in fact
column2: it has already been resolved by the 2016 winners of the Nobel Prize in Physics
column3: Vadim Berezinskii
column4: J. Michael Kosterlitz and David Thouless
column5: who studied the behavior of so-called ""exotic magnetism""
column6: which occurs in quantum magnetic systems.

column1: The Nobel Prize winners used advanced mathematical methods to describe
column2: in the 1970s
column3: the properties of a two-dimensional quantum magnet
column4: which shed light on the strange – or ""exotic"" – states that matter can take on.

column1: Instead of proving quantum supremacy
column2: which happens when a quantum computer runs a calculation that is impossible to resolve with classical means
column3: D-Wave's latest research demonstrates that the company's quantum annealing processors can lead to a computational performance advantage.

column1: This work is the clearest evidence yet that quantum effects provide a computational advantage in D-Wave processors
column2: said Andrew King
column3: director of performance research at D-Wave.

column1: D-Wave's processors are based on quantum annealing technology
column2: which is a quantum computing technique used to find solutions to optimization problems. While some argue that the scope of the problems that can be resolved by the technology is limited
column3: quantum annealing processors are easier to control and operate than their gate-based equivalents
column4: which is why D-Wave's technology has already reached much higher numbers of qubits than can be found in the devices built by big players like IBM or Google.

column1: To simulate exotic magnetism
column2: King and his team used the D-Wave 2
column3: 000-qubit system
column4: which was recently revised to reduce noise
column5: to model a programmable quantum magnetic system
column6: just like Berezinskii
column7: Kosterlitz and Thouless did in the 1970s to observe the unusual states of matter. The researchers also programmed a standard classical algorithm for this kind of simulation
column9: to compare the quantum results with CPU-run calculations. As the numbers show
column10: the quantum simulation outperformed classical methods by a margin.

column1: What we see is a huge benefit in absolute terms
column2: said King. ""This simulation is a real problem that scientists have already attacked using the algorithms we compared against
column3: marking a significant milestone and an important foundation for future development. This wouldn't have been possible today without D-Wave's lower noise processor.""

column1: Equally as significant as the performance milestone
column2: said D-Wave's team
column3: is the fact that the quantum annealing processors were used to run a practical application
column4: instead of a proof-of-concept or an engineered
column5: synthetic problem with little real-world relevance. Until now
column6: quantum methods have mostly been leveraged to prove that the technology has the potential to solve practical problems
column7: and is yet to make tangible marks in the real world.

column1: In contrast
column2: D-Wave's latest experiment resolved a meaningful problem that scientists are interested in independent of quantum computing. The findings have already attracted the attention of scientists around the world.

column1: The search for quantum advantage in computations is becoming increasingly lively because there are special problems where genuine progress is being made. These problems may appear somewhat contrived even to physicists
column2: said Gabriel Aeppli
column3: professor of physics at ETH Zürich and EPF Lausanne.

column1: But in this paper from a collaboration between D-Wave Systems
column2: Google
column3: and Simon Fraser University
column4: it appears that there is an advantage for quantum annealing using a special purpose processor over classical simulations for the more 'practical' problem of finding the equilibrium state of a particular quantum magnet.""

column1: D-Wave
column2: however
column3: stayed clear of claiming quantum advantage
column4: which happens when a quantum processor can demonstrate superiority over all possible classical competition; King stressed that it is still possible to design highly specialized algorithms to simulate the model once the properties of the model are already known.

column1: The real significance of the experiment lies in the proof that a computational advantage can already be achieved using existing quantum methods to solve a valuable materials science problem.
These experiments are an important advance in the field
column2: providing the best look yet at the inner workings of D-Wave computers
column3: and showing a scaling advantage over its chief classical competition
column4: said King. ""All quantum computing platforms will have to pass this kind of checkpoint on the way to widespread adoption.""

column1: From improving the logistics of retail supply chains to simulating new proteins for therapeutic drugs
column2: through optimizing vehicles' routes through busy city streets
column3: D-Wave is currently counting 250 early quantum annealing applications from various different customers.";5366;['gop6fbb'

column1: c92b11e5facbe9bd5c90b702b5a9e1d1e8d0d8d8a4d0c7b85729bd2b559a210f;posted_link;r/space;http://www.astronomy.com/news/2019/05/antimatter-acts-like-regular-matter-in-classic-double-slit-experiment;['bmki0y'];['clayt6'];[1557412226.0];"[""Antimatter acts as both a particle and a wave
column2: just like normal matter. Researchers used positrons—the antimatter equivalent of electrons—to recreate the double-slit experiment
column3: and while they've seen quantum interference of electrons for decades
column4: this is the first such observation for antimatter.""]";[nan];2019-05-08;"Bailey Bedford; Inside Science Contributor; Published Wednesday; May 8";Antimatter acts like regular matter in classic double-slit experiment;"One of the strangest things about quantum mechanics is that a particle can act like a wave. In particular
column5: in a double-slit experiment
column6: individual particles that are shot through a pair of slits create a pattern as if they each went through both slits simultaneously and interfered with themselves. Researchers have now shown for the first time that antimatter behaves in the same unintuitive way.

column1: Antimatter particles correspond to the regular particles that we are used to
column2: such as protons and electrons
column3: but with the opposite electrical charge and magnetic properties. But when antimatter and matter meet
column4: they both disappear in a flash of energy
column5: which makes antimatter rare and difficult to study.

column1: A new experiment uses positrons — the antimatter counterpart of electrons — to create a situation similar to a traditional double-slit experiment. While scientists have been able to see the quantum interference of electrons for decades
column2: this is the first time they have been able to observe it for antimatter. They present their results in an article published today in the journal Scientific Advances.

column1: The researchers used positrons that were emitted by a radioactive material and then accelerated and formed into a beam. Instead of traveling through just two slits
column2: as in the classic experiment
column3: the beam went through two sequential gratings with different spacing between the slits. This setup helped magnify the effects the researchers needed to measure. The positrons that survived the trip hit a detector
column4: where they formed an interference pattern.

column1: The difference in how many positrons were detected in the high and low points of the pattern depended on the particles’ energy. When the researchers analyzed this dependence
column2: they were able to show that the pattern must have come from the positrons behaving like waves. Since
column3: on average
column4: fewer than one positron should have been travelling through the gratings at any time
column5: the researchers also note that the interference pattern must have come from the individual particles interfering with themselves.

column1: Researchers believe that more experiments like this will open new windows on the behavior of antimatter
column2: including how gravity affects it. While Einstein’s theory of relativity predicts that gravity will affect antimatter in the same way it affects matter
column3: other theories propose differences.";2355;['emvh5xo'

column1: 2be0d8fe7e5daa86ffb1b15af7319940e649bf382eede35623ee5b04f9068395;posted_link;r/technews;https://scitechdaily.com/free-open-access-quantum-computer-now-operational/;['meqr5g'];['MichaelTen'];[1616892067.0];['Free Open-Access Quantum Computer Now Operational'];[nan];2021-03-19;Mike O'Neill;Free Open-Access Quantum Computer Now Operational;"Scientists worldwide can use ion-based testbed at Sandia National Laboratories.

A new Department of Energy open-access quantum computing testbed is ready for the public. Scientists from Indiana University recently became the first team to begin using Sandia National Laboratories’ Quantum Scientific Computing Open User Testbed
column2: or QSCOUT.

column1: Quantum computers are poised to become major technological drivers over the coming decades. But to get there
column2: scientists need to experiment with quantum machines that relatively few universities or companies have. Now
column3: scientists can use Sandia’s QSCOUT for research that might not be possible at their home institutions
column4: without the cost or restrictions of using a commercial testbed.

column1: “QSCOUT serves a need in the quantum community by giving users the controls to study the machine itself
column2: which aren’t yet available in commercial quantum computing systems. It also saves theorists and scientists from the trouble of building their own machines. We hope to gain new insights into quantum performance and architecture as well as solve problems that require quantum computation
column3: ” said Sandia physicist and QSCOUT lead Susan Clark.

column1: She said the new testbed is a rare machine in three ways: first
column2: as a free
column3: open-access testbed; second
column4: as one made with trapped ion technology; and third
column5: as a platform that gives users an uncommon amount of control over their research.

column1: Last month
column2: Sandia began running the testbed’s first user experiment for scientists from Indiana University. Researchers from IBM
column3: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
column4: the University of New Mexico and the University of California
column5: Berkeley
column6: have also been selected to begin experiments soon. Their projects range from testing benchmarking techniques to developing algorithms that could someday solve problems in chemistry too complex for normal computers.

column1: Researchers interested in using the Quantum Scientific Computing Open User Testbed are invited to sign up for notifications by emailing [email protected]. Sandia expects to select the next round of projects in the spring
column2: subject to change.

column1: Sandia soliciting proposals
Now
column2: Sandia is getting ready for more research proposals. Anyone can submit a proposal to use QSCOUT
column3: and computing time is free thanks to funding from the DOE Office of Science
column4: Advanced Scientific Computing Research program. The next group of projects is expected to be selected in the spring.

column1: On top of providing an exceptional research opportunity
column2: QSCOUT has a rare design for a testbed. Most commercial testbeds use technology called superconducting circuits. Such machines need to be kept at ultralow temperatures
column3: making them expensive to build and operate. But Sandia’s testbed uses what is called an ion trap instead. This means Sandia’s testbed can run at warmer temperatures. Trapped ions also yield clearer signals than circuits and hold on to information longer
column4: enabling scientists to perform different types of experiments and compare the two platforms.

column1: Trapped ions are held inside QSCOUT in a so-called “trap on a chip
column2: ” a flat
column3: bow tie-shaped device
column4: about 2 cm (0.8 inches) long
column5: overlaid on a semiconductor chip. Three electrically charged atoms of the element ytterbium are suspended in place by radio waves and an electric field above a hairline channel that runs down the center of the device. Lasers encode information in each ion as a qubit
column6: comparable to a bit in a conventional computer

column1: Sandia plans to expand the system from three to 32 qubits over the next three years so scientists can perform more sophisticated tests.";3604;['grl9eby'

column1: bde786e25c05f23816451f432f9a0e634997366b567e201ae9efcb6c036a367c;posted_link;r/technology;http://www.technologyreview.com/view/514581/government-lab-reveals-quantum-internet-operated-continuously-for-over-two-years/;['1ds6rp'];['r721'];[1367829444.0];['Government Lab Reveals It Has Operated Quantum Internet For Over Two Years'];[nan];2013-03-06;   Emerging Technology from the arXiv;Government Lab Reveals It Has Operated Quantum Internet for Over Two Years;"That sets things up nicely for perfectly secure messaging known as quantum cryptography and this is actually a fairly straightforward technique for any half decent quantum optics lab. Indeed
column2: a company called ID Quantique sells an off-the-shelf system that has begun to attract banks and other organisations interested in perfect security.

column1: These systems have an important limitation
column2: however. The current generation of quantum cryptography systems are point-to-point connections over a single length of fibre
column3: So they can send secure messages from A to B but cannot route this information onwards to C
column4: D
column5: E or F. That’s because the act of routing a message means reading the part of it that indicates where it has to be routed. And this inevitably changes it
column6: at least with conventional routers. This makes a quantum internet impossible with today’s technology

column1: Various teams are racing to develop quantum routers that will fix this problem by steering quantum messages without destroying them. We looked at one of the first last year. But the truth is that these devices are still some way from commercial reality.
Today
column2: Richard Hughes and pals at Los Alamos National Labs in New Mexico reveal an alternative quantum internet
column3: which they say they’ve been running for two and half years. Their approach is to create a quantum network based around a hub and spoke-type network. All messages get routed from any point in the network to another via this central hub.

column1: This is not the first time this kind of approach has been tried. The idea is that messages to the hub rely on the usual level of quantum security. However
column2: once at the hub
column3: they are converted to conventional classical bits and then reconverted into quantum bits to be sent on the second leg of their journey.

column1: So as long as the hub is secure
column2: then the network should also be secure.

column1: The problem with this approach is scalability. As the number of links to the hub increases
column2: it becomes increasingly difficult to handle all the possible connections that can be made between one point in the network and another.

column1: Hughes and co say they’ve solved this with their unique approach which equips each node in the network with quantum transmitters–i.e.
column2: lasers–but not with photon detectors which are expensive and bulky. Only the hub is capable of receiving a quantum message (although all nodes can send and receiving conventional messages in the normal way).

column1: That may sound limiting but it still allows each node to send a one-time pad to the hub which it then uses to communicate securely over a classical link. The hub can then route this message to another node using another one time pad that it has set up with this second node. So the entire network is secure
column2: provided that the central hub is also secure.

column1: The big advantage of this system is that it makes the technology required at each node extremely simple–essentially little more than a laser. In fact
column2: Los Alamos has already designed and built plug-and-play type modules that are about the size of a box of matches. “Our next-generation [module] will be an order of magnitude smaller in each linear dimension
column3: ” they say.

column1: Their ultimate goal is to have one of these modules built in to almost any device connected to a fibre optic network
column2: such as set top TV boxes
column3: home computers and so on
column4: to allow perfectly secure messaging.

column1: Having run this system now for over two years
column2: Los Alamos are now highly confident in its efficacy.

column1: Of course
column2: the network can never be more secure than the hub at the middle of it and this is an important limitation of this approach. By contrast
column3: a pure quantum internet should allow perfectly secure communication from any point in the network to any other.

column1: Another is that this approach will become obsolete as soon as quantum routers become commercially viable. So the question for any investors is whether they can get their money back in the time before then. The odds are that they won’t have to wait long to find out.";3987;['c9tcui7'

column1: 0bcc1e323e41ebf61d76b7695132dabca1a6089eaf7aeb17cdbb937a6c547c49;posted_link;r/space;http://www.astronomy.com/news/2018/05/the-case-against-dark-matter;['8hr7hw'];['clayt6'];[1525728731.0];"['Emergent Gravity seeks to replace the need for dark matter. According to the theory
column2: gravity is not a fundamental force that ""just is
column3: but rather a phenomenon that springs from the entanglement of quantum bodies
column4: similar to the way temperature is derived from the motions of individual particles.']";[nan];2018-05-07;Tyler Krueger;The case against dark matter;"Verlinde believes that this is an indication that he is on to something.

column1: “That fact kind of hints that it has something to do with the Hubble expansion [of the universe]
column2: which at present is due to the presence of dark energy
column3: ” he says.

column1: The Hubble constant describes the observed accelerating expansion of the universe. This acceleration is unexplained
column2: but has been attributed to “dark energy
column3: ” which Verlinde says can be used to explain away the idea of dark matter.

column1: “Dark energy is quite an important part of my theory
column2: ” Verlinde says. “I don’t do away with everything that’s called ‘dark
column3: ’ I just explain what is what we now call ‘dark matter’ by thinking about what the influence of dark energy would be
column4: and that [dark energy] actually gives the same effect.”

column1: It should be noted that Verlinde is tackling the problem with dark matter from a specific point of view as a string theorist and is working to fit it into that perspective. Mark Van Raamsdonk
column2: a professor of physics at the University of British Columbia
column3: says that this method should be approached with caution.

column1: “This possibility is intriguing
column2: but as far as I'm aware
column3: it's not based on a precise model that is mathematically consistent
column4: ” Van Raamsdonk says. “Rather
column5: he's using his intuition to piece together a set of ideas and provide a story for how things might work. He is a very accomplished physicist
column6: so I think his intuition is worth paying attention to.”

column1: Early days
So far
column2: the ideas that Verlinde confidently stand by have proven to be mathematically and observationally valid — at least
column3: as far as galaxy rotation curves go. The real project will be building a theory that describes more than the rotation of galaxies. Sabine Hossenfelder
column4: a research fellow at the Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies
column5: says that a major challenge will be describing the evolution of the early universe.

column1: Currently
column2: theories that incorporate particle dark matter correctly predict the observed temperature variations in the cosmic microwave background. “Unfortunately
column3: Verlinde’s emergent gravity model does not allow the necessary analysis [to prove its validity] — at least not yet
column4: ” she wrote in a Forbes

column1: article.
Verlinde is aware of the young theory’s shortcomings
column2: but is confident that he can address them in the future.

column1: “I only focused mostly on trying to explain these rotation curves
column2: but dark matter has been used in many other parts of trying to understand the early universe
column3: ” Verlinde says. “I have to develop an explanation of how galaxies form
column4: but also these fluctuations in what we see in the cosmic microwave background. If I want to describe the evolution of the universe
column5: I have to calculate much more what is happening on longer timescales. That is the next step for me.”

column1: Searching for support
Pitching this idea around the world has been quite a task for Verlinde. Given that the idea goes so strongly against popular belief
column2: he has only a handful of allies even amongst his own teammates.

column1: “I have to sell my ideas to various audiences
column2: not just to cosmologists and people that are dealing with dark matter in other ways
column3: but also my string theory colleagues
column4: ” he says. “I think people are slowly starting to see the advantages of the logic of my reasoning.”

column1: “There is a lot of work still to be done
column2: but I think this is a better theory than to just assume that there is dark matter. Because if dark matter has so many forms in which people can imagine it’s there
column3: and there are a zoo of those theories and nobody really knows which one it is
column4: maybe all of those are wrong indeed.”

column1: Regardless of how Verlinde’s theory fares overall in the pursuit of understanding
column2: the outcome has some exciting prospects.

column1: “In any case
column2: trying to understand the implications of these new connections between gravity and [quantum] entanglement
column3: is very exciting and many of us are working hard to see where this will lead
column4: ” Van Raamsdonk says. “Even if Verlinde's specific explanation for dark matter doesn't turn out to be correct
column5: we are already learning new things about gravity and black holes
column6: and I'm optimistic that we will learn something exciting about cosmology

column1: 198e2416cf4bae6d79ecf481c6468a7871e786996523c95324b8549d611ae84f;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.thesciverse.com/2022/06/uk-military-wants-to-install-quantum.html;['vc2907'];['soulpost'];[1655209245.0];['UK military wants to install quantum computers in tanks'];[nan];2022-06-14;Blogger;UK military wants to install quantum computers in tanks;"According to New Scientist
column2: the UK Ministry of Defense recently purchased a quantum computer to see if the technology may one day be used to make tanks smart.

column1: The acquisition was revealed this week by Richard Murray
column2: the CEO of quantum computing firm Orca. Part of the reason Orca's product caught the MoD's interest
column3: according to Murray
column4: is that some of their devices can fit on a standard computer shelf and work at ambient temperature.

column1: Murray told the outlet
column2: ""It lends itself to all of those sorts of things
column3: plus it's more durable."" ""I mean
column4: maybe a fighter plane one day. I believe we're concentrating on a larger-scale platform that can be deployed on the ground.""

column1: But there's a major issue: it's unclear what these computers are expected to accomplish on board any type of military equipment
column2: especially because experts have yet to demonstrate that the technology has any innovative
column3: real-world uses.

column1: This equipment we're giving to them surely won't accomplish anything a conventional computer won't
column2: Murray told New Scientist. ""I suppose
column3: in that view
column4: it's a research instrument."" ""Right now
column5: a lot of activity is being supported.

column1: That's a little hazy. Quantum computers have already been proven to dramatically accelerate the solution of extremely particular mathematical problems.
Even less obvious is how those talents may be used to assist in a combat situation.
Through applications such as picture identification and sensor management
column2: an Orca representative told New Scientist
column3: ""our hope is that this technology will make communication on the battlefield substantially simpler.""

column1: This technology will make information processing for command decisions on the battlefield more nimble
column2: while also reducing the hazards of data exchange with an undeployable processor outside the battlefield
column3: says the company.

column1: We can't help but think that Orca's agreement with the Ministry of Defense is an issue in search of a solution.
At this moment
column2: it's anyone's guess if quantum computers will allow tanks to become smarter and offer the UK military a large enough advantage on the battlefield.";2102;['icbkcv0'

column1: 3160a1832a29ffc7580ad55a00f2f6dd94c03fba90beb4306afb822112f18a12;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/quantum-computers-canada-1.6546128;['wnqygj'];['thisisjas9n'];[1660431264.0];['Quantum computers may be for sale sooner than you think. And Canadian firms are at the forefront'];[nan];2022-08-09;Nisha Patel · CBC News;Quantum computers may be for sale sooner than you think. And Canadian firms are at the forefront | CBC News;"These Canadian startups are taking quantum computing mainstream
Experts say technology is getting closer to commercialization
It's not what you'd expect to find on the 29th floor of a Toronto office building. Instead of cubicles
column2: a complex arrangement of lasers
column3: mirrors and optical fibres run from floor to ceiling
column4: making up the quantum computer called Borealis.

column1: And Borealis recently hit a milestone by solving a colossal math problem.
If we ran [the problem] on the most powerful supercomputer out there
column2: it would take 9
column3: 000 years. For Borealis
column4: it takes less than a second
column5: which is quite incredible
column6: says Christian Weedbrook

column1: Weedbrook said it's just the third time a quantum computer has tackled something out of reach for an ordinary computer
column2: a scenario called quantum advantage. The first time was by Google in 2019
column3: the second by a team of Chinese researchers in 2020. Xanadu's achievement was published earlier this summer in the magazine Nature.

column1: For years
column2: quantum computers have mostly been the focus of academics and government. Now
column3: experts say we could be near a turning point where the technology is closer to commercialization.

column1: It's a really nice step showing that the technology is mature … and could be a candidate for more wide-scale adoption of quantum computers
column2: said Anne Broadbent
column3: an associate professor at the University of Ottawa where she researches quantum computing.

column1: Weedbrook said the potential for quantum computers is almost limitless
column2: opening the door to ""solving important business problems in industries from finance to drug discovery and material design.""

column1: Exponential possibilities
The concepts used in quantum computing may seem mind-bending
column2: and they're very powerful. Ordinary computers encode information using zeros and ones
column3: called binary digits — or bits for short. Using quantum physics
column4: these supercomputers can use zeros
column5: ones
column6: or any value in between
column7: in something known as quantum digits — or qubits. This allows them to perform calculations much faster on problems that are more complex.

column1: But the big difference between the two types of computers is how they actually approach a problem. If a regular computer were to try to get through a maze
column2: it would consider each possible route one at a time. A quantum computer would consider all the routes at once.

column1: Just adding one [qubit] doubles the computational capacity of your system
column2: says Stephanie Simmons
column3: an associate professor of physics at Simon Fraser University and a founder of Vancouver-based quantum startup Photonic. ""It's exponential … so the scale is off the charts and that's the kind of power that we're hoping to leverage.""

column1: In July
column2: Simmons and her team also had an innovation published in Nature: a silicon chip that holds 150
column3: 000 qubits. Since silicon is already so widely used in technology
column4: Simmons says it will be easier to produce these beefier chips on a larger scale.

column1: What we see next is the commercialization of quantum
column2: and so we'll start to see little glimmers and then all of a sudden it's going to change everything we do.""

column1: The race is on to build a universal quantum computer that can solve a wide array of problems. Startups in the sector are booming
column2: with 23 quantum businesses based in Canada
column3: according to McKinsey & Co.
column4: a global management consultant. The U.S. is the only country further ahead
column5: sitting at 59 quantum-related startups.

column1: Weedbrook said the growth in this field offers an opportunity to attract scientific talent to the country.
Xanadu is kind of doing … a brain gain of sorts
column2: he said. ""We have over half the people that started it are actually from overseas.""

column1: American corporate heavyweights like IBM
column2: Google and Microsoft are making a big commercial push
column3: as are Amazon and Honeywell. And governments are increasingly making quantum computing a priority. The U.S. just signed the CHIPS and Science Act
column4: which provides about $280 billion US for quantum
column5: computing and artificial intelligence research and development. Meanwhile
column6: China and the EU are also investing heavily in this technology.

column1: We're looking at a scenario where there's international competition that is very strong
column2: said Broadbent
column3: the Ottawa professor. ""Canada has been traditionally ahead in many areas … we want to keep that effort going.""

column1: Canada committed $360 million in the 2021 federal budget towards building a national quantum strategy. Simmons said she hopes that with continued investment ""we could really make a big difference in terms of keeping the jobs here
column2: keeping the talent here and actually benefiting from this economic windfall.""

column1: Getting practical
While quantum computers are still in their nascent stage
column2: experts already point to them as having the potential to solve complex problems like climate change and cybersecurity. The technology is beginning to creep into business plans too
column3: with Goldman Sachs using quantum computers to improve calculations in options financing and Volkswagen looking to use them to optimize its manufacturing.

column1: Prof. Daniel Gottesman
column2: a theoretical computer scientist at the University of Maryland
column3: acknowledges there is still plenty of hype in the industry.

column1: There's a lot of reason to hope for the future of quantum computing
column2: but there's also uncertainty as well … progress could slow down
column3: he said.

column1: Still he predicts quantum computers will live up to expectations; it's just a matter of when. ""It will be some time before we get ones that are big enough to do things that are useful for anything — and even longer before we get ones that are useful for lots of things.""
The technology does face hurdles
column2: including cost and the scale of production
column3: but Simmons expects quantum computing to make a big difference.

column1: Even if you don't use quantum computers at your desk
column2: you're still going to live the effects. Because lots of firms are going to be able to use this exponential boost in computing power to change what they can deliver to us as consumers.""";5983;['ik6yrky'

column1: f19ad34e670bf695d067d5213d8ce141090285a119f44585635a973c8fbd32dc;posted_link;r/worldnews;https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2020/02/quantum-internet-closer-physicists-stretch-spooky-link-between-atoms?rss=1;['f3nmdr'];['the_karma_llama'];[1581658501.0];['Scientists have demonstrated quantum entanglement in a fiber optic cable over a distance of 50 kms
column2: in a step towards a quantum internet'];[nan];2020-02-13;Adrian Cho;Quantum internet closer as physicists stretch spooky link between atoms;"Physicists in China have forged a mysterious quantum connection between particles
column3: called entanglement
column4: over dozens of kilometers of standard optical fiber
column5: setting a new record. The advance marks a long step toward a fully quantum mechanical internet—although such a network is still years away.

column1: The achievement springs not from one particular breakthrough
column2: but from the careful implementation of multiple techniques
column3: says David Awschalom
column4: a physicist at the University of Chicago. ""I'm very impressed that they've integrated these various technologies into a full system
column5: he says. ""It's a beautiful piece of work.""

column1: Entanglement links the strange states of tiny quantum mechanical objects. For example
column2: a top can spin either clockwise or counterclockwise
column3: but an atom can spin both ways at once—at least until it is measured and that two-way state collapses one way or the other. Two atoms can be entangled so that each is in an uncertain two-way state
column4: but their spins are definitely correlated
column5: say
column6: in opposite directions. So if physicists measure the first atom and find it spinning clockwise
column7: they know instantly the other one must be spinning counterclockwise
column8: no matter how far away it is.

column1: Entanglement would be key to a fully quantum internet that would let quantum computers of the future communicate with one another and be immune to hacking. If hackers messed with communication
column2: they would spoil the entanglement
column3: revealing their presence. Various companies already sell systems that send messages in quantum states of light that are largely unhackable. But to use such links
column4: the information must still be decoded at each network node
column5: which is potentially vulnerable. In a quantum internet
column6: any node could be entangled with any other
column7: so messages between them couldn't be decoded at intermediate nodes.

column1: But developers must first stretch entanglement over greater distances. Previously
column2: researchers had demonstrated entanglement of two bits of matter over 1.3 kilometers of optical fiber. Now
column3: Xiao-Hui Bao
column4: Jian-Wei Pan
column5: and colleagues at the University of Science and Technology of China
column6: Beijing
column7: have demonstrated entanglement over fiber optic links of up to 50 kilometers
column8: as they report this week in Nature.

column1: The details are dizzying
column2: but the basic idea of the experiment is relatively simple. Researchers start with two identical stations in a single lab
column3: each containing a cloud of rubidium atoms. Prodding each cloud with a laser
column4: they generate a photon whose polarization
column5: which can corkscrew clockwise or counterclockwise
column6: is entangled with the cloud's internal state. They then send the photons down two parallel optical fibers to a third station in another lab 11 kilometers away
column7: where the photons interact in a way that instantly passes the original entanglement connection to the two faraway atom clouds.

column1: To do that
column2: physicists take advantage of the fact that
column3: according to quantum mechanics
column4: a measurement can affect the state of the measured object. At the destination lab
column5: the physicists set up a measurement of the photons' polarizations that
column6: even as it consumes the photons
column7: it also ""projects"" them into a specific entangled state with 25% probability. For those trials
column8: the measurement instantly passes the entanglement back to the atom clouds. The researchers performed a variant of the experiment that extended the link from 22 kilometers to 50 kilometers
column9: albeit with fibers wound on spools.

column1: To make the experiment work
column2: the team had to get several elements just right
column3: Pan says. A major hurdle was avoiding absorption of the photons in the optical fiber. To do that
column4: Pan and colleagues used another laser pulse and a device called a waveguide to stretch the photons' wavelength 60% to the sweet spot for transmission down a standard optical fiber.

column1: At the same
column2: the researchers made life easier for themselves because the atoms clouds were actually less than 1 meter apart and merely connected by a long optical fiber. That closeness made synchronizing the experiment significantly simpler. So
column3: strictly speaking
column4: the record of entangling atomic-scale particles separated by 1.3 kilometers still stands
column5: says
column6: Ronald Hanson
column7: a physicist at Delft University of Technology

column1: Still
column2: Hanson says
column3: the experiment is significant because
column4: for a network
column5: the setup link is about half of the basic element called a quantum repeater. A repeater would consist of two systems like the one in the experiment placed end to end. Once physicists had entangled the atom clouds at the ends of each system
column6: they could perform additional measurements on clouds in the middle that would swap the entanglement to the clouds on the ends
column7: stretching the entanglement twice as far. ""This experiment is a big step toward a quantum repeater

column1: But several aspects of the work need to be improved before it can be used to make a quantum repeater
column2: Hanson says. In particular
column3: the atom clouds do not yet hold their delicate quantum states long enough to allow the multiple linking needed in a quantum repeater. Pan agrees
column4: but says his group is working on that and urges patience. ""I think a true quantum network is at least 10 years away.""";5200;['fhjxlgw'

column1: c21ef5cec094b63c1f442501cbce6fc262e8445ee93c4353c9626b48fda1bcf3;posted_link;r/science;https://newsroom.unsw.edu.au/news/science-tech/hot-qubits-made-sydney-break-one-biggest-constraints-practical-quantum-computers;['g227nl'];['______---------'];[1586989438.0];"['A new quantum processor unit cell works at temperatures 15 times greater than competing models. It still requires refrigeration
column2: but only a ""few thousand dollars\' worth
column3: rather than the millions of dollars"" currently needed.']";[nan];2020-04-16;"UNSW Media; Science";Hot qubits made in Sydney break one of the biggest constraints to practical quantum computers;"Most quantum computers being developed around the world will only work at fractions of a degree above absolute zero. That requires multi-million-dollar refrigeration and as soon as you plug them into conventional electronic circuits they’ll instantly overheat.

column1: But now researchers led by Professor Andrew Dzurak at UNSW Sydney have addressed this problem.
“Our new results open a path from experimental devices to affordable quantum computers for real world business and government applications
column2: ” says Professor Dzurak.

column1: Getting warmer
The researchers’ proof-of-concept quantum processor unit cell
column2: on a silicon chip
column3: works at 1.5 Kelvin – 15 times warmer than the main competing chip-based technology being developed by Google
column4: IBM
column5: and others
column6: which uses superconducting qubits.

column1: “This is still very cold
column2: but is a temperature that can be achieved using just a few thousand dollars’ worth of refrigeration
column3: rather than the millions of dollars needed to cool chips to 0.1 Kelvin
column4: ” explains Dzurak.

column1: “While difficult to appreciate using our everyday concepts of temperature
column2: this increase is extreme in the quantum world.”

column1: Quantum computers are expected to outperform conventional ones for a range of important problems
column2: from precision drug-making to search algorithms. Designing one that can be manufactured and operated in a real-world setting
column3: however
column4: represents a major technical challenge.

column1: The UNSW researchers believe that they have overcome one of the hardest obstacles standing in the way of quantum computers becoming a reality.
In a paper published in the journal Nature today
column2: Dzurak’s team
column3: together with collaborators in Canada
column4: Finland and Japan
column5: report a proof-of-concept quantum processor unit cell that
column6: unlike most designs being explored worldwide
column7: doesn’t need to operate at temperatures below one-tenth of one Kelvin.

column1: Dzurak’s team first announced their experimental results via the academic pre-print archive in February last year. Then
column2: in October 2019
column3: a group in the Netherlands led by a former post-doctoral researcher in Dzurak’s group
column4: Menno Veldhorst
column5: announced a similar result using the same silicon technology developed at UNSW in 2014. The confirmation of this ‘hot qubit’ behaviour by two groups on opposite sides of the world has led to the two papers being published ‘back-to-back’ in the same issue of Nature today.

column1: Qubit pairs are the fundamental units of quantum computing. Like its classical computing analogue – the bit – each qubit characterises two states
column2: a 0 or a 1
column3: to create a binary code. Unlike a bit
column4: however
column5: it can manifest both states simultaneously
column6: in what is known as a “superposition”.

column1: Cheaper and easier to integrate
The unit cell developed by Dzurak’s team comprises two qubits confined in a pair of quantum dots embedded in silicon. The result
column2: scaled up
column3: can be manufactured using existing silicon chip factories
column4: and would operate without the need for multi-million-dollar cooling. It would also be easier to integrate with conventional silicon chips
column5: which will be needed to control the quantum processor.

column1: A quantum computer that is able to perform the complex calculations needed to design new medicines
column2: for example
column3: will require millions of qubit pairs
column4: and is generally accepted to be at least a decade away. This need for millions of qubits presents a big challenge for designers.

column1: “Every qubit pair added to the system increases the total heat generated
column2: ” explains Dzurak
column3: “and added heat leads to errors. That’s primarily why current designs need to be kept so close to absolute zero.”

column1: The prospect of maintaining quantum computers with enough qubits to be useful at temperatures much colder than deep space is daunting
column2: expensive and pushes refrigeration technology to the limit.

column1: The UNSW team
column2: however
column3: have created an elegant solution to the problem
column4: by initialising and “reading” the qubit pairs using electrons tunnelling between the two quantum dots.

column1: The proof-of-principle experiments were performed by Dr Henry Yang from the UNSW team
column2: who Dzurak describes as a “brilliant experimentalist”.

column1: Team effort
Other authors on the paper include Ross Leon
column2: Jason Hwang (now at the University of Sydney)
column3: Andre Saraiva
column4: Tuomo Tanttu
column5: Wister Huang
column6: Kok-Wai Chan and Fay Hudson
column8: as well as long-time collaborators Dr Arne Laucht and Professor Andrea Morello from UNSW.

column1: Dr Kuan-Yen from Aalto University in Finland assisted the device fabrication team
column2: while Professor Kohei Itoh from Keio University in Japan provided enriched silicon-28 wafers from which the devices were made. The qubit devices incorporated nano-scale magnets to help enable qubit operation
column3: and these were designed with support from a team led by Professor Michel Pioro-Ladrière at Université de Sherbrooke in Canada
column4: including his PhD student Julien Camirand Lemyre.";4835;['fnj9zxg'

column1: bb6823749eb0cf27b1606d33ffc5f79153d89c8199956820434bcc892059849e;posted_link;r/science;http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21328495.200-first-quantum-jiggles-detected-in-solid-object.html;['p0iie'];['DrJulianBashir'];[1327763130.0];['First quantum jiggles detected in solid object - A quantum-mechanical twang has been detected in a bar of silicon – previously such movement had been measured only in particles'];[nan];2012-01-25;;First quantum jiggles detected in solid object;"NOTHING sits still. Even at absolute zero
column2: when the thermal jiggling of matter is frozen
column3: all things must still buzz to the tune of quantum mechanics. Now this subtle jittering has been detected in a small silicon bar
column4: the first solid object ever to reveal its quantum vibrations.

column1: This phenomenon
column2: called zero-point fluctuation
column3: is a consequence of Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle
column4: which says that we can never pin down the precise position and motion of any object. So far zero-point energy has only been seen directly in single atoms or small collections of particles.

column1: The new experiment uses a silicon bar about 12 micrometres long and less than a micrometre across. Oskar Painter at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena and colleagues cooled the bar to within half a degree of absolute zero and then used a laser to detect its motion.
Some photons from this laser got a shift in energy when they hit the vibrating bar. Ordinary thermal vibrations can either boost or reduce photon energy
column2: but the zero-point quantum vibration is different. Because it is the lowest energy state possible
column3: it can only absorb energy. Painter’s group detected this bias towards lower-energy scattered light
column4: a clear signature of a quantum twang (Physical Review Letters

column1: “Seeing these effects in large objects can provide us with a way to probe the foundations of quantum mechanics
column2: ” says Caltech team member Amir Safavi-Naeini.";1467;['c3lit6o'

column4: 'c3liyoc'
