column1: d12a09ea3ce255785c7308048b93287235713b3e2af06b771f4654c3ded96d18;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.tomshardware.com/news/amd-teleportation-quantum-computing-patent;['pghepu'];['ourlifeintoronto'];[1630587633.0];['New AMD Patent Proposes Teleportation to Make Quantum Computing More Efficient'];[nan];2021-08-30;Francisco Pires;New AMD Patent Proposes Teleportation to Make Quantum Computing More Efficient;"A team of researchers with AMD have filed a patent application that looks toward a more efficient and reliable quantum computing architecture
column2: thanks to a conventional multi-SIMD (Single Instruction Multiple Data) approach.

column1: According to the application
column2: AMD is researching a system that aims to use quantum teleportation to increase a quantum system's reliability
column3: while simultaneously reducing the number of qubits necessary for a given calculation. The aim is to both alleviate scaling problems and calculation errors stemming from system instability.

column1: There are two major hurdles on the road to quantum development and eventual quantum supremacy: scalability and stability. Quantum states are a fickle matter
column2: so sensitive that they can decohere at the slightest provocation -- and a quantum system's sensitivity tends to increase with the presence of more qubits in a given system.

column1: The AMD patent
column2: titled ""Look Ahead Teleportation for Reliable Computation in Multi-SIMD Quantum Processor
column3: aims to improve quantum stability
column4: scalability
column5: and performance in novel
column6: more efficient ways. It describes a quantum architecture based on quantum processing regions: areas of the chip that hold or can hold qubits
column7: lying in wait for their turn on the processing pipeline. AMD's approach aims to improve on existing quantum architectures by actually reducing the number of qubits needed to perform complex calculations -- via the science fiction-esque concept of quantum teleportation.

column1: AMD's design aims to teleport qubits across regions
column2: enabling workloads that would theoretically require in-order execution to become capable of being processed in an out-of-order philosophy. As a quick refresher
column3: in-order execution features dependencies between one instruction and the next
column4: meaning that a workload has to be processed sequentially
column5: with later steps dependent on the previous step being fully processed and its result being known before the chip can move ahead with the computation.

column1: As you may imagine
column2: there are chip resources (in this case
column3: qubits) that sit idle until it's their time to perform the next calculation step. On the other hand
column4: Out-of-order execution analyzes a given workload
column5: figures out which parts of it are dependent on previous results and which are not
column6: and executes every step of the instruction that doesn't require a previous result
column7: thus improving performance via increased parallelism.

column1: AMD's patent also includes a look-ahead processor embedded into the architecture
tasked to analyze the input workload
column2: predict what steps can be tackled in parallel (and those that can't)
column3: and appropriately distribute the workload across qubits
column4: using a quantum teleporting technique to deliver them to the required quantum processing
column5: SIMD-based region.

column1: How this quantum teleportation occurs isn't described in the patent -- it looks like AMD is playing its cards close to its chest on this one. Perhaps we're looking at the beginning of AMD's ""Zen 98"" design (that's a joke
column2: to be clear)
column3: or maybe this will not materialize in an actual product. But it does show
column4: beyond any doubt and surprising no one
column5: that AMD is indeed working on quantum computing. That seems to be the next great computing race. And while AMD may or may not be backing the right horse to ride toward an eventual victory
column6: at least it seems the company does plan to be a part of the race.";3372;['hb15ebw'

column1: ca2e2ee5d2e3091569a9caa499f6cde9cb0477e40ca948d080720dcc0d2a88f4;posted_link;r/technews;https://news.uchicago.edu/story/chicago-quantum-network-argonne-pritzker-molecular-engineering-toshiba;['vfc9tt'];['giuliomagnifico'];[1655577085.0];['Chicago expands and activates quantum network
column2: taking steps toward a secure quantum internet'];[nan];2022-06-16;Mheslinga;Chicago expands and activates quantum network
column3: taking steps toward a secure quantum internet;"Scientists with the Chicago Quantum Exchange (CQE) at the University of Chicago’s Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering announced today that for the first time they’ve connected the city of Chicago and suburban labs with a quantum network—nearly doubling the length of what was already one of the longest in the country. The Chicago network
column4: which will soon be opened to academia and industry
column5: will become one of the nation’s first publicly-available testbeds for quantum security technology.

column1: The network is now actively running quantum security protocols using technology provided by Toshiba
column2: distributing quantum keys over optic cable at a speed of over 80
column3: 000 quantum bits per second between Chicago and the western suburbs. Toshiba’s participation in the project makes the Chicago network a unique collaboration between academia
column4: government and industry.

column1: Researchers will use the Chicago network to test new communication devices
column2: security protocols
column3: and algorithms that will eventually connect distant quantum computers around the nation and the world. The work represents the next step towards a national quantum internet
column4: which will have a profound impact on communications
column5: computing
column6: and national security.

column1: A new 35-mile (56-kilometer) extension has built upon Argonne National Laboratory’s already 89-mile (144-kilometer) quantum loop
column2: launched in 2020. The total network
column3: announced today
column4: is now composed of six nodes and 124 miles (200 kilometers) of optical fiber—transmitting particles carrying quantum-encoded information between the U.S. Department of Energy’s Argonne National Laboratory in suburban Lemont and two buildings on the South Side of Chicago
column5: one on the UChicago campus and the other at the CQE headquarters in the Hyde Park neighborhood. It puts Chicago at the heart of one of the largest quantum networks in the country and further solidifies the region as a leading global hub for quantum research.";1933;['icv3vi1'
column6: 'icv48b6'

column1: 76ce4cf476b0fba2feaa2e284274ce84f156b133ab4126cb9041b5e2c3ad8570;posted_link;r/Physics;https://news.rice.edu/news/2022/sun-matter-about-3-billion-times-colder-deep-space;['x3fv2p'];['kmrbillya13'];[1662059469.0];['Japanese and U.S. physicists have used atoms about 3 billion times colder than interstellar space to open a portal to an unexplored realm of quantum magnetism.'];[nan];2022-08-31;;SU(N) matter is about 3 billion times colder than deep space;"HOUSTON – Japanese and U.S. physicists have used atoms about 3 billion times colder than interstellar space to open a portal to an unexplored realm of quantum magnetism.
“Unless an alien civilization is doing experiments like these right now
column2: anytime this experiment is running at Kyoto University it is making the coldest fermions in the universe
column3: ” said Rice University’s Kaden Hazzard
column4: corresponding theory author of astudy published today in Nature Physics. “ Fermions are not rare particles. They include things like electrons and are one of two types of particles that all matter is made of.”

column1: A Kyoto team led by study author Yoshiro Takahashi used lasers to cool its fermions
column2: atoms of ytterbium
column3: within about one-billionth of a degree of absolute zero
column4: the unattainable temperature where all motion stops. That’s about 3 billion times colder than interstellar space
column5: which is still warmed by the afterglow from the Big Bang.

column1: “The payoff of getting this cold is that the physics really changes
column2: ” Hazzard said. “The physics starts to become more quantum mechanical
column3: and it lets you see new phenomena.”

column1: Atoms are subject to the laws of quantum dynamics just like electrons and photons
column2: but their quantum behaviors only become evident when they are cooled within a fraction of a degree of absolute zero. Physicists have used laser cooling to study the quantum properties of ultracold atoms for more than a quarter century. Lasers are used to both cool the atoms and restrict their movements to optical lattices
column3: 1D
column4: 2D or 3D channels of light that can serve as quantum simulators capable of solving complex problems beyond the reach of conventional computers.

column1: Takahashi’s lab used optical lattices to simulate a Hubbard model
column2: an oft-used quantum model created in 1963 by theoretical physicist John Hubbard. Physicists use Hubbard models to investigate the magnetic and superconducting behavior of materials
column3: especially those where interactions between electrons produce collective behavior
column4: somewhat like the collective interactions of cheering sports fans who perform “the wave” in crowded stadiums.

column1: “The thermometer they use in Kyoto is one of the important things provided by our theory
column2: ” said Hazzard
column3: associate professor of physics and astronomy and a member of the Rice Quantum Initiative. “Comparing their measurements to our calculations
column4: we can determine the temperature. The record-setting temperature is achieved thanks to fun new physics that has to do with the very high symmetry of the system.”

column1: The Hubbard model simulated in Kyoto has special symmetry known as SU(N)
column2: where SU stands for special unitary group — a mathematical way of describing the symmetry — and N denotes the possible spin states of particles in the model. The greater the value of N
column3: the greater the model’s symmetry and the complexity of magnetic behaviors it describes. Ytterbium atoms have six possible spin states
column4: and the Kyoto simulator is the first to reveal magnetic correlations in an SU(6) Hubbard model
column5: which are impossible to calculate on a computer.

column1: “That’s the real reason to do this experiment
column2: ” Hazzard said. “Because we're dying to know the physics of this SU(N) Hubbard model.”

column1: Study co-author Eduardo Ibarra-García-Padilla
column2: a graduate student in Hazzard’s research group
column3: said the Hubbard model aims to capture the minimal ingredients to understand why solid materials become metals
column4: insulators
column5: magnets or superconductors.

column1: “One of the fascinating questions that experiments can explore is the role of symmetry
column2: ” Ibarra-García-Padilla said. “To have the capability to engineer it in a laboratory is extraordinary. If we can understand this
column3: it may guide us to making real materials with new
column4: desired properties.”

column1: Takahashi’s team showed it could trap up to 300
column2: 000 atoms in its 3D lattice. Hazzard said accurately calculating the behavior of even a dozen particles in an SU(6) Hubbard model is beyond the reach of the most powerful supercomputers. The Kyoto experiments offer physicists a chance to learn how these complex quantum systems operate by watching them in action.

column1: The results are a major step in this direction
column2: and include the first observations of particle coordination in an SU(6) Hubbard model
column3: Hazzard said.

column1: “Right now this coordination is short-ranged
column2: but as the particles are cooled even further
column3: subtler and more exotic phases of matter can appear
column4: ” he said. “One of the interesting things about some of these exotic phases is that they are not ordered in an obvious pattern
column5: and they are also not random. There are correlations
column6: but if you look at two atoms and ask
column7: ‘Are they correlated?' you won't see them. They are much more subtle. You can't look at two or three or even 100 atoms. You kind of have to look at the whole system.”

column1: Physicists don’t yet have tools capable of measuring such behavior in the Kyoto experiment. But Hazzard said work is already underway to create the tools
column2: and the Kyoto team’s success will spur those efforts.

column1: “These systems are pretty exotic and special
column2: but the hope is that by studying and understanding them
column3: we can identify the key ingredients that need to be there in real materials
column4: ” he said.

column1: An artist’s conception of the complex magnetic correlations physicists have observed with a groundbreaking quantum simulator at Kyoto University that uses ytterbium atoms about 3 billion times colder than deep space. Different colors represent the six possible spin states of each atom. The simulator uses up to 300
column2: 000 atoms
column3: allowing physicists to directly observe how particles interact in quantum magnets whose complexity is beyond the reach of even the most powerful supercomputer. ";5650;['impibre'

column6: 'impthv7'

column1: fa45bb4e5a1ff9353de43555f3a9f9aa1030de53a192ce93011d289820241189;posted_link;r/Futurology;http://nextbigfuture.com/2014/01/dwave-has-1000-qubit-quantum-computer.html;['1v0xa9'];['Simcurious'];[1389525693.0];['Dwave has a 1000 qubit quantum computer now in their lab and will release in later in 2014'];[nan];2014-01-12;Brian Wang;Dwave has a 1000 qubit quantum computer now in their lab and will release in later in 2014 | NextBigFuture.com;"The Washington Post interviewed Jeremy Hilton
column2: D-Wave’s vice president of processor development. Jeremy has been at the company since 2000.

column1: Right now
column2: we [Dwave Systems] have a 1000 qubit processor in our lab. Dwave has a plan to release it later in 2014. The major thing that’s changing aside from some of the design details is the scale of the problem you can represent
column3: going from a 500-variable graph to a 1000-variable graph. Complexity of that is growing tremendously. [It leads to an] unimaginable exponential blowup of the number of solutions. That scale of problems is getting that much harder for classical algorithms to solve.

column1: [After that] we’re planning to release a 2000-bit processor design. That’s pushing into a scale of territory where we’re tackling problems that are very difficult for people to solve [with conventional methods]. The community is working on getting a few qubits to work at the scale they’re trying to work at.
Dwave saw that between that 128 qubit and 512 qubit
column2: there was a 300
column3: 000x improvement in performance. That kind of performance gain is really unprecedented.

column1: There are algorithms related to the factoring problem that can be run on Dwave hardware and they have done some basic work along those lines. It’s simply not a particularly interesting market segment for a business. Dwave has focused on problems that can connect to things like machine learning
column2: financial modeling
column3: logistics and scheduling. They clearly relate to major business challenges.

column1: Google and Lockheed have purchased DWave systems. Dwave has received about $130 million in investment from Draper Fisher Jurvetson (major venture capital company) and some from the CIA’s investment arm.

column1: af95ecc5118a0e8112771a7d2f01227bcc3156db9a19e968cabbdfd67e161e4a;posted_link;r/philosophy;https://aeon.co/ideas/you-thought-quantum-mechanics-was-weird-check-out-entangled-time;['9l1wd9'];['ADefiniteDescription'];[1538578615.0];['If you thought quantum mechanics was weird
column2: consider entangled time'];[nan];2018-02-02;Elise Crull;You thought quantum mechanics was weird: check out entangled time | Aeon Ideas;"In the summer of 1935
column3: the physicists Albert Einstein and Erwin Schrödinger engaged in a rich
column4: multifaceted and sometimes fretful correspondence about the implications of the new theory of quantum mechanics. The focus of their worry was what Schrödinger later dubbed entanglement: the inability to describe two quantum systems or particles independently
column5: after they have interacted.

column1: Until his death
column2: Einstein remained convinced that entanglement showed how quantum mechanics was incomplete. Schrödinger thought that entanglement was the defining feature of the new physics
column3: but this didn’t mean that he accepted it lightly. ‘I know of course how the hocus pocus works mathematically
column4: ’ he wrote to Einstein on 13 July 1935. ‘But I do not like such a theory.’ Schrödinger’s famous cat
column5: suspended between life and death
column6: first appeared in these letters
column7: a byproduct of the struggle to articulate what bothered the pair.

column1: The problem is that entanglement violates how the world ought to work. Information can’t travel faster than the speed of light
column2: for one. But in a 1935 paper
column3: Einstein and his co-authors showed how entanglement leads to what’s now called quantum nonlocality
column4: the eerie link that appears to exist between entangled particles. If two quantum systems meet and then separate
column5: even across a distance of thousands of lightyears
column6: it becomes impossible to measure the features of one system (such as its position
column7: momentum and polarity) without instantly steering the other into a corresponding state.

column1: Up to today
column2: most experiments have tested entanglement over spatial gaps. The assumption is that the ‘nonlocal’ part of quantum nonlocality refers to the entanglement of properties across space. But what if entanglement also occurs across time? Is there such a thing as temporal nonlocality?

column1: The answer
column2: as it turns out
column3: is yes. Just when you thought quantum mechanics couldn’t get any weirder
column4: a team of physicists at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem reported in 2013 that they had successfully entangled photons that never coexisted. Previous experiments involving a technique called ‘entanglement swapping’ had already showed quantum correlations across time
column5: by delaying the measurement of one of the coexisting entangled particles; but Eli Megidish and his collaborators were the first to show entanglement between photons whose lifespans did not overlap at all.

column1: Here’s how they did it. First
column2: they created an entangled pair of photons
column3: ‘1-2’ (step I in the diagram below). Soon after
column4: they measured the polarisation of photon 1 (a property describing the direction of light’s oscillation) – thus ‘killing’ it (step II). Photon 2 was sent on a wild goose chase while a new entangled pair
column6: was created (step III). Photon 3 was then measured along with the itinerant photon 2 in such a way that the entanglement relation was ‘swapped’ from the old pairs (‘1-2’ and ‘3-4’) onto the new ‘2-3’ combo (step IV). Some time later (step V)
column7: the polarisation of the lone survivor
column10: and the results are compared with those of the long-dead photon 1 (back at step II).

column1: The upshot? The data revealed the existence of quantum correlations between ‘temporally nonlocal’ photons 1 and 4. That is
column2: entanglement can occur across two quantum systems that never coexisted.

column1: What on Earth can this mean? Prima facie
column2: it seems as troubling as saying that the polarity of starlight in the far-distant past – say
column3: greater than twice Earth’s lifetime – nevertheless influenced the polarity of starlight falling through your amateur telescope this winter. Even more bizarrely: maybe it implies that the measurements carried out by your eye upon starlight falling through your telescope this winter somehow dictated the polarity of photons more than 9 billion years old.

column1: Lest this scenario strike you as too outlandish
column2: Megidish and his colleagues can’t resist speculating on possible and rather spooky interpretations of their results. Perhaps the measurement of photon 1’s polarisation at step II somehow steers the future polarisation of 4
column3: or the measurement of photon 4’s polarisation at step V somehow rewrites the past polarisation state of photon 1. In both forward and backward directions
column4: quantum correlations span the causal void between the death of one photon and the birth of the other.

column1: Just a spoonful of relativity helps the spookiness go down
column2: though. In developing his theory of special relativity
column3: Einstein deposed the concept of simultaneity from its Newtonian pedestal. As a consequence
column4: simultaneity went from being an absolute property to being a relative one. There is no single timekeeper for the Universe; precisely when something is occurring depends on your precise location relative to what you are observing
column5: known as your frame of reference. So the key to avoiding strange causal behaviour (steering the future or rewriting the past) in instances of temporal separation is to accept that calling events ‘simultaneous’ carries little metaphysical weight. It is only a frame-specific property
column6: a choice among many alternative but equally viable ones – a matter of convention

column1: The lesson carries over directly to both spatial and temporal quantum nonlocality. Mysteries regarding entangled pairs of particles amount to disagreements about labelling
column2: brought about by relativity. Einstein showed that no sequence of events can be metaphysically privileged – can be considered more real – than any other. Only by accepting this insight can one make headway on such quantum puzzles.

column1: The various frames of reference in the Hebrew University experiment (the lab’s frame
column2: photon 1’s frame
column3: photon 4’s frame
column4: and so on) have their own ‘historians’
column5: so to speak. While these historians will disagree about how things went down
column6: not one of them can claim a corner on truth. A different sequence of events unfolds within each one
column7: according to that spatiotemporal point of view. Clearly
column9: any attempt at assigning frame-specific properties generally
column10: or tying general properties to one particular frame
column11: will cause disputes among the historians. But here’s the thing: while there might be legitimate disagreement about which properties should be assigned to which particles and when
column12: there shouldn’t be disagreement about the very existence of these properties

column1: These findings drive yet another wedge between our beloved classical intuitions and the empirical realities of quantum mechanics. As was true for Schrödinger and his contemporaries
column2: scientific progress is going to involve investigating the limitations of certain metaphysical views. Schrödinger’s cat
column3: half-alive and half-dead
column4: was created to illustrate how the entanglement of systems leads to macroscopic phenomena that defy our usual understanding of the relations between objects and their properties: an organism such as a cat is either dead or alive. No middle ground there.

column1: Most contemporary philosophical accounts of the relationship between objects and their properties embrace entanglement solely from the perspective of spatial nonlocality. But there’s still significant work to be done on incorporating temporal nonlocality – not only in object-property discussions
column2: but also in debates over material composition (such as the relation between a lump of clay and the statue it forms)
column3: and part-whole relations (such as how a hand relates to a limb
column4: or a limb to a person). For example
column5: the ‘puzzle’ of how parts fit with an overall whole presumes clear-cut spatial boundaries among underlying components
column6: yet spatial nonlocality cautions against this view. Temporal nonlocality further complicates this picture: how does one describe an entity whose constituent parts are not even coexistent?

column1: Discerning the nature of entanglement might at times be an uncomfortable project. It’s not clear what substantive metaphysics might emerge from scrutiny of fascinating new research by the likes of Megidish and other physicists. In a letter to Einstein
column2: Schrödinger notes wryly (and deploying an odd metaphor): ‘One has the feeling that it is precisely the most important statements of the new theory that can really be squeezed into these Spanish boots – but only with difficulty.’ We cannot afford to ignore spatial or temporal nonlocality in future metaphysics: whether or not the boots fit
column3: we’ll have to wear ’em.";8366;['dzoddux'

column1: VANCOUVER — When the world’s largest defence contractor reportedly paid $10 million for a superfast quantum computer
column2: the Burnaby
column3: B.C.
column4: company that built it earned a huge vote of confidence.

column1: Two years after Lockheed Martin acquired the first commercially viable quantum computer from D-Wave Systems
column2: the American aerospace and technology giant is once again throwing its weight behind a technology many thought was still the stuff of science fiction.

column1: Lockheed Martin has just upgraded its D-Wave One quantum computer to the D-Wave Two
column2: a machine the company’s founder Geordie Rose said is 500
column3: 000 times faster than its predecessor
column4: which was already faster than a conventional computer.

column1: “I don’t think we would have been able to succeed to the extent that we have without them
column2: ” said Rose of Lockheed Martin’s investment.

column1: Quantum computers operate at speeds unattainable by even today’s most powerful supercomputers
column2: operations that are so fast
column3: they can process millions of calculations in a fraction of the months
column4: even years
column5: traditional computers take.

column1: They can even be taught and can recognize objects in images
column2: a task standard computers struggle with.

column1: The computers are so advanced that Ray Johnson
column2: Lockheed’s chief technical officer
column3: told the New York Times his company would use the technology to create and test complex radar
column4: space and aircraft systems.

column1: Rose wouldn’t say how much Lockheed Martin paid for the computer
column2: but several tech blogs put the number at $10 million.

column1: It’s a big win for D-Wave
column2: said Rose
column3: who has battled skeptics who questioned the legitimacy of his quantum technology — a technology he noted no other company is working on today.

column1: If the company continues on the same path
column2: it will release a new
column3: faster commercial processor every two years
column4: said Rose who graduated from the University of British Columbia with a PhD in theoretical physics.

column1: “It will be like the Wright brothers taking off
column2: ” he said. “There will be an entirely new thing that wasn’t possible before.”

column1: D-Wave set up in Burnaby because the city was already home to all of its founders
column2: Rose said
column3: and when they looked to expand and considered other cities
column4: the reasons to stay multiplied.

column1: Rose said while he plans to keep D-Wave in Burnaby
column2: he finds it annoying that Metro Vancouver
column3: with all of its obvious positive attributes
column4: doesn’t have more depth in the technology sector.

column1: “Canada has a beautiful system of supporting researchers and the generation of immensely valuable ideas
column2: ” said Rose. “But taking the bull by the horns and making it into a hundred-billion-dollar business just doesn’t happen.”";2802;['c99wafw'

column1: 76c971eff2c22979a55cadcf6f5a6edc1b069381f6a93485305cef48831b5c07;posted_link;r/CryptoCurrency;https://www.forbes.com/sites/billybambrough/2021/08/21/urgent-warning-issued-over-the-future-of-bitcoin-even-as-the-crypto-market-price-smashes-past-2-trillion/?sh=785005b02b30;['p9rv9z'];['monamikonami'];[1629690768.0];['Forbes says quantum computing is expected in 5 years and that it poses a potentially fatal risk to blockchain and cryptocurrency technology. How serious is this risk and is anyone doing anything to fix it?'];[nan];2021-08-21;Billy Bambrough;‘Urgent’ Warning Issued Over The Future Of Bitcoin Even As The Crypto Market Price Smashes Past $2 Trillion;"Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies have seen a huge resurgence over the last year following the brutal so-called crypto winter that began in 2018.
The bitcoin price has this year climbed to never-before-seen highs
column2: topping $60
column3: 000 per bitcoin before falling back slightly. Other smaller cryptocurrencies have risen at an even faster clip than bitcoin
column4: with many making percentage gains into the thousands.

column1: Now
column2: as bitcoin and cryptocurrencies begin to carve out a place among traditional assets in investor portfolios
column3: technologists have warned that advances in quantum computing could mean the encryption that underpins bitcoin is ""fundamentally"" undermined as soon as 2026—unless the software is updated.

column1: Quantum computers
column2: expected to be operational by around 2026
column3: will easily undermine any blockchain security systems because of their power
column4: says the founder of quantum encryption company Arqit
column5: David Williams
column6: speaking over the phone. Arqit is gearing up for a September SPAC listing in New York.

column1: There needs to be rather more urgency
column2: Williams adds.

column1: Quantum computing
column2: which sees traditional computer ""bits"" replaced with quantum particles (qubits) that can calculate information at vastly increased speed
column3: has been in development since the 1990s. Researchers at universities around the world are now on the verge of creating a working quantum computer
column4: with search giant Google and scientists from the University of New South Wales in Sydney
column5: Australia
column6: recently making headlines with breakthroughs.

column1: Williams
column2: pointing to problems previously identified by the cofounder of ethereum and creator of cardano
column3: Charles Hoskinson
column4: warns that upgrading to post-quantum algorithms will ""dramatically slow blockchains down"" and called for blockchain developers to adopt so-called quantum encryption keys.

column1: Blockchains are effectively fundamentally flawed if they don’t address the oncoming quantum age. The grownups in the room know what's coming.""
Others have also begun working on getting bitcoin and other blockchains ahead of quantum computing.
If this isn't addressed before quantum computers pose a threat
column2: the impact would be massive
column3: says Duncan Jones
column4: head of quantum cybersecurity at Cambridge Quantum Computing
column5: speaking via email. ""Attackers could create fraudulent transactions and steal currency
column6: as well as potentially disrupting blockchain operations.""

column1: Earlier this month
column2: Cambridge Quantum Computing
column3: along with the Inter-American Development Bank and Tecnológico de Monterrey
column4: identified four potential threats to blockchain networks posed by quantum computers and used a post-quantum cryptography layer to help protect them
column5: including a new generation of quantum-proof cryptographic keys.

column1: Time is of the essence here
column2: says Jones
column3: pointing to Google chief executive Sundar Pichai's prediction that encryption could be broken in as little as five to 10 years. ""It's important for decentralized networks to start this migration process soon because it requires careful planning and execution. However
column4: I'm hopeful the core developers behind these platforms understand the issues and will be addressing them.""

column1: Recently
column2: it's been reported that China is pulling ahead in the global quantum race
column3: something Williams fears could undermine both traditional and crypto markets to the same degree as the 2008 global financial crisis.

column1: On day one
column2: the creation of a quantum computer doesn't break everything
column3: says Williams. ""It will probably initially happen in secret and the information will slowly leak out that the cryptography has been broken. Then there will be a complete loss of confidence
column4: similar to how the global financial crisis saw confidence in the system disintegrate.""

column1: With more than 11
column2: 000 different cryptocurrencies now listed on crypto data website CoinMarketCap and competition between bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies reaching fever pitch
column3: adding protection against the coming quantum revolution could be beneficial.

column1: If any one blockchain company could deliver proof it's quantum-safe it would have an advantage
column2: says Williams.";4070;['h9zrf7k'

column1: 37a4407d48b3a5537fc5de3cba040359104312f2235a41525e31e3fbdf7ccfd9;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.media.uzh.ch/en/Press-Releases/2018/artificial-photosynthesis.html;['9kpha3'];['mvea'];[1538476388.0];['Researchers developed a nanoparticle type for novel use in artificial photosynthesis by adding zinc sulfide on the surface of indium-based quantum dots to produce clean hydrogen fuel from water and sunlight
column2: a sustainable source of energy with new eco-friendly and powerful materials.'];[nan];2018-10-01;;Eco-Friendly Nanoparticles for Artificial Photosynthesis;"Researchers at the University of Zurich have developed a nanoparticle type for novel use in artificial photosynthesis by adding zinc sulfide on the surface of indium-based quantum dots. These quantum dots produce clean hydrogen fuel from water and sunlight – a sustainable source of energy. They introduce new eco-friendly and powerful materials to solar photocatalysis.

column1: Quantum dots are true all-rounders. These material structures
column2: which are only a few nanometers in size
column3: display a similar behavior to that of molecules or atoms
column4: and their form
column5: size and number of electrons can be modulated systematically. This means that their electrical and optical characteristics can be customized for a number of target areas
column6: such as new display technologies
column7: biomedical applications as well as photovoltaics and photocatalysis.

column1: Fuel production using sunlight and water
Another current line of application-oriented research aims to generate hydrogen directly from water and solar light. Hydrogen
column2: a clean and efficient energy source
column3: can be converted into forms of fuel that are used widely
column4: including methanol and gasoline. The most promising types of quantum dots previously used in energy research contain cadmium
column5: which has been banned from many commodities due to its toxicity. The team of Greta Patzke
column6: Professor at the Department of Chemistry of the University of Zurich (UZH)
column7: and scientists from Southwest Petroleum University in Chengdu and the Chinese Academy of Sciences have now developed a new type of nanomaterials without toxic components for photocatalysis.

column1: Indium-containing core with a thin layer of zinc sulfide
The three-nanometer particles consist of a core of indium phosphide with a very thin surrounding layer of zinc sulfide and sulfide ligands. “Compared to the quantum dots that contain cadmium
column2: the new composites are not only environmentally friendly
column3: but also highly efficient when it comes to producing hydrogen from light and water
column4: ” explains Greta Patzke. Sulfide ligands on the quantum dot surface were found to facilitate the crucial steps involved in light-driven chemical reactions
column5: namely the efficient separation of charge carriers and their rapid transfer to the nanoparticle surface.

column1: Great potential for eco-friendly applications

The newly developed cadmium-free nanomaterials have the potential to serve as a more eco-friendly alternative for a variety of commercial fields. “The water-soluble and biocompatible indium-based quantum dots can in the future also be tested in terms of biomass conversion to hydrogen. Or they could be developed into low-toxic biosensors or non-linear optical materials
column2: for example
column3: ” adds Greta Patzke. She will continue to focus on the development of catalysts for artificial photosynthesis within the University Research Priority Program “LightChEC”. This interdisciplinary research program aims to develop new molecules
column4: materials and processes for the direct storage of solar light energy in chemical bonds.";2983;['e70uvg4'

column1: b8954375d63dbe9af7aeee42a446e2da4686483a14ba9dda5640a07ac5af4bd7;posted_link;r/technology;http://a.msn.com/01/en-us/AAV6eyR?ocid=se;['th57j1'];['FoulYouthLeader'];[1647620625.0];['Microsoft Says Its Had a Breakthrough in Quantum Computer System'];[nan];2022-03-15;;Microsoft Says Its Had a Breakthrough in Quantum Computer System;"On March 14

column4: and therefore scale like no other."". Microsoft aims to create a million-qubit quantum computer
column5: which experts say is required to solve large-scale problems not possible on current computers. What’s amazing is humans have been able to engineer a system to demonstrate one of the most exotic pieces of physics in the universe.
column6: Krysta Svore
column7: a Microsoft distinguished engineer who leads the company’s quantum software program
column9: AI and Innovation. And we expect to capitalize on this to do the almost unthinkable — to push towards a fault-tolerant quantum machine that will enable computation on an entirely new level that’s closer to the way nature operates
column11: a Microsoft distinguished engineer who leads the company’s quantum software program
column13: AI and Innovation. It’s never been done before
column14: and until now it was never certain that it could be done. And now it’s like yes
column15: here’s this ultimate validation that we’re on the right path

column19: AI and Innovation. The company plans to create a qubit with ""built-in protection from environmental noise
column20: which means it should take far fewer qubits to perform useful computation and correct errors."". Figuring out how to feed the world or cure it of climate change will require discoveries or optimization of molecules that simply can’t be done by today’s classical computers

column25: AI and Innovation. Figuring out how to feed the world or cure it of climate change will require discoveries or optimization of molecules that simply can’t be done by today’s classical computers

column30: AI and Innovation. There’s no fundamental obstacle to producing a topological qubit anymore. This definitely doesn’t mean that we’re done — we still have tons of work to do.

column1: 105be516af6ed91a2be61dedadc92fa90235680ccc4e00fa3276d836f586e6e1;posted_link;r/science;https://newatlas.com/electronics/absolute-quantum-speed-limit-electronics/;['tql73c'];['MistWeaver80'];[1648506824.0];['It often feels like electronics will continue to get faster forever
column2: but at some point the laws of physics will intervene to put a stop to that. Now scientists have calculated the ultimate speed limit – the point at which quantum mechanics prevents microchips from getting any faster.'];[nan];2022-03-28;Michael Irving;Scientists calculate absolute quantum speed limit for electronics;"Scientists calculate absolute quantum speed limit for electronics

column1: It often feels like electronics will continue to get faster forever
column2: but at some point the laws of physics will intervene to put a stop to that. Now scientists have calculated the ultimate speed limit – the point at which quantum mechanics prevents microchips from getting any faster.

column1: It’s well known that nothing moves faster than light
column2: and that holds true for electronics – systems that use light to control electricity
column3: known as optoelectronics
column4: are the fastest devices. And in the new study
column5: researchers from TU Wien
column6: TU Graz and the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics have identified the upper limit for how fast optoelectronics could possibly get.

column1: The team conducted experiments using semiconductor materials and lasers. The semiconductor is hit with an ultra-short laser pulse
column2: which shifts electrons in the material into a higher energy state
column3: allowing them to move around freely. Then
column4: a second
column5: slightly longer laser pulse sends them shooting off in a certain direction
column6: producing an electrical current.

column1: Using this technique
column2: as well as complex computer simulations
column3: the team hit semiconductors with shorter and shorter laser pulses. But at a certain point
column4: the process begins to bump up against Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle – this is the strange quantum quirk where the more accurately you measure one characteristic of a particle
column5: the less you can be sure of another.

column1: In this case
column2: using shorter laser pulses means the observers can tell exactly when the electrons gain energy
column3: but that comes at the cost of being less certain about the amount of energy they gain. And that’s a major problem for electronic devices
column4: because not knowing the exact energies of electrons means they can’t be controlled as precisely.

column1: From this
column2: the team calculated the absolute upper limit for how fast optoelectronic systems could possibly ever get – one Petahertz
column3: which is a million Gigahertz. That’s a hard limit
column4: one that can’t be engineered around because the barrier is baked into the very laws of quantum physics.

column1: Of course
column2: it’s unlikely we’ll ever actually have to directly worry about that anyway. The team says that other technological hurdles would arise long before optoelectronic devices reach the realm of PHz. But understanding the hard limit could help develop better electronics.";2366;['i2hw8ma'

column1: e268a3100bd2bf15c77f5fee34c7de4e01bd14033c0e282dfdcdd216a42422c0;posted_link;r/Physics;https://news.stanford.edu/2019/07/24/quantum-microphone-counts-particles-sound/;['ciut96'];['chicompj'];[1564313649.0];['Physicists have developed a “quantum microphone” so sensitive that it can measure individual particles of sound
column2: called phonons. The device could eventually lead to smaller
column3: more efficient quantum computers that operate by manipulating sound rather than light.'];[nan];2019-07-24;Stanford University;Quantum microphone counts particles of sound | Stanford News;"Stanford physicists count sound particles with quantum microphone

column1: A device that eavesdrops on the quantum whispers of atoms could form the basis of a new type of quantum computer.
Stanford physicists have developed a “quantum microphone” so sensitive that it can measure individual particles of sound
column2: called phonons.

column1: The device
column2: which is detailed July 24 in the journal Nature
column3: could eventually lead to smaller
column4: more efficient quantum computers that operate by manipulating sound rather than light.

column1: “We expect this device to allow new types of quantum sensors
column2: transducers and storage devices for future quantum machines
column3: ” said study leader Amir Safavi-Naeini
column4: an assistant professor of applied physics at Stanford’s School of Humanities and Sciences.

column1: Quantum of motion
First proposed by Albert Einstein in 1907
column2: phonons are packets of vibrational energy emitted by jittery atoms. These indivisible packets
column3: or quanta
column4: of motion manifest as sound or heat
column5: depending on their frequencies.

column1: Like photons
column2: which are the quantum carriers of light
column3: phonons are quantized
column4: meaning their vibrational energies are restricted to discrete values – similar to how a staircase is composed of distinct steps.

column1: “Sound has this granularity that we don’t normally experience
column2: ” Safavi-Naeini said. “Sound
column3: at the quantum level
column4: crackles.”

column1: The energy of a mechanical system can be represented as different “Fock” states – 0
column4: and so on – based on the number of phonons it generates. For example
column5: a “1 Fock state” consist of one phonon of a particular energy
column6: a “2 Fock state” consists of two phonons with the same energy
column7: and so on. Higher phonon states correspond to louder sounds.

column1: Until now
column2: scientists have been unable to measure phonon states in engineered structures directly because the energy differences between states – in the staircase analogy
column3: the spacing between steps – is vanishingly small. “One phonon corresponds to an energy ten trillion trillion times smaller than the energy required to keep a lightbulb on for one second
column4: ” said graduate student Patricio Arrangoiz-Arriola
column5: a co-first author of the study.

column1: To address this issue
column2: the Stanford team engineered the world’s most sensitive microphone – one that exploits quantum principles to eavesdrop on the whispers of atoms.

column1: In an ordinary microphone
column2: incoming sound waves jiggle an internal membrane
column3: and this physical displacement is converted into a measurable voltage. This approach doesn’t work for detecting individual phonons because
column4: according to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle
column5: a quantum object’s position can’t be precisely known without changing it.

column1: “If you tried to measure the number of phonons with a regular microphone
column2: the act of measurement injects energy into the system that masks the very energy that you’re trying to measure
column3: ” Safavi-Naeini said.

column1: Instead
column2: the physicists devised a way to measure Fock states – and thus
column3: the number of phonons – in sound waves directly. “Quantum mechanics tells us that position and momentum can’t be known precisely – but it says no such thing about energy
column4: ” Safavi-Naeini said. “Energy can be known with infinite precision.”

column1: Singing qubits
The quantum microphone the group developed consists of a series of supercooled nanomechanical resonators
column2: so small that they are visible only through an electron microscope. The resonators are coupled to a superconducting circuit that contains electron pairs that move around without resistance. The circuit forms a quantum bit
column3: or qubit
column4: that can exist in two states at once and has a natural frequency
column5: which can be read electronically. When the mechanical resonators vibrate like a drumhead
column6: they generate phonons in different states.

column1: “The resonators are formed from periodic structures that act like mirrors for sound. By introducing a defect into these artificial lattices
column2: we can trap the phonons in the middle of the structures
column3: ” Arrangoiz-Arriola said.

column1: Like unruly inmates
column2: the trapped phonons rattle the walls of their prisons
column3: and these mechanical motions are conveyed to the qubit by ultra-thin wires. “The qubit’s sensitivity to displacement is especially strong when the frequencies of the qubit and the resonators are nearly the same
column4: ” said joint first-author Alex Wollack
column5: also a graduate student at Stanford.

column1: However
column2: by detuning the system so that the qubit and the resonators vibrate at very different frequencies
column3: the researchers weakened this mechanical connection and triggered a type of quantum interaction
column4: known as a dispersive interaction
column5: that directly links the qubit to the phonons.

column1: This bond causes the frequency of the qubit to shift in proportion to the number of phonons in the resonators. By measuring the qubit’s changes in tune
column2: the researchers could determine the quantized energy levels of the vibrating resonators – effectively resolving the phonons themselves.

column1: “Different phonon energy levels appear as distinct peaks in the qubit spectrum
column2: ” Safavi-Naeini said. “These peaks correspond to Fock states of 0
column4: 2 and so on. These multiple peaks had never been seen before.”

column1: Mechanical quantum mechanical

Mastering the ability to precisely generate and detect phonons could help pave the way for new kinds of quantum devices that are able to store and retrieve information encoded as particles of sound or that can convert seamlessly between optical and mechanical signals.
Such devices could conceivably be made more compact and efficient than quantum machines that use photons
column2: since phonons are easier to manipulate and have wavelengths that are thousands of times smaller than light particles.

column1: “Right now
column2: people are using photons to encode these states. We want to use phonons
column3: which brings with it a lot of advantages
column4: ” Safavi-Naeini said. “Our device is an important step toward making a ‘mechanical quantum mechanical’ computer.”";5829;['euxeq7g'

column1: 4b865ce095268498e64a8f5d11ab8f2586a4f0e058562604901680fe68dd26bb;posted_link;r/CryptoCurrency;https://asiatimes.com/2021/12/quantum-hackers-can-bring-down-bitcoin-expert/;['rk25jw'];['RestlesslyLazy'];[1639937285.0];['Quantum hackers can bring down Bitcoin: expert'];[nan];2021-12-02;David P Goldman;Quantum hackers can bring down Bitcoin: expert;"NEW YORK – $3 trillion of cryptocurrency assets are
column2: or soon will be
column3: vulnerable to hacking by quantum computers
column4: one of China’s top cryptographers told an Asia Times webinar on November 30.

column1: You won’t know if it’s happening until it’s too late
column2: Professor Jintao Ding of Tsinghua University
column3: a US citizen
column4: explained. And the best thing about hacking Bitcoin
column5: he explained
column6: is that it isn’t against the law.

column1: Crypto analysts have worried about the quantum invasion for some time. Motley Fool’s Zhiyuan Sun wrote in September
column2: “The rise of quantum computing may soon give governments a means to crack down on Bitcoin and other types of cryptocurrencies… Governments could potentially decrypt digital currencies or launch hash attacks to take over their network for a regulatory shutdown with these machines.”

column1: “Most governments like Bitcoin as much as we like walking with rocks in our shoes
column2: ” Sun added. No government dislikes Bitcoin as much as China
column3: which banned onshore trading of cryptocurrencies in 2019 and forbade Chinese from trading on offshore crypto exchanges last September.

column1: “Our modern information system relies completely on public key cryptography
column2: including Bitcoin
column3: ” Ding told the “Data Wars” webinar
column4: co-sponsored by the American Affairs journal and Asia Times. “If we have a quantum computer
column5: our Zoom would be finished
column6: and everything actually—the whole information system
column7: because our fundamental security solution relies on it.”

column1: Public key cryptography based on the RSA standard has been in use since the late 1970s. Each user has a public key for purposes of identification
column2: and a private key – a password – for decryption.

column1: The public key is based on two very large prime numbers
column2: which are secret; only the recipient knows the prime numbers
column3: which are required to decrypt the message. Factoring extremely large numbers into primes
column4: decrypting the private key requires factoring extremely large numbers into primes
column5: something that takes supercomputers a very long time to do.

column1: As computers get faster
column2: cryptography uses bigger numbers. But quantum computers will be able to factor extremely large numbers into primes very quickly. Maybe they already can—but if that’s the case
column3: no one is saying so yet.

column1: Today’s encryption methods “can be broken by quantum computers. We must work together to have a smooth transition from the current situation and find a solution. We have to do it. And the transition process will be very difficult
column2: ” Ding added.

column1: Mathematicians have known that quantum computers would be able to break the RSA code quickly since 1994
column2: when Peter Shor published an algorithm for factoring extremely large numbers into primes.

column1: Development of such a quantum computer is inevitable
column2: Ding argues. There are rumors in the tech world that machines capable of using Shor’s algorithm to break RSA already exist.

column1: When will that happen? It might have happened already
column2: but if it has
column3: no-one will let on
column4: Ding explained.

column1: “Watch the movie ‘Imitation Game’ about [Alan] Turing
column2: ” the great British mathematician who led the team that broke the German Enigma code during World War II. British signals intelligence (GCHQ) didn’t reveal until the 1970s that it could read German coded messages in close to real time during World War II. “If I can read every message
column3: why wouldn’t I keep quiet about it? I would be in a very good position. I think this is what I would do
column4: ” he said.

column2: I serialized a spy thriller in Asia Times under the title
column3: The Quantum Supremacy
column4: premised on just such a scenario.

column1: What does that mean for Bitcoin? I asked Ding during the webinar.
He replied: “That’s a very good question. In my opinion
column2: once you have a quantum computer
column3: blockchain and Bitcoin are finished. Let me expand a bit. You don’t own Bitcoin. The owner is your private key. When they give you the money
column4: they give it to an address. The address is a short form of your public key. They use that to verify the address. Only you have the private key; everyone knows the public key to verify that it is from you.”

column1: “When they give you the money
column2: they give it to an address
column3: ” Ding said. “ The address is a short form of your public key. We use that to verify when you give me the coins. But if I don’t know the private part key
column4: if I only know the address. I cannot take anything.”

column1: “But if I have a quantum computer
column2: ” Ding continued
column3: “what I would do first is to get all the coins
column4: because there’s no liability there. I wouldn’t attack banks—then there’s a big lawsuit
column5: or you go to jail. But with a quantum computer
column6: I just take the Bitcoin. It’s legal in my opinion. I didn’t do anything; I just see your public key and use your private key and assign the money to my own account.”

column1: That’s the downside of anonymity. Your name and government ID number aren’t linked to a Bitcoin account (as they are to an ordinary bank account). Your proof of ownership is simply the fact that you have the private key (your password). If someone else hacks that
column2: you have no legal recourse.

column1: Bitcoins have another vulnerability
column2: Ding said. “When I do a transaction
column3: there’s 10 minutes delay because we have to confirm the transaction. In this period
column4: if your transaction is delayed
column5: if people have a quantum computer
column6: then they can do a new transaction to replace your transaction
column7: and then they can send it all the funds to themselves. Then you’re finished. They can just take all your Bitcoin right away.”

column1: The professor doesn’t think that the cryptocurrency world’s efforts to enhance security will do much good. “Bitcoin did an update called Taproot
column2: ” he said. “This is actually very bad because in this case
column3: because they are very much prone to attack from content within it.” Taproot creates an interface between Bitcoin and ordinary cash transactions
column4: in order to reduce transaction costs.

column1: If quantum computers capable of hacking your crypto account exist
column2: they are in the hands of governments or large corporations with the resources to build them. If and when such quantum computers are functional
column3: their owners won’t draw attention by stealing from individual bitcoin accounts.

column1: If a state actor hacks cryptocurrency transactions
column2: it almost certainly would use that capability to monitor ownership of these assets for intelligence purposes. Knowing who is trying to hide money
column3: or transfer money away from the scrutiny of regulators
column4: would give the intelligence service of any country enormous political leverage.

column1: But if the whole $3 trillion crypto market were to disintegrate
column2: no one would be more pleased than China
column3: which wants to promote its own digital yuan at the expense of anonymously traded Bitcoins.";6617;['hn0q4fr'

column1: 0a36598418fef43301f9a364903b8e2523d34619b10c28b23f506fb457455fdb;posted_link;r/science;http://www.nist.gov/pml/div686/refrigerator-030513.cfm;['19zx8r'];['jojoma42'];[1362874744.0];['Quantum Refrigerator Offers Extreme Cooling and Convenience'];[nan];2013-03-05;;NIST Quantum Refrigerator Offers Extreme Cooling and Convenience;"Researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) have demonstrated a solid-state refrigerator that uses quantum physics in micro- and nanostructures to cool a much larger object to extremely low temperatures.
What's more
column2: the prototype NIST refrigerator
column3: which measures a few inches in outer dimensions
column4: enables researchers to place any suitable object in the cooling zone and later remove and replace it
column5: similar to an all-purpose kitchen refrigerator. The cooling power is the equivalent of a window-mounted air conditioner cooling a building the size of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington
column6: D.C.

column1: It's one of the most flabbergasting results I've seen
column2: project leader Joel Ullom says. ""We used quantum mechanics in a nanostructure to cool a block of copper. The copper is about a million times heavier than the refrigerating elements. This is a rare example of a nano- or microelectromechanical machine that can manipulate the macroscopic world.""

column1: The technology may offer a compact
column2: convenient means of chilling advanced sensors below standard cryogenic temperatures—300 milliKelvin (mK)
column3: typically achieved by use of liquid helium—to enhance their performance in quantum information systems
column4: telescope cameras
column5: and searches for mysterious dark matter and dark energy.

column1: As described in Applied Physics Letters
column2: the NIST refrigerator's cooling elements
column3: consisting of 48 tiny sandwiches of specific materials
column4: chilled a plate of copper
column5: 2.5 centimeters on a side and 3 millimeters thick
column6: from 290 mK to 256 mK. The cooling process took about 18 hours. NIST researchers expect that minor improvements will enable faster and further cooling to about 100 mK.

column1: The cooling elements are sandwiches of a normal metal
column2: a 1-nanometer-thick insulating layer
column3: and a superconducting metal. When a voltage is applied
column4: the hottest electrons ""tunnel"" from the normal metal through the insulator to the superconductor. The temperature in the normal metal drops dramatically and drains electronic and vibrational energy from the object being cooled.

column1: NIST researchers previously demonstrated this basic cooling method but are now able to cool larger objects that can be easily attached and removed. Researchers developed a micromachining process to attach the cooling elements to the copper plate
column2: which is designed to be a stage on which other objects can be attached and cooled. Additional advances include better thermal isolation of the stage
column3: which is suspended by strong
column4: cold-tolerant cords.

column1: Cooling to temperatures below 300 mK currently requires complex
column2: large and costly apparatus. NIST researchers want to build simple
column3: compact alternatives to make it easier to cool NIST's advanced sensors. Researchers plan to boost the cooling power of the prototype refrigerator by adding more and higher-efficiency superconducting junctions and building a more rigid support structure.";2890;['c8sug51'

column1: 626eb66fedcae59f9278664c99144098f07bfe149757f1e9e6683d4e31946b95;posted_link;r/programming;https://www.quantamagazine.org/teenager-finds-classical-alternative-to-quantum-recommendation-algorithm-20180731/;['93tpbn'];['rieslingatkos'];[1533162432.0];['18-year-old Ewin Tang has proven that classical computers can solve the “recommendation problem” nearly as fast as quantum computers. The result eliminates one of the best examples of quantum speedup.'];[nan];2018-07-31;Kevin Hartnett July;Major Quantum Computing Advance Made Obsolete by Teenager | Quanta Magazine;"A teenager from Texas has taken quantum computing down a notch. In a paper posted online earlier this month
column2: 18-year-old Ewin Tang proved that ordinary computers can solve an important computing problem with performance potentially comparable to that of a quantum computer.

column1: In its most practical form
column2: the “recommendation problem” relates to how services like Amazon and Netflix determine which products you might like to try. Computer scientists had considered it to be one of the best examples of a problem that’s exponentially faster to solve on quantum computers — making it an important validation of the power of these futuristic machines. Now Tang has stripped that validation away.

column1: “This was one of the most definitive examples of a quantum speedup
column2: and it’s no longer there
column3: ” said Tang
column4: who graduated from the University of Texas
column5: Austin
column6: in spring and will begin a Ph.D. at the University of Washington in the fall.

column2: at age 14 and after skipping the fourth through sixth grades
column3: Tang enrolled at UT Austin and majored in mathematics and computer science. In the spring of 2017 Tang took a class on quantum information taught by Scott Aaronson
column4: a prominent researcher in quantum computing. Aaronson recognized Tang as an unusually talented student and offered himself as adviser on an independent research project. Aaronson gave Tang a handful of problems to choose from
column5: including the recommendation problem. Tang chose it somewhat reluctantly.

column1: “I was hesitant because it seemed like a hard problem when I looked at it
column2: but it was the easiest of the problems he gave me
column3: ” Tang said.

column1: The recommendation problem is designed to give a recommendation for products that users will like. Consider the case of Netflix. It knows what films you’ve watched. It knows what all of its other millions of users have watched. Given this information
column2: what are you likely to want to watch next?

column1: You can think of this data as being arranged in a giant grid
column2: or matrix
column3: with movies listed across the top
column4: users listed down the side
column5: and values at points in the grid quantifying whether
column6: or to what extent
column7: each user likes each film. A good algorithm would generate recommendations by quickly and accurately recognizing similarities between movies and users and filling in the blanks in the matrix.

column1: In 2016 the computer scientists Iordanis Kerenidis and Anupam Prakash published a quantum algorithm that solved the recommendation problem exponentially faster than any known classical algorithm. They achieved this quantum speedup in part by simplifying the problem: Instead of filling out the entire matrix and identifying the single best product to recommend
column2: they developed a way of sorting users into a small number of categories — do they like blockbusters or indie films? — and sampling the existing data in order to generate a recommendation that was simply good enough.

column1: At the time of Kerenidis and Prakash’s work
column2: there were only a few examples of problems that quantum computers seemed to be able to solve exponentially faster than classical computers. Most of those examples were specialized — they were narrow problems designed to play to the strengths of quantum computers (these include the “forrelation” problem Quanta covered earlier this year). Kerenidis and Prakash’s result was exciting because it provided a real-world problem people cared about where quantum computers outperformed classical ones.

column1: “To my sense it was one of the first examples in machine learning and big data where we showed quantum computers can do something that we still don’t know how to do classically
column2: ” said Kerenidis
column3: a computer scientist at the Research Institute on the Foundations of Computer Science in Paris.

column1: Kerenidis and Prakash proved that a quantum computer could solve the recommendation problem exponentially faster than any known algorithm
column2: but they didn’t prove that a fast classical algorithm couldn’t exist. So when Aaronson began working with Tang in 2017
column3: that was the question he posed — prove there is no fast classical recommendation algorithm
column4: and thereby confirm Kerenidis and Prakash’s quantum speedup is real.

column1: “That seemed to me like an important ‘t’ to cross to complete this story
column2: ” said Aaronson
column3: who believed at the time that no fast classical algorithm existed.

column1: Tang set to work in the fall of 2017
column2: intending for the recommendation problem to serve as a senior thesis. For several months Tang struggled to prove that a fast classical algorithm was impossible. As time went on
column3: Tang started to think that maybe such an algorithm was possible after all.

column1: “I started believing there is a fast classical algorithm
column2: but I couldn’t really prove it to myself because Scott seemed to think there wasn’t one
column3: and he was the authority
column4: ” Tang said.

column1: Finally
column2: with the senior thesis deadline bearing down
column3: Tang wrote to Aaronson and admitted a growing suspicion: “Tang wrote to me saying
column4: actually
column5: ‘I think there is a fast classical algorithm
column6: ’” Aaronson said.

column1: Throughout the spring Tang wrote up the results and worked with Aaronson to clarify some steps in the proof. The fast classical algorithm Tang found was directly inspired by the fast quantum algorithm Kerenidis and Prakash had found two years earlier. Tang showed that the kind of quantum sampling techniques they used in their algorithm could be replicated in a classical setting. Like Kerenidis and Prakash’s algorithm
column2: Tang’s algorithm ran in polylogarithmic time — meaning the computational time scaled with the logarithm of characteristics like the number of users and products in the data set — and was exponentially faster than any previously known classical algorithm.

column1: Once Tang had completed the algorithm
column2: Aaronson wanted to be sure it was correct before releasing it publicly. “I was still nervous that once Tang put the paper online
column3: if it’s wrong
column4: the first big paper of [Tang’s] career would go splat
column5: ” Aaronson said.

column1: Aaronson had been planning to attend a quantum computing workshop at the University of California
column2: Berkeley
column3: in June. Many of the biggest names in the field were going to be there
column4: including Kerenidis and Prakash. Aaronson invited Tang to come out to Berkeley to informally present the algorithm in the days after the official conference ended.

column1: On the mornings of June 18 and 19 Tang gave two lectures while fielding questions from the audience. By the end of four hours
column2: a consensus emerged: Tang’s classical algorithm seemed correct. What many people in the room didn’t realize
column3: however
column4: was just how young the speaker was. “I did not know Ewin was 18
column5: and I certainly did not get that from the talk. To me [Ewin] was someone who was giving a very mature talk
column6: ” Kerenidis said. The algorithm now faces a formal peer review before publication.

column1: For quantum computing
column2: Tang’s result is a setback. Or not. Tang has eliminated one of the clearest
column3: best examples of a quantum advantage. At the same time
column4: Tang’s paper is further evidence of the fruitful interplay between the study of quantum and classical algorithms.

column1: “Tang is killing [Kerenidis and Prakash’s] quantum speedup
column2: but then in another sense Tang is giving a big improvement and building on what they did. Tang never would have come up with this classical algorithm but for their quantum algorithm
column3: ” Aaronson said.";7276;['e3e4eov'

column1: 4662805110723ef2a6bf57a1262de8bbf345f33e5aee808e35a44c96d582b24c;posted_link;r/technology;https://scitechdaily.com/harvard-mit-quantum-computing-breakthrough-we-are-entering-a-completely-new-part-of-the-quantum-world/;['ojr4kr'];['radiant_bear23'];[1626216922.0];['Harvard-MIT Quantum Computing Breakthrough – “We Are Entering a Completely New Part of the Quantum World”'];[nan];2021-07-09;Mike O'Neill;Harvard-MIT Quantum Computing Breakthrough – “We Are Entering a Completely New Part of the Quantum World”;"Team develops simulator with 256 qubits
column2: largest of its kind ever created.

column1: A team of physicists from the Harvard-MIT Center for Ultracold Atoms and other universities has developed a special type of quantum computer known as a programmable quantum simulator capable of operating with 256 quantum bits
column2: or “qubits.”

column1: The system marks a major step toward building large-scale quantum machines that could be used to shed light on a host of complex quantum processes and eventually help bring about real-world breakthroughs in material science
column2: communication technologies
column3: finance
column4: and many other fields
column5: overcoming research hurdles that are beyond the capabilities of even the fastest supercomputers today. Qubits are the fundamental building blocks on which quantum computers run and the source of their massive processing power.

column1: “This moves the field into a new domain where no one has ever been to thus far
column2: ” said Mikhail Lukin
column3: the George Vasmer Leverett Professor of Physics
column4: co-director of the Harvard Quantum Initiative
column5: and one of the senior authors of the study published on July 7
column7: in the journal Nature. “We are entering a completely new part of the quantum world.”

column1: According to Sepehr Ebadi
column2: a physics student in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and the study’s lead author
column3: it is the combination of system’s unprecedented size and programmability that puts it at the cutting edge of the race for a quantum computer
column4: which harnesses the mysterious properties of matter at extremely small scales to greatly advance processing power. Under the right circumstances
column5: the increase in qubits means the system can store and process exponentially more information than the classical bits on which standard computers run.

column1: “The number of quantum states that are possible with only 256 qubits exceeds the number of atoms in the solar system
column2: ” Ebadi said
column3: explaining the system’s vast size.

column1: Already
column2: the simulator has allowed researchers to observe several exotic quantum states of matter that had never before been realized experimentally
column3: and to perform a quantum phase transition study so precise that it serves as the textbook example of how magnetism works at the quantum level.

column1: These experiments provide powerful insights on the quantum physics underlying material properties and can help show scientists how to design new materials with exotic properties.
The project uses a significantly upgraded version of a platform the researchers developed in 2017
column2: which was capable of reaching a size of 51 qubits. That older system allowed the researchers to capture ultra-cold rubidium atoms and arrange them in a specific order using a one-dimensional array of individually focused laser beams called optical tweezers.

column1: This new system allows the atoms to be assembled in two-dimensional arrays of optical tweezers. This increases the achievable system size from 51 to 256 qubits. Using the tweezers
column2: researchers can arrange the atoms in defect-free patterns and create programmable shapes like square
column3: honeycomb
column4: or triangular lattices to engineer different interactions between the qubits.

column1: “The workhorse of this new platform is a device called the spatial light modulator
column2: which is used to shape an optical wavefront to produce hundreds of individually focused optical tweezer beams
column3: ” said Ebadi. “These devices are essentially the same as what is used inside a computer projector to display images on a screen
column4: but we have adapted them to be a critical component of our quantum simulator.”

column1: The initial loading of the atoms into the optical tweezers is random
column2: and the researchers must move the atoms around to arrange them into their target geometries. The researchers use a second set of moving optical tweezers to drag the atoms to their desired locations
column3: eliminating the initial randomness. Lasers give the researchers complete control over the positioning of the atomic qubits and their coherent quantum manipulation.

column1: Other senior authors of the study include Harvard Professors Subir Sachdev and Markus Greiner
column2: who worked on the project along with Massachusetts Institute of Technology Professor Vladan Vuleti?
column3: and scientists from Stanford
column4: the University of California Berkeley
column5: the University of Innsbruck in Austria
column6: the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column7: and QuEra Computing Inc. in Boston.

column1: “Our work is part of a really intense
column2: high-visibility global race to build bigger and better quantum computers
column3: ” said Tout Wang
column4: a research associate in physics at Harvard and one of the paper’s authors. “The overall effort [beyond our own] has top academic research institutions involved and major private-sector investment from Google
column5: IBM
column6: Amazon

column1: The researchers are currently working to improve the system by improving laser control over qubits and making the system more programmable. They are also actively exploring how the system can be used for new applications
column2: ranging from probing exotic forms of quantum matter to solving challenging real-world problems that can be naturally encoded on the qubits.

column1: “This work enables a vast number of new scientific directions
column2: ” Ebadi said. “We are nowhere near the limits of what can be done with these systems.”";5192;['h53eurx'
