column1: 95fa0265697a7f0067a3c0ccc3ccf6713b830925f180c22b09e29b5f4c1eb463;posted_link;r/science;http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/2016/09/19/quantum-teleportation-enters-real-world/#.V-BfGz4rKX0;['53k53g'];['nscharping'];[1474323161.0];['Two separate teams of researchers transmit information across a city via quantum teleportation.'];[nan];2016-09-19;Nathaniel Scharping;Quantum Teleportation Enters the Real World;"Two separate teams of scientists have taken quantum teleportation from the lab into the real world. Researchers working in Calgary
column2: Canada and Hefei
column3: China
column4: used existing fiber optics networks to transmit small units of information across cities via quantum entanglement — Einstein's ""spooky action at a distance.""

column1: Stepping Outside the Lab
According to quantum mechanics
column2: some objects
column3: like photons or electrons
column4: can be entangled. This means that no matter how far apart they are
column5: what happens to one will affect the other instantaneously. To Einstein
column6: this seemed ridiculous
column7: because it entailed information moving faster than the speed of light
column9: numerous experiments have shown that entanglement does indeed exist.

column1: The challenge was putting it to use. A few experiments in the lab had previously managed to send information using quantum entanglement. But translating their efforts to the real world
column2: where any number of factors could confound the process is a much more difficult challenge.

column1: That’s exactly what these two teams of researchers have done. Their breakthrough
column2: published in two separate papers today in Nature Photonics
column3: promises to offer important advancements for communications and encryption technologies. Both experiments encode a message into a photon and send it to a way station of sorts.

column1: There
column2: the message is transferred to a different photon
column3: which is entangled with a photon held by the receiver. This destroys the information held in the first photon
column4: but transmits the information via entanglement to the receiver. When the way station measures the photon
column5: it creates kind of key — a decoder ring of sorts — that can decrypt the entangled photon’s information. That key is then sent over an internet connection
column6: where it is combined with the information contained within the entangled photon to reveal the message.

column1: The two experiments weren't able to transmit very much information — the Calgary experiment was the quickest
column2: and they only managed 17 photons a minute. The Hefei experiment was able to guess the state of the photons with better accuracy
column3: however. While the Calgary researchers succeeded about 25 percent of the time
column4: the Hefei researchers were right at most 50 percent of the time
column5: due to their inclusion of an extra
column6: albeit time-consuming

column1: Because both methods possess their own advantages
column2: they will likely each form the basis for further research. Nevertheless
column3: both teams were able to use existing telecommunications infrastructure to accomplish something that had only been done in the lab before — a big step forward. The Calgary team sent photons over a distance of about 4 miles
column4: while the Hefei team spanned almost 9.

column1: Beam Me Up Scotty?
This isn't teleportation in the ""Star Trek"" sense — the photons aren't disappearing from one place and appearing in another. Instead
column2: it's the information that's being teleported through quantum entanglement. The teleportation moniker is used because the initial message sent is destroyed when the photon carrying it gets measured
column3: and it is only the information that gets teleported from one place to another.

column1: One of the largest hurdles for both teams to overcome was the tendency of fiber optic cables to stretch and compress due to temperature changes. While this doesn't matter for regular telecommunications
column2: for quantum communication
column3: the photons that are sent must arrive at precisely the same time. Both teams of researchers used additional complex data inputs to ensure that their photons were arriving exactly the same as they started out.

column1: Quantum teleportation over long distances has actually been accomplished before — in 2012
column2: a team of researchers from Austria sent information almost 90 miles between two of the Canary Islands using lasers. Using lasers to send information can work in some situations
column3: but adverse environmental conditions can disrupt the signal. This is why the internet today consists of a network of fiber optic cables instead.

column1: Quantum teleportation’s biggest application will likely be as a means of encrypting information. Because the two photons communicate with each other by entanglement
column2: there's no way for an outsider to read them. To decrypt a message
column3: you would need the key
column4: which is sent over the internet. Even if you intercepted the key
column5: you would still only have half of the puzzle — to fully read it
column6: you would need the entangled photons themselves.

column1: The process could even theoretically be used to create a network of quantum repeaters to stretch the networks capabilities between cities and countries
column2: New Scientist writes. Someday
column3: the same spooky action that frustrated Einstein could be delivering your emails. ";4727;['d7tsz7a'

column1: 0ba5397aa7e55a3599693501b77e8f8658d0306f88bc26e4433655ecb2e9896e;posted_link;r/technology;http://esciencenews.com/articles/2013/06/28/large.scale.quantum.chip.validated;['1hbx2a'];['Buck-Nasty'];[1372541682.0];"[""Google's Quantum Computer validated at the University of Southern California""]";[nan];2013-06-28;;Large-scale quantum chip validated;"Large-scale quantum chip validated

A team of scientists at USC has verified that quantum effects are indeed at play in the first commercial quantum optimization processor. The team demonstrated that the D-Wave processor housed at the USC-Lockheed Martin Quantum Computing Center behaves in a manner that indicates that quantum mechanics plays a functional role in the way it works. The demonstration involved a small subset of the chip's 128 qubits.
This means that the device appears to be operating as a quantum processor -- something that scientists had hoped for but have needed extensive testing to verify.

The quantum processor was purchased from Canadian manufacturer D-Wave nearly two years ago by Lockheed Martin and housed at the USC Viterbi Information Sciences Institute (ISI). As the first of its kind
column2: the task for scientists putting it through its paces was to determine whether the quantum computer was operating as hoped.

column1: Using a specific test problem involving eight qubits we have verified that the D-Wave processor performs optimization calculations (that is
column2: finds lowest energy solutions) using a procedure that is consistent with quantum annealing and is inconsistent with the predictions of classical annealing
column3: said Daniel Lidar
column4: scientific director of the Quantum Computing Center and one of the researchers on the team
column5: who holds joint appointments with the USC Viterbi School of Engineering and the USC Dornsife College of Letters
column6: Arts and Sciences.

column1: Quantum annealing is a method of solving optimization problems using quantum mechanics -- at a large enough scale
column2: potentially much faster than a traditional processor can.

column1: Research institutions throughout the world build and use quantum processors
column2: but most only have a few quantum bits
column3: or ""qubits.""

column1: Qubits have the capability of encoding the two digits of one and zero at the same time -- as opposed to traditional bits
column2: which can encode distinctly either a one or a zero. This property
column3: called ""superposition
column4: along with the ability of quantum states to ""tunnel"" through energy barriers
column5: are hoped to play a role in helping future generations of the D-Wave processor to ultimately perform optimization calculations much faster than traditional processors.

column1: With 108 functional qubits
column2: the D-Wave processor at USC inspired hopes for a significant advance in the field of quantum computing when it was installed in October 2011 -- provided it worked as a quantum information processor. Quantum processors can fall victim to a phenomenon called ""decoherence
column3: which stifles their ability to behave in a quantum fashion.

column1: The USC team's research shows that the chip
column2: in fact
column3: performed largely as hoped
column4: demonstrating the potential for quantum optimization on a larger-than-ever scale.

column1: Our work seems to show that
column2: from a purely physical point of view
column3: quantum effects play a functional role in information processing in the D-Wave processor
column4: said Sergio Boixo
column5: first author of the research paper
column6: who conducted the research while he was a computer scientist at ISI and research assistant professor at the USC Viterbi School of Engineering.

column1: Boixo and Lidar collaborated with Tameem Albash
column2: postdoctoral research associate in physics at USC Dornsife; Federico M. Spedalieri
column3: computer scientist at ISI; and Nicholas Chancellor
column4: a recent physics graduate at USC Dornsife. Their findings will be published in Nature Communications on June 28.

column1: The news comes just two months after the Quantum Computing Center's original D-Wave processor -- known commercially as the ""Rainier"" chip -- was upgraded to a new 512-qubit ""Vesuvius"" chip. The Quantum Computing Center
column2: which includes a magnetically shielded box that is kept frigid (near absolute zero) to protect the computer against decoherence
column3: was designed to be upgradable to keep up with the latest developments in the field.

column1: The new Vesuvius chip at USC is currently the only one in operation outside of D-Wave. A second such chip
column2: owned by Google and housed at NASA's Ames Research Center in Moffett Field
column3: California
column4: is expected to become operational later this year.

column1: Next
column2: the USC team will take the Vesuvius chip for a test drive
column3: putting it through the same paces as the Rainier chip.";4219;['castvs0'

column1: 74435a27b9cd11244137c122407b177cbfa1fd2d26a7ecb9c8c798a89b802f56;posted_link;r/worldnews;https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/quantum-teleportation-nasa-internet-b1777105.html;['kiefzm'];['CorthX'];[1608672263.0];['Nasa scientists achieve long-distance quantum teleportation that could pave way for quantum internet'];[nan];2020-12-21;Adam Smith;Nasa scientists achieve long-distance quantum teleportation that could pave way for quantum internet;"Scientists sent qubits through 44 kilometers of fiber-optic network with a 90 per cent degree of fidelity. This network was built with off-the-shelf equipment
column2: which would be compatible with existing internet infrastructure.

column1: Qubits work by replacing traditional bits – the ‘1’s’ and ‘0’s’ used to encode digital information – with quantum bits
column2: or qubits.

column1: These are able to function as both a ‘1’ and a ‘0’ at the same time by existing in a state of superposition
column2: meaning each new qubit added to the computer increases is power exponentially rather than linearly.

column1: Quantum teleportation
column2: therefore
column3: is a transfer of quantum states from one location to the other. This transfer was done using quantum entanglement
column4: where two particles are linked in such a way that information shared with one is shared with the other at exactly the same time.

column1: This is because the particles exist in states of probabilities
column2: where their exact position
column3: momentum
column4: and spin is not determined until the particle has been measured.

column1: Photons behave in this way
column2: becoming a wave or a particle depending on how they are measured.

column1: “We wanted to push the envelope for this type of research and take important steps on a path to realise both real-life applications for quantum communications and networks and test fundamental physics ideas
column2: ” Panagiotis Spentzouris
column3: head of the Quantum Science Program at Fermilab
column4: told Motherboard.

column1: “People on social media are asking if they should sign up for a quantum internet provider (jokingly of course)
column2: ” Maria Spiropulu
column3: Shang-Yi Ch’en professor of physics at Caltech
column4: said. “We need (a lot) more R&D work.”

column1: Quantum computers are capable of performing computations nearly 100 trillion times faster than the world’s most powerful supercomputer. Teams from the University of Science and Technology of China
column2: as well as Google
column3: have managed to achieve such feats using two different methods.

column1: The US Department of Energy recently unveiled a blueprint for national quantum internet in Chicago
column2: and the demonstration achieved by the scientists could “lay the foundation for the construction of a Chicago-area metropolitan quantum network
column3: ” Spentzouris said.

column1: “We are very proud to have achieved this milestone on sustainable
column2: high-performing and scalable quantum teleportation systems
column3: ” Professor Spiropulu said. “The results will be further improved with system upgrades we are expecting to complete by Q2 2021.”";2419;['ggqd953'

column1: 1a86bf3d473f8bb8a5f6bf4363326801c29b71c762ccd8df2b6c67c93872d8df;posted_link;r/science;http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2014/04/flipping-the-switch/;['24rsp4'];['AGreatWind'];[1399295377.0];['Harvard researchers have succeeded in creating quantum switches made from single atoms that can be turned on and off using a single photon. First step to a quantum internet.'];[nan];2014-04-22;Peter Reuell;Flipping the switch;"Harvard researchers have succeeded in creating quantum switches that can be turned on and off using a single photon
column2: a technological achievement that could pave the way for creating highly secure quantum networks.

column1: Built from single atoms
column2: the first-of-their-kind switches could one day be networked via fiber-optic cables to form the backbone of a “quantum Internet” that allows for perfectly secure communications
column3: said Professor of Physics Mikhail Lukin
column4: who
column5: together with Professor Vladan Vuletic of MIT
column6: led a team consisting of graduate students Jeff Thompson and Lee Liu and postdoctoral fellows Tobias Tiecke and Nathalie de Leon to construct the new system. Their research is detailed in a recently published paper in the journal Nature.

column1: “From a technical standpoint
column2: it’s a remarkable accomplishment
column3: ” Lukin said of the advance. “Conceptually
column4: the idea is very simple: Push the conventional light switch to its ultimate limit. What we’ve done here is to use a single atom as a switch that
column5: depending on its state
column6: can open or close the flow of photons … and it can be turned on and off using a single photon.”

column1: Though the switches could be used to build a quantum computer
column2: Lukin said it’s unlikely the technology will show up in the average desktop computer.

column1: Where it will be used
column2: he said
column3: is in creating fiber-optical networks that use quantum cryptography
column4: a method for encrypting communications using the laws of quantum mechanics to allow for perfectly secure information exchanges. Such systems make it impossible to intercept and read messages sent over a network
column5: because the very act of measuring a quantum object changes it
column6: leaving behind telltale signs of the spying.

column1: “It’s unlikely everyone would need this type of technology
column2: ” he said. “But there are some realistic applications that could someday have transformative impact on our society. At present
column3: we are limited to using quantum cryptography over relatively short distances — tens of kilometers. Based on the new advance
column4: we may eventually be able to extend the range of quantum cryptography to thousands of kilometers.”

column1: Importantly
column2: Tiecke said
column3: their system is highly scalable
column4: and could one day allow for the fabrication of thousands of such switches in a single device.

column1: “What we’ve really done is take ideas that people have been exploring
column2: and still are exploring
column3: in macroscopic systems where the light bounces back and forth on two centimeter-size mirrors to interact with an atom. We’ve taken that and shrunk it down
column4: ” said Thompson. “For two decades
column5: researchers have been working on coupling two or three of these macroscopic systems and [creating] a simple network. But it’s very easy for us to create three or four
column6: or 10
column7: 000 of these optical circuits. What the present paper shows is

column1: That is one way
column2: Lukin believes
column3: for quantum systems to make the same transition that conventional computers made decades ago.

column1: “Conventional computers were initially built using vacuum tubes
column2: and people eventually developed integrated circuits used in modern computers
column3: ” he said. “Where quantum systems stand today
column4: the best systems are still analogous to vacuum tubes. They typically use vacuum chambers to isolate and hold single atoms using electromagnetic fields.

column1: “But it’s very clear
column2: if we want to scale these systems up
column3: we have to think about using integrated circuits
column4: ” he continued. “What Jeff and Tobias have done is create a hybrid system. We take atoms in vacuum chambers and combine them with integrated circuits.”

column1: Though fabricated in a way similar to how traditional computer chips are made
column2: the integrated circuits built by Thompson and Tiecke don’t run on electricity
column3: but on light.

column1: The chips use nanophotonic technology — essentially the ability to create “wiring” that can channel and control the pathway of light — to build optical circuits that can then be connected to fiber optic cables.
After placing the optical circuits in a vacuum chamber
column2: researchers used “optical tweezers” — precisely focused lasers — to capture a single atom and cool it to a fraction above absolute zero. They then move the atom to within a few hundred nanometers of the chip.

column1: Simply bringing the two parts together
column2: however
column3: isn’t enough. To create quantum switches that one day may be at the heart of quantum networks
column4: the researchers bombard the atom with microwaves and lasers
column5: causing it to enter a quantum superposition state
column6: meaning it can occupy multiple quantum states
column7: corresponding to on and off states of the switch

column1: “For this to work
column2: the atom switch must be prepared in this special superposition state
column3: ” Lukin explained. “This superposition state is extremely fragile — so fragile that when a single photon hits it
column4: it actually changes its phase. That change of phase is what allows it to act like a valve
column5: and be turned on or off.”

column1: While it’s unlikely the switches will become standard equipment for personal computers
column2: Lukin said
column3: they could appear in prototype quantum networks in as little as a decade.

column1: “There are other systems that are more sophisticated in terms of building a quantum computer
column2: ” Thompson said. “But the key advantage to what’s demonstrated in this paper is the single-atom switch is very tightly coupled to light
column3: and specifically to light in optical fibers.”";5329;['cha0cxh'

column1: 29c78ffc62beebcc4df8e6c87f47a58bee0cc4d6183ba50c883baecba6bc320d;posted_link;r/science;https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2021/07/harvard-led-physicists-create-256-qubit-programmable-quantum-simulator/;['ogt834'];['MistWeaver80'];[1625828446.0];"['Scientists developed a special type of quantum computer known as a programmable quantum simulator capable of operating with 256 quantum bits
column2: or “qubits.” ""The number of quantum states that are possible with only 256 qubits exceeds the number of atoms in the solar system.""']";[nan];2021-07-07;Juan Siliezar;Harvard-led physicists create 256-qubit programmable quantum simulator;"A team of physicists from the Harvard-MIT Center for Ultracold Atoms and other universities has developed a special type of quantum computer known as a programmable quantum simulator capable of operating with 256 quantum bits
column3: or “qubits.”

column1: The system marks a major step toward building large-scale quantum machines that could be used to shed light on a host of complex quantum processes and eventually help bring about real-world breakthroughs in material science
column2: communication technologies
column3: finance
column4: and many other fields
column5: overcoming research hurdles that are beyond the capabilities of even the fastest supercomputers today. Qubits are the fundamental building blocks on which quantum computers run and the source of their massive processing power.

column1: “This moves the field into a new domain where no one has ever been to thus far
column2: ” said Mikhail Lukin
column3: the George Vasmer Leverett Professor of Physics
column4: co-director of the Harvard Quantum Initiative
column5: and one of the senior authors of the study published today in the journal Nature. “We are entering a completely new part of the quantum world.”

column1: According to Sepehr Ebadi
column2: a physics student in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and the study’s lead author
column3: it is the combination of system’s unprecedented size and programmability that puts it at the cutting edge of the race for a quantum computer
column4: which harnesses the mysterious properties of matter at extremely small scales to greatly advance processing power. Under the right circumstances
column5: the increase in qubits means the system can store and process exponentially more information than the classical bits on which standard computers run.

column1: “The number of quantum states that are possible with only 256 qubits exceeds the number of atoms in the solar system
column2: ” Ebadi said
column3: explaining the system’s vast size.

column1: Already
column2: the simulator has allowed researchers to observe several exotic quantum states of matter that had never before been realized experimentally
column3: and to perform a quantum phase transition study so precise that it serves as the textbook example of how magnetism works at the quantum level.

column1: These experiments provide powerful insights on the quantum physics underlying material properties and can help show scientists how to design new materials with exotic properties.
The project uses a significantly upgraded version of a platform the researchers developed in 2017
column2: which was capable of reaching a size of 51 qubits. That older system allowed the researchers to capture ultra-cold rubidium atoms and arrange them in a specific order using a one-dimensional array of individually focused laser beams called optical tweezers.

column1: This new system allows the atoms to be assembled in two-dimensional arrays of optical tweezers. This increases the achievable system size from 51 to 256 qubits. Using the tweezers
column2: researchers can arrange the atoms in defect-free patterns and create programmable shapes like square
column3: honeycomb
column4: or triangular lattices to engineer different interactions between the qubits.

column1: “The workhorse of this new platform is a device called the spatial light modulator
column2: which is used to shape an optical wavefront to produce hundreds of individually focused optical tweezer beams
column3: ” said Ebadi. “These devices are essentially the same as what is used inside a computer projector to display images on a screen
column4: but we have adapted them to be a critical component of our quantum simulator.”

column1: The initial loading of the atoms into the optical tweezers is random
column2: and the researchers must move the atoms around to arrange them into their target geometries. The researchers use a second set of moving optical tweezers to drag the atoms to their desired locations
column3: eliminating the initial randomness. Lasers give the researchers complete control over the positioning of the atomic qubits and their coherent quantum manipulation.";3850;['h4kv4b2'

column1: eaaffba4c5f53b9a0962c45494864cde9445a0e328778180f8d0e1238fc94f76;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2022-07-mathematical-quantum-interstellar-space.html;['vt3f6a'];['criticalbeta37'];[1657148982.0];['Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible'];[nan];2022-07-06;Bob Yirka;Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible;"Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible

A team of physicists at the University of Edinburgh's School of Physics and Astronomy has used mathematical calculations to show that quantum communications across interstellar space should be possible. In their paper published in the journal Physical Review D
column2: the group describes their calculations and also the possibility of extraterrestrial beings attempting to communicate with us using such signaling.

column1: Over the past several years
column2: scientists have been investigating the possibility of using quantum communications as a highly secure form of message transmission. Prior research has shown that it would be nearly impossible to intercept such messages without detection. In this new effort
column3: the researchers wondered if similar types of communications might be possible across interstellar space. To find out
column4: they used math that describes that movement of X-rays across a medium
column5: such as those that travel between the stars. More specifically
column6: they looked to see if their calculations could show the degree of decoherence that might occur during such a journey.

column1: With quantum communications
column2: engineers are faced with quantum particles that lose some or all of their unique characteristics as they interact with obstructions in their path—they have been found to be quite delicate
column3: in fact. Such events are known as decoherence
column4: and engineers working to build quantum networks have been devising ways to overcome the problem. Prior research has shown that the space between the stars is pretty clean. But is it clean enough for quantum communications? The math shows that it is. Space is so clean
column5: in fact
column6: that X-ray photons could travel hundreds of thousands of light years without becoming subject to decoherence—and that includes gravitational interference from astrophysical bodies. They noted in their work that optical and microwave bands would work equally well.

column1: The researchers noted that because quantum communication is possible across the galaxy
column2: if other intelligent beings exist in the Milky Way
column3: they could already be trying to communicate with us using such technology and we could begin looking for them. They also suggest that quantum teleportation across interstellar space should be possible.";2318;['if4bktq'

column1: 28dc4cea2e5191b861553243d4fc662a282c4e7db068ca311a33f044e0d08df6;posted_link;r/Futurology;http://www.technologyreview.com/news/544421/googles-quantum-dream-machine/;['3xbugx'];['Simcurious'];[1450433148.0];"['Inside Google\'s Quantum Computing Lab - ""In 10 years there’s nothing but quantum machine learning""']";[nan];2015-12-18;Tom Simonite;Google’s Quantum Dream Machine;"Physicist John Martinis could deliver one of the holy grails of computing to Google—a machine that dramatically speeds up today’s applications and makes new ones possible.

John Martinis used the arm of his reading glasses to indicate the spot where he intends to demonstrate an almost unimaginably powerful new form of computer in a few years. It is a cylindrical socket an inch and a half across
column2: at the bottom of a torso-sized stack of plates
column3: blocks
column4: and wires of brass
column5: copper
column6: and gold. The day after I met with him this fall
column7: he loaded the socket with an experimental superconducting chip etched with a microscopic Google logo and cooled the apparatus to a hundredth of a degree Celsius above absolute zero. To celebrate that first day of testing the machine
column8: Martinis threw what he called “a little party” at a brewpub with colleagues from his newly outfitted Google lab in Santa Barbara

column1: John Martinis has been researching how quantum computers could work for 30 years. Now he could be on the verge of finally making a useful one.

That party was nothing compared with the celebration that will take place if Martinis and his group can actually create the wonder computer they seek. Because it would harness the strange properties of quantum physics that arise in extreme conditions like those on the ultracold chip
column2: the new computer would let a Google coder run calculations in a coffee break that would take a supercomputer of today millions of years. The software that Google has developed on ordinary computers to drive cars or answer questions could become vastly more intelligent. And earlier-stage ideas bubbling up at Google and its parent company
column3: such as robots that can serve as emergency responders or software that can converse at a human level
column4: might become real.

column1: The theoretical underpinnings of quantum computing are well established. And physicists can build the basic units
column2: known as qubits
column3: out of which a quantum computer would be made. They can even operate qubits together in small groups. But they have not made a fully working
column4: practical quantum computer.

column1: Martinis is a towering figure in the field: his research group at the University of California
column2: Santa Barbara
column3: has demonstrated some of the most reliable qubits around and gotten them running some of the code a quantum computer would need to function. He was hired by Google in June 2014 after persuading the company that his team’s technology could mature rapidly with the right support. With his new Google lab up and running
column4: Martinis guesses that he can demonstrate a small but useful quantum computer in two or three years. “We often say to each other that we’re in the process of giving birth to the quantum computer industry
column5: ” he says.

column1: Google and quantum computing are a match made in algorithmic heaven. The company is often said to be defined by an insatiable hunger for data. But Google has a more pressing strategic addiction: to technology that extracts information from data
column2: and even creates intelligence from it. The company was founded to commercialize an algorithm for ranking Web pages
column3: and it built its financial foundations with systems that sell and target ads. More recently
column4: Google has invested heavily in the development of AI software that can learn to understand language or images
column5: perform basic reasoning
column6: or steer a car through traffic—all things that remain tricky for conventional computers but should be a breeze for quantum ones. “Machine learning is a core
column7: transformative way by which we’re rethinking how we’re doing everything
column10: recently informed investors. Supporting that effort would be the first of many jobs for Martinis’s new quantum industry.

column1: Dream maker
As recently as last week the prospect of a quantum computer doing anything useful within a few years seemed remote. Researchers in government
column2: academic
column3: and corporate labs were far from combining enough qubits to make even a simple proof-of-principle machine. A well-funded Canadian startup called D-Wave Systems sold a few of what it called “the world’s first commercial quantum computers” but spent years failing to convince experts that the machines actually were doing what a quantum computer should (see “The CIA and Jeff Bezos Bet on Quantum Computing”).

column1: Then NASA summoned journalists to building N-258 at its Ames Research Center in Mountain View
column2: California
column3: which since 2013 has hosted a D-Wave computer bought by Google. There Hartmut Neven
column4: who leads the Quantum Artificial Intelligence lab Google established to experiment with the D-Wave machine
column5: unveiled the first real evidence that it can offer the power proponents of quantum computing have promised. In a carefully designed test
column6: the superconducting chip inside D-Wave’s computer—known as a quantum annealer—had performed 100 million times faster than a conventional processor.

column1: As recently as last week the prospect of a quantum computer doing anything useful within a few years seemed remote. Then NASA summoned journalists to its Ames Research Center in Mountain View.
However
column2: this kind of advantage needs to be available in practical computing tasks
column3: not just contrived tests. “We need to make it easier to take a problem that comes up at an engineer’s desk and put it into the computer
column4: ” said Neven
column5: a talkative machine-learning expert. That’s where Martinis comes in. Neven doesn’t think D-Wave can get a version of its quantum annealer ready to serve Google’s engineers quickly enough
column6: so he hired Martinis to do it. “It became clear that we can’t just wait
column7: ” Neven says. “There’s a list of shortcomings that need to be overcome in order to arrive at a real technology.” He says the qubits on D-Wave’s chip are too unreliable and aren’t wired together thickly enough. (D-Wave’s CEO
column9: responds that he’s not worried about competition from Google.)

column1: Google will be competing not only with whatever improvements D-Wave can make
column2: but also with Microsoft and IBM
column3: which have substantial quantum computing projects of their own (see “Microsoft’s Quantum Mechanics” and “IBM Shows Off a Quantum Computing Chip”). But those companies are focused on designs much further from becoming practically useful. Indeed
column4: a rough internal time line for Google’s project estimates that Martinis’s group can make a quantum annealer with 100 qubits as soon as 2017. D-Wave’s latest chip already has 1
column5: 097 qubits
column6: but Neven says a high-quality chip with fewer qubits will probably be useful for some tasks nonetheless. A quantum annealer can run only one particular algorithm
column7: but it happens to be one well suited to the areas Google most cares about. The applications that could particularly benefit include pattern recognition and machine learning
column9: a senior staff member at MIT Lincoln Laboratory who has studied the potential of quantum computing.

column1: John Martinis
column3: is the perfect person to wrestle a mind-bogglingly complex strand of quantum physics research into a new engineering discipline. Not only can he dive into the esoteric math
column4: but he loves to build things. Operating even a single qubit is a puzzle assembled from deep quantum theory
column5: solid-state physics
column6: materials science
column10: who is tall with a loud
column12: makes a point of personally mastering the theory and technical implementation of every piece. Giving a tour of his new lab at Google
column13: he is as excited about the new soldering irons and machine tools in the conventional workshop area as he is about the more sophisticated equipment that chills chips and operates them. “To me it’s fun
column14: ” he says. “I’ve been able to do experiments no one else could do
column15: because I could build my own electronics.”

column1: Martinis and his team have to be adept at so many things because qubits are fickle. They can be made in various ways—Martinis uses aluminum loops chilled with tiny currents until they become superconductors—but all represent data by means of delicate quantum states that are easily distorted or destroyed by heat and electromagnetic noise
column2: potentially ruining a calculation.

column1: Qubits use their fragile physics to do the same thing that transistors use electricity to do on a conventional chip: represent binary bits of information
column2: either 0 or 1. But qubits can also attain a state
column3: called a superposition
column4: that is effectively both 0 and 1 at the same time. Qubits in a superposition can become linked by a phenomenon known as entanglement
column5: which means an action performed on one has instant effects on the other. Those effects allow a single operation in a quantum computer to do the work of many
column6: many more operations in a conventional computer. In some cases
column7: a quantum computer’s advantage over a conventional one should grow exponentially with the amount of data to be worked on.

column1: The difficulty of creating qubits that are stable enough is the reason we don’t have quantum computers yet. But Martinis has been working on that for more than 11 years and thinks he’s nearly there. The coherence time of his qubits
column2: or the length of time they can maintain a superposition
column3: is tens of microseconds—about 10
column4: 000 times the figure for those on D-Wave’s chip.

column1: Martinis’s confidence in his team’s hardware even has him thinking he can build Google an alternative to a quantum annealer that would be even more powerful. A universal quantum computer
column2: as it would be called
column3: could be programmed to take on any kind of problem
column4: not just one kind of math. The theory behind that approach is actually better understood than the one for annealers
column5: in part because most of the time and money in quantum computing research have been devoted to universal quantum computing. But qubits have not been reliable enough to translate the theory into a working universal quantum computer.

column1: Until March
column2: that is
column3: when Martinis and his team became the first to demonstrate qubits that crossed a crucial reliability threshold for a universal quantum computer (see “Google Researchers Make Quantum Computing Components More Reliable”). They got a chip with nine qubits to run part of an error-checking program
column4: called the surface code
column5: that’s necessary for such a computer to operate (IBM has since gotten part of the surface code working on four qubits). “We demonstrated the technology to a point where I knew we could scale up
column6: ” says Martinis. “This was for real.”

column1: Martinis aims to show off a complete universal quantum computer with about 100 qubits around the same time he delivers Google’s new quantum annealer
column2: in about two years. That would be a milestone in computer science
column3: but it would be unlikely to help Google’s programmers right away. Such is the complexity of the surface code that although a chip with 100 qubits could run the error-checking program
column4: it would be unable to do any useful work in addition to that
column5: says Robert McDermott
column6: who leads a quantum computing research group at the University of Wisconsin. Yet Martinis thinks that once he can get his qubits reliable enough to put 100 of them on a universal quantum chip
column7: the path to combining many more will open up. “This is something we understand pretty well
column8: ” he says. “It’s hard to get coherence but easy to scale up.”

column1: Stupid algorithms
When Martinis explains why his technology is needed at Google
column2: he doesn’t spare the feelings of the people working on AI. “Machine-learning algorithms are really kind of stupid
column3: ” he says
column4: with a hint of wonder in his voice. “They need so many examples to learn.”

column1: Indeed
column2: the machine learning used by Google and other computing companies is pathetic next to the way humans or animals pick up new skills or knowledge. Teaching a piece of software new tricks
column3: such as how to recognize cars and cats in photos
column4: generally requires thousands or millions of carefully curated and labeled examples. Although a technique called deep learning has recently produced striking advances in the accuracy with which software can learn to interpret images and speech
column5: more complex faculties like understanding the nuances of language remain out of machines’ reach.

column1: Figuring out how Martinis’s chips can make Google’s software less stupid falls to Neven. He thinks that the prodigious power of qubits will narrow the gap between machine learning and biological learning—and remake the field of artificial intelligence. “Machine learning will be transformed into quantum learning
column2: ” he says. That could mean software that can learn from messier data
column3: or from less data
column4: or even without explicit instruction. For instance
column5: Google’s researchers have designed an algorithm they think could allow machine-learning software to pick up a new trick even if as much as half the example data it’s given is incorrectly labeled. Neven muses that this kind of computational muscle could be the key to giving computers capabilities today limited to humans. “People talk about whether we can make creative machines–the most creative systems we can build will be quantum AI systems
column6: ” he says.

column1: More practically
column2: with only D-Wave’s machine to practice on for now
column3: Google’s researchers can’t do much more than speculate about what exactly they could or should do with the chips Martinis is building. Even when they do get their hands on them
column4: it will take time to invent and build the infrastructure needed to operate large numbers of the exotic devices so they can contribute materially to Google’s business.

column1: Neven is confident that Google’s quantum craftsmen and his team can get through all that. He pictures rows of superconducting chips lined up in data centers for Google engineers to access over the Internet relatively soon. “I would predict that in 10 years there’s nothing but quantum machine learning–you don’t do the conventional way anymore
column2: ” he says. A smiling Martinis warily accepts that vision. “I like that
column3: but it’s hard
column4: ” he says. “He can say that
column5: but I have to build it.”";13940;['cy39gsl'

column1: 67c47b25edf1d5f068270aa4c1d18b0a8258c7ecc2d6e2cb3f5deb2014488300;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2022-09-artificial-intelligence-equation-quantum-physics.html;['xp2o2y'];['Semifreak'];[1664242701.0];['Artificial intelligence reduces a 100
column2: 000-equation quantum physics problem to only four equations'];[nan];2022-09-26;Thomas Sumner;Artificial intelligence reduces a 100
column3: 000-equation quantum physics problem to only four equations;"Artificial intelligence reduces a 100
column4: 000-equation quantum physics problem to only four equations

column1: Using artificial intelligence
column2: physicists have compressed a daunting quantum problem that until now required 100
column3: 000 equations into a bite-size task of as few as four equations—all without sacrificing accuracy. The work
column4: published in the September 23 issue of Physical Review Letters
column5: could revolutionize how scientists investigate systems containing many interacting electrons. Moreover
column6: if scalable to other problems
column7: the approach could potentially aid in the design of materials with sought-after properties such as superconductivity or utility for clean energy generation.

column1: We start with this huge object of all these coupled-together differential equations; then we're using machine learning to turn it into something so small you can count it on your fingers
column2: says study lead author Domenico Di Sante
column3: a visiting research fellow at the Flatiron Institute's Center for Computational Quantum Physics (CCQ) in New York City and an assistant professor at the University of Bologna in Italy.

column1: The formidable problem concerns how electrons behave as they move on a gridlike lattice. When two electrons occupy the same lattice site
column2: they interact. This setup
column3: known as the Hubbard model
column4: is an idealization of several important classes of materials and enables scientists to learn how electron behavior gives rise to sought-after phases of matter
column5: such as superconductivity
column6: in which electrons flow through a material without resistance. The model also serves as a testing ground for new methods before they're unleashed on more complex quantum systems.

column1: The Hubbard model is deceptively simple
column2: however. For even a modest number of electrons and cutting-edge computational approaches
column3: the problem requires serious computing power. That's because when electrons interact
column4: their fates can become quantum mechanically entangled: Even once they're far apart on different lattice sites
column5: the two electrons can't be treated individually
column6: so physicists must deal with all the electrons at once rather than one at a time. With more electrons
column8: making the computational challenge exponentially harder.

column1: One way of studying a quantum system is by using what's called a renormalization group. That's a mathematical apparatus physicists use to look at how the behavior of a system—such as the Hubbard model—changes when scientists modify properties such as temperature or look at the properties on different scales. Unfortunately
column2: a renormalization group that keeps track of all possible couplings between electrons and doesn't sacrifice anything can contain tens of thousands
column3: hundreds of thousands or even millions of individual equations that need to be solved. On top of that
column4: the equations are tricky: Each represents a pair of electrons interacting.

column1: Di Sante and his colleagues wondered if they could use a machine learning tool known as a neural network to make the renormalization group more manageable. The neural network is like a cross between a frantic switchboard operator and survival-of-the-fittest evolution. First
column2: the machine learning program creates connections within the full-size renormalization group. The neural network then tweaks the strengths of those connections until it finds a small set of equations that generates the same solution as the original
column3: jumbo-size renormalization group. The program's output captured the Hubbard model's physics even with just four equations.

column1: It's essentially a machine that has the power to discover hidden patterns
column2: Di Sante says. ""When we saw the result
column3: we said
column4: 'Wow
column5: this is more than what we expected.' We were really able to capture the relevant physics.""

column1: Training the machine learning program required a lot of computational muscle
column2: and the program ran for entire weeks. The good news
column3: Di Sante says
column4: is that now that they have their program coached
column5: they can adapt it to work on other problems without having to start from scratch. He and his collaborators are also investigating just what the machine learning is actually ""learning"" about the system
column6: which could provide additional insights that might otherwise be hard for physicists to decipher.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the biggest open question is how well the new approach works on more complex quantum systems such as materials in which electrons interact at long distances. In addition
column3: there are exciting possibilities for using the technique in other fields that deal with renormalization groups
column4: Di Sante says
column5: such as cosmology and neuroscience.";4577;['iq1bb3z'
column6: 'iq1q49q'

column1: ec6950e4738a52f153382ef5921a5a769042fdbd47c85d9fcf242ea396ced227;posted_link;r/technews;https://phys.org/news/2022-11-fluxonium-qubits-creation-quantum-closer.html;['z2kc6l'];['dont_step_on_toes'];[1669194570.0];['Fluxonium qubits bring the creation of a quantum computer closer'];[nan];2022-11-21;"The National University; Technology MISIS";Fluxonium qubits bring the creation of a quantum computer closer;"Fluxonium qubits bring the creation of a quantum computer closer

Russian scientists from University of Science and Technology MISIS and Bauman Moscow State Technical University were one of the first in the world to implement a two-qubit operation using superconducting fluxonium qubits. Fluxoniums have a longer life cycle and a greater precision of operations
column2: so they are used to make longer algorithms. An article on research that brings the creation of a quantum computer closer to reality has been published in npj Quantum Information.

column1: One of the main questions in the development of a universal quantum computer is about qubits. Namely
column2: which quantum objects are the best to make processors for quantum computers: electrons
column3: photons
column4: ions
column5: superconductors
column6: or other ""quantum transistors."" Superconducting qubits have become one of the most successful platforms for quantum computing during the past decade. To date
column7: the most commercially successful superconducting qubits are transmons
column8: which are actively investigated and used in the quantum developments of Google
column9: IBM and other world leading laboratories.

column1: The main task of a qubit is to store and process information without errors. Accidental noise and even mere observation can lead to the loss or alteration of data. The stable operation of superconducting qubits often requires extremely low ambient temperatures—close to zero Kelvin
column2: which is hundreds of times colder than the temperature of open space.

column1: Russian physicists from the Superconducting Metamaterials laboratory at MISIS University and Bauman Moscow State Technical University were one of the first in the world to implement a two-qubit operation using superconducting fluxonium qubits. To protect qubits from noise
column2: the researchers added to the circuit a superinductor (a superconducting element with a high level of resistance to alternating current) which is a chain of 40 Josephson contacts—structures of two superconductors separated by a thin layer of dielectric.

column1: Fluxonium qubits are more complex and less studied than transmons. The main advantage of fluxoniums is that they can be operated at a low frequency of about 600 MHz. We know that the lower the frequency
column2: the longer the lifetime of qubits
column3: which means that more operations can be performed with them. During the tests
column4: it turned out that the dielectric losses of fluxonium qubits allow to keep the state of the superposition longer than that of transmons
column5: said Ilya Besedin
column6: one of the authors of the study
column7: an engineer of the scientific project at the NUST MISIS Superconducting Metamaterials laboratory.

column1: To implement a universal set of logical operations
column2: scientists used high-precision two-qubit gates: fSim and CZ. In order to bring the qubits into resonance with each other
column3: parametric modulation of the flow of one of the qubits of the system was used. The authors of the study note
column4: that due to the tunable coupling element
column5: it was simultaneously possible not only to obtain the accuracy of two-qubit operations above 99.22%
column6: but also to suppress the residual ZZ interaction between the qubits
column7: which allowed to perform parallel single-qubit operations with an accuracy of 99.97%.

column1: The low frequency of computational qubits opens the way not only to longer qubits' lifetimes and accuracy of valve operations
column2: which will lead to making longer algorithms
column3: but also makes it possible to use subgigahertz electronics in qubit control lines
column4: which significantly reduces the complexity of the quantum processor control system
column5: said Ilya Besedin.

column1: The obtained results reveal an interesting and promising approach toward fault-tolerant quantum computing with low-frequency qubits that can be a good alternative to the transmon system.
In the future
column2: scientists plan to continue research with computations based on fluxonium qubits
column3: optimizing the qubit control system
column4: improving readout rates and beginning to develop multi-qubit systems based on them.";3948;['ixgxeve'

column1: 42ab40eb67912bbf9099d0fb97d2cb0d211f13f94a4dc55c887174832b65a481;posted_link;r/programming;https://medium.com/the-physics-arxiv-blog/602f88552b64;['257il3'];['jonhayes37'];[1399732105.0];['REAL random number generation on a Nokia N9
column2: thanks to quantum mechanics'];[nan];2014-05-10;The Physics arXiv Blog;Quantum Random Number Generator Created Using A Smartphone Camera;"Quantum Random Number Generator Created Using A Smartphone Camera

column1: Physicists have exploited the laws of quantum mechanics to generate random numbers on a Nokia N9 smartphone
column2: a breakthrough that could have major implications for information security

column1: One of the hidden foundations of modern life are random numbers. If you make credit card payments over the internet
column2: for example
column3: you’re a serial user of random numbers which are necessary to guarantee the security of your personal details.

column1: And with the advent of techniques such as quantum cryptography
column2: which guarantees perfect secrecy and requires vast quantities of random numbers
column3: the demand for these mathematical objects is set to increase dramatically.

column1: But there’s a problem—genuine random numbers are notoriously hard to find. In particular
column2: they cannot be generated by a deterministic process such as a computer program. That’s because a deterministic process can easily be repeated to reproduce the number
column3: proving that it cannot be random.

column1: So physicists have long searched for other ways to make genuinely random numbers based on physical processes that produce random outcomes. The gold standard is the quantum random number generator—a device that exploits the probabilistic nature of quantum mechanics to produce a sequence of entirely random digits.
However
column2: quantum random number generators are complex
column3: expensive devices. So physicists would dearly love to find a cheaper and easier way to generate quantum random numbers.

column1: And now they’ve found it. Today
column2: Bruno Sanguinetti and pals at the University of Geneva in Switzerland have worked out how to generate random numbers on an ordinary smartphone using genuine quantum processes. And they say their new technique can produce random numbers at the rate of 1 megabit per second
column3: more than enough for most security applications.

column1: The quantum process that these guys exploit is the way light sources emit photons. Because each emission is a quantum process
column2: the instant of emission cannot be predicted. So the number of photons that a light source emits in a unit of time will always vary by an amount that is entirely random.

column1: This is the basis of the new technique. Sanguinetti and co point out that smartphone cameras have improved so much in recent years that they are capable of detecting the quantum variations in the number of photons they detect.
They put this to the test with a Nokia N9 smartphone
column2: which has an ordinary 8 megapixel rear-facing colour camera (and is the only phone to run Nokia’s short-lived Meego operating system). And they compared its performance against a monochrome CCD array designed for astronomical use—an ATIK 383L which also has 8 megapixels.

column1: The set up is simple in principle. Each pixel senses the number of photons that arrive in a certain period of time. These photons are converted into electrons
column2: which are then amplified by a factor determined by the camera’s sensitivity setting (ISO setting).

column1: It’s straightforward to calculate the average number of electrons this process should produce
column2: given the probabilistic nature of photon emission. But the actual number of electrons should differ by a number that is random. That produces a single random digit. And since a light-sensitive array consists of many pixels working in parallel
column3: it is possible to generate a large quantity of random digits from each image.

column1: In practice
column2: the first step is to characterise the light sensitivity of the camera by shining a green LED at it. That allows the team to work out the number of photons that saturate a pixel and ensure this does not happen while the random numbers are being generated (otherwise the results are no longer random).

column1: Sanguinetti and co determined that they should illuminate each pixel in the Nokia camera with enough light to generate about 410 electrons and each pixel in the ATIK camera with enough light to generate about 15
column2: 000 electrons
column3: quantities that are easily controlled by limiting the exposure time for each image.

column1: So the process of generating random numbers consists of pointing the camera at a green LED that evenly illuminates all the pixels and pressing the shutter button. A simple program then extracts the random digits.

An important question for any random number generator is whether the resulting numbers are genuinely random. This is a notoriously difficult problem because it is impossible to prove beyond doubt that any given number really is random.

But Sanguinetti and co calculate that their numbers are pretty close to random. They say that the process would have to be repeated 10^118 times before any deviation from randomness might be observed. “If everybody on earth used such a device constantly at 1Gbps
column2: it would take 10^80 times the age of the universe for one to notice a deviation from a perfectly random bit string
column3: ” they say.

column1: That’s not bad. There are also various standard tests that mathematicians have devised that look for specific weaknesses in random numbers. Sanguinetti and co put their device through a number of these. “The random number generator passed all tests
column2: ” they say.

column1: That’s an exciting result. It means that with the appropriate app
column2: anybody with a standard smartphone can generate an almost unlimited quantity of random digits. “We believe that the

column1: simplicity and performance of this device will make the widespread use of quantum random numbers a reality
column2: ” say Sanguinetti and co.

column1: The security implications of this are important. In cryptography
column2: there is a well known idea called Kerckhoffs’s principle that states that the security of a cypher should lie entirely in the key. So while every other aspect of a security system can be public
column3: the information it carries will remain secure as long as the key is also secure.

column1: And applications? Secure credit card transactions are only the beginning. A quantum random number generator that works at 1 Mbps can also secure emails and even phone calls.

There ought to be significant demand for this kind of service given the wholesale eavesdropping that various states have indulged in recently. So it’s not beyond the realms of possibility that some governments will want to regulate the use of this kind of technology.
Be warned: there may be a battle brewing here.";6242;['chea3sr'
