column1: 6763d5878b0ccdf4ed74af92684bdc0977ecaf9627da4bd6f73de0ef59e172a4;posted_link;r/CryptoCurrency;https://m.slashdot.org/story/410693;['110aeso'];['hquer'];[1676188751.0];['Will Quantum Computing Bring a Cryptopocalypse?'];[nan];2023-02-02;Kevin Townsend;Cyber Insights 2023 | Quantum Computing and the Coming Cryptopocalypse;"The cryptopocalypse is the point at which quantum computing becomes powerful enough to use Shor’s algorithm to crack PKI encryption.
The waiting time for general purpose quantum computers is getting shorter
column2: but they are still probably decades away. The arrival of cryptanalytically-relevant quantum computers (CRQCs) that will herald the cryptopocalypse will be much sooner – possibly less than a decade.

column1: At that point our existing PKI-protected data will become accessible as plaintext to anybody; and the ‘harvest now
column2: decrypt later’ process will be complete. This is known as the cryptopocalypse. It is important to note that all PKI-encrypted data that has already been harvested by adversaries is already lost. We can do nothing about the past; we can only attempt to protect the future.

column1: Here we are going to examine the why
column2: what
column3: and how we need to prepare for that cryptopocalypse – but first we need a few definitions to ensure we’re all singing the same song.

column1: - CRQC: A quantum computer capable of running Shor’s algorithm and cracking current PKI encryption.
- Cryptopocalypse: The point at which the existence of CRQCs are able to turn our currently encrypted data into plaintext.
- Quantum safe: Cryptography that is believed to be resistant to CRQCs
column2: but cannot be proven to be so.

column1: - Quantum secure: Cryptography that is provably secure against CRQCs
column2: and cannot be broken.

column1: - Post quantum cryptography (PQC): A term for cryptography designed for the post CRQC era
column2: but one that doesn’t differentiate between ‘safe’ and ‘secure’.

column1: The cryptopocalypse

The cryptopocalypse is the point at which quantum computing becomes powerful enough to use Shor’s algorithm to crack PKI encryption. Since public key encryption is used to secure almost all data in transit
column2: both between separate IT infrastructures and even within individual infrastructures
column3: that data will become accessible by anyone with a sufficiently powerful quantum computer.

column1: “That means that all secrets are at risk
column2: ” explains Bryan Ware
column3: CEO at LookingGlass; “nuclear weapons
column4: banks
column5: business IP
column6: intelligence agencies
column8: are at risk of losing their confidentiality and integrity.”

column1: But this is not a threat for the future – the threat exists today. Adversaries are known to be stealing and storing encrypted data with the knowledge that within a few years they will be able to access the raw data. This is known as the ‘harvest now
column2: decrypt later’ threat. Intellectual property and commercial plans – not to mention military secrets – will still be valuable to adversaries when the cryptopocalypse happens.

column1: “Even if a cryptographically relevant quantum computer is still years away
column2: the time to start preparing is now
column3: ” warns Rebecca Krauthamer
column4: co-founder and CPO at QuSecure.

column1: The one thing we can say with certainty is that it definitely won’t happen in 2023 – probably. That probably comes from not knowing for certain what stage in the journey to quantum computing has been achieved by foreign nations or their intelligence agencies – and they’re not likely to tell us. Nevertheless
column2: it is assumed that nobody yet has a quantum computer powerful enough to run Shor’s algorithm and crack PKI encryption in a meaningful timeframe.

column1: It is likely that such computers may become available as soon as three to five years. Most predictions suggest ten years. Note that a specialized quantum computer designed specifically for Shor does not need to be as powerful as a general-purpose quantum computer – which is more likely to be 20 to 30 years away.

It is difficult to make precise predictions because the power of a quantum computer comes from the number of qubits that can be used. This is further complicated by the instability of qubits that require a high number of additional qubits used solely for error correction. Consequently
column2: the number of qubits that can be ‘used’ (logical qubits) is much less than the total number needed (physical qubits).

column1: It has been suggested that as many as 1
column2: 000 physical qubits may be required for each logical qubit. This will depend on the quality of the error correction in use – and this is an area of intense research. So
column3: at some time in the next few years
column4: as the number of physical qubits increases
column5: and the number of required physical qubits per logical qubit decreases
column6: quantum developers will have a quantum computer able to crack PKI. It has been estimated that this will require between approximately 1

column1: To put some flesh on this skeleton
column2: we can look at an announcement made by IBM on November 9
column3: 2022: a new 433 qubit Osprey processor. This was accompanied by a roadmap that that shows a progression toward a 4
column4: 000 plus qubit quantum computer
column5: codenamed Kookaburra
column6: due in 2025.

column1: Error correction is being approached by a new version of IBM’s Qskit Runtime software that allows ‘a user to trade speed for reduced error count with a simple option in the API’. This is supported by a new modular IBM Quantum System Two able to combine multiple processors into a single system with communication links. System Two is expected to go live in 2023
column2: around the same time that IBM expects to have a 1k+ qubit processor codenamed Condor.

column1: System Two will be a building block in what IBM calls quantum-centric supercomputing. Scott Crowder
column2: the VP of IBM quantum adoption and business
column3: explains in more detail: “Quantum-centric supercomputing (which describes a modular architecture and quantum communication designed to increase computational capacity
column4: and which employs hybrid cloud middleware to seamlessly integrate quantum and classical workflows) is the blueprint for how quantum computing will be used in the years to come.”

column1: He added
column2: “This approach to scaling quantum systems alongside the recent
column3: dramatic improvements in techniques to deal with quantum processor errors is how we envision a path to near-term
column4: practical quantum advantage – the point when quantum processors will be capable of performing a useful computation
column5: faster
column6: more accurately
column7: or cheaper than using exclusively classical computing.”

column1: Navigating such projections doesn’t tell us precisely when to expect the cryptopocalypse
column2: but they clearly show it is getting perilously close. “Quantum computing is not
column3: yet
column4: to the point of rendering conventional encryption useless
column5: at least that we know of
column6: but it is heading that way
column8: senior technical engineer at Vulcan Cyber.

column1: The additional threat from AI
Skip Sanzeri
column2: co-founder and COO at QuSecure
column3: warns that the threat to current encryption is not limited to quantum decryption. “New approaches are being developed promising the same post-quantum cybersecurity threats as a cryptographically relevant quantum computer
column4: only much sooner
column5: ” he said. “It is also believed that quantum advancements don’t have to directly decrypt today’s encryption. If they weaken it by suggesting or probabilistically finding some better seeds for a classical algorithm (like the sieve) and make that more efficient
column6: that can result in a successful attack. And it’s no stretch to predict
column8: that people are going to find ways to hack our encryption that we don’t even know about yet.”

column1: Steve Weston
column2: co-founder and CTO at Incrypteon
column3: offers a possible illustration. “Where is the threat in 2023 and beyond?” he asks. “Is it the threat from quantum computers
column4: or is the bigger threat from AI? An analysis of cryptoanalysis and code breaking over the last 40 years shows how AI is used now
column5: and will be more so in the future.”

column1: QKD
Quantum key distribution (QKD) is a method of securely exchanging encryption keys using quantum properties transmitted via fiber. While in this quantum state
column2: the nature of quantum mechanics ensures that any attempt to access the transmission will disturb the content. It does not prevent attacks
column3: but ensures that an attempted attack is immediately visible
column4: and the key can be discarded. Successful QKD paves the way for data to be transmitted using the latest and best symmetrical encryption. Current symmetrical algorithms are considered safe against quantum decryption.

column1: “Symmetric encryption
column2: like AES-256
column3: is theorized to be quantum aafe
column4: but one can speculate that key sizes will soon double
column5: ” comments Silvio Pappalardo
column6: chief revenue officer at Quintessence Labs.

column1: “Quantum cryptography is a method of encryption that uses the principles of quantum physics in securing and transmitting data
column2: ” says Ganesh Subramanya
column3: head of data protection CoE cybersecurity at TCS. “It creates security so strong that data coded in quantum state cannot be compromised without the sender being notified. Traditional cryptography uses technologies like SSL and TLS to secure data over the internet
column4: but they have been vulnerable to a variety of attacks
column5: as an attacker can change the communication between two parties (like user’s browser and the webpage / application) and make them believe they’re still communicating with each other. With quantum cryptography
column6: such an alteration of data is not possible
column7: thereby strengthening the security of online transactions.”

column1: John Prisco
column2: Toshiba partner and president/CEO of Safe Quantum
column3: applies these principles to QKD. “Quantum key distribution contains a key security aspect that cannot be overstated
column4: ” he says
column5: “especially if it is being utilized in tandem with the NIST post-quantum encryption standards (PQC). The gold standard in cybersecurity is considered to be defense in-depth
column6: as this leverages two totally different technologies with diverse failure mechanisms
column7: working for protection. With harvest now decrypt later attacks becoming more frequent
column8: there is no delay time that is safe to defend against quantum attacks. QKD authenticated with PQC signature algorithms is the only defense that can be deployed immediately and guarantee a successful defense against harvest now

column1: Terry Cronin
column2: the VP at Toshiba who oversees the QKD Division
column3: agrees with this assessment. “The use of QKD as part of a hybrid solution to quantum resistance can offer the security needed ensuring that a harvest and decrypt attack cannot succeed in accessing the data.”

column1: The practical difficulties in introducing wide-scale fiber based QKD means that it cannot be implemented everywhere. Its immediate use will likely be limited to point-to-point communications between high value sites – such as some government agencies and between major bank offices.
Post Quantum Cryptography
NIST

NIST began a competition to select and standardize post quantum encryption algorithms in 2016. “We’re looking to replace three NIST cryptographic standards and guidelines that would be the most vulnerable to quantum computers
column2: ” said NIST mathematician Dustin Moody at the time. “They deal with encryption
column3: key establishment and digital signatures
column4: all of which use forms of public key cryptography.”

column1: In July 2022
column2: NIST announced its first four finalists. However
column3: it emerged in August 2022 that a different finalist
column4: the Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation (SIKE) algorithm had already been broken. SIKE is designed to deliver keys securely from source to destination across an untrusted network. Researchers had demonstrated
column5: however
column6: the algorithm could be cracked on a single classical PC in little over an hour.

column1: This illustrates a problem that all security professionals need to confront. Any encryption algorithm is secure only until it is cracked. Whitehat researchers will tell you if they can crack an algorithm — foreign governments will not. In effect
column2: this means that the ‘later’ part of ‘harvest now
column3: decrypt later’ is an optimistic view. We believe that encrypted IP being stolen today cannot yet be decrypted — but we cannot be certain.

column1: We do
column2: however
column3: know that current PKI encryption will certainly be broken by quantum computers in the relatively near future. The solution from NIST is to replace current vulnerable PKI algorithms with more complex algorithms — that is to solve more powerful computing by using more powerful algorithms.

column1: Ultimately
column2: we will be in the same position we are in today. We will believe our IP protected by NIST’s post quantum algorithms will be safe — but we cannot be certain. Remember that at least one proposed post-quantum algorithm has been broken on a PC. So
column3: even if we switch to a NIST-approved post quantum encryption standard tomorrow
column4: we cannot be certain that the harvest now decrypt later philosophy has been beaten.

column1: One-time pads
NIST’s PQC algorithms are ‘quantum safe’
column2: they are not ‘quantum secure’. The former is thought to be safe against quantum decryption but cannot be proven to be so (since they are mathematical in nature and susceptible to mathematical decryption). Cryptography that can be proven to be safe is known as ‘quantum secure’ — and the only way to achieve this is to remove mathematics from the equation.

column1: The only quantum secure cryptography known is the one-time pad because it relies on information security rather than mathematical security. Technically
column2: QKD could be described in similarly secure terms since any attempt to obtain the keys for mathematical decryption could result in the immediate destruction of the keys (preventing them from being usefully decrypted). We have already seen that QKD has problems for widespread use — but it remains an open question whether modern technology is able to deliver usable one-time pads.

column1: Historically
column2: OTP has been considered unworkable for the internet age because it requires keys of the same length or longer than the message being encrypted. Nevertheless
column3: several companies have been exploring the possibilities becoming available with new technology.

column1: Qrypt started from the basis that the quantum threat comes from the communication of encryption keys from source to destination. If you can avoid the necessity to communicate the keys
column2: you can eliminate the threat. It consequently developed a process that allows the generation of the same quantum random numbers simultaneously at both source and destination. A quantum random number is a genuinely random number generated with quantum mechanics principles. These numbers can then be used to generate identical keys without them needing to be transmitted across the internet.

column1: However
column2: since the generation of the numbers can be performed and stored until use
column3: there remains the potential to chain the process to provide genuine OTP for the keys without requiring them to be transmitted across the internet. Solutions based on this process are quantum secure.

column1: Incrypteon
column2: a British startup
column3: has taken a different route by applying Shannon’s information theories to the one-time pad. The science is a bit mind-numbing but is based on Shannon’s equivocation from his Communication Theory of Secrecy Systems published in 1949. “The definition of perfect secrecy is based on statistics and probabilities
column4: ” says Incrypteon. “A ciphertext maintains perfect secrecy if the attacker’s knowledge of the contents of the message is the same both before and after the adversary inspects the ciphertext
column5: attacking it with unlimited resources.”

column1: Using its own patented software and ‘Perpetual Equivocation’
column2: Incrypteon “ensures that conditional entropy never equals zero
column3: therefore achieving Perfect Secrecy.” The result is something that is automatically quantum secure (not just quantum safe) — and is available today.

column1: Co-founder Helder Figueira had been an electronic warfare signals officer commanding a cryptanalysis unit in the South African Army. The concepts of Shannon’s equivocation are well-understood by the military
column2: and he has long-been concerned that the commercial market is forced to accept encryption that is
column3: by definition
column4: ‘insecure’ — if something cannot be proven to be secure
column5: it must be insecure.

column1: A third and potentially future approach to the one-time pad could evolve from current advances in tokenization – more specifically cloud-based vaultless tokenization protected by immutable servers.
Rixon
column2: another startup
column3: is involved in this area. Its primary purpose is to protect PII stored by organizations with a web presence – but the principles could easily be extended. Plaintext is immediately tokenized in the cloud
column4: and no plaintext is held onsite. Nor is the plaintext held at the tokenization engine in the cloud – all that is stored is the tokenization route for each tokenized character (for the purpose of comparison
column5: this tokenization route is equivalent to the cryptographic key
column6: but is random for each character).

column1: This provides the primary parallel with the OTP – the ‘key’ is the same length as the message. Currently
column2: Rixon concentrates on tokenizing PII; but the same concept could be extended to secure high value files at rest such as intellectual property and commercial plans.

column1: Transition to post quantum cryptography

The coming cryptopocalypse requires organizations to transition from known quantum-vulnerable encryption (such as current PKI standards) to something that is at least quantum safe if not quantum secure. This will be a long process
column2: and in 2023 businesses will need to start planning their route in greater detail.

column1: Most companies will start from the viewpoint that NIST post-quantum algorithms is the only way forward. We have discussed OTP developments in some depth to show that the NIST route is not the only available route – and we expect further OTP developments during 2023.
The full transition to post quantum readiness will take many years
column2: and will not be achieved by throwing a switch from classical to PQC. This has led to the concept of ‘crypto agility’. “It will be essential that quantum ready algorithms (QRAs) are able to coexist with existing cryptographic capabilities
column3: in a hybrid manner
column4: while the complete transition to quantum safe occurs
column5: ” explains Silvio Pappalardo
column6: chief revenue officer at Quintessence Labs.

column1: “Crypto agility enables applications to migrate between key types and cryptographic algorithms without the need to update the application software — transitioning from homogenous towards micro-service architecture
column2: ” he said. “With encryption ciphers changing due to the threat of quantum
column3: decreasing longevity
column4: increasing key sizes
column5: and the expanding requirements to protect more data
column6: more effectively
column7: crypto agility becomes a business enabler and defender to keep pace with constant innovations and enable greater flexibility into the future.” Such agility also allows companies to switch from one quantum safe algorithm to another if the one in use gets broken.

column1: For now
column2: government agencies will have little choice but to follow NIST. On November 18
column4: the White House issued a memorandum to the heads of executive departments and agencies requiring that CRQC readiness begins with taking an inventory of vulnerable assets. “By May 4
column6: and annually thereafter until 2035”
column8: “agencies are directed to submit a prioritized inventory of information systems and assets
column10: that contain CRQC-vulnerable cryptographic systems to ONCD and the Department of Homeland Security Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA).”

column1: On December 21
column3: Biden signed the Quantum Computing Cybersecurity Preparedness Act into law. “Quantum computers are under development globally with some adversarial nation states putting tens of billions of dollars into programs to create these very powerful machines that will break the encryption we use today
column4: ” comments Sanzeri. “While not here yet
column5: quantum computers will be online in coming years
column6: but it will take more than a few years for our federal agencies and commercial enterprises to upgrade their systems to post quantum cybersecurity.”

column1: This Act
column2: he continued
column3: “requires federal agencies to migrate systems to post quantum cryptography which is resilient against attacks from quantum computers. And the Office of Management and Budget is further required to send an annual report to Congress depicting a strategy on how to assess post-quantum cryptography risks across the federal government.”

column1: The government is clearly wedded to the NIST proposals. This may be because NIST is correct in its assertion that OTP is not realistic. NIST computer security mathematician Dustin Moody told SecurityWeek in October 2022
column2: “The one-time pad must be generated by a source of true randomness
column3: and not a pseudo-random process.” But there are numerous sources for the generation of genuinely random numbers using quantum mechanics.

column1: “The one-time pad must be as long as the message which is to be encrypted
column2: ” added Moody. “If you wish to encrypt a long message
column3: the size of the one-time pad will be much larger than key sizes of the algorithms we [NIST] selected.” This is also being challenged as a problem by both Qrypt and Incrypteon
column4: and potentially tokenization firms like Rixon.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: most companies will follow the incremental process of NIST rather than the more revolutionary process of OTP
column3: if only because of NIST’s reputation and government support. 2023 will see more companies beginning their move to CRQC readiness – but there are more options than are immediately obvious.";21191;['j87v349'

column1: aadb1f281f6e55b296321264cc37677a39e867259d257e3a4c75a99fc9e2e4a4;posted_link;r/science;https://news.griffith.edu.au/2020/08/18/new-quantum-paradox-reveals-contradiction-between-widely-held-beliefs/;['ijeucg'];['rustoo'];[1598802604.0];['Quantum physicists have unveiled a new paradox that says
column2: when it comes to certain long-held beliefs about nature
column3: “something’s gotta give”. The paradox means that if quantum theory works to describe observers
column4: scientists would have to give up one of three cherished assumptions about the world.'];[nan];2020-08-18;Contributed;New quantum paradox reveals contradiction between widely-held beliefs;"Quantum physicists at Griffith University have unveiled a new paradox that says
column5: when it comes to certain long-held beliefs about nature
column6: “something’s gotta give”.

column1: Quantum theory is practically perfect at predicting the behaviour we observe when we perform experiments on tiny objects like atoms. But applying quantum theory at scales much larger than atoms
column2: in particular to observers who make the measurements
column3: raises difficult conceptual issues.

column1: In a paper published in Nature Physics
column2: an international team led from Griffith University in Australia has sharpened those issues into a new paradox.

column1: “The paradox means that if quantum theory works to describe observers
column2: scientists would have to give up one of three cherished assumptions about the world
column3: ” said Associate Professor Eric Cavalcanti
column4: a senior theory author on the paper.

column1: “The first assumption is that when a measurement is made
column2: the observed outcome is a real
column3: single event in the world. This assumption rules out
column4: for example
column5: the idea that the universe can split
column6: with different outcomes being observed in different parallel universes.”

column1: “The second assumption is that experimental settings can be freely chosen
column2: allowing us to perform randomised trials. And the third assumption is that once such a free choice is made
column3: its influence cannot spread out into the universe faster than light
column4: ” he said.

column1: “Each of these fundamental assumptions seems entirely reasonable
column2: and is widely believed. However
column3: it is also widely believed that quantum experiments can be scaled up to larger systems
column4: even to the level of observers. But we show that one of these widely held beliefs must be wrong! Giving up any one of them has far-reaching consequences for our understanding of the world.”

column1: The team has established the paradox by analysing a scenario with well-separated entangled quantum particles combined with a quantum ‘observer’ – a quantum system which can be manipulated and measured from the outside
column2: but which can itself make measurements on a quantum particle.

column1: “Based on the three fundamental assumptions
column2: we have mathematically determined limits on what experimental results are possible in this scenario. But quantum theory
column3: when applied to observers
column4: predicts results which violate these limits. In fact
column5: we have already performed a proof-of-principle experiment using entangled photons (particles of light)
column6: ” said Dr Nora Tischler
column7: a senior experimental author. “And we found a violation just as quantum theory predicted.”

column1: “But our ‘observer’ had a very small ‘brain’
column2: so to speak. It has just two memory states
column3: which are realised as two different paths for a photon. That’s why we call it a proof-of-principle experiment
column4: not a conclusive demonstration that one of the three fundamental assumptions in our paradox must be wrong
column5: ” she said.

column1: “For a more definitive implementation of the paradox
column2: our dream experiment is one where the quantum observer is a human-level artificial intelligence program running on a massive quantum computer
column3: ” said Professor Howard Wiseman
column4: the leader of the project and Director of Griffith’s Centre for Quantum Dynamics
column5: where the theoretical and experimental teams are based.

column1: “That would be a pretty convincing test of whether quantum theory fails for observers
column2: or whether one of the three fundamental assumptions is false. But that’s probably decades away.”

column1: The Centre for Quantum Dynamics laboratory in which the experiment was performed is also part of the Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology
column2: an Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence.

column1: “It has long been recognised that quantum computers will revolutionise our ability to solve hard computational problems
column2: ” Professor Wiseman said.

column1: “What we didn’t realise until we started this research is that they may also help answer hard philosophical problems – the nature of the physical world
column2: the mental world
column3: and their relationship.”";3916;['g3dbuhd'
